webTitle: Blair feels 'isolated' by loss of Mandelson

fields.headline: Blair feels 'isolated' by loss of Mandelson
fields.trailText: Tony Blair believes the loss of Peter Mandelson has been a severe blow to the Government and left him isolated in a Cabinet dominated by Chancellor Gordon Brown.
fields.body:
Tony Blair believes the loss of Peter Mandelson has been a severe blow to the Government and left him isolated in a Cabinet dominated by Chancellor Gordon Brown.

The Prime Minister has told colleagues that without one of his oldest political friends he feels the Blairite wing in the Government could suffer and he regrets having had to sack the former Northern Ireland Secretary, according to sources close to Mandelson.

In comments that will revive speculation about ten sions between the Blair and Brown camps, friends of the Prime Minister say that he feels exposed and that 'Gordon is rampant'.

Although Downing Street sources insisted that Blair, if presented with the same facts on the Hinduja passport affair, would act in the same way again, they admit that the loss of Mandelson has produced a 'big hole' in the Prime Minister's political life.

Blair and Mandelson are now in regular telephone contact, revealing the importance that Blair still places on the man he once thanked for masterminding his campaign to become Labour leader.

'The relationship is much the same as it was before all this happened,' said one senior party source. In addition, relations between Mandelson and Alastair Campbell, Blair's official spokesman, were described as warm, despite allegations that Campbell had been feuding with the ex-Minister.

The fact that Mandelson has been so readily rehabilitated into Blair's inner circle will alarm many in the Government who thought that the former Minister misjudged the seriousness of the passports issue which led to his resignation six weeks ago. Many in the party, some of them enemies of Mandelson, were predicting that he would be cast into the political wilderness and that Blair would turn his back on him. But the Prime Minister is now expected to use Mandelson as a sounding board on issues such as Northern Ireland, Europe and the general election. He specifically refused to say what he felt about Mandelson's resignation when asked about the crisis on Friday after the publication of the Hammond inquiry report which cleared Mandelson of any impropriety over the Hinduja passport applications. Last week the ex-Minister admitted adding to the 'muddle' over the issue, and said he would not seek a return to government.

The revelations come as the Prime Minister faces increasing pressure to reveal whether he saw intelligence documents suggesting the Hindujas 'had been involved in a number of dubious practices, in some cases potentially amounting to illegal activities'.

The Hammond report confirms that while Trade Secretary and in charge of the Dome, Mandelson was shown security briefings but decided to accept Hinduja funds for the Dome's faith zone. If Blair had seen the reports it would have been before Blair and his wife, Cherie, attended a Diwali party thrown by the brothers. The intelligence material emerged after Jen nie Page, then chief executive of the New Millennium Experience Company, sought a thorough check on the Indian-born businessmen.

One intelligence expert told The Observer that with a project as sensitive as the Dome it would be 'inconceivable' that intelligence briefings on controversial businessman such as the Hindujas had not reached Downing Street.

It has also emerged that in the Nineties the then Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, and her Home Secretary, David Waddington, were advised by officials to stay away from the Hindujas' Diwali party because of fears that it would lead to embarrassment.

Ann Widdecombe, Shadow Home Secretary, said: 'The Prime Minister must tell whether he or any of staff were aware of intelligence material on the Hindujas, and if so why did he continue to do business with them?'

Opposition MPs are calling on Jack Straw, the Home Secretary, to answer a number of questions emerging from the Hammond inquiry, particularly the role he played in helping the third Hinduja brother, Prakash, last May. A minute reveals that Straw wanted the case to be dealt with 'helpfully'.

Liberal Democrat MP Norman Baker, whose parliamentary question originally helped tease out ministerial involvement in the passport applications, said this weekend that the Home Secretary 'must explain why he was willing do such favours'.

webTitle: Single mothers get IT call-up

fields.headline: Single mothers get IT call-up
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will this week unveil a plan to push thousands of jobless single mothers into high-flying computer jobs as Labour raises its ambitions for the New Deal.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will this week unveil a plan to push thousands of jobless single mothers into high-flying computer jobs as Labour raises its ambitions for the New Deal.

Ministers intend to hit back at criticism that they are simply forcing people into work. 'This is basically the next phase - the ambition is for jobs with good prospects, not just any old job,' said a source in the Department for Education and Employment. 'It is not just about the first rung on the ladder, but about getting in higher up.'

The so-called 'Ambition IT' scheme for 5,000 claimants - with priority given to single parents and those from ethnic minorities - will be contained in a Green Paper published on Wednesday - coinciding with figures expected to show unemployment falling again, possibly below the magic one million mark.

'There may only be one million unemployed now, but that is still a million too many,' said a Downing Street source. 'There was a time when people used to think this idea of full employment was a dream, but unemployment has been falling and it can fall further.'

The paper also promises a £100 million package of help for lone parents, including grants to cover advance childcare costs before starting new jobs, plus £40m for drug addicts emerging from rehabilitation. But it will also extend benefit cuts for non-compliance to over-25s.

The 'Ambition IT' scheme will be extended to other boom areas, such as the hotel and restaurant trade or financial services, if it works.

The Chancellor's chief adviser, Ed Balls, said yesterday that the paper would also target employment blackspots. 'There is an assumption that, because for much of the twentieth century cities north of London have fallen behind the South East, that somehow this is inevitable - our new approach is now to be based on the strongly held conviction that the opposite is true,' he told a Unions 21 conference in London.

webTitle: Blair in fresh sleaze row over planning bid

fields.headline: Blair in fresh sleaze row over planning bid
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was fighting a fresh sleaze row last night over a leaked memo suggesting Downing Street intervened in a planning application by billionaire arms broker Wafic Said.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was fighting a fresh sleaze row last night over a leaked memo suggesting Downing Street intervened in a planning application by billionaire arms broker Wafic Said.

The Syrian-born tycoon had been locked in a lengthy and highly controversial dispute over the building of a business school in his name in Oxford.

The note from a planning official dealing with the case complains of coming 'under pressure from the Prime Minister's office not to delay the decision' over the project, which was to be set up in a listed building.

The row hits close to home because Sir Charles Powell, brother of Blair's chief of staff Jonathan, is chair of the school's trustees and a director of several Said companies. Said is also a friend of Peter Mandelson: they have a mutual friend in Powell's wife Carla.

But last night Downing Street hit back, insisting it had played no part in the actual decision over whether the business school could go ahead. Officials had only been in touch with the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions to check when the announcement was being made because it was potentially newsworthy, sources insisted, dismissing the allegations as 'ridiculous' and based on innuendo.

'The facts are that neither the Prime Minister, nor any of his officials had anything to do with the decision. The only involvement of Number 10 was an enquiry about the timing of the announcement of the decision after that decision had already been taken,' said one Downing Street source.

But opposition MPs are bound to exploit the affair to ask fresh questions about Labour's relationship with its rich friends. It comes just as Blair was hoping to put the whiff of sleaze behind him after the Hammond inquiry into the obtaining of passports by the millionaire Hinduja brothers cleared Ministers of any impropriety.

Said is no stranger to controversy: he helped broker the £20 billion al Yamamah arms deal between Britain and Saudi Arabia, and was famously a guest in the Ritz hotel in Paris the same weekend as Jonathan Aitken's fateful stay.

The memo from south-east regional planning official Avis Gerry to planning Minister Nick Raynsford, dating back to October 1998, responds to complaints from local Liberal Democrat MP Evan Harris that he was not given formal notification of the decision going through as is normal procedure.

'This was because we were under pressure from the Prime Minister's office not to delay the decision, and exceptionally we issued it and phoned the MP's office before sending draft letters to the MPs,' it adds.

It suggests the excuse that should be given to Harris is the 'sheer volume of correspondence in Ministers' offices' but adds: 'Feel free to change this as appropriate.'

Raynsford later wrote to Harris apologising, saying that he was unable to sign correspondence at the time as he was abroad on government business.

Last night Harris demanded an explanation.

'The Prime Minister's involvement means this is either control freakery taken to the extreme, a sudden interest in old railway buildings or something more suspicious,' he added. 'There must be a full explanation of why the Prime Minister's office was involved.'

Said has donated £20 million to build the business school but the project has been fraught with difficulty. Its original site on the playing field in central Oxford was rejected and the decision to build it near the old railway station, threatening a Victorian building, has provoked local controversy.

Protestors in Oxford wanted a public inquiry into the project which could have delayed it for years. But the DETR declined and the station building was duly dismantled and rebuilt at a railway museum in Buckinghamshire.

Last month, Harris tabled a parliamentary question to Beverley Hughes, junior Minister at the DETR, asking if her department had received representations about the deal from elsewhere. She replied: 'Our records include no representations from other government Ministers or officials about the Wafic Said business school in Oxford.'

Downing Street said last night that the reply was true because the only contact with No 10 had been a routine query about when the case would be decided so that it could be plotted into the 'grid', Labour's weekly schedule of imminent government announcements.

The Syrian-born tycoon had been locked in a lengthy and highly controversial dispute over the building of a business school in his name in Oxford. The note from a planning official dealing with the case complains of coming 'under pressure from the Prime Minister's office not to delay the decision' over the project, which was to be set up in a listed building. The row hits close to home because Sir Charles Powell, brother of Blair's chief of staff Jonathan, is chair of the school's trustees and a director of several Said companies. Said is also a friend of Peter Mandelson: they have a mutual friend in Powell's wife Carla. But last night Downing Street hit back, insisting it had played no part in the actual decision over whether the business school could go ahead. Officials had only been in touch with the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions to check when the announcement was being made because it was potentially newsworthy, sources insisted, dismissing the allegations as 'ridiculous' and based on innuendo. 'The facts are that neither the Prime Minister, nor any of his officials had anything to do with the decision. The only involvement of Number 10 was an enquiry about the timing of the announcement of the decision after that decision had already been taken,' said one Downing Street source. But opposition MPs are bound to exploit the affair to ask fresh questions about Labour's relationship with its rich friends. webTitle: Railtrack admits delays will stretch way past Easter

fields.headline: Railtrack admits delays will stretch way past Easter
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack has admitted for the first time that government-imposed deadlines to get the railways running normally by Easter will not be met, leaving passengers facing more months of delays and cancellations.
fields.body:
Railtrack has admitted for the first time that government-imposed deadlines to get the railways running normally by Easter will not be met, leaving passengers facing more months of delays and cancellations.

New figures sent from Railtrack to the Government reveal that at the end of April, two weeks after Easter, there will still be 61 speed restrictions in place across the rail network. They were imposed after the Hatfield crash in which four people were killed last October.

Railtrack has admitted its definition of 'normal' operation will include more than 500 speed restrictions in place before the accident, which was blamed on cracked, badly maintained rails.

Transport experts said such a definition of 'normal' revealed the rundown state of the service, now one of the most disliked by the public.

Government sources said there was intense irritation with the way Railtrack was managing the crisis on the railways, which meant hours of delays for passengers and millions of pounds being paid in compensation.

The development will be of particular embarrassment to the Prime Minister. Last month he gave a personal assurance that Britain's trains would be running normally by the middle of April and said he would put pressure on Railtrack to ensure the deadline was met.

At Christmas, John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister, also said the railway service would be back to normal by Easter. He is angry at the lack of progress since Hatfield. 'They have not shown themselves adept at dealing with this,' said a source close to Prescott. 'They don't seem to be able to put in place what seems to be a simple solution.'

Downing Street is concerned that, with a general election imminent, the issue of the crumbling railways will come back to haunt it. Lord Macdonald, the Transport Minister, is holding weekly emergency meetings with senior railway managers to speed up progress.

'There is absolutely no possibility that the public will feel they have a normal service by Easter,' said Bernard Jenkin, the Conservative transport spokesman. 'The promise that the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister gave has been exposed as a lie.'

The latest figures from Railtrack reveal the extent of the problem. The company expects 177 Hatfield-related restrictions still to be in place at the end of March. Although that drops to 61 by the end of April, these are thought to be the most stubborn cases that could take many months to clear up.

Critics said the figures provided by Railtrack for the Department of Transport underestimated the extent of the problem. On 5 March, the last date when figures have been made available to the Government, there were still 287 restrictions affecting more than 70 per cent of the most important rail routes.

A Railtrack spokesman insisted that services would be 'broadly normal' by Easter. 'That could still mean 400 or 500 speed restrictions, which was the normal level before Hatfield,' he said.

webTitle: Background to the overhaul of the London underground

fields.headline: Facts and figures in a crucial debate
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Background to the overhaul of the London underground
fields.body:
 About 3m journeys are made on the tube each day. Three-quarters of commuters using the railways daily also have to use the tube.

 The tube is vital to the UK economy: London and the south-east account for a third of the economy.

 The tube is deteriorating rapidly. Last month, journey times took on average eight minutes longer than they should, even on London Underground's calculations.

 Train cancellations have increased by 43% in peak hours - the period when the management structure reflects how the system would run under public private partnership proposals (PPP).

 The tube PPP is intended to bring investment of £12-15bn over 25-30 years, a sum which dwarfs other public services' investments.

 The Jubilee line extension costs doubled and the public sector ended up picking up the bill for an extra £1.5bn while the private sector walked away. This is one of the key reasons the Treasury wants the financial risk transferred to the private sector.

 There is a funding gap of £100m a year or more in the government's PPP proposals for the tube, which will have to be met by public subsidy, says Labour's thinktank, the IPPR. That could amount to more than £2.5bn of government subsidy over the period of the private contracts.

 A national audit office report found that the PPP could not be shown to represent best value for money.

 If the new infrastructure companies deliver a level of service 5% worse than that which prevails, they will earn the full profit agreed in their contracts under the PPP.

 Because it costs private companies more to borrow than it would the government (which cannot default), the cost of financing - such as the money paid to the banks - will be about £800m more in the first 7 years under PPP than if London Underground issued its own bonds.

webTitle: Love, honour, cherish? Yes, I do - now let's surf

fields.headline: Love, honour, cherish? Yes, I do - now let's surf
fields.trailText: Combining travel and weddings is no longer confined to honeymoons or even to the bridal couple. Whole wedding parties are travelling around the country.
fields.body:
Ever since I walked the Cornish coast path, when I was 15, I've loved the south-west tip of Britain. I love the way it sticks out into the Atlantic and makes you feel you're not in England. When I can't sleep because of worries about work, money, or other trivia, I imagine myself floating in the blue Cornish water, without any cares beyond what to have for lunch. It usually does the trick.

My fiancé is a keen surfer so when we were looking for somewhere to get married last year Cornwall was the obvious choice. Our ideal venue was a beautiful old building, with a marriage licence, near a surfing beach. After the law change in 1994, there are now more than 3,000 premises licensed for civil weddings in England and Wales (none in Scotland or Northern Ireland) from castles to the London Eye. About 23 per cent of the 162,000 couples who opted for a civil wedding last year made their vows somewhere other than a Register Office and more than 30,000 couples married abroad. So combining travel and weddings is no longer confined to honeymoons or even to the bridal couple. Whole wedding parties are travelling around the country.

We imagined that one of the 3,000 venues might satisfy our requirements, but had no idea how to find it. Salvation came through a website called confetti.co.uk. The site is a symphony of pastel colours and cute drawings designed to help couples plan their wedding. Last year, confetti incorporated a venue-finding service and it came up with a couple of pages of options for us. Nestling between a Best Western hotel and a disused convent on Cornwall's south coast was an old fort, with a marriage licence, next to a surfing beach.

'Cornwall? Excellent,' said the first friend we told. 'Oh, lovely!' added my mum. Nobody, it seemed, minded travelling. Sadly, the fort was hot property and fully booked all year, forcing us to snap up a date for this summer. Apparently, everybody wants to get married where the beaches are sandy, the water is clear, and the surfers look like shiny black seals in the sea. A brief trawl through the confetti site today suggests that the venue finding service has been scaled down. All I was able to do now was to ask for Cornwall and a civil venue and I was given 10 pages to trawl. I did revisit the message board to look up 'Hiring candlesticks', 'wedding insurance?' and that perennial 'Brighton hen night - where to go?'

When we visited the fort, we found it was everything we had been seeking. The headland was shrouded in fog so thick that we missed the turning several times, but the building was perfect, with high ceilings, a lawn and spectacular sea views. Furthermore, it was staffed by friendly and professional women who, although they do this every week, appeared genuinely excited for us.

With their help, I have discovered that it's surprisingly easy to organise a Cornish wedding from Brighton. In fact, it has been almost bizarrely easy to find a local photographer, caterers, a string quartet and a florist. The nice women sent detailed instructions and phone numbers for everyone we might like to contact. With a few trips to the area, we think we now have everything in place for the summer.

There's one thing I hadn't imagined for the honeymoon, though: lots of friends joining us on the beach.

 www.polhawn-fort.co.uk

webTitle: Young GPs will get golden hello

fields.headline: Young GPs will get golden hello
fields.trailText: Dcotors are set for 'golden hellos' to lure them into general practice under new plans to tackle a shortage of GPs.
fields.body:
Dcotors are set for 'golden hellos' to lure them into general practice under new plans to tackle a shortage of GPs.

Cash incentives for young doctors to take up less popular jobs in the community, plus 'golden handcuffs' deals to persuade older family doctors not to retire early, are expected to form the heart of the £135 million package being drawn up by Health Secretary Alan Milburn.

Ministers have bowed to warnings from the profession that there are not enough GPs to meet promises of better, faster treatment. 'We know GPs are under pressure and that the only real answer to the service challenges they are facing is to address the numbers,' said one source close to Milburn. 'Our recruitment and retention package will ensure we deliver on the target of 2,000 more by 2004 - and if we can deliver that earlier than promised, all the better.'

Milburn was working out detailed proposals this weekend, after securing funding in last week's Budget. The scheme is expected to be modelled on similar incentives for teachers, where graduates are to be offered £2,000 'golden hellos' to pay off student debts if they stay in teaching.

Doctors' leaders say rising workloads, organisational upheaval and a 'culture of blame' after episodes such as the Shipman murders are putting young doctors off general practice. Older colleagues are also becoming disillusioned: a recent survey of Scottish GPs found 60 per cent considering leaving for other careers, with nearly three-quarters less happy now than five years ago.

Thousands of GPs re-cruited abroad in the Sixties and Seventies are approaching retirement, leaving more holes to be plugged.

'When people of my generation and younger entered general practice it was the exciting place to be: there was considerable competition for vacancies. That has completely turned around in the last 10 years,' said Dr John Chisholm, chair of the BMA's general practice committee. 'As far as young doctors are concerned, about half are going to need to become GPs and that is just not happening.'

Likely options include changes to pension entitlements for older doctors, making it more worthwhile to stay on after 60; family-friendly policies for women returning after career breaks; and allowing GPs who have retired early to come back without damaging their pension entitlements.

webTitle: Germany leads world with hotel for disabled

fields.headline: Germany leads world with hotel for disabled
fields.trailText: Wheelchair users need not worry about being confined to a corner of the dining room in the world's first luxury hotel dedicated to the disabled. The concept is being pioneered in Germany with the 108-bedroom Haus Rheinsberg, due to open in June.
fields.body:
Wheelchair users need not worry about being confined to a corner of the dining room or getting stuck in the corridor in the world's first luxury hotel dedicated to the disabled.

The concept is being pioneered in Germany with the 108-bedroom Haus Rheinsberg, due to open in June on the shores of the picturesque Grienerick lake in the state of Brandenburg in east Germany, one and a half hours' drive from Berlin.

Everything has been designed with disabled travellers in mind, from the reception desk at wheelchair height to the specially adapted bowling alley.

'There isn't a hotel like this in Germany or Europe and possibly not in the world,' said Michael Schmidt, managing director.

'A lot of hotels have one or two rooms designed for wheelchair users but not a whole hotel and not all the recreation areas.'

The £20 million property is being built by a Berlin-based charity for the disabled that was concerned about the lack of holiday facilities for the handicapped.

As well as extra-wide corridors, rooms have wheelchair-accessible balconies and everything from minibars to plug sockets at wheelchair height.

Special lifting apparatus is available and trained staff can help guests wash and dress. Sauna and steam rooms accommodate wheelchairs and the luxury indoor pool, billiards room and children's playroom are adapted for disabled guests but can still be used by their able-bodied companions. Watersports can be practised on the lake with the help of a landing stage complete with lift.

And in true German fashion, there is also a beer garden designed for wheelchair use. 'Disabled people drink beer too,' said Schmidt, who is paralysed on one side of his body. 'This is not a clinic, it is a hotel offering every comfort.'

Reg McLaughlin, director of Greater London Action on Disability, welcomed the idea. 'Hotels like this should be held up as a model of good practice,' he said

Perhaps not surprisingly, Haus Rheinsberg has bookings stretching as far as December and is already sold out in July. Rooms, subsidised by the charity, cost less than £60 a night.

· Call 0049 33931 34696 for bookings.

webTitle: Screen: Andrew Lincoln is neurotic in new Channel 4 drama

fields.headline: Egg and Mr Chips
fields.standfirst: The makers of This Life have cast Andrew Lincoln, the dithering Egg, as another reluctant adult who can't cope with responsibility - but this time his neurotic character is a teacher
fields.trailText: The makers of This Life have cast Andrew Lincoln, the dithering Egg, as another reluctant adult who can't cope with responsibility - but this time his neurotic character is a teacher.
fields.body:
Simon is always late for school. He doodles in class, smokes in the bogs, resents authority figures and is a complete ass when it comes to girls. But here's the twist: he's a member of staff. In Teachers, a new Channel 4 series, the format of the school drama is thrown up in the air. This is a very different beast to Jimmy McGovern's Hearts and Minds, where teachers were forever discussing government education policy during morning break, or Lucy Gannon's Hope and Glory, where staff hit the bottle and, occasionally, pupils. In Teachers, as in This Life, North Square and Attachments, the professional setting informs, rather than dictates, what happens to the characters. The school is an excuse for the drama, rather than its point, and at a time when Labour's attitude to state education is a hot political topic, Teachers seems almost wilfully unaware of the issues.

'The series is open to so much abuse because of the subject matter,' says Andrew Lincoln, who sprang to fame as Egg in This Life, and now has a lead role in Teachers as Simon. 'It'll be a target: people will say it's irresponsible TV. But you've got to see it for what it is, a lighthearted look at the lives of a few people. It's just about gags, basically.'

He's right. And they're great. There are overtones of David Lodge here, and of Lucky Jim: The feckless, ambivalent protagonist finds himself trapped in an institution and has to puzzle his way through it, without much common sense to help him along. With its genial teens and profound lack of interest in Ofsted reports, paperwork and underfunding, Teachers may be pure escapism, but the writing is pin-sharp, the direction often touched with genius, and the show is further distinguished by a breezy lack of sentimentality.

Since sentimentality tends to be as intrinsic to the genre as chalk and bad food, the three writers (Tim Loane, Julie Rutterford and Andrew Rattenbury) have done well in avoiding the usual scenes of fat kids being bullied or broken spectacles on the gymnasium floor. The students aren't the ones having the problems in this show: instead, they're all reserved for Simon, an English teacher fresh out of training college who is having difficulties adapting to his sudden elevation into a position of responsibility. At 27, he is a very reluctant adult indeed.

'I never, ever thought of anyone else for the part,' says Jane Fallon, executive producer, who first worked with Lincoln on This Life. 'We didn't talk to anyone else, we just went straight to Andy, and luckily he was able to do it. Simon, on paper, could be very irritating. We needed someone who could make him more than that, who could make him boyish, charming and funny, and I knew Andy could do it.'

Lincoln liked the idea as soon as Fallon approached him, but he was anxious about how it might come across, so he asked his older brother to have a look at the script. His brother, who teaches RE and philosophy at a school in Surrey, loved it. 'If he'd thought it was offensive, taking the piss, I wouldn't have done it. But he read it and said it was just a laugh. He said, "Oh do it, it's great, it's not saying anything about the school system!" The school isn't a real school: it's a heightened, trippy, dreamy, oddball place.'

No kidding. In the world of Summerdown comprehensive, bells and rules no longer count. Simon, who would rather be seen as a dude than a beak, gets stoned with his pupils, is humiliated when a new girlfriend turns out to be a copper, and hands out textbooks in the pub in order to get his essays marked in time. There's a lot of editorial skittishness, narrative detours into fantasy sequences and imaginary outcomes, as pioneered in Dream On and finessed in Ally McBeal; but the whimsy count is thankfully low. Much of this boils down to Lincoln's ability to play a character whom you warm to, against your better judgment. Lincoln describes Simon as 'a jerk, frankly. He's Woody Allenesque: self-obsessed, juvenile, refusing to grow up. He's so neurotic, and yet charming at the same time'.

One might assume that by the end of the series, Simon has wised up a little, but Lincoln, who is optioned for a second series, assures me this is not the case.

'He doesn't! That's my dilemma. But then again, how many people do evolve? How long does it take someone to get out of adolescence? Some people never leave it. But it is a key question, where would the second series go?'

When a character central to a TV drama refuses to grow or learn, audiences tend to get restless. The recent slump of interest in Ally McBeal is a case in point: what was initially novel and engaging soon turns deathly dull, and not even a broadening of focus, taking in Ally's agonisingly wacky co-workers, can get that show on the road again.

But the omens for Teachers are more promising because Simon is surrounded by colleagues - wry confidante Susan; twin geeks Brian and Kurt; and Jenny, his icy nemesis - who might shine if allowed a more prominent role.

'I think the other characters need to be developed more,' agrees Lincoln. 'That needs to happen, otherwise people may get bored.' But for now, at least, boredom is not on the curriculum. A big gold star.

 Teachers starts on Channel 4 on Wednesday 21 March

webTitle: Saviour of the UK's worst school

fields.headline: Saviour of the UK's worst school
fields.standfirst:
The Ridings in Halifax became a byword for failure but a remarkable effort by a determined head has brought it back from the brink. Martin Bright reports

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The Ridings in Halifax became a byword for failure but a remarkable effort by a determined head has brought it back from the brink.  Martin Bright  reports
fields.body:
A minor miracle happened at The Ridings last Friday: Barry Higgins came back. He walked straight through the gates of a school once dubbed 'the worst in Britain' and asked to be taught to read.

Staff at The Ridings were already basking in the warm glow of a schools inspectorate report that congratulated them on a spectacular transformation from sink school to model institution. The return of Barry Higgins was the icing on the cake.

Four years ago Higgins was one of a hard core of 12 pupils excluded from the Halifax school. It had been closed after a complete breakdown of discipline and parents were told it would not reopen until the most disruptive children were removed.

The 11-year-old was so out of control he was considered a danger to himself. He didn't go back to school much after that and when others started choosing exam options and he still couldn't read he drifted away altogether.

Barry was interviewed by this newspaper in November 1996, wearing a beanie hat with the word 'Trash' written across it. He was the collateral damage of the battle for the soul of the education system, and was still suffering the effects of the death of his twin brother in a road accident a year earlier.

Back then, The Ridings couldn't deal with someone as needy as Higgins. Now 15, he has come back under his own steam and tomorrow will begin a course of remedial reading at a specialist computer-aided learning centre.

'Sometimes it takes a long time, a very long time, to persuade children back into the classroom,' said Anna White, the headteacher responsible for reversing the fortunes of the school. 'But you just have to be patient and keep trying.'

Patience is something White knows a lot about. She was part of the rescue team that took over the school that month and became headteacher the following April. Even now, exam results are well below average.

Last week's Ofsted report described her as 'highly conscientious' and said 'her commitment, enthusiasm, and determination have been significant factors in the school's continual improvement'. This stands in stark contrast to the findings of the original report in 1996 which slammed weak management and said that 'behaviour was... at times completely unacceptable'.

White recalls the day she first walked into The Ridings. The cold stone steps had been made infamous by a BBC Panorama programme that showed feral children giving V-signs to the camera. 'At the time we didn't know if it would stay open or be closed. When I walked into the school, the first thing that struck me was how depressed everyone was.' The Ridings had come to symbolise the worst of state education: crumbling buildings, poor attendance, bad discipline and pitiful exam results. The inclination of the then Conservative government was to close such places down.

At first, White worked with fellow superhead Peter Clark, brought in from neighbouring Rastrick High School. Together they decided that discipline was a priority. There had been 150 children temporarily excluded in the previous school year, but most were repeat offenders.

Staff said that 60 children were unteachable, but the superheads decided to make an example of a dozen hard cases like Barry Higgins, regardless of family circumstances. Discipline began to improve almost immediately.

White recognises that she benefited from an immediate injection of cash into the school from Calderdale local education authority, which had been shamed into releasing funds by the grim media coverage of the school.

The school has changed beyond recognition. A dilapidated gymnasium was converted into a drama and dance studio. Four state of the art laboratories have been added and a technology and economics suite has just opened. In a final, highly symbolic, move, the notorious flight of steps leading up to the front door of The Ridings has been condemned and will soon disappear altogether.

White says her greatest achievement has been 'creating a friendly and welcoming school'. But her modesty hides a ruthless streak that has allowed her to squeeze resources from the local authority and replace the majority of staff working at the school when she arrived.

Whatever happens, White has committed herself to another two years in the job, during which time she hopes to address the serious problems that remain. On any given day, as many as a fifth of pupils just don't turn up and still only 9 per cent of children get five A*-C grades at GCSE against a national average of 49 per cent.

The problems facing The Ridings are vast, not least of them that two grammar schools and two church schools cream off the best students. More than 40 per cent of children qualify for free school meals.

Malcolm Nutton, chair of the parent-teacher association, whose daughter Samantha started school at the time of 'the troubles', says: 'It's always been an uphill battle and it was a fair tormented time when she first started. But when everyone was taking their kids out left, right and centre, we stuck it out and I'm glad we did.'

Lynn Ellison, who like Nutton attended the school when it was a secondary modern, said her 16-year-old son Ben was planning to go to university and wanted to be a lawyer. 'A lot of what happened was blown up out of all proportion by the media. But it's true that the reputation of school is much better now.'

Her view is confirmed by Pearllynder, aged 16, who plans to enter the school's small sixth form next year. 'Now, when you say you are from The Ridings you can feel proud of yourself.'

Word about the change in fortunes has even filtered down to Barry Higgins's mother, Eileen Joyce. 'I hear the teachers are doing a lot better,' she said. 'But Barry is not really in school or anything and anyway he leaves at the end of the year.'

When The Observer called on Friday she had no idea that Barry had been back at The Ridings that morning asking to be taught to read.

webTitle: Stop being paranoid, Britain's parents told

fields.headline: Stop being paranoid, Britain's parents told
fields.standfirst: Controversial book says obsessive fears about children's safety are a bigger threat than bullies or paedophiles
fields.trailText: Controversial book says obsessive fears about children's safety are a bigger threat than bullies or paedophiles.
fields.body:
A controversial new book on child-rearing to be published this week will urge parents to let their children take more risks and stop panicking about playground bullies and paedophiles.

The book's author, Frank Furedi, Reader in Sociology at the University of Kent, argues that parents' obsession with the safety of their children is more damaging than the risks themselves.

Paranoid Parenting: Abandon Your Anxieties And Be A Good Parent says parents should be wary of traditional 'child-centred' experts and urges the Government not to meddle in the family and parenting.

Penelope Leach, Britain's leading childcare authority and a target of the book, said: 'Almost everyone who writes about children has something to offer and I don't understand why we end up being so aggressive with each other.' However, she said that she had some fundamental disagreements with Paranoid Parenting : 'He concludes that governments should not get involved, but I cannot think of a more appropriate issue for policy than children's issues.'

Furedi is no stranger to controversy. He was a prominent member of the Revolutionary Communist Party, a Trotskyite group whose members founded the magazine Living Marxism or LM . The magazine was forced to close last year after it lost a libel case against ITN, which it had accused of doctoring footage of Serb concentration camps. LM was one of the few British publications sympathetic to the Serb cause.

In his new book, Furedi argues children are introduced to the culture of fear from the moment they are born. This begins with new measures to guard against hospital babynappers and is followed by guidelines about the minimal risk of cot death. Arriving home, they are surrounded by an army of midwives, health visitors and doctors. They then hem themselves in even more by buying childcare books. As their babies grow, their insecurity makes them easy prey for manufacturers.

Furedi is also concerned about the mixed messages in the news. One day a national charity will be castigating parents for turning their children into couch potatoes; the next, he argues, it will announce that letting children play outdoors on their own is a form of child abuse.

Add to this fears about accidents in the home and paedophiles, and it's small wonder many parents are inclined to be overprotective, says Furedi. Fear of abuse means no one dares to watch over children who are outside without their adult 'owners'. But in watching their backs, they are undermining what Furedi calls 'adult solidarity'. The casual neighbourhood safety net has disappeared, leaving children who do venture beyond their front doors far less protected than they were before. The author also attacks Dr Jane Healy, a childcare specialist who received publicity last year for telling a parenting conference that young children should not be put in front of computers because this changed the way their brains were wired. Supporters of Healy have said her argument was misrepresented in media scare stories that followed. They say that her central argument was that parents need not think they have to buy all the latest educational gizmos, as research showed the children learnt more when parents put their child on their knee and read them a storybook - a position not dissimilar to Furedi's.

According to Paranoid Parenting , it is cruel to keep children inside. They need room to explore the world around them, they need time to make their own friendships in their own way without an army of anxious adults monitoring their every movement.

But at the heart of the Furedi argument is an attack on government interference and in particular Labour's social policy: 'The politicisation of parenthood is a failure of the political imagination. Unable to work out effective social policies that can tackle the real problems facing British society, some politicians have been persuaded that if they can re-educate parents everything would turn out fine. Politicians, who have failed to provide Britain with a decent system of education, somehow assume that nevertheless they are fit to educate parents.'

Furedi told The Observer that he hopes the book will help parents put their anxieties in perspective, and understand that 'most of the really big issues that plague parents have little to do with problems instrinsic to child-rearing'. He believes they should turn their backs on experts and build on their own experiences. Rather than seek support from professionals in all matters, he'd like parents to pay more attention to friends and relatives familiar with their way of life.

Critics of Furedi, such as Guardian columnist Catherine Bennett, argue that he is simply giving parents more to worry about. Writing last week, Bennett quoted Furedi's concern that playground areas are now covered with rubber to limit the damage when a child falls. 'Should they, perhaps be constructed from something more challenging: shards of broken glass, say, or the traditional grit which was once so successful at lacerating young knees?'

webTitle: Geordie an Essex boy now

fields.headline: Geordie an Essex boy now
fields.standfirst: Future all claret and blue for gifted Michael Carrick
fields.trailText: Like most professional footballers in the country, Michael Carrick has not been taxing himself trying to understand the implications of the impending transfer shake-up. And why should he? A laid-back and lavishly gifted teenager gliding through his first full season in the high life, absorbing his 'frightening' progress as a West Ham regular and new addition to the England squad is more than enough to be getting along with.
fields.body:
Like most professional footballers in the country, Michael Carrick has not been taxing himself trying to understand the implications of the impending transfer shake-up. And why should he? A laid-back and lavishly gifted teenager gliding through his first full season in the high life, absorbing his 'frightening' progress as a West Ham regular and new addition to the England squad is more than enough to be getting along with.

But when he does sit down for a moment to imagine just what may happen to his club if the EU and Fifa proposals are in place for next season, he doesn't like what he sees. It's not beyond the realms of possibility that he could come back from his summer holidays to find any number of West Ham's most coveted talents, Paolo Di Canio, Freddie Kanouté, Joe Cole et al - and even Carrick himself - tempted by tantalisingly fat contracts elsewhere.

Maturing beautifully at a club where he feels secure and comfortable, around players he sees as mates and inspirations, the thought that all of a sudden no one will know whether they (or anyone else) are coming or going is not Carrick's idea of football. 'Weird' is the word that springs to his 19-year-old mind. 'It's good for the players in the money sense but in the footballing sense we'll be all over the place,' he laments. 'Without stability you don't know where you are. If you chop and change that quickly you won't know who you are playing with in the end. Team spirit and camaraderie are massively important to me. You've got to look out for each other. That's one of the strengths of me, Lamps [Frank Lampard] and Joe [Cole]. We all look out for each other on the pitch and if somebody is having a bad time we try to help out and gee each other along.'

The blossoming rapport between this homegrown midfield trio has been a highlight of West Ham's season. Carrick may be least heralded, considering Lampard is three years his senior and Cole was earmarked for greatness before his voice had broken, but those in the know believe that the lean and elegant Geordie is destined to shine the brightest of them all. His perception, in the way he seems to instinctively know where ball, players and movement are headed at all times, reminds more than a few Hammers of Bobby Moore.

And Joe Cole thought he had a lot to live up to... With the voyeurs gawking at Upton Park to see if Cole really was the new Gazza, Carrick is grateful that he was able to emerge more naturally. You sense the greatest expectation he feels comes from within. 'Sustaining high standards week in week out is the hardest thing,' he notes. His eagerness to learn holds him in good stead, and he owes a great deal of that learning to the age-defying leader who talks him through life on and off the field, Stuart Pearce. Carrick can't disguise his amazement for a man who cares so much 'he wants to fight you if you've done something wrong'. It's an approach which is rubbing off. 'When a 39-year-old has the attitude to come in and train like he does, it spurs you on. I don't know how he does it considering he's got a Zimmer-frame coming soon. The effort he puts in is unbelievable - that's one of the best lessons a young player can learn. If you don't have that hunger it will all pass you by. All the top players have desire. Someone like Luis Figo has talent but he also has the determination to be the best. I think I have that naturally but it can be improved, and that's what makes an ordinary player into a great player. Determination makes the difference.'

Carrick's willingness to push himself was evident in his response to his first major setback. During his first few games he felt reasonably pleased with his contribution - but then came Old Trafford. When the champions destroyed West Ham on New Year's Day it was a wake up call: 'That was the game I thought: You have to take a step back and take a look at yourself and realise you are not as good as you thought you were. I learned from it, which showed when we played them the second time.'

Euphoric revenge exacted a month later at the same venue in the FA Cup, suddenly gave the Hammers a sneaky feeling about claret and blue ribbons in May. 'If you go away to Man U and win, after that you think you can beat anyone,' Carrick confirms. webTitle: Young GPs will get golden hello

fields.headline: Young GPs will get golden hello
fields.trailText: Doctors are set for 'golden hellos' to lure them into general practice under new plans to tackle a shortage of GPs.
fields.body:
Doctors are set for 'golden hellos' to lure them into general practice under new plans to tackle a shortage of GPs.

Cash incentives for young doctors to take up less popular jobs in the community, plus 'golden handcuffs' deals to persuade older family doctors not to retire early, are expected to form the heart of the £135 million package being drawn up by Health Secretary Alan Milburn.

Ministers have bowed to warnings from the profession that there are not enough GPs to meet promises of better, faster treatment. 'We know GPs are under pressure and that the only real answer to the service challenges they are facing is to address the numbers,' said one source close to Milburn. 'Our recruitment and retention package will ensure we deliver on the target of 2,000 more by 2004 - and if we can deliver that earlier than promised, all the better.'

Milburn was working out detailed proposals this weekend, after securing funding in last week's Budget. The scheme is expected to be modelled on similar incentives for teachers, where graduates are to be offered £2,000 'golden hellos' to pay off student debts if they stay in teaching.

Doctors' leaders say rising workloads, organisational upheaval and a 'culture of blame' after episodes such as the Shipman murders are putting young doctors off general practice. Older colleagues are also becoming disillusioned: a recent survey of Scottish GPs found 60 per cent considering leaving for other careers, with nearly three-quarters less happy now than five years ago.

Thousands of GPs recruited abroad in the Sixties and Seventies are approaching retirement, leaving more holes to be plugged.

'When people of my generation and younger entered general practice it was the exciting place to be: there was considerable competition for vacancies. That has completely turned around in the last 10 years,' said Dr John Chisholm, chair of the BMA's general practice committee. 'As far as young doctors are concerned, about half are going to need to become GPs and that is just not happening.'

Likely options include changes to pension entitlements for older doctors, making it more worthwhile to stay on after 60; family-friendly policies for women returning after career breaks; and allowing GPs who have retired early to come back without damaging their pension entitlements.

webTitle: Give and you shall receive

fields.headline: Give and you shall receive
fields.standfirst: Philanthropy can also be good for the bank balance, says  Colin Cottell
fields.trailText: Philanthropy can also be good for the bank balance, says Colin Cottell.
fields.body:
Philanthropy is thriving in the United States, but here it is a different story, with income to the UK's leading charities falling in real terms in 1999. Cathy Pharoah, research director at Charities Aid Foundation, is aware of the gulf and the main reason for it. 'US charitable giving is higher because of giving by the rich. For individuals worth below $1 million it is about the same,' she says.

The effects on the charitable sectors in each country are startling. The £3.3 billion donated by Bill Gates last year was almost three times the combined income of the UK's top 10 charities in 1999. Such largesse boosts the average US giving per household to five times that in the UK. Clearly, something needs to be done about the wealthy. Now something has.

Describing itself as 'A new organisation to make it easier for philanthropy to thrive' The Institute for Philanthropy was established in London at the end of 2000. Peter Mimpriss, a partner in Allen and Overy, one of its backers, says: 'The institute's objective is to bring the level of charitable giving up to that of the States.' Hilary Browne-Wilkinson, director of the institute, explains its philosophy. 'The Institute's founders believe that philanthropy will thrive when private wealth is matched with more sympathetic Government policy towards tax allowances and a society that encourages and rewards giving.'

She says the Institute of Philanthropy intends to inject fresh thinking. 'We will be looking at how philanthropy works overseas, in particular the US, to see whether there are lessons we can take advantage of in this country.' In addition, it will conduct and encourage independent research, to boost giving and to ensure that good causes receive the maximum benefit from donations.

Browne-Wilkinson intends that the whole charity sector will benefit rather than specific charities. 'We won't advise charities individually, but will dispense advice so they will be informed.'

Mimpriss says part of the institute's work will be to educate people about how to give. 'We will help them to go through in some detail each of the many ways available to them, and help them to embark on a culture of giving.' The institute will focus on 'anyone who feels they might have some money left over,' he says. In reality this is more likely to be the wealthy.

Browne-Wilkinson believes the time is right. 'There is wealth now that there hasn't been for many years, and the significant changes brought about by last year's Budget, mean there are now tax incentives which will encourage individual private giving.'

Clive Mackintosh, head of private clients at Price Waterhouse Coopers, accepts that a benign tax regime can make a significant difference. He says: 'Tax breaks are very important, though some people would deny they are giving for that reason.'

But even for the non-wealthy, understanding the tax implications of the different ways of giving can make a big difference to the donor and to the charity. And following last year's Budget, which brought in some important changes, here are some of the main ways both can benefit.

Gift Aid

The Gift Aid scheme now applies to any donation: it was previously limited to one-off donations greater than £250. The donation is treated as a net amount after deduction of basic rate income tax. The charity can then claim this from the Inland Revenue. Higher tax rate donors may claim higher rate tax relief via their self assessment form.

Cathy Pharoah says this change could see extra revenue of £200- £400 million per annum over the next few years. Barnardo's say: 'Gift Aid will increase our income by at least £500,000 a year.'

According to Clive Mackintosh: 'As income tax is the most difficult to get relief from, it is the most important way of giving for our clients.'

Give As You Earn

With Give As You Earn the donor pays direct from their gross salary before tax has been deducted, and the Government adds an extra 10 per cent.

There is now no maximum donation. Barnardo's say: 'The 10 per cent top-up on payroll giving from Government will add a further £300,000 over a three-year period.'

Shares and Securities

UK taxpayers donating quoted shares or securities to a charity can obtain double relief. They avoid capital gains tax liability on the gift and gain relief at their marginal rate of income tax.

Here is an example: A higher rate income tax payer (40 per cent) makes a gift of quoted shares worth £20,000. His income tax liability reduces by £8,000 (£20,000 at 40 per cent) making the after income tax cost £12,000. If the shares included a capital gain of £10,000, capital gains tax liability of £4,000 is avoided. This reduces the full after-tax cost of the gift to £8,000.

Stephen Burgess, charities consultant to accountants Saffery Champness, says: 'If you organise it properly the value to charity can be up to five times the after-tax costs to the donor.' Christine Cryne, director of marketing at Help the Aged, says: 'Giving of shares and securities is tiny. There is low awareness, and companies haven't really thought about it. We would prefer the cash, but it is early days.'

Charitable Trusts

Anyone setting up a charitable trust can benefit from generous tax breaks. Donors may benefit by using any of the methods mentioned. Where basic rate tax relief is claimed, it is added to the trust. However, where quoted shares and securities are gifted, the tax benefits go to the donor while the trust receives the shares.

The Charities Aid Foundation says: 'A personal charitable trust is the perfect way to support causes, even beyond your lifetime.'

webTitle: Observer review: number9dream by David Mitchell

fields.headline: When Blade Runner meets Jack Kerouac
fields.standfirst: David Mitchell lets his imagination run riot in number9dream, but can he control the results?
fields.trailText: David Mitchell lets his imagination run riot in number9dream, but can he control the results?
fields.body:
number9dream
David Mitchell
Sceptre £10, pp419
Buy it at a discount at BOL

There was a recent cinema advertisement for a mobile phone company in which every object in an urban landscape was represented only by the letters of its name. The world is nothing more than text, the ad implied; 'everything' is information. This is more or less the post-structuralist vision of David Mitchell's second novel, set in a Tokyo in which, as one character reflects: 'Reality is the page. Life is the word.'

The filmic opening sequences of number9dream plunge us into a Blade Runner-ish world of bioborgs and exotic firearms. Eijie Miyake walks out of a Tokyo café and first blags, then shoots his way into a lawyer's office to abstract a dossier on his father. Fifteen high-octane pages into the book, the prose is broken by a Microsoft 'open file' icon, and suddenly we're back in the café, where Eijie is now watching the city being submerged by a surreal deluge of biblical proportions. Six pages further on comes another rerun of the same scene, in another style and with an alternative ending.

This rather irritating tricksiness sets the tone for the first half of the novel, in which the writing segues without explanation between alternate plot lines, and narrative doors open unexpectedly into other stories. Only gradually does it become clear that the various scenarios are the result of Eijie's hair-trigger imagination; they are nothing more than different screens in his multiplex consciousness. This is the mind of postmodern youth, Mitchell seems to be saying, weaned on computer games, movies, online multiverses and habituated to an incorrigible plurality of realities. Make up your mind, one is inclined to reply, tell the story.

Nevertheless, the plot does proceed, and by degrees Eijie's character and his past emerge from the flux. He is just 20 and has come to Tokyo to find his father. Attitudinous and pustular on the outside, attractively vulnerable on the inside, Eijie sleeps in a capsule-room, picks up odd jobs and lives a strange, retroactive life of memories. His main real-time activity is searching for his father, a quest which takes him on a picaresque tour of Tokyo. Over the course of the book, we realise that Eijie's search is a metaphor for a wider Japanese malaise - the desire to have something to believe in, some way to give reliable meaning to life in a postmodern, late-capitalist wilderness of mirrors.

The most engaging character of number9dream is the city itself, a zirconium-gothic Weberian nightmare, a metal-and-glass superbeast of energy and automation. The worker drones of Tokyo swirl through the prose in their faceless millions, migrating ceaselessly between work and home. The city goes continuously about its business, grinding out its complementary products of capital and pleasure, and crushing humanity in the process. 'These are days when computers humanise and humans computerise,' thinks Eijie.

Mitchell catches the multicoloured atmosphere of the city brilliantly - from its lubricious demi-monde of pink love-hotels and sex emporia, to the boardrooms where high-level yakuza plan murderous operations around mahogany tables. Along the way, he creates a cast of gloriously odd bit-part characters, including a saki-swilling hairdresser and a posturing rentier son who has a litre of blood drained from him by a disgruntled gangster.

Mitchell writes a bravura, reckless prose which takes its cues from William Gibson and Jack Kerouac, and which takes aim at jejune realism. He is a wonderfully amphibious writer, happy in all manner of elements, and seems able to produce an endless parade of interesting characters. number9dream resounds to the same marvellous chatter of different voices that marked out Ghostwritten, his outstanding first novel.

But while Ghostwritten was a tightly controlled, intricately structured work of fiction, number9dream is a sprawling, wanton affair. For all its attractions, the book suffers from an imaginative hyper-fecundity. What with the alternative realities, the narrative byways and cul-de-sacs, there is just too much information coming at you.

webTitle: Who needs celebrities?

fields.headline: Who needs celebrities?
fields.standfirst: In our haste to hail Michael Jackson's campaign, we are overlooking the brutal truth of child abuse
fields.trailText: For Michael Jackson to set himself up as a defender of children's rights seems hardly more plausible than Mullah Omar, head of the Taleban, declaring himself curator-in-chief of the Buddhist statuary of Afghanistan.
fields.body:
For Michael Jackson to set himself up as a defender of children's rights seems hardly more plausible than Mullah Omar, head of the Taleban, declaring himself curator-in-chief of the Buddhist statuary of Afghanistan. Seven years ago, Jackson reached a multi-million dollar, out-of-court settlement with Jordan Chandler, a boy who claimed that the singer had had sex with him. While the payment does not imply guilt in Jackson, who denied the allegations, the episode left an unpleasant aftertaste never quite dispelled until last week, when the star, his china-doll face currently adorned with a nose on which you could squeeze lemons, bewitched the Oxford Union.

There Mr Jackson delivered his "planet-healing" message that "childhood has become the great casualty of modern living". He retold the well-rehearsed story of his bad relationship with his father. He launched his Heal the Kids foundation, which has now been asked by the Charity Commissioners to "clarify a number of issues". A tear drizzled through his eye-liner and his enraptured audience gave him a three-minute standing ovation.

Most newspapers reported the speech politely and prominently. The Guardian devoted a slab of its front page to the story, appending the "universal bill of rights" compiled by Mr Jackson and enshrining, among other sugared garbage, "the right to be thought of as adorable [even if you have a face only a mother could love]". By coincidence, on the same day but tucked towards the back, the papers carried the brief story of a child never deemed adorable by an "unfeeling" mother or by the father who slammed her against the ceiling and hurled her bruised body into the air to "toughen her up", shortly before shaking her to death.

Chelsea Brown was two when she was murdered. A social worker had visited often but took no action despite Chelsea's many injuries and her father's violent record. A hospital doctor who treated a black eye said the damage was accidental. And so another child was left to die, like Anna Climbie a few weeks ago and, before her, a long litany in which only the names and the faces vary. The mistakes, always similar, eventually herald the muted reportage, stripped of shock or anger, that marked Chelsea's death. What is there left to say? But hopelessness does not betoken heartlessness. Of course we care. Hence the emotional reaction to Michael Jackson's maudlin tales of childhood and the deference paid to his banal bill of rights. When child abuse is too disturbing or dispiriting to confront, then the sanitised version, filtered through the prism of celebrity, becomes a new reality.

Perhaps as a respite from a diet of decline - bad hospitals, bad transport, bad schools - we are all starstruck now. Almost every debate has been correspondingly lobotomised. On racism, the big story is Anne Robinson being nasty to the Welsh. Of course she would be. If rudeness is your hallmark, and if you must confess your loathings on television, you are not going to say you have never been mad about pop socks or over-boiled Brussels sprouts. So the Welsh get teased. Cue fabricated fury, acres of lovely publicity for Robinson and, surreally, squeaks by two MPs for her to be hauled before the Welsh affairs select committee and forced to apologise for her 'racist' remarks. Is this what Sir William Macpherson had in mind?

Forget violent crime statistics. What we need to know is who gunned down EastEnder Phil Mitchell. More expensive spectacles for the elderly? The only optical story around is the ban by Coronation Street 's style police on the windshield glasses favoured, these days, only by arc-welders and Deirdre Rachid. The scandal of Dr Harold Shipman (aka James Bolam of The Likely Lads) is being turned into a £1.5 million TV docu-drama even before inquiries are concluded. The Townsend Report on 'Breadline Europe' is eclipsed by pre-publicity for the BBC's fatuously-entitled Pants To Poverty initiative and, amid the tributes to John Diamond, a leading surgeon's warning that the government's cancer plan is dangerously flawed merits only a paragraph or two. Meanwhile, Hull University's proposed course in Yorkshire studies is hailed by the Daily Express as "a chance to study the county that gave us Mel B and the Brontës".

Then there is the flip-side of celebrity cultism, as demonstrated by Paul Templeman-Wright, the Surrey headmaster who excluded 60 pupils to get rid of "the language of the street". Kicking children out is a dangerous, damaging business, but what is a head to do when his school is being polluted by the disgusting influence of stars like Eminem and Elton John? It is a pity he does not know that most teenagers think Eminem is a loser or that Elton's worst forays into vulgarity are duets with Kiki Dee and pink spectacles at which even Deirdre might baulk. Mr Templeman-Wright certainly has a problem, but his celebrity villains are merely camouflage to his autocracy.

Loathed or venerated, celebs are the icons of a secular age. Star worship is the opiate not of the masses but of the chattering classes and the thinking classes and of anyone whose spirits lift upon discovering this week's Hello! magazine in the dentist's waiting- room. The French, much better than us at bathos, have a new television hit show called Le Gout Du Noir, in which a blind presenter hosts a dinner in a darkened room. The programme, filmed with infra-red cameras and intended to give the sighted a feel for the world of the blind, is also a forum for showbusiness guests to dribble, spill wine, look helpless and fail to recognise their closest friends.

Better, deglamorised participants must discuss an abstract or philosophical theme, presumably on the basis that a phone-in on the ontological proof of God could hardly be duller than a solipsistic rant delivered to an unctuous Parky or a fawning Esther. But egomania is bound to flourish when the powerful can no longer define who they are without a celebrity acting as a cue card.

Prince Charles, for example, is both a switched-on dad (when pictured with Charlie's Angels) and a heart-of-oak muck-shoveller (when pictured with the Archers.) The food chain of glamour meant, in turn, that the Press Complaints Commission had to snap up Charles - and Camilla and William - for a star-studded party demonstrating its sterling defence of ordinary folk.

As for politicians, the Number 10 canapé-munchers - Damien Hirst, the Gallaghers, Chris Evans - are less in evidence now. Some of the lustrous turned against Blair, and the Icarus effect of Peter Mandelson's schmoozing with the famous may have proved the greatest dampener since Danbert Nobacon of Chumbawamba hurled a bucket of water over John Prescott at the Brit Awards.

Possibly the government realises that the tables have been turned. Obeisance to celebrity is no longer a symbol of being in touch. It is, at worst, the mark of a society grown so cynical or so despairing that it would rather take lessons on abuse from a pop star of questionable reputation than from the history of Chelsea Brown. The crescendo of public anger previously generated by such tragedies has been largely unheard or unheeded by politicians. Perhaps this time they might listen to the silence.

webTitle: Japan's premier signals a long goodbye

fields.headline: Japan's premier signals a long goodbye
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: Japan was braced for its eighth prime minister in eight years last night after Yoshiro Mori indicated his intention to resign.
fields.body:
Japan was braced for its eighth prime minister in eight years last night after Yoshiro Mori indicated his intention to resign.

The demise of Mori, whose 11-month premiership has been marked by gaffes, scandals and economic decline, will be welcomed by a jaded electorate and is expected to boost Tokyo's slumping financial markets.

But with no obvious successor, Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party faces a period of turmoil that will distract from the central task of preventing the economy from skidding into recession.

At an emergency meeting last night, Mori indicated to senior party officials that he was ready to resign but, in an attempt to save face, the wording and timing were vague. Mori said he would bring forward elections for a new party president, who would automatically succeed him as head of government if coalition allies agree.

He will not announce his resignation publicly until the end of the month. This will allow him to go ahead with summits with President George W. Bush on 19 March and Russian President Vladimir Putin on 25 March.

With support ratings of only 6 per cent, Mori is the second most unpopular premier in postwar Japanese history. Calls for him to stand down have reached a fever pitch in the past week amid a declining economy and a growing political scandal.

In a speech on Wednesday, he is expected to take 'responsibility' - the code word for a resignation - for his government's failings.

The search for his successor has already begun, but none of the leading candidates has expressed much enthusiasm.

Whoever replaces Mori will accept a poisoned chalice. The LDP, which has ruled Japan for all but one of the past 46 years, has seen a steady decline in its support since the economic bubble burst in 1989.

webTitle: Random drug tests for doctors

fields.headline: Random drug tests for doctors
fields.standfirst: NHS in crackdown on substance abuse at work
fields.trailText: Doctors and nurses face random testing for drink and drugs under radical plans being drawn up by the National Health Service.
fields.body:
Doctors and nurses face random testing for drink and drugs under radical plans being drawn up by the National Health Service.

The proposal, which is backed by the General Medical Council, is designed to prevent doctors and nurses working while under the influence.

NHS Trusts have held talks with companies specialising in testing for substance abuse in the workplace. 'They [the NHS Trusts] are very serious about it,' said one source involved in the talks. The NHS Confederation, which represents the trusts, confirmed that plans for tests were part of a review of work safety procedures.

'We know there is a high incidence of substance problems [among doctors],' said Alistair Henderson, policy manager at the NHS Confederation. 'It is a question of sifting through and supporting staff. [Tests] should not be show trials.'

Random drug tests in the workplace are increasingly common. Train drivers, military personnel and prison officers already face them. It is illegal for a company to allow intoxicated staff to endanger lives at work. According to some studies, up to 15% of doctors have a drink or drug problem in their lifetime.

The General Medical Council, responsible for upholding ethics in the medical profession, said it was in favour of randomly testing all NHS staff. 'Employers should have robust mechanisms for ensuring that doctors working for them are fit to practise,' a spokesman said.

The plans are likely to provoke fierce opposition. The British Medical Association has vowed to oppose random testing, calling for tests only if an incident arouses suspicion.

The Royal College of Nursing said random compulsory tests were an 'invasion of privacy', but would accept voluntary schemes.

Health trusts have yet to set a date for when the testing will start.

Medical students are overwhelmingly in favour of random alcohol and drug testing and pressured the BMA into considering tests last year.

Last year the GMC recorded a 50% rise in complaints against medical staff, many of which were attributed to younger GPs appalled at the practices of their senior colleagues.

Students told the BMA that random testing would help secure patients' goodwill as the medical profession struggles to stay self-regulated.

webTitle: Video releases

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Dirty Pictures | Titus | Chopper
fields.trailText: Dirty Pictures | Titus | Chopper
fields.body:
Dirty Pictures
(2000, 18, Warner, VHS/Rental)

The 'dirty pictures' at the centre of this first-class docu-drama - made for US cable TV and going straight to video here - are the homoerotic photographs of Robert Mapplethorpe that in 1990 led to an obscenity trial in Cincinnati, Ohio and left the director of the city's Contemporary Arts Centre (James Woods) facing a jail sentence. The movie, directed by veteran screenwriter Frank Pierson, who won an Oscar for Dog Day Afternoon, takes a libertarian stance, but it presents zealots at both ends of the spectrum as well as troubled people in between.

The dramatised parts are punctuated by newsreel interviews and specially-filmed comments from, among others, Salman Rushdie, William Buckley and Mapplethorpe himself. Woods is outstanding as the decent, agonising man in the middle whose family is torn apart by the controversy, and the movie ends not on a note of liberal triumphalism about upholding free speech, but with a frightening coda in which a right-wing upholder of family values claims a long-term victory for his side.

Titus
(1999, 18, Buena Vista, VHS/Rental)
Julie Taymor, the US theatre director who put The Lion King on the stage, here makes a dazzlingly confident cinematic debut with this version of Shakespeare's Titus Andronicus . Set in a world which is part ancient Rome, part Mussolini's fascist Italy, it is a cruel, darkly comic affair that makes painful contemporary sense, though there is a dubious framing device. As the tortured Roman general of the title, Anthony Hopkins leads a fine cast who handle the magnificent verse with verve and clarity.

Chopper
(2000, 18, Metrodome, VHS/DVD Retail/Rental)
Dramatised portrait of the notorious Australian criminal Mark 'Chopper' Reed, a violent psychopathic racist who terrorised the Melbourne underworld, defied the cops and, like our own 'Mad' Frankie Fraser, became a media celebrity and author. Stand-up comic Eric Bana is frighteningly convincing as Chopper, but the movie lacks context for British audiences.

webTitle: 'Flawed' figures appear in record for first time

fields.headline: 'Flawed' figures appear in record for first time
fields.trailText: A century ago it chronicled the lives of the rich and famous. But the Dictionary of National Biography was seen as a flawed work for its refusal to include certain prominent figures because of scandals in their private lives or undesirable professional behaviour.
fields.body:
A century ago it chronicled the lives of the rich and famous. But the Dictionary of National Biography was seen as a flawed work for its refusal to include certain prominent figures because of scandals in their private lives or undesirable professional behaviour.

Now, in the first fully revised edition of the DNB, people such as the spy Guy Burgess, Lord Randolph Churchill, previously ignored because of his alcoholism, and others who were shunned for being homosexual will be included.

The slogan of the DNB - founded in 1901 and open only to the dead - may have been 'all human life is there' but critics argued that it neglected an array of colourful characters because of its moral censorship. The Oxford University Press editors of the New DNB say it is time to reflect changing social attitudes.

'The original Victorian edition recognised that many people who attract attention in the historical record do so for the wrong reasons,' said Robert Faber, director of the project.

In the new edition, there is an acknowledgement for an 18th-century Oxford college head, Warden Thistlethwayte of Wadham, previously shunned for involvement in a homosexual scandal.

One of those who makes it in for the first time is George Washington - omitted when British imperialism was rampant - as part of the new policy of including candidates with links to the British Isles. Even Jack the Ripper, although never identified, will make an appearance as will Robert Maxwell and Rillington Place killer John Christie.

The DNB plans to revise all existing 36,000 articles and add 14,000 new ones over the next four years. Women will also be given greater prominence as the editors try to modernise the dictionary. Diana, Princess of Wales, will be included along with the lesser known Phyllis Pearsall who brought out the first London A-Z maps.

Pop stars, comedians, sports men and women and what the editor, Brian Harrison, calls 'non-metropolitan' people will be also feature more heavily.

Articles will also reflect the modern obsession with celebrities' personal lives. 'If it has entered the historical record, it will be included,' said Faber. The historical record is made up of everything from tabloid news reports to academic papers.

The book will also keep its references to the worthy but obscure, such as Sir Farquhar Buzzard, an Oxford doctor, and AV Dicey, a jurist.

Harrison said the new edition will appear in 2004.
