The general enemy is the assumption - from pundit to couch potato - that Labour has it in the bag and that a second term can be taken for granted. The specific enemy - welcome back our old chum, the Daily Mail - is a series of stinking, stinging attacks designed to build cynicism. It is a theory with substance, worth looking at down the press end of the telescope. First, Labour's poll lead is cavernous. If everybody assumes it's all over, it probably is. Second, smaller majorities make better headlines and - pace Francis Pym - better governments. Third, the pall of predictability reaches deep inside editorial offices themselves. We pretty much know already who'll endorse who. We could write the final editorials now. The Telegraph will vote Conservative. (Small earthquake in Canary Wharf: nobody wakes up.) The Mirrors , the FT, the Guardian and the Independent will stick to Labour with varying degrees of enthusiasm. The Express will commune with Posh Spice and then back Blair (to show that it's not the Mail). Rupert Murdoch said the other day he hadn't made his mind up yet, but never kid a kidder. The Sun made up its (Good on yer, Gordon) mind on Budget day. The Sunday Times chunters so much about Europe that perhaps nobody cares what it says elsewhere. The Times has a rare loathing for Hague. 'Losing an election is a serious matter for any political democracy,' it observed last week after the foreign country fulminations, 'but losing a reputation for honour and decency is a much more serious one.' Change here will only come with the arrival of El Portillo. So, for a flicker of unpredictability, we are back with the bête noire of Derry Street. Even the Mail jumped ship four years ago as its benign proprietor announced his antipathy to modern Toryism. Well, Vere Harmsworth is in his grave and balances shift: the Mail is crabby about Blairism these days and occasionally - on married family tax breaks - mildly encouraging to Mr Hague. Nevertheless, nobody in Smith Square should expect a clear conversion. No editor - especially Paul Dacre, trailing his most-powerful-man-in-Britain glory - likes backing a losing side. No editor lightly urges his readers to do something they won't do. Thus, as the Millbank mob deduce, there will be opportunistic plagues on Labour's houses coupled with suitably agonised leaders. That may have the chilling effect the spinners fear. It may be the only byzantine way of helping a hapless Hague. But it also tugs at a dismal truth that afflicts all newspapers. This is simply that elections - moments of great decision - ought to herald buoyant sales figures. Engaged electorates equal paying customers, so there are two reasons for editors to get excited. Yet that is not the reality. Look at May 1997. The Sun's circulation lost nearly 200,000 as campaigning began. April and May were way below the first three months of the year. The Mirror sold fewer copies in April and May than in January and February. The Express slid as usual. Nothing happened at the Mail until July (when politics went to the beaches). More glumly still, the April tallies for Telegraph, Guardian, Independent, Times and FT were all down on March. In short, elections are circulation downers, not uppers. The broadsheets get a boost the morning after the vote, but otherwise apathy barely needs stirring. And this was an election of upheaval, of change - the high tide of Blairism. One set of figures, of course, can't be the whole story. Yet, if you go back to 9 April, 1992, things were not so different. The Mirror, Sun and Express were all losers again; the Mail trod water; the Telegraph and the Times slipped back. Only the Guardian and the Independent, of surviving newspapers, made worthwhile gains. And here, significantly, may be the only kiss of life elections still provide. The really big winner in 1992 was Today, up from 460,000 to 533,000 over eight weeks. Like the Independent, it benefited from sampling and shopping around. New papers have that edge in a period of flux. Such surges, though, soon fade. Today is a distant yesterday now. The Indy is 165,000 off its erstwhile pace. It is small wonder this morning that, as Tony Blair fingers the Go button, little adrenalin races round Fleet Street. The tabloids face a month of awful sales statistics; the qualities have little to look forward to. Campaigning itself is a grim switch-off. Much expense and effort for scant reward. Duty calls, of course. They'll do their duty. They may even get excited at one or two points. But if apathy is the foe, it's infectious far beyond Mail HQ. For this, alas, would seem to be apathy reciprocated.

webTitle: Mark Morris on this year's indie film success story

fields.headline: Oscar's big surprise
fields.standfirst: From the Sundance Festival to Academy Award nominee - You Can Count On Me beat the odds to become this year's indie success story, writes  Mark Morris
fields.trailText: From the Sundance Festival to Academy Award nominee - You Can Count On Me beat the odds to become this year's indie success story, writes Mark Morris
fields.body:
If you can't compete with Hollywood on its own terms, you need a hook, a gimmick. Think of the breakthrough films associated with the independent, low-budget Sundance Film Festival over the years and each had a unique selling point. The Blair Witch Project had the shaking cameras and the tease of cinema verité while Reservoir Dogs had the ear-slicing.

With Clerks, it was the story behind the story of how Kevin Smith made the film for next to nothing at the store he was working at; with Slacker, it was the dozens of monologuing freaks, while Sex, Lies, and Videotape had the instantly immortal title. It was something you could grab straightaway, something that said: 'This Is Not Hollywood.'

This year, the fuss has been about Richard Linklater's Waking Life, a conventional, talkie indie movie rendered extraordinary by its unsettling animation, and Memento, which is already something of a cult over here.

Last year, Sundance's Grand Jury Prize was split between two films. One was the excellent Girlfight. Although it is a superb piece of ghetto realism, it also has a title that explains everything you need to know, and provokes debates about whether women should box. But the other winner, was You Can Count On Me. And here's the odd thing: You Can Count On Me has no obvious must-see factor.

There is no high-concept reason why you should see this low-budget, small-town drama. It doesn't even have true outsider status: its writer-director Kenneth Lonergan wrote Analyze This and The Adventures of Rocky and Bullwinkle. Matthew Broderick is in the cast and Martin Scorsese was executive producer.

The bare outline of the plot doesn't help much either. The main characters are an orphaned brother (Mark Ruffalo) and sister (Laura Linney), now grown up. The sister is a single mother, who has stayed in the town and is trying to live a respectable life working at the bank; the brother is a slacker who escaped as soon as he could. That, and the title, had cynics suggesting it was going to resemble a TV movie.

All You Can Count On Me has going for it is that it is a brilliantly subtle, intelligent, compassionate and terrifically-acted movie. And for once, the Academy has recognised its virtues, giving Laura Linney a best actress nomination and putting Lonergan in the running for best original screenplay. Linney can't win - this is Julia Roberts's year - but Lonergan just might, having already picked up a Writers' Guild award.

'I like awards a lot when they give them to me, but I feel that one should not attach too much importance to them if one wants to avoid becoming a shoddy person,' Lonergan says on the phone from his New York apartment. Surely it is exciting to be nominated for an Oscar? 'Very exciting,' Lonergan says in a deliberate voice that is slightly unsettling. 'It's the highest honour our civilisation has to bestow.'

You Can Count On Me is built around its fully-realised characters, right from the beginning, where we learn of the parents' death in an exquisitely-executed prologue. 'I do try hard to make sure that the story is driven by the personalities of the people involved, or by the circumstances they're in, and not by more general structural concerns. I generally follow what I think would happen.' The unexpected benefit of this is that the narrative of the film surprises you in a way that many films don't. 'I don't set out to to be unpredictable, but I don't want it to be predictable because not just in films but in plays you can always see what's coming a mile away.'

Given that this is Lonergan's debut film and it has such an immediacy, the easy assumption - the one I made - is that it must be autobiographical. Not so. The small-town setting has nothing to do with Lonergan's upbringing in Manhattan's well-heeled Upper West Side. His take on small-town America is interesting, while dodging both the idyllic clichés of Old Hollywood and its subversion by the likes of David Lynch.

'The first isn't true, because nothing is absolutely wonderful, and the second is not the most interesting point to make anymore; it's been made many times by many fine plays and novels. I was mostly interested in two aspects of small-town life - the sense of peacefulness, quiet and serenity in town in a beautiful setting, combined with this feeling of isolation and constriction, and which of those two aspects come to the fore at what point.'

Lonergan acts in the film - he plays the church minister who is called in by Sam (Linney) to try to get Terry (Ruffalo) to find some purpose in his life. Some critics have seen this as an authorial intervention, Lonergan arriving in the text like an eighteenth-century novelist to lay down the law.

Lonergan dismisses the idea gently: 'That's a lovely idea that comes from their imaginations.' So is Lonergan a religious person? 'No, I was brought up in a very secular household, and don't believe in God or anything like it. Nobody believed in God in my house.'

He is 38, son of a 'non-believing Irish-Catholic father and a non-believing Jewish mother'. He went to private school with Matthew Broderick, a lifelong friend who is superb in You Can Count On Me as Sam's officious new boss at the bank. 'People are starting to get the idea that he's not just the sweet, innocent Matthew, who does not exist in any form, by the way.'

After NYU and a brief stint at the Royal Court, his writing career developed along two fronts: a growing reputation as a playwright in New York, and an attempt to establish himself as a screenwriter for hire in Hollywood, which mostly consisted of years of hawking Analyze This around.

He has never seen the film, but says reports of his bitterness about what was done to his script, and his unsatisfactory time working on The Adventures of Rocky and Bullwinkle, are grossly exaggerated.

'They were standard Hollywood experiences. I did not enjoy that process, and without approving of that process, I entered those situations with eyes wide open. I don't think I went in there with some artistic vision and got burned by bad people. I wrote Analyze This to sell it and make money and that's what happened.'

What is clearly true is that the writing in You Can Count On Me owes nothing to the commercial strictures of his Hollywood scripts and a lot to his plays. 'I see myself as both a playwright and filmmaker. I'm very comfortable in the theatre.'

That You Can Count On Me was a relatively unproblematic experience is due largely to Scorsese - Lonergan slightly self-consciously refers to him as 'Marty'. Knowing they were unlikely to give final cut to someone who had never directed anything on film before, Lonergan suggested to the company that they entrust the last say to Scorsese. With America's finest living director backing his decisions, Lonergan got his way. In return, Lonergan spent the winter in Rome doing script rewrites on Scorsese's epic Gangs of New York.

Kenneth Lonergan is an interesting character, bright and strong. He's certainly got a lot more interesting work in him. But right now, he is waiting to see whether the Hollywood establishment will bestow an award on a film that has nothing to sell it but good writing, good acting and a laudable refusal to tie up loose ends.

 You Can Count On Me opens on 23 March

webTitle: Dawn Airey shoots from the hip

fields.headline: Dawn Airey shoots from the hip
fields.trailText: 'I'm sorry if the broadcasting establishment don't like what we do - but our viewers do. We're not part of that establishment.
fields.body:
'I'm sorry if the broadcasting establishment don't like what we do - but our viewers do. We're not part of that establishment.

'It's right that any broadcaster should aspire high. You have an important responsibility to the audience and to do things for the greater good.

'But at the end of the day this is a business; and one that does not have the luxury of a licence fee like the BBC; or not being accountable to shareholders like Channel 4; or a 40-year inheritance to draw on like ITV.

'People may say you should be making Bafta- winning drama, or whatever, but that's not the business we're in.

'One thing you cannot get away from is that Channel 5 is the most leanly funded terrestrial channel. We are so successful as a business because we are the most efficient at turning pounds spent into ratings. We are far more efficient than the rest of them.

'We are also pretty smart when it comes down to predicting just what we need to do to get to a certain share of viewing. We know which slots we need to improve share in.'

webTitle: C5 alive and confounding the critics

fields.headline: C5 alive and confounding the critics
fields.standfirst: As TV's terrestrial baby nears four it must find its own voice, says  Jason Deans, broadcasting editor of mediaguardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: As TV's terrestrial baby nears four it must find its own voice, says Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Opinion has always been divided on Channel 5. Commercially, few in television would argue that it has been anything other than a pretty hefty success. Critically - well, that's another matter.

However, as the fifth terrestrial broadcaster nears its fourth birthday later this month, it is a given that if Channel 5 is to continue driving up its audience share and advertising revenue, it needs to move away from the cheap, cheerful and sometimes saucy programmes that have so vexed TV puritans.

Instead, it needs to invest more money to create its own EastEnders and Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? - compelling shows that attract big audiences, week in, week out.

So far, so simple. Except that Channel 5's owner, the French RTL Group, which holds 65 per cent, and United Business Media, which owns the other 35 per cent, appear at loggerheads over its future.

There is a strong argument to be made that critics who bang on about shoddy Channel 5 programming are missing the point. The channel was not set up, like Channel 4, to encourage programming diversity and win bucket-loads of Baftas. It was always an out-and-out commercial beast that gave advertisers an alternative to ITV.

And Channel 5 has achieved this goal fantastically well, in the process creating a business already valued at around £1 billion. From a standing start in March 1997, it went on to achieve an average 5.4 per cent share of the national audience in 1999. In the second quarter of last year, the station hit an average of 6 per cent. Since then Channel 5 has hit a plateau, partly because of the Big Brother effect last September. It reached 6 per cent again in October, but slipped to an average of 5.6 per cent across the eight months to the end of last month.

The pilot who guided Channel 5 successfully for its first three and a half years, chief executive David Elstein, was dropped in October. He left amid talk of bust-ups with RTL and its anxiety not to lose his successor, the then- director of programmes Dawn Airey, who was being wooed elsewhere.

RTL, which became the broadcaster's majority owner last spring when it was formed by the merger of Channel 5 shareholders Pearson TV and CLT-Ufa, has made its ambitions clear. RTL chief executive Didier Bellens wants to see Channel 5's audience share reach 10 per cent in the next two or three years.

To this end, RTL sought a 50 per cent increase in Channel 5's 2001 programming budget to £180m, but was opposed by United chief executive Lord Clive Hollick, a man not renowned for putting his hand in his pocket. A couple of weeks ago United bragged that a programming budget of £140m had been agreed for 2001.

This difference of opinion came to a head over extra money for a £10m movie deal with Warner Brothers. United got an injunction blocking the deal, which was overturned on appeal by RTL.

The budget-haggling took place while RTL and United were said to be unable to agree a price for the latter's stake in the channel, which has been valued at around £350m.

But now Hollick has ruled out selling United's Channel 5 shares this year, so the uneasy relationship between the owners looks set to continue for the time being.

Peter Bazalgette, creative director of Endemol UK, says: 'Grabbing around 6 per cent when you haven't even got distribution across the whole country has been nothing short of a triumph. But if you have to go to court to buy movies, that's not good news. Unless RTL and United sort out the shareholding, they are going to lose share.'

New Channel 5 chief executive Airey, who is understood to have been promised extra cash by shareholders before she took the top job, says the station is now exactly where it expected to be. Performance was always going to level off 'if substantial extra resources weren't put in', says Airey.

She declares herself happy with the 2001 programming budget: the £140m is still a big increase on the previous year: 'We're conducting a business review and hope to make a compelling case to the board for additional resources.'

She will seek the extra money on a case by case basis. 'Dawn can come to us if there's a film package or football she thinks will do a job for the channel,' says an RTL spokesman. 'That's the way Channel 5 has always worked with its shareholders.'

When it comes to specific plans, Airey is not giving much away. But she does say: 'We'll concentrate on ratings between 7pm and 9pm.'

The biggest weapon here will be 'big, one-hour entertainment shows, which are our forte'. She reels off a list that includes established shows Night Fever and Fort Boyard, just-finished reality game show series The Mole, the endurance show Touch the Truck, which starts tonight, and the upcoming £1m prize game show Greed.

Other priorities include upgrading Channel 5's movie stock. This has begun, with the Warner deal including titles The Fugitive and Unforgiven, and a package bought jointly with Channel 4 that will give Channel 5 the terrestrial premiere of Gladiator. Airey says she is increasing the budgets for factual series, where Channel 5 has enjoyed success with its 'crime documentary franchises' and makeover show House Doctor. Football remains on the radar, with the England v Albania World Cup qualifier coming up later this month. In July, she will begin broadcasting Aussie soap Home and Away, poached from ITV.

Airey will be judged on audience share. 'Ten per cent is achievable, but what it will cost, I'm not sure,' she says. It's about where you get the audience from. TV viewing is going down, so you've got to take it off somebody else.'

Dawn Airey shoots from the hip

I'm sorry if the broadcasting establishment don't like what we do - but our viewers do. We're not part of that establishment.

'It's right that any broadcaster should aspire high. You have an important responsibility to the audience and to do things for the greater good.

'But at the end of the day this is a business; and one that does not have the luxury of a licence fee like the BBC; or not being accountable to shareholders like Channel 4; or a 40-year inheritance to draw on like ITV.

'People may say you should be making Bafta-winning drama, or whatever, but that's not the business we're in.

'One thing you cannot get away from is that Channel 5 is the most leanly funded terrestrial channel. We are so successful as a business because we are the most efficient at turning pounds spent into ratings. We are far more efficient than the rest of them.

'We are also pretty smart when it comes down to predicting just what we need to do to get to a certain share of viewing. We know which slots we need to improve share in.'

Airey will be judged on audience share. 'Ten per cent is achievable, but what it will cost, I'm not sure,' she says. It's about where you get the audience from. TV viewing is going down, so you've got to take it off somebody else.' Dawn Airey shoots from the hip I'm sorry if the broadcasting establishment don't like what we do - but our viewers do. We're not part of that establishment. 'It's right that any broadcaster should aspire high. You have an important responsibility to the audience and to do things for the greater good. 'But at the end of the day this is a business; and one that does not have the luxury of a licence fee like the BBC; or not being accountable to shareholders like Channel 4; or a 40-year inheritance to draw on like ITV. 'People may say you should be making Bafta-winning drama, or whatever, but that's not the business we're in. 'One thing you cannot get away from is that Channel 5 is the most leanly funded terrestrial channel. We are so successful as a business because we are the most efficient at turning pounds spent into ratings. We are far more efficient than the rest of them. 'We are also pretty smart when it comes down to predicting just what we need to do to get to a certain share of viewing. We know which slots we need to improve share in.'

webTitle: Single mothers get IT call-up

fields.headline: Single mothers get IT call-up
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will this week unveil a plan to push thousands of jobless single mothers into high-flying computer jobs as Labour raises its ambitions for the New Deal.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will this week unveil a plan to push thousands of jobless single mothers into high-flying computer jobs as Labour raises its ambitions for the New Deal.

Ministers intend to hit back at criticism that they are simply forcing people into work. 'This is basically the next phase - the ambition is for jobs with good prospects, not just any old job,' said a source in the Department for Education and Employment. 'It is not just about the first rung on the ladder, but about getting in higher up.'

The so-called 'Ambition IT' scheme for 5,000 claimants - with priority given to single parents and those from ethnic minorities - will be contained in a Green Paper published on Wednesday - coinciding with figures expected to show unemployment falling again, possibly below the magic one million mark.

'There may only be one million unemployed now, but that is still a million too many,' said a Downing Street source. 'There was a time when people used to think this idea of full employment was a dream, but unemployment has been falling and it can fall further.'

The paper also promises a £100 million package of help for lone parents, including grants to cover advance childcare costs before starting new jobs, plus £40m for drug addicts emerging from rehabilitation. But it will also extend benefit cuts for non-compliance to over-25s.

The 'Ambition IT' scheme will be extended to other boom areas, such as the hotel and restaurant trade or financial services, if it works.

The Chancellor's chief adviser, Ed Balls, said yesterday that the paper would also target employment blackspots. 'There is an assumption that, because for much of the twentieth century cities north of London have fallen behind the South East, that somehow this is inevitable - our new approach is now to be based on the strongly held conviction that the opposite is true,' he told a Unions 21 conference in London.

webTitle: Media Diary

fields.headline: Media Diary
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Lowering the toner
fields.body:
Lowering the toner

Diary hears more tales of porn baron Richard Desmond's generosity and editorial investment over at the Sexpress. The paper's shrinking staff now switch on their machines in the morning only to find stacks of emails pleading for, er... toner for the photocopiers. Lately, our moles report, even editorial director Paul Ashford's secretary has joined in the deluge, pleading for tubes of the precious black powder. Either someone there's a toner squirrel or our Desmond thinks copiers copy by magic.

Kiss me, Hardy

Here's a brilliant idea for newspaper editors under fire. Why not appoint your spouse as one of your deputies? Hey presto, instant support. Sadly the decision by Scotsman ed Rebecca Hardy to make hubby Mike Knapp (formerly a sports hack with the Sexpress) deputy editor of her Glasgow office has not gone down too well with staff. For some reason they see the move as nepotism.

Puppet on a Stringie

Is there any one left who hasn't been interviewed by the DTI in relation to Slickergate? Inspectors looking for evidence of insider dealing at the Mirror recently had a little chat with Diary's hunk of the month, Peter Stringfellow. Diary is keen to stress that there is no suggestion of wrongdoing on Stringie's part. The chat is in addition to similar conflabs with practically the entire Mirror IT department and most of the paper's management, not to mention the son of a director of one of London's largest football clubs. Diary rings its great friend, ex-Slicker James Hipwell, to check out the story. 'I used to go to Stringfellows to look at beautiful women, not to talk about the City,' Hipwell tells us. Never one to mix business with pleasure, our James.

To the Max

Diary's three readers are invited to submit suggestions as to why Kevin Keegan was seen in Max Clifford's offices last week. Apparently the two are discussing a beautiful future together, of which more details soon. Entries should try to include the words 'perm' and the phrase 'love it if we beat them'. A date with Stringie discussing share tips for the lucky winner.

An odds choice

Diary is fascinated to learn that Sunday Business is to feature a regular spread-betting column offering top-drawer advice from resident expert 'Devon Loch'. Diary questions the advice of a man who takes as his nom de plume the name of a racehorse famous for failing in spectacular style to win the Grand National. Still, providing Devon knows his onions, punters won't worry that his name is synonymous with 'loser'. So who is this mystery man upon whose words they will act with great haste? One David Simpson. A legendary gambler perchance? Er, no. Dave is actually a senior PR man with City spinmeister Square Mile. Would you put your shirt on this man's advice?

In search of a smile?

Diary hears on the sly that the Indie is to appoint a new ad agency. Walsh Trott Chick Smith, best known for its Channel 5 smiley face campaign, will get the nod.

webTitle: Paddy Considine

fields.headline: Paddy Considine
fields.standfirst: The best-kept secret in British movies
fields.trailText: Paddy Considine, the best-kept secret in British movies.
fields.body:
Two years ago Paddy Considine played the obsessive loner in Shane Meadows's A Room For Romeo Brass. Considine, a non-professional who got the chance to make his screen debut partly due to a long-standing friendship with the director, gave a finely balanced performance that crackled with menace.

Both Considine and the film received a rousing reception at the Edinburgh Film Festival. Here was a star in the making. But not yet. The following Monday he was back at the dole office in Burton-on-Trent.

Considine, who initially trained to be a photographer, decided to concentrate on acting. His new film, Pawel Pawlikowski's The Last Resort, is another substantial effort from the British independent sector. In this Edinburgh favourite from last year he plays the unlikely romantic exiled to dreary Margate where he is a benign small-time entrepreneur. Catering to the needs of the local refugee population, he combines altruism and self-interest by deciding to help an attractive Russian illegal immigrant (Dina Korzun).

A delicate romance unfolds, framed by Pawlikowski's expressionist vision of the Kent coastal town as a Kafka-esque final destination. Considine is superb as an aspirant everyman; rich in sentiment but rarely sentimental.

The 27-year-old grew up on a council estate in Burton-on-Trent. After school he took a college drama course and met Meadows. The pair collaborated on a series of anarchic short films and formed a band. Then he completed a photography course, and later published and exhibited his images.

Considine has a scene-stealing cameo in the British comedy Born Romantic and last year he also filmed Happy Now, a black comedy starring Ioan Gruffudd and Susan Lynch.

He's currently working on 24 Hour Party People, the much-anticipated film about Factory Records and the Madchester scene. It will be only his fourth major film role but his choices to date are to be applauded. There are no wonky Britflick crime capers on his CV. Long may it continue.

 Last Resort opens on Friday

Five things you need to know about Paddy Considine

1 He studied at Brighton University. 2 He got a first-class degree in photography. 3 He specialises in photographic studies of bare-knuckle fighters. 4 He likes to improvise a lot on set. 5 In 24-Hour Party People he plays Rob Gretton, the man who discovered Joy Division.

webTitle: This is spaniel tap

fields.headline: This is spaniel tap
fields.standfirst: Having satirised the world of rock music, Christopher Guest goes to the dogs
fields.trailText: Philip French: Best in Show is gentle satire, more at the expense of the absurdity of human life than this particular doggie subculture, which it views with affection
fields.body:
Dogs have, as it were, left their mark on numerous milestones in the history of cinema. The first significant British movie is Cecil Hepworth's technically accomplished six-minute Rescued by Rover (Rover was a collie), made in 1905. Until the coming of sound, Warner Brothers were kept solvent by films featuring the German shepherd Rin Tin Tin, most of them scripted by Darryl Zanuck, founder of 20th Century-Fox. A little later, the Yorkshire collie Lassie (dubbed 'Greer Garson in Furs') became a major star at MGM, and from Pluto to 101 Dalmatians, dogs have always played a leading role at the Disney studio.

Movie dogs have usually been man's best (sometimes only) friend, as in De Sica's Umberto D. Occasionally, though, they're his worst enemy - in Stephen King's Cujo, for instance, and Sam Fuller's White Dog, which distributors rejected because it featured a canine racist. Dogs have brought disparate people together (the homophobic Jack Nicholson and his gay neighbour in As Good as It Gets), and have helped solve crimes (Nick and Nora Charles's schnauzer Asta in the Thin Man films; Tom Hanks's giant watchdog in Turner and Hooch) and been the victims of murderers (Hitchcock's Rear Window).

Before this column attracts the comment: 'Enough four-footed-friend flicks - Ed', let me proceed to the film that caused my mind to scamper down memory lane, the consistently funny Best in Show. It's directed and co-scripted by the American comedian Christopher Guest, who co-wrote and passed himself off as the English rock musician Nigel Tufnel in This is Spinal Tap. Like Spinal Tap, his new film is a spoof documentary, in this case about competitive dog owners, though in Best in Show we don't get to meet the film's supposed makers, and only when talking direct to camera do the participants show an awareness of being filmed.

As documentaries do, the film follows five couples from different social strata and different parts of America, all of them credible grotesques, and all treating their pets like the children they never had, and probably never will have. Christopher Guest himself plays a North Carolina backwoods store owner, who has a bloodhound and counts as his hobbies hunting, reeling off lists of nuts, and ventriloquism.

Next up the social scale is a lower-middle-class couple from Florida, with a tiny Norwich terrier; the husband (Eugene Levy, the film's co-author) quite literally has two left feet and is constantly being made aware of the raunchy past of his wife (Catherine O'Hara). From Illinois comes a yuppie couple (Parker Posey and Michael Hitchcock), both lawyers and in therapy along with their weimaraner bitch dog that's been traumatised by seeing them have sex.

New York contributes a pair of outrageous Cage aux Folles-style gays, the leading hairdresser Stefan Vanderhoof (Michael McKean, another Spinal Tap alumnus) and his lover Scott Donlan (John Michael Higgins), who dote on two fluffy little shih-tzus. Top of the social scale, but tackiest of all, is the gold-digging Sherri (Jennifer Coolidge), who's married a senile Pennsylvanian multimillionaire, but is on the brink of a lesbian affair with the expert dog handler (Jane Lynch), who cares for Rhapsody in White, Sherri's champion poodle. Guest never runs a scene too long or lets the actors (who improvised a lot of the material) step out of character.

The hearts of all five couples are set on their dogs winning the best in their class, then going on to get the blue riband for 'best in show' at the annual Mayflower Dog Show, which has, we're persuaded, been held in Philadelphia since 1875. Here we meet another splendid collection of characters - the prissy descendant of the show's patrician founder, the manager of the coliseum where the event is staged and, most amusingly, the toffee-nosed manager (Ed Begley Jr) of the hotel where the dog owners traditionally stay. He's very tall and on meeting him the gay hairdresser remarks: 'You make me feel like Alan Ladd on Easter Island.'

The film sends up the conventions and clichés of Hollywood competition movies - the sudden crises, the inexperienced dog handler forced to take over at the last minute, the rejection of the overweaning and the little guy turning up trumps. But what makes the show so splendid is the arrival of two new figures, a pair of TV commentators, one a reserved Englishman, Trevor Beckworth (Jim Piddock), who knows everything about canine competitions, and the other an extravagantly vulgar American, Buck Laughlin (Fred Willard), there to flaunt his ignorance as a representative of the people. The movie provokes steady smiles and chuckles from its opening moments, but the exchanges between Trevor and Buck produce loud laughter.

Best in Show is gentle satire, more at the expense of the absurdity of human life than this particular doggie subculture, which it views with affection. Only occasionally does it sting or draw blood. The astonishing thing is that apart from the hotel manager's little lecture on hygiene, there are no jokes about dogs peeing or defecating.

This is unlike every dumbed-down Hollywood picture you see nowadays, not to mention Robert Altman's Prét-à-Porter, which in satirising the fashion business chooses to have as its chief running gag people stepping in dog shit.

webTitle: Paperbacks: 11 Mar

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: 'Country good. Town bad.' Mavis Cheek's protagonist throws herself into a post-feminist version of The Good Life, plus Music for the Third Ear, Prince, Lenin and Smiling in Slow Motion
fields.body:
Mrs Fytton's Country Life
Mavis Cheek
Faber & Faber £6.99, pp332
Buy it at BOL

'Country good. Town bad.' Angela Fytton, superwife to Ian and mother of two, adopts this mantra when she is dumped for a younger model. Ostracised by her west London circle, she doesn't get mad, she gets pastoral, buying a three-bedroomed idyll in Somerset and throwing herself into a post-feminist version of The Good Life.

Blissfully unaware of the phoniness of the community she idolises, Angela pursues rustic crafts to recover her sense of purpose and to win Ian back. As her retreat means that the new Mrs Fytton is lumbered with Ian's teenage offspring (who make Kevin and Perry look like Ovaltinies), success is almost inevitable.

But Mavis Cheek's intentions are satirical and her targets various. Aware that those who write pastoral never smelt a sheep (or a homemade mutton-fat candle), this somewhat patchy novel breathes some savvy new life into an age-old formula.

Music for the Third Ear
Susan Schwartz Senstad
Black Swan £6.99, pp255
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Zhelijka and Mesud are refugees from the Bosnian war who come to Norway to repair their lives. Their brief presence in the house of Mette, whose own parents survived Auschwitz, stirs up memories and hopes that involve desperate means for their resolution.

Senstad, a family therapist of many years, draws on her understanding of trauma to create a collective case-study for the recurring nightmares of European history. On seeing Zhelijka, Mette recognised 'she was looking again into her father's nightmare eyes, eyes that see nothing but pain'.

By focusing on the fate of five-year-old Zero, the boy born to the rape-victim Zhelijka, Senstad explores the moral consequences of self-interest and idealism, the very wellsprings of war. Zero is the blank page upon which others inscribe their schemes for political and personal reparation, transforming a domestic drama into a harrowing ethical allegory with a gripping emotional climax.

Prince
Ib Michael
Vintage £6.99, pp245
Buy it at a discount at BOL

From its opening image of a frozen ship breaking out of its 100-year iceberg prison, to the poignant final paragraph, this Danish author's latest novel is a pure delight.

It's the summer of 1912, and a young boy roams the beach of a small Danish village, pursuing the schemes of childhood and wrapped in a private world of fiction-fuelled fantasy. He is watched over by his guardian angel, a metempsychotic mariner whose own sad history is eventually unravelled through his role as omniscient narrator: telling of what is past, passing and to come in richly inventive, poetically-precise prose.

Michael brilliantly evokes the joys, fears and frustrations of childhood, 'when the world was a treasure-house, a bottomless cask of experiences'. Recall Pip encountering Magwich, and Leo acting as go-between all those summers ago, and you capture something of the enchantment and imaginative richness of this captivating book.

Lenin: A Biography
Robert Service
Macmillan £12, pp561
Buy it at a discount at BOL

When the civil unrest broke out in Petrograd in 1917, sparking off events that culminated in the October Revolution, a group of revolutionary émigrés boarded a special train bound for Russia, thus allowing Lenin to seize his destiny. Lenin, who didn't smoke, was infuriated by the long queues to the train's only lavatory, which had become a smoker's corner. He promptly organised a rationing system, with tickets for peeing or puffing.

This 'comic little episode' none the less indicates the organisational ruthlessness of the man who would leave that train and 'turn the world upside down'. But it also shows Lenin the lavatory-user, the human being who can now emerge for the first time from behind the myth, through Robert Service's insights from the recently unsealed Central Party archives.

Revealing a hypochondriac who possibly had an affair and may have died of syphilis, Service puts the bio back into biography.

Smiling in Slow Motion
Derek Jarman
Vintage £7.99, pp392
Buy it at a discount at BOL

From May 1991 to the turn of 1894, when he could no longer see the page upon which his nib scratched, Derek Jarman recorded the details of a rich and productive life cut short by the HIV virus; days spent filmmaking or painting, at international film festivals or on Hampstead Heath, or in tending the Dungeness garden that provided stability and renewal in the face of a protracted wasting decline.

His illness gives 'a finality to every gesture - is this the last flower I will plant?', heightening experience and compelling Jarman to capture the sunlight on the garden in little nets of prose: 'Wallflowers, sea thrift, yellow and pink, patches of fluttering white'.

Gossip and anecdote jostle with frustrated diatribes from the interminable days of Tory rule, leaving a poignant affirmation of life, love and creativity and a tribute to the carers and the lover whose tireless support he celebrates here.

Music for the Third Ear Susan Schwartz Senstad Black Swan £6.99, pp255 Buy it at a discount at BOL Zhelijka and Mesud are refugees from the Bosnian war who come to Norway to repair their lives. Their brief presence in the house of Mette, whose own parents survived Auschwitz, stirs up memories and hopes that involve desperate means for their resolution. Senstad, a family therapist of many years, draws on her understanding of trauma to create a collective case-study for the recurring nightmares of European history. On seeing Zhelijka, Mette recognised 'she was looking again into her father's nightmare eyes, eyes that see nothing but pain'. By focusing on the fate of five-year-old Zero, the boy born to the rape-victim Zhelijka, Senstad explores the moral consequences of self-interest and idealism, the very wellsprings of war. Zero is the blank page upon which others inscribe their schemes for political and personal reparation, transforming a domestic drama into a harrowing ethical allegory with a gripping emotional climax. Prince Ib Michael Vintage £6.99, pp245 Buy it at a discount at BOL From its opening image of a frozen ship breaking out of its 100-year iceberg prison, to the poignant final paragraph, this Danish author's latest novel is a pure delight. It's the summer of 1912, and a young boy roams the beach of a small Danish village, pursuing the schemes of childhood and wrapped in a private world of fiction-fuelled fantasy. He is watched over by his guardian angel, a metempsychotic mariner whose own sad history is eventually unravelled through his role as omniscient narrator: telling of what is past, passing and to come in richly inventive, poetically-precise prose. Michael brilliantly evokes the joys, fears and frustrations of childhood, 'when the world was a treasure-house, a bottomless cask of experiences'. Recall Pip encountering Magwich, and Leo acting as go-between all those summers ago, and you capture something of the enchantment and imaginative richness of this captivating book. Lenin: A Biography Robert Service Macmillan £12, pp561 Buy it at a discount at BOL When the civil unrest broke out in Petrograd in 1917, sparking off events that culminated in the October Revolution, a group of revolutionary émigrés boarded a special train bound for Russia, thus allowing Lenin to seize his destiny. Lenin, who didn't smoke, was infuriated by the long queues to the train's only lavatory, which had become a smoker's corner. He promptly organised a rationing system, with tickets for peeing or puffing. This 'comic little episode' none the less indicates the organisational ruthlessness of the man who would leave that train and 'turn the world upside down'. But it also shows Lenin the lavatory-user, the human being who can now emerge for the first time from behind the myth, through Robert Service's insights from the recently unsealed Central Party archives. Revealing a hypochondriac who possibly had an affair and may have died of syphilis, Service puts the bio back into biography. Smiling in Slow Motion Derek Jarman Vintage £7.99, pp392 Buy it at a discount at BOL From May 1991 to the turn of 1894, when he could no longer see the page upon which his nib scratched, Derek Jarman recorded the details of a rich and productive life cut short by the HIV virus; days spent filmmaking or painting, at international film festivals or on Hampstead Heath, or in tending the Dungeness garden that provided stability and renewal in the face of a protracted wasting decline. His illness gives 'a finality to every gesture - is this the last flower I will plant?', heightening experience and compelling Jarman to capture the sunlight on the garden in little nets of prose: 'Wallflowers, sea thrift, yellow and pink, patches of fluttering white'. Gossip and anecdote jostle with frustrated diatribes from the interminable days of Tory rule, leaving a poignant affirmation of life, love and creativity and a tribute to the carers and the lover whose tireless support he celebrates here.

webTitle: Children's choice: Secret Heart

fields.headline: Children's choice
fields.trailText: With his latest novel, the award-winning author of Skellig and Kit's Wilderness moves even further into the realms of magic realism.
fields.body:
Secret Heart
David Almond
Hodder, £10, pp202
Buy it at a discount at BOL

With his latest novel, the award-winning author of Skellig and Kit's Wilderness moves even further into the realms of magic realism. Joe Maloney is a strange, dreamy boy who doesn't fit in and constantly plays truant. He feels different. 'It was so hard to separate what existed in his head from what existed in the world.'

He lives with his mother, who loves him, doesn't understand him, but accepts him, in Helmouth, in a wasteland full of old names such as the Ratty Paddocks and the Lostleg Railway. When a circus full of eccentric and mysterious characters arrives, Joe is visited in his dreams by a tiger. 'The huge head hung over him. The glittering cruel eyes stared into him.'

He is drawn to the circus and finds the bizarre people there seem to know all about him and the way he sees more than others see. Almond writes - and this could be his motto as a writer: 'Sometimes the most important things are the most mysterious.'

At the end, the real world and the circus world come together in a delightful scene. For 10-ups.

webTitle: Bad Blood by Lorna Sage read by Jenny Agutter

fields.headline: Bad Blood by Lorna Sage read by Jenny Agutter
fields.trailText: The narration of this memoir of a childhood on the Welsh Borders is a tribute to the late writer, allowing her internal voice to be heard
fields.body:
Bad Blood: A Memoir
Lorna Sage
Read by Jenny Agutter
Running time 3hrs
Harper Collins £8.99

Lorna Sage grew up in the Welsh Borders in a dirty, rambling old vicarage filled with the palpable hatred festering between her grandparents. Through the war years, her mother waited in that dismal household for the return of her husband, her confidence crushed long before by her false front teeth (which replaced those broken as a child when she intervened in one of her parents' bitter quarrels) and by her vicar father's affair with her best friend when they were still at school.

Lorna's hair is left in plaits for days on end, and when she gets nits, Grandmother refuses to treat them as it would take too many kettles to boil the water for the shampoo. However, Lorna becomes her grandfather's protégé, and in his study, where the books' titles are blacked out to discourage borrowers, she finds escape in books. From D.H. Lawrence, she learned that sex was a 'visionary initiation' and so, having experienced no such thing, she believes herself a virgin when in fact she is pregnant at 16. Is the old sinner's inherited 'bad blood' directing her life?

Sage's monitoring of a past age is acutely observed: the emergence of post-1955 teenagers as a 'tribe apart' - watching rock movies, shuffling awkwardly with moist-palmed boys at the school dance - while their disapproving mothers tried to be Constance Spry and their fathers scraped a postwar living. The narration is a tribute to the late writer, allowing her internal voice to be heard.

webTitle: Paperback of the week: To the Hermitage

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: The first thing that strikes you about this paperback edition of Malcolm Bradbury's last novel is the effusive cover quote from Auberon Waugh describing it as 'the funniest book ever written' and the realisation that these were among the last words that either reviewer or author would write.
fields.body:
To the Hermitage
Malcolm Bradbury
Picador £6.99, pp528

Buy it at a discount at BOL

The first thing that strikes you about this paperback edition of Malcolm Bradbury's last novel is the effusive cover quote from Auberon Waugh describing it as 'the funniest book ever written' and the realisation that these were among the last words that either reviewer or author would write.

To The Hermitage, if perhaps not quite deserving of Waugh's superlative, is nevertheless a wonderful last flourish of Bradbury's comic gifts. It is prefaced with a touching essay on his work by his friend, colleague and fellow campus novelist David Lodge and a tribute by Bradbury's former student Ian McEwan.

'This is (I suppose) a story,' begins the writer's own preface to the book, a sly pun on Diderot's "Ceci N'est Pas Un Conte". Diderot, 'the most pleasing of all the philosophers', is the central character, and the author happily admits that he has played fast and loose with history.

The narrative is carried by a contemporary narrator, a Bradbury-like figure. 'I'm a writer,' he confesses self-mockingly, 'a professionally observant person, one of those collectors of life's little data, an avid thinker of thoughts and a watcher of things.' The narrator is recounting his journey to Russia with a mismatched collection of academics, including an American who sports a baseball cap with the logo 'I Love Deconstruction', on a vague mission known as the Diderot Project. Interlaced with his observations are chapters on Diderot's residence at the court of Catherine the Great, who bought Diderot's library and then appointed the philosopher custodian of his own collection at her court.

Into Diderot's story he scatters anecdotal histories and arcane facts about the lives of many of Europe's great thinkers and writers, whose lives and works collided in patterns that Bradbury makes appear more than coincidence, so that the novel is an engrossing (if unreliable) history of the progress of European humanism.

Bradbury's swan song is full, vivid, witty and thoughtful, and an impressive finale to a unique and enduring body of work.

webTitle: Shane MacGowan gets the drinks in

fields.headline: Shane MacGowan gets the drinks in
fields.standfirst:
He won a scholarship to Westminster and became a rent boy; he topped the charts with The Pogues but ended up broke; he's planning a bank robbery and wants Lynn Barber to drive the getaway car...
Read an extract from 'A Drink with Shane MacGowan' here
fields.trailText: He won a scholarship to Westminster and became a rent boy; he topped the charts with The Pogues but ended up broke; he's planning a bank robbery and wants Lynn Barber to drive the getaway car...
fields.body:
Five o'clock, Bloom's Hotel, Dublin. Shane MacGowan tumbles out of the lift into my waiting arms. The photographer and his assistant and I have been waiting since three, with a cheery Irish PR saying, 'Oh, this is nothing - he kept a journalist waiting four hours yesterday!' I want to murder him. We made various sorties to Shane's hotel room but were blocked by a burly man who seemed to be acting as his minder.

So on the one hand I am relieved to see Shane at last. On the other hand, I quite want to bundle him back in the lift and forget him. I was prepared for the teeth, the famous blackened stumps, but the suit is an unanticipated horror show, with its thickening patina of stains down the trousers culminating in big blobby spatters on the shoes. If he has not been sick down his trousers several dozen times, he must have a very good stylist. His skin has the shiny pallor of someone who has never seen daylight. He lurches towards the bar. The photographer tries to head him off, saying he wants to do photographs outside before the daylight fades. Shane says, 'Ginantonic' and plonks himself in a chair. I chatter brightly about James Joyce; Shane mumbles unintelligibly; the photographer tears his hair.

But eventually, with coaxing from the photographer, the assistant, the PR and me, we get him out into the street. He flinches as the last rays of sunlight hit him and sinks into a doorway - luckily a very photogenic doorway - and the photographer clicks away. Every single person who passes down the street stops and says, 'Shane, good on yer!' or 'How're you doing?' A few bravely rush up and hug him. I didn't realise till then that he is a sort of god in Dublin - or not a god, more a prodigal son. Everyone seems to know him, everyone seems to love him, even little old ladies who surely can't ever have been Pogues fans shake their heads fondly and say, 'Shane! God love you!'

After the photographs, we stagger back to the hotel. I remark that the bar is terribly noisy - couldn't we sit somewhere else? Shane says, with sudden furious clarity - 'It's a bar . It's meant to be noisy.' The bar it is then - our home for the next six hours. Of all the Irish bars in all the world, this must be the most thoroughly charmless. It looks like a motorway Travelodge.

But it is Shane's bar and no doubt after his death it will be called Shane's Bar - maybe the hotel will be rechristened Shane's Hotel. Gin and tonics begin to appear as if by magic - rows and rows of them filling the table, perhaps materialised by fairy folk because I never see them coming.

I start by saying I very much enjoyed his book A Drink with Shane MacGowan - it is one of the freshest, most original biographies I've ever read. It's written as a conversation with his girlfriend, Victoria Mary Clarke, and it's a picture of their relationship as much as of his life. Shane, truculently, mumbles that it's not his book, and he is not happy with it. He doesn't like the title - 'a drink with Shane MacGowan' is not accurate because of course it is many drinks over many years. And then he doesn't like the byline - why is he credited as co-author when it was all Victoria's work? It was just an interview , he insists, just her sometimes switching on the tape recorder when they were talking. And he doesn't 'stand by' anything he is quoted as saying because he might say one thing one day and something else the next.

So is he cross with her for writing the book? 'I can't be cross with her ,' he says indignantly, 'I love her!' But he is cross with the book. And with the publishers, Sidgwick & Jackson. There is some ongoing saga whereby he claims they agreed to pay his hotel bill and haven't done so. They say they did agree to pay - for two days while he was doing interviews - not the six weeks (and counting) he has stayed there.

Anyway, he says ominously that he has not finished cutting the book. The press release claims that it recounts his days as a rent boy in London, but there is nothing about being a rent boy in the book. 'I can't believe you were a rent boy,' I say rudely, 'who would pay to rent you?' 'You'd be surprised,' he says. 'There are women who would climb over their grandmothers to get to a celebrity - Victoria, for instance!' and he emits the first of his exploding coffee-machine laughs.

Where is Victoria now? 'Off ligging with U2 in London,' he says. She is Irish but prefers living in London - he prefers Dublin or Tipperary. He was meant to go to the U2 concert but couldn't face travelling to England. Travel must be a serious problem for him - Victoria in the book mentions the hours or even days spent in airports waiting to find a flight willing to take him. Once when he was booked to join Bob Dylan in the States, four flights came and went without him.

And yet Victoria is obviously devoted - she calls him Sweet Pea throughout the book. They have been together 15 years, so why haven't they married? 'Because we never had enough celebrities in the same place at the same time.' (This gnomic utterance is later explained by Victoria - they plan to sell their wedding to Hello! or OK!.) 'But we're getting married this year. Hopefully.' And will they start a family? 'I think when we grow up we should [he is 43, she 35] - it's something we've discussed. But probably I'm dropping myself in the shit even talking about it.'

His mother told him never to have children till he was rich. He was rich, he made millions with the Pogues, but he says now he's spent it all. 'If you hug money, you clog up the cash flow, know what I mean?' He says he's not destitute - he still gets enough from songwriting royalties to keep him in booze and fags - but he missed out on the rock-star mansions. All he owns is a flat in Gospel Oak which he shares with Victoria, and the old family farm in Tipperary which has no running water. His current group, the Popes, has never achieved success by Pogues standards. Supposing he never makes another record, will he have enough to live on? 'Well,' he sputters, 'I could always open supermarkets!'

The wit is quick and comes like a wake-up call to me, reminding me of Bono's remark, 'Shane is more together than people imagine.' (Bono obviously respects him, because he lent him his Martello Tower to live in for a year after the Pogues split up.) Shane's speech may be slurred, his movements uncoordinated, he sometimes gets stuck on saying, 'Know what I mean? Know what I mean? Know what I mean?' till you want to scream - but he is not 'out of it'. On the contrary, he seems to be controlling this interview much better than me. When he doesn't want to answer a question, he ignores it, or mumbles into his G&T. But every time he mentions an Irish name, he spells it out carefully, complete with accents, into my tape recorder. Moreover, unlike me, he remembers everything he says. This was brought sharply home a couple of hours into our conversation when the barman called him over to take a phone call. It was from Victoria and he came back saying, 'You've got to take out that line about her climbing over her grandmother to get to a celebrity. She didn't think it was funny. So take it out, or I'll fucking sue you, right?' (Later, in London, I persuaded Victoria to let me keep it in - she says it's OK because her grandmother is dead - but fancy him remembering.)

Shane sees it as his duty to educate me in Irish history, so I'm in for a lot of lecturing about Brian Ború, the Black and Tans, Michael Collins, Partition, 'Ireland is a woman', the craic, the whole tear-stained Emerald-Isle package. And yet if you step outside Bloom's Hotel, you can see that Dublin today is just about the glossiest, yuppiest place in Europe - it has such full employment it actually has to import workers. Hasn't Shane noticed?

Evidently not. 'I live in the past. It doesn't feel like 2001 to me.' In any case, his Ireland is an entirely personal construct of songs and myths and stories his relatives told him in infancy, ie an Ireland that was probably extinct by the time he was born, if it ever even existed. He has lived in England since he was six - he won a scholarship to Westminster, for heaven's sake! (Admittedly only for a year, but still...) There are people who knew him in his teens who say he didn't have an Irish accent then. But, on the other hand, all his songwriting inspiration comes from Ireland and he achieved his 'crusade' with the Pogues to make Irish music hip and popular, to build Irish self-esteem. In fact, he was one of the founders of the current Irish cultural renaissance - it is just unfortunate that he looks more like a relic of the old pre-boom Ireland of hopeless old pissheads doing zilch.

Shane's father 'likes a drink', his uncles, aunts, cousins ditto. Shane claims that when he was a small child in Tipperary, they gave him two Guinnesses a night as his bedtime drink and later, when he was eight, an uncle introduced him to Powers whiskey. He says he never really drew a sober breath after the age of 14. 'In our family it was like, if the kid likes a drink, let him have a drink - because all the kids who weren't allowed to have a drink turned into raging alcoholics.' Mmm, yes, Shane - and...? Even he notices some logical flaw in his argument because he starts sputtering, 'We'd never even heard of alcoholism. We'd have thought it was some kind of weird religion. Our household was an open house where no one was refused, there was a continuous ceilidh going on, people would come from miles around for a drink, 24 hours, there's always one or two people awake.'

This was his mother's family's house in Tipperary, where he lived till he was six, while his parents worked in England. He says in the book, 'My life was a happy dream when I was a little boy.' But when he came to live with his parents in London, the picture grows darker and there are glimpses in the book of a deeply dysfunctional family - father out boozing every night, mother lying in bed with arthritis or depression, pilled out of her head, Shane trying to look after his little sister Siobhan. In the book he talks about his mother having a nervous breakdown but now he retracts that and says: 'I was just projecting you know. I was depressed.'

When he was 17, he had a major breakdown and was admitted to a psychiatric hospital for six months. 'I was drinking a lot and I'd been put on a heavy prescription of tranquillisers by the GP. This was a big thing in the 70s - there's thousands of people in mental hospitals who were made zombies by downers. Anyway, they got me off the gear, the drugs that had put me there, and I started drinking again - but then they wouldn't let me drink, which is where the trouble started. It was called Acute Situational Anxiety - which basically meant I didn't like being in London. Perpetual panic - I panic in London.'

Does he panic about performing? 'No, that isn't the panic at all. My family were, are, all singers, performers. No, just sitting in a goddamn bloody flat in bloody London, that's a panic situation. Basically, I've been holding my breath half my fucking life. I can only relax when I'm in Ireland or one or two other places - Thailand, Spain, Japan and certain parts of America. I actually feel physically sick when I think of London.'

And yet, Victoria told me later he seemed happy enough living in London till Christmas, but then he went to Dublin for a Popes concert and never came back. He now claims to live in Tipperary, in the old family farmhouse with the sign on the door saying 'Trespassers will be shot'. His parents live in a new house down the road. He describes them as 'very young at heart, intelligent, warm, loving sociopaths!' (Everyone else describes them as 'characters'.) But actually he seems to have been living in Bloom's Hotel, Dublin, since January.

What it seems to boil down to is that he feels happy and sociable and safe drinking in Ireland, and depressed and lonely and paranoid drinking in London. But what about not drinking - is that ever a possibility? Yes, he says, 'I don't have to drink.' Victoria took him to the Priory last autumn for a dryout and he says it worked. But, er, what are all these glasses on the table? 'This isn't drinking. We're just having a couple of drinks, you know?' Right. How long did he stay sober after the Priory? 'As long as it took to get to the nearest bar.' So is that his pattern - to dry out, then start drinking again? 'I don't have a pattern. I can't remember from one day to the next.'

At one point I said something about his attraction to drink and drugs, and he was suddenly beadily alert. 'What! I'm a drinker. I drink. But drugs, you said - I don't take drugs.' What? Never ? 'So long ago I can't remember.' He should read Victoria's book, then, because it's full of drugs - uppers and downers and acid and cocaine. He once said that by the time the Pogues ended in 1991 he was taking 50 tabs of acid a day - 'You get used to it, you can function on it.'

But it has obviously become a touchy subject since November 1999, when Sinead O'Connor shopped him to the police for taking heroin. She told The Sun she went round to his flat and found him practically in a coma on the floor and called the police because 'I love Shane and it makes me angry to see him destroy himself.' He says he was sitting peacefully on the sofa watching a Sam Peckinpah video. Whatever - no police charges were brought. So was he ever on heroin? 'What - addicted to heroin?' Well, on heroin? 'I've tried it a long time ago.' The only drugs he will admit to taking now are prescription tranquillisers - 'If the doctor prescribes them, I take them, and sometimes quite a heavy dose, for stress. But at least I go to a doctor, know what I mean?'

Midway through the evening, a man comes into the bar, sees Shane, and rushes over. Shane lurches to his feet and hugs him for a good five minutes. He is Gerry O'Boyle, former owner of Filthy MacNasty's bar in Islington, and they 'go back a long way'. Gerry rustles up a few more G&Ts but, I notice, drinks water. He stays with us for the rest of the evening, and Shane seems happy to have him. Later, when I am drunk as a skunk, Gerry serves the useful purpose of changing the tape when necessary.

At some point they decide to teach me how to say a rosary and both whip out their rosaries and an amazing array of medals and scapulas and plastic folders saying: 'I am a Catholic. If I am dying, please call a priest.' Shane says he would certainly want a priest if he were dying. One reason why he likes St John of God - a Dublin drying-out home he sometimes uses - is that it's run by nuns, and priests come round to hear your confession. 'I haven't been to mass for a long time. But I pray every day, every night. I pray all the time. I pray whenever I'm struck by fear and worry, and I pray in gratitude when the release is given to me, you know?'

As a Catholic, doesn't he feel bad about not having children? 'I've got children!' How many? 'I don't know. I only know about one. He's a young man. He lives in Scotland. He knows where to get hold of me. I saw him once, when he was three. He knows I'm his father. Years ago, me and Lesley agreed that any time he wanted to come and see me he could come and see me and I'd take him out for a drink, get him whatever he wants. But she married a good man, and he seems to be satisfied with him as his father.'

Later in the evening Shane and Gerry announce that they have decided they can trust me, so they will cut me in on the bank robbery they are doing tomorrow. They are driving to a country town, about an hour out of Dublin, and they need a getaway driver. 'She'd be a fucking brilliant driver!' Shane opines. 'She'd be a good driver, yes,' Gerry agrees. 'Well, I don't know. I stop at zebra crossings. I'm rather a slow driver,' I warn them. Both nod eagerly, 'See, if you were a fast driver, it would be very obvious. A slow getaway driver is good!'

The evening reels on. Shane sings me ' Woman come in the name of love ' and ends with the plea - 'Can I not convince you to come out with us and rob a bank?' I tell him my husband wouldn't like it and he accepts that - obeying your husband is good. But, he suggests with great delicacy, perhaps my husband will die before me and then I can come out and rob a bank? I promise to think about it.

Gerry reminds Shane periodically that there's a party at the Clarence they should go to. 'You come!' Shane orders. 'I haven't got anything to wear,' I whimper - rather a feeble excuse in view of Shane's suit. 'Come as you are,' he says magnanimously. So several hours or aeons later, we stagger into the glossy streets of Temple Bar round to the Clarence, which luckily is only a few yards. Apparently le tout Dublin is there - Candace Bushnell and Marianne Faithfull and two Corrs! But my vision isn't too great by this stage and in a sudden flash of clarity I realise I must go to bed or I will die. I totter over to Shane and say, 'Gorra go' - and somehow the big friend from his hotel room appears at my elbow and steers me gently back to the hotel.

In the morning, badly hungover, I wander downstairs about nine to ask the receptionist what time I can decently phone Shane to say goodbye. 'Ask him,' she says cheerily. 'He's in the bar.' Ohmigod, he is - sitting at the bar with four or five G&Ts in front of him, chatting to the barman. The barman looks near death but Shane looks much as usual. 'Where were you?' he says quite sharply - 'you missed a good night.' Apparently he and his friends went from the party to a club to another party and another club, where he sang a few songs. Then they came back to talk. But now everyone else has gone to bed, and he is quite eager to start chatting all over again. But sorry, Shane, I just can't face it and anyway I have to catch a plane. I tell him it was a joy to meet him and he lurches to his feet and says with great formality, 'The pleasure's all mine.' What a well-brought-up boy!

Back in London, I immediately ring Victoria Clarke, agog to see what Shane's girlfriend can be like. She says she would love to meet but she's going to some place in Kennington for a five-day residential fast. Next day, however, she rings to say she is having a sauna at her health club in Hampstead and I can join her there. I drive there thinking - sauna, health club, fast - and this is Shane's girlfriend? My jaw actually drops when I met her - she is peachy-skinned and milkmaid-wholesome, as fresh and glowing as a yogurt ad. How can she bear to marry an alky who by his own admission never has a bath?

But she doesn't see Shane like that: she thinks he is beautiful. She first met him 20 years ago when she was 15 and 'I thought he was gorgeous. At first I didn't like him as a person - I always fancied him, but thought he was really arrogant. I know he's not conventionally handsome but he is beautiful.' And yes, she confirms, they are getting married as soon as they can get someone to pay. 'I hear Hello! pay to up 500 grand! You've got to get lots of celebrities to come, though, for that.'

Gosh, what can I say? I just sit there gawping at her. But hasn't she noticed this, er, problem with Shane? Yes, she says calmly, she knows about alcoholism. She's been to AA and Al Anon (she prefers AA, found Al Anon 'very gloomy'). She thinks Shane could stop drinking if he wanted to - in fact, she says he drinks much less at home than when he's on show - part of his problem is social anxiety, which he covers up with booze. 'But I would hate it if someone said to me, "You've got to stop drinking." I love wine.'

In any case, she sympathises with addiction because she suffers it herself - she has a mild addiction to food and a major addiction to fame, and has had therapy for both. But now she plans to cure her fame addiction by hiring herself a publicist - she thinks probably Matthew Freud - to make her famous so she can get it out of her system. 'Because it's one of those things, like with heroin - you've got to try it before you can decide that you're going to give it up.'

But doesn't this fame obsession make her relationship with Shane a bit suspect? Doesn't he worry that she might leave him for someone more famous? 'I've already done that. [Apparently she had an affair with Van Morrison.] We've been through it, we've had the affairs, we've had the breakups, we've had the nervous breakdowns. But with me it didn't last - the connection was never strong enough with anyone else - so it must be that I actually genuinely like him more than anyone else. And also we did meet before he was famous.'

Shane told me sweetly: 'I would never pretend to understand Victoria - or if I did understand her, I probably wouldn't love her, you know?' I do know. He is so lucky to have the love of a good woman, but at least he knows it - he writes in the foreword to her book, 'God bless the day I found her, and I feel like the luckiest fucker alive.' I hope they get married; I hope they live happily ever after. A few days later I bumped into Sir Bob Geldof at a party and asked him whether he thought Hello! would pay for their wedding. 'Well,' he said, 'I'll pay for it if Hello! won't - I just want to see it happen!' Me too - perhaps we should start a Victoria and Shane Wedding Appeal. Meanwhile, buy the book, it's great.

A life in brief

Born Christmas Day, 1957.

Lived in Ireland until he was six, then England. Father a wages clerk at C & A, mother a typist.

As Shane O'Hooligan, fronted band called the Nipple Erectors. Started the Pogues in 1983.

Best albums Rum, Sodomy and the Lash (1985) and If I Should Fall from Grace with God (1987), which includes 'Fairy Tale of New York', with Kirsty MacColl. Sacked from Pogues in 1991 for 'nervous exhaustion'. Started the Popes in 1994 and released two albums - The Snake (1994) and The Crock of Gold (1997). He guested on their third album, Holloway Boulevard (2000).
