fields.bodyText: Five o'clock, Bloom's Hotel, Dublin. Shane MacGowan tumbles out of the lift into my waiting arms. The photographer and his assistant and I have been waiting since three, with a cheery Irish PR saying, 'Oh, this is nothing - he kept a journalist waiting four hours yesterday!' I want to murder him. We made various sorties to Shane's hotel room but were blocked by a burly man who seemed to be acting as his minder. So on the one hand I am relieved to see Shane at last. On the other hand, I quite want to bundle him back in the lift and forget him. I was prepared for the teeth, the famous blackened stumps, but the suit is an unanticipated horror show, with its thickening patina of stains down the trousers culminating in big blobby spatters on the shoes. If he has not been sick down his trousers several dozen times, he must have a very good stylist. His skin has the shiny pallor of someone who has never seen daylight. He lurches towards the bar. The photographer tries to head him off, saying he wants to do photographs outside before the daylight fades. Shane says, 'Ginantonic' and plonks himself in a chair. I chatter brightly about James Joyce; Shane mumbles unintelligibly; the photographer tears his hair. But eventually, with coaxing from the photographer, the assistant, the PR and me, we get him out into the street. He flinches as the last rays of sunlight hit him and sinks into a doorway - luckily a very photogenic doorway - and the photographer clicks away. Every single person who passes down the street stops and says, 'Shane, good on yer!' or 'How're you doing?' A few bravely rush up and hug him. I didn't realise till then that he is a sort of god in Dublin - or not a god, more a prodigal son. Everyone seems to know him, everyone seems to love him, even little old ladies who surely can't ever have been Pogues fans shake their heads fondly and say, 'Shane! God love you!' After the photographs, we stagger back to the hotel. I remark that the bar is terribly noisy - couldn't we sit somewhere else? Shane says, with sudden furious clarity - 'It's a bar . It's meant to be noisy.' The bar it is then - our home for the next six hours. Of all the Irish bars in all the world, this must be the most thoroughly charmless. It looks like a motorway Travelodge. But it is Shane's bar and no doubt after his death it will be called Shane's Bar - maybe the hotel will be rechristened Shane's Hotel. Gin and tonics begin to appear as if by magic - rows and rows of them filling the table, perhaps materialised by fairy folk because I never see them coming. I start by saying I very much enjoyed his book A Drink with Shane MacGowan - it is one of the freshest, most original biographies I've ever read. It's written as a conversation with his girlfriend, Victoria Mary Clarke, and it's a picture of their relationship as much as of his life. Shane, truculently, mumbles that it's not his book, and he is not happy with it. He doesn't like the title - 'a drink with Shane MacGowan' is not accurate because of course it is many drinks over many years. And then he doesn't like the byline - why is he credited as co-author when it was all Victoria's work? It was just an interview , he insists, just her sometimes switching on the tape recorder when they were talking. And he doesn't 'stand by' anything he is quoted as saying because he might say one thing one day and something else the next. So is he cross with her for writing the book? 'I can't be cross with her ,' he says indignantly, 'I love her!' But he is cross with the book. And with the publishers, Sidgwick & Jackson. There is some ongoing saga whereby he claims they agreed to pay his hotel bill and haven't done so. They say they did agree to pay - for two days while he was doing interviews - not the six weeks (and counting) he has stayed there. Anyway, he says ominously that he has not finished cutting the book. The press release claims that it recounts his days as a rent boy in London, but there is nothing about being a rent boy in the book. 'I can't believe you were a rent boy,' I say rudely, 'who would pay to rent you?' 'You'd be surprised,' he says. 'There are women who would climb over their grandmothers to get to a celebrity - Victoria, for instance!' and he emits the first of his exploding coffee-machine laughs. Where is Victoria now? 'Off ligging with U2 in London,' he says. She is Irish but prefers living in London - he prefers Dublin or Tipperary. He was meant to go to the U2 concert but couldn't face travelling to England. Travel must be a serious problem for him - Victoria in the book mentions the hours or even days spent in airports waiting to find a flight willing to take him. Once when he was booked to join Bob Dylan in the States, four flights came and went without him. And yet Victoria is obviously devoted - she calls him Sweet Pea throughout the book. They have been together 15 years, so why haven't they married? 'Because we never had enough celebrities in the same place at the same time.' (This gnomic utterance is later explained by Victoria - they plan to sell their wedding to Hello! or OK!.) 'But we're getting married this year. Hopefully.' And will they start a family? 'I think when we grow up we should [he is 43, she 35] - it's something we've discussed. But probably I'm dropping myself in the shit even talking about it.' His mother told him never to have children till he was rich. He was rich, he made millions with the Pogues, but he says now he's spent it all. 'If you hug money, you clog up the cash flow, know what I mean?' He says he's not destitute - he still gets enough from songwriting royalties to keep him in booze and fags - but he missed out on the rock-star mansions. All he owns is a flat in Gospel Oak which he shares with Victoria, and the old family farm in Tipperary which has no running water. His current group, the Popes, has never achieved success by Pogues standards. Supposing he never makes another record, will he have enough to live on? 'Well,' he sputters, 'I could always open supermarkets!' The wit is quick and comes like a wake-up call to me, reminding me of Bono's remark, 'Shane is more together than people imagine.' (Bono obviously respects him, because he lent him his Martello Tower to live in for a year after the Pogues split up.) Shane's speech may be slurred, his movements uncoordinated, he sometimes gets stuck on saying, 'Know what I mean? Know what I mean? Know what I mean?' till you want to scream - but he is not 'out of it'. On the contrary, he seems to be controlling this interview much better than me. When he doesn't want to answer a question, he ignores it, or mumbles into his G&T. But every time he mentions an Irish name, he spells it out carefully, complete with accents, into my tape recorder. Moreover, unlike me, he remembers everything he says. This was brought sharply home a couple of hours into our conversation when the barman called him over to take a phone call. It was from Victoria and he came back saying, 'You've got to take out that line about her climbing over her grandmother to get to a celebrity. She didn't think it was funny. So take it out, or I'll fucking sue you, right?' (Later, in London, I persuaded Victoria to let me keep it in - she says it's OK because her grandmother is dead - but fancy him remembering.) Shane sees it as his duty to educate me in Irish history, so I'm in for a lot of lecturing about Brian Ború, the Black and Tans, Michael Collins, Partition, 'Ireland is a woman', the craic, the whole tear-stained Emerald-Isle package. And yet if you step outside Bloom's Hotel, you can see that Dublin today is just about the glossiest, yuppiest place in Europe - it has such full employment it actually has to import workers. Hasn't Shane noticed? Evidently not. 'I live in the past. It doesn't feel like 2001 to me.' In any case, his Ireland is an entirely personal construct of songs and myths and stories his relatives told him in infancy, ie an Ireland that was probably extinct by the time he was born, if it ever even existed. He has lived in England since he was six - he won a scholarship to Westminster, for heaven's sake! (Admittedly only for a year, but still...) There are people who knew him in his teens who say he didn't have an Irish accent then. But, on the other hand, all his songwriting inspiration comes from Ireland and he achieved his 'crusade' with the Pogues to make Irish music hip and popular, to build Irish self-esteem. In fact, he was one of the founders of the current Irish cultural renaissance - it is just unfortunate that he looks more like a relic of the old pre-boom Ireland of hopeless old pissheads doing zilch. Shane's father 'likes a drink', his uncles, aunts, cousins ditto. Shane claims that when he was a small child in Tipperary, they gave him two Guinnesses a night as his bedtime drink and later, when he was eight, an uncle introduced him to Powers whiskey. He says he never really drew a sober breath after the age of 14. 'In our family it was like, if the kid likes a drink, let him have a drink - because all the kids who weren't allowed to have a drink turned into raging alcoholics.' Mmm, yes, Shane - and...? Even he notices some logical flaw in his argument because he starts sputtering, 'We'd never even heard of alcoholism. We'd have thought it was some kind of weird religion. Our household was an open house where no one was refused, there was a continuous ceilidh going on, people would come from miles around for a drink, 24 hours, there's always one or two people awake.' This was his mother's family's house in Tipperary, where he lived till he was six, while his parents worked in England. He says in the book, 'My life was a happy dream when I was a little boy.' But when he came to live with his parents in London, the picture grows darker and there are glimpses in the book of a deeply dysfunctional family - father out boozing every night, mother lying in bed with arthritis or depression, pilled out of her head, Shane trying to look after his little sister Siobhan. In the book he talks about his mother having a nervous breakdown but now he retracts that and says: 'I was just projecting you know. I was depressed.' When he was 17, he had a major breakdown and was admitted to a psychiatric hospital for six months. 'I was drinking a lot and I'd been put on a heavy prescription of tranquillisers by the GP. This was a big thing in the 70s - there's thousands of people in mental hospitals who were made zombies by downers. Anyway, they got me off the gear, the drugs that had put me there, and I started drinking again - but then they wouldn't let me drink, which is where the trouble started. It was called Acute Situational Anxiety - which basically meant I didn't like being in London. Perpetual panic - I panic in London.' Does he panic about performing? 'No, that isn't the panic at all. My family were, are, all singers, performers. No, just sitting in a goddamn bloody flat in bloody London, that's a panic situation. Basically, I've been holding my breath half my fucking life. I can only relax when I'm in Ireland or one or two other places - Thailand, Spain, Japan and certain parts of America. I actually feel physically sick when I think of London.' And yet, Victoria told me later he seemed happy enough living in London till Christmas, but then he went to Dublin for a Popes concert and never came back. He now claims to live in Tipperary, in the old family farmhouse with the sign on the door saying 'Trespassers will be shot'. His parents live in a new house down the road. He describes them as 'very young at heart, intelligent, warm, loving sociopaths!' (Everyone else describes them as 'characters'.) But actually he seems to have been living in Bloom's Hotel, Dublin, since January. What it seems to boil down to is that he feels happy and sociable and safe drinking in Ireland, and depressed and lonely and paranoid drinking in London. But what about not drinking - is that ever a possibility? Yes, he says, 'I don't have to drink.' Victoria took him to the Priory last autumn for a dryout and he says it worked. But, er, what are all these glasses on the table? 'This isn't drinking. We're just having a couple of drinks, you know?' Right. How long did he stay sober after the Priory? 'As long as it took to get to the nearest bar.' So is that his pattern - to dry out, then start drinking again? 'I don't have a pattern. I can't remember from one day to the next.' At one point I said something about his attraction to drink and drugs, and he was suddenly beadily alert. 'What! I'm a drinker. I drink. But drugs, you said - I don't take drugs.' What? Never ? 'So long ago I can't remember.' He should read Victoria's book, then, because it's full of drugs - uppers and downers and acid and cocaine. He once said that by the time the Pogues ended in 1991 he was taking 50 tabs of acid a day - 'You get used to it, you can function on it.' But it has obviously become a touchy subject since November 1999, when Sinead O'Connor shopped him to the police for taking heroin. She told The Sun she went round to his flat and found him practically in a coma on the floor and called the police because 'I love Shane and it makes me angry to see him destroy himself.' He says he was sitting peacefully on the sofa watching a Sam Peckinpah video. Whatever - no police charges were brought. So was he ever on heroin? 'What - addicted to heroin?' Well, on heroin? 'I've tried it a long time ago.' The only drugs he will admit to taking now are prescription tranquillisers - 'If the doctor prescribes them, I take them, and sometimes quite a heavy dose, for stress. But at least I go to a doctor, know what I mean?' Midway through the evening, a man comes into the bar, sees Shane, and rushes over. Shane lurches to his feet and hugs him for a good five minutes. He is Gerry O'Boyle, former owner of Filthy MacNasty's bar in Islington, and they 'go back a long way'. Gerry rustles up a few more G&Ts but, I notice, drinks water. He stays with us for the rest of the evening, and Shane seems happy to have him. Later, when I am drunk as a skunk, Gerry serves the useful purpose of changing the tape when necessary. At some point they decide to teach me how to say a rosary and both whip out their rosaries and an amazing array of medals and scapulas and plastic folders saying: 'I am a Catholic. If I am dying, please call a priest.' Shane says he would certainly want a priest if he were dying. One reason why he likes St John of God - a Dublin drying-out home he sometimes uses - is that it's run by nuns, and priests come round to hear your confession. 'I haven't been to mass for a long time. But I pray every day, every night. I pray all the time. I pray whenever I'm struck by fear and worry, and I pray in gratitude when the release is given to me, you know?' As a Catholic, doesn't he feel bad about not having children? 'I've got children!' How many? 'I don't know. I only know about one. He's a young man. He lives in Scotland. He knows where to get hold of me. I saw him once, when he was three. He knows I'm his father. Years ago, me and Lesley agreed that any time he wanted to come and see me he could come and see me and I'd take him out for a drink, get him whatever he wants. But she married a good man, and he seems to be satisfied with him as his father.' Later in the evening Shane and Gerry announce that they have decided they can trust me, so they will cut me in on the bank robbery they are doing tomorrow. They are driving to a country town, about an hour out of Dublin, and they need a getaway driver. 'She'd be a fucking brilliant driver!' Shane opines. 'She'd be a good driver, yes,' Gerry agrees. 'Well, I don't know. I stop at zebra crossings. I'm rather a slow driver,' I warn them. Both nod eagerly, 'See, if you were a fast driver, it would be very obvious. A slow getaway driver is good!' The evening reels on. Shane sings me ' Woman come in the name of love ' and ends with the plea - 'Can I not convince you to come out with us and rob a bank?' I tell him my husband wouldn't like it and he accepts that - obeying your husband is good. But, he suggests with great delicacy, perhaps my husband will die before me and then I can come out and rob a bank? I promise to think about it. Gerry reminds Shane periodically that there's a party at the Clarence they should go to. 'You come!' Shane orders. 'I haven't got anything to wear,' I whimper - rather a feeble excuse in view of Shane's suit. 'Come as you are,' he says magnanimously. So several hours or aeons later, we stagger into the glossy streets of Temple Bar round to the Clarence, which luckily is only a few yards. Apparently le tout Dublin is there - Candace Bushnell and Marianne Faithfull and two Corrs! But my vision isn't too great by this stage and in a sudden flash of clarity I realise I must go to bed or I will die. I totter over to Shane and say, 'Gorra go' - and somehow the big friend from his hotel room appears at my elbow and steers me gently back to the hotel. In the morning, badly hungover, I wander downstairs about nine to ask the receptionist what time I can decently phone Shane to say goodbye. 'Ask him,' she says cheerily. 'He's in the bar.' Ohmigod, he is - sitting at the bar with four or five G&Ts in front of him, chatting to the barman. The barman looks near death but Shane looks much as usual. 'Where were you?' he says quite sharply - 'you missed a good night.' Apparently he and his friends went from the party to a club to another party and another club, where he sang a few songs. Then they came back to talk. But now everyone else has gone to bed, and he is quite eager to start chatting all over again. But sorry, Shane, I just can't face it and anyway I have to catch a plane. I tell him it was a joy to meet him and he lurches to his feet and says with great formality, 'The pleasure's all mine.' What a well-brought-up boy! webTitle: Fiona Maddocks on Hildegard of Bingen

fields.headline: Some sister, some act...
fields.standfirst: With a long career as visionary, scientist, musician, painter and inventor of homeopathic remedies, the twelfth-century German nun Hildegard of Bingen defies easy categories - as her biographer found out
fields.trailText: With a long career as visionary, scientist, musician, painter and inventor of homeopathic remedies, the twelfth-century German nun Hildegard of Bingen defies easy categories - as her biographer found out.
fields.body:
For me, Hildegard of Bingen was a blind date, or rather an arranged marriage brokered by my publisher. I was intrigued by the suggestion, though what I knew of Hildegard could be written (and often had been) in large letters on the back of a CD cover. I certainly did not know that I would be spending many months in the compelling company of a woman whose artistic originality was lodged in a battling personality, as if Margaret Thatcher were united with Joan of Arc.

A twelfth-century German abbess, it is true, was hardly the obvious non-fiction choice for a bestseller (one can but dream). Yet cult nuns elicit a strange frisson in which fascination combines with distaste, admiration with aversion. Hildegard (1098-1179) is particularly susceptible to such a response. A nun who composed music and who set up her own monastery on the Rhine in the face of strong monkish resistance, who wrote apocalyptic tracts and had lurid, fantastical visions, who chastised popes and emperors and who, as far we can tell, fell in love with another nun, invites trouble.

Neglected for some eight centuries, her reappraisal in the 1970s coincided with hippies, feminism, New Age-ism, Greens and, critically, the explosion of interest in early music. Thus, through no fault of her own, Hildegard seemed to meet the criteria for membership of every conceivable special interest group - cranky, outlandish, profane or sacred. Each felt proprietorial about her and adopted her as a mascot, however flimsy their surmise or unfounded their justification. Almost certainly a migraine sufferer, as Oliver Sacks has argued in his study of that affliction, she is unofficial patron saint of the ailment. The St Aelred and St Hildegard Gay and Lesbian Ministry at the Episcopal Church of the Messiah, Santa Ana, California, however, seem to me to push their luck in harnessing her to their cause. Hildegard, in the words of one American feminist fan, sure was 'one tough sister'. Would I be able to understand, stand up to or even stand her?

But I was committed. Suddenly my challenge had become clear. For secretly, in my ignorance, I had felt a degree of resistance to her myself. Her name had almost become a cliché, her reputation summed up over and over again like a mantra in those same CD liner notes - theologian, scientist, musician, artist, prolific correspondent, friend of the twelfth-century high and mighty. The rest was left to scholars poring over obscure medieval Latin texts. Yet even the bare storyline that emerged was amazing and baffling enough, starting with a living death as an anchorite confined to a cell at the age of eight and ending up in old age with international fame and universal notoriety.

My only brush with nuns was a year spent at an Ursuline convent in the Italian Alps where I once taught English literature (Beowulf to Virginia Woolf) to young contessas. These nuns, not in the least bit Germanic but straight out of Boccaccio, swigged wine, giggled and eavesdropped. Struggle as I might, I could not make a useful connection across nations or centuries to ease my task.

Having assumed that source material would be scarce, my immediate worry was how to verify the existing information about her, some quite audacious. The shock, daunting in itself, was to discover how prolific she was, and how much of her work, including nearly 400 letters, a contemporary biography and several weighty theological tomes, had survived. Sources were often insecure, editions dodgy or abridged. Hundreds of books had been written about her in the past century, examining every aspect of her life and works.

Restless, driven and stubborn, Hildegard had a theory on everything, from sexuality and conception (about which she is explicit) to Creation and the cosmos. She founded two monasteries and inspired the painting of extraordinary visionary images. She made encyclopedic studies of fish and fowl, animals and trees. Her writings on health matters, some of the earliest surviving of their kind, have been pounced upon by practitioners of alternative medicine. She analyses the onset and suggests causes for all kinds of disease, from ulcers and depression to cancer in its various recognisable stages. Many of her cures are based on sound medical sense and tally with modern homeopathy.

Not all her remedies appeal today (partridge bile mixed with old fat to banish lice; water with a mouse steeped in it to chase off epilepsy), but two German doctors have recently based an entire theory of medicine on her teachings. Health-food addicts, too, have found in her a friend. Her advocacy of spelt, an inferior form of wheat, has stimulated recipe books and food products (pasta, biscuits, cereal, a grim kind of coffee) bearing her name. In addition, our fashionable belief in the efficacy of crystals had an ancient precursor in Hildegard: according to her writings, sapphires cure styes and conjunctivitis as well as quenching lust; chalcedony encourages confident speech; tumours will shrink if rubbed with amethyst.

Yet she is best known as a composer which surely, one would think, escapes temporal faddism. That was why I was writing the book, even though I was instructed that it 'should not be a book about chant'. Chant, not my own favoured musical medium, has its ardent supporters. Following the surprise success of a highly specialised CD of Hildegard's music by Christopher Page and Gothic Voices, A Feather on the Breath of God, her cult grew in the 1980s and 1990s. Commerce beckoned. Chanting monks were all the rage. What better than a swung nun?

Soon her music reached far beyond concert halls and churches and entered the charts. It was mixed with disco rhythms in that musical no-man's-land known as 'fusion' and played in the discotheques of Ibiza and the bars of Manhattan. But her fame as a composer is new. She did not appear in Grove's Dictionary of Music and Musicians until the 1980 edition. Even those who knew of her compositions had seen no reason to take them seriously. The birth of feminist musicology changed all that. To find that one of the first named composers in the history of Western music was a woman aroused understandable excitement. The question now asked - and this too came as a surprise - is whether Hildegard even wrote the works which bear her name, a subject still hotly debated. Art history still has to engage in a similar debate over the paintings that she seems to have masterminded.

If it has taken me a while to acquire a taste for the pure, single vocal line of Hildegard's hymns, my enthusiasm for the period in which it was written - often viewed as a rehearsal for the Renaissance - remains as irrepressible as it is irrational. We all have our foibles. Faced with a Romanesque arch or stone carving my pulse quickens. The chance to immerse myself in an era that witnessed the First and Second Crusade, Abelard and Eloise, The Song of Roland, Chrétien de Troyes, the building of the great Cistercian monasteries and the cathedrals which track the pilgrim routes across Europe, was what made me yearn to engage with Hildegard, one of its liveliest personalities.

What else would have possessed me to drag my family to Bingen in the middle of a sodden August in quest of her spirit, if not her footsteps. This sad Rhineland town, flattened by Allied bombing in 1945, has scarcely a pre-war building, let alone a medieval stone still standing. The site of this formidable woman's monastery, the building of which she herself oversaw, is now covered in a Spaghetti Junction of railway lines built partly upon its rubble. Yet once a year, Hildegard in person walks its streets in the form of a procession celebrating her feast-day on 17 September. A bejewelled casket containing her relics is held high, while mass is chanted, bells rung.

Back at the church, the casket is opened to allow pilgrims to offer prayers. On that day only, her shrouded skull is exposed to the world. Some biographers of the living are lucky enough to have met their subjects. Those who tell the stories of the dead have photographs to study, paintings or engravings to give them some sense of presence. Few writers on celebrities eight centuries dead can have come head to head with their subject in quite the same unnerving way.

I was intrigued by the suggestion, though what I knew of Hildegard could be written (and often had been) in large letters on the back of a CD cover. I certainly did not know that I would be spending many months in the compelling company of a woman whose artistic originality was lodged in a battling personality, as if Margaret Thatcher were united with Joan of Arc. A twelfth-century German abbess, it is true, was hardly the obvious non-fiction choice for a bestseller (one can but dream). Yet cult nuns elicit a strange frisson in which fascination combines with distaste, admiration with aversion. Hildegard (1098-1179) is particularly susceptible to such a response. A nun who composed music and who set up her own monastery on the Rhine in the face of strong monkish resistance, who wrote apocalyptic tracts and had lurid, fantastical visions, who chastised popes and emperors and who, as far we can tell, fell in love with another nun, invites trouble. Neglected for some eight centuries, her reappraisal in the 1970s coincided with hippies, feminism, New Age-ism, Greens and, critically, the explosion of interest in early music. Thus, through no fault of her own, Hildegard seemed to meet the criteria for membership of every conceivable special interest group - cranky, outlandish, profane or sacred. Each felt proprietorial about her and adopted her as a mascot, however flimsy their surmise or unfounded their justification. Almost certainly a migraine sufferer, as Oliver Sacks has argued in his study of that affliction, she is unofficial patron saint of the ailment. The St Aelred and St Hildegard Gay and Lesbian Ministry at the Episcopal Church of the Messiah, Santa Ana, California, however, seem to me to push their luck in harnessing her to their cause. Hildegard, in the words of one American feminist fan, sure was 'one tough sister'. Would I be able to understand, stand up to or even stand her? But I was committed. webTitle: Novelist Dave Eggers gets hissy

fields.headline: When the tiff gets going...
fields.standfirst: A hissy feud between novelist Dave Eggers and a New York journalist highlights the love-hate relationship of celebrity and press
fields.trailText: A hissy feud between novelist Dave Eggers and a New York journalist highlights the love-hate relationship of celebrity and press.
fields.body:
This is a story of a sorry tiff between Dave and David. It is also, in its way, an ethical parable both for our times and and our trade.

The homonymous pair first cosied up to each other on the internet. Dave was dubious (he'd been hurt before) but David sent emails which begged: 'Please please please.' Who could resist such raw need, such a flattering lube-job? Dave surrendered. 'You sound like a normal, even warm person,' he whispered down the wire. Within days, David betrayed Dave by blabbing his secretist thoughts. Then, in retaliation, Dave made David's urgent mash notes electronically available to the world at large and kissed off his former confidant as a 'bitter little bastard'.

Let me explain. Dave is Dave Eggers, the J.D. Salinger of Generation X, whose tragicomic memoir, A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius, published last year, just about lived up to its ironically boastful title. David is David Kirkpatrick, a dim hack from the New York Times, who craved an interview with Eggers to coincide with the paperback edition of his book.

Dave was wary about meeting in person - you never now what you might catch from personal contact. He agreed to answer questions by email, and David handsomely offered the chance to approve quotes before publication. But by the time the article appeared in mid-February, Dave had decamped from New York to New Zealand. The international dateline, like the hostile astrological signs in Romeo and Juliet, meant he didn't see the proof until too late; just how star-crossed can two buddies be?

David's piece was a dull, bland combination of puffery and anodyne tittle-tattle. It could hardly have been anything else, since its instigator was Dave's publisher. The errors were negligible (David got the name of a New Jersey town wrong). Nevertheless, Dave reviled David for hypocrisy and malice, and paid him back by publishing their correspondence - complete with the New York Times man's spelling mistakes - grocers' apostrophes and semi-literate burbling - on a website he edits.

Reading through those pages at www.mcsweeneys.net - an online literary journal - I wondered if they gave away rather more about the gladiatorial erotics of literary collaboration and competition than the participants might have wished. 'I'm not married to anything,' hints David, meaning he has no advance notion of what kind of piece he's going to write. He fumbles for a month with an article no longer than the one you are reading, and his incompetence cues a spasm of misogyny: 'I'm having a bitch of a time getting it down.' Then he offers Dave the right of approval, the equivalent of lying face-down on the bed. 'Your willingness to bend is great,' says Dave. In cyberspace, no one has a face, but do I intuit a triumphal smirk from a seducee who pretended to be so hard to get?

The bender, however, only pretends submissiveness. Misled, mistreated, Dave finally impugns David's masculinity by claiming online that at weekends he sheds his business suit, wears eyeliner and smokes clove cigarettes.

Laughably trivial as it is, the hissy fit raises larger issues about journalistic procedures and the hoity-toity privileges of celebrity. The affair is a labyrinth of double-standards. According to Dave, David, like the far more distinguished Janet Malcolm, a New Yorker profile writer who was sued for breach of confidence and fabrication of quotes by one of her subjects, the psychoanalyst Jeffrey Masson - is a 'hatchet-wielder', happy to conceal or alter the truth if it suits his story. Malcolm herself admitted that journalists are instinctively and justifiably treacherous; aren't they entitled to their own artistic licence? And Dave's fulminations, madly excessive given the deferential nature of David's article, somehow miss the point that his own book owed its success to his defiance of the same rules he accuses David of flouting.

A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius, a non-fiction novel, regaled readers with a mordant account of the deaths of Dave's parents. He now zealously prizes his privacy and will only be interviewed by email. But he thought nothing of publishing the phone numbers of friends who were conscripted as characters in his book. (As it happened, the friends weren't besieged by crank callers; readers assumed the numbers were false.)

Dave's mercurial irony evinces a genuine anxiety or distress about his own artistic morality, which battens on disaster and misery and fortuitously makes money from the wreckage of other people's lives. What he sees in David, I think, is a replica of himself - it takes one to know one. Of course, David is a less talented and successful facsimile. You can tell he's not very bright when, checking facts, he asks Dave: 'Are you still 29? Or older now?'

In fact, both Dave and David were case-hardened harlots. This was no feckless fling, but a shrewd commercial transaction. Celebrities only give interviews when they have something to sell. Dave was under pressure from his publisher to help them earn back the $1.4 million advance they'd paid him. And David, with cynical candour, conceded during the wooing process that he too had economic reasons for obtaining a commission from the New York Times: 'I have an occupational obligation to try to talk you into talking with me.'

What was the value, then, of the fulsome compliments he paid Dave? This was the hooker's unfelt rhetoric of solicitation and encouragement.

Dave's chastening of David is not about ethics at all, since morally they're on a par. It's about the supposedly superior rights of the celebrity. Dave's fame exempts him from the customary moral laws, and from emotional qualms that we might otherwise feel about his behaviour. His book turns his family tragedy into a soap opera. Now his angry pedantry about David's inaccuracy is an episode from a sitcom (think of Frasier on the rampage over a lapse of etiquette).

Humbling David, he reminds him of what the celebrity is entitled to get away with. Stars possess the power of indifference, a chilling refusal to reciprocate the adoration they're offered; Dave reprints David's emails and also his own non-responses, snubbing the intrusive fan all over again.

Nevertheless, in spurning David, Dave has committed an act of hubris. The celebrity is a personality marketed for popular consumption. Dave happens to be a fine writer, but the publicity campaign for the paperback treated him like any other commodity, a product to be exchanged for cash. David, coaxed to write the profile by Dave's publicist, was essential to the selling strategy.

This is where Dave's arrogant error comes in. Celebrities are invented by the hacks who celebrate them, and they exist only so long as those cheerleaders maintain public interest in their carryings-on. Princess Diana knew this, and courted the press; her in-laws, fancying themselves above such vulgarity, fatally froze out the photographers and gossip columnists.

Dave is now asserting his own proud disconnection from his fan base. The Queen and the reclusive Salinger give no interviews; Dave gives them, if at all, only in cyber-limbo. But where would these aloof creatures be if their names and pictures no longer appeared in the papers?

My message to Dave and David is this: guys, get over it. Make up, meet for latte. See if the flame can be rekindled. You depend on each other. More than that, you deserve each other.

webTitle: The book I'd give: Fay Weldon

fields.headline: The book I'd give
fields.trailText:
Journal of a Somerset Rector 1803-1834
John Skinner
Oxford University Press (1984)
Buy it at a discount at BOL
fields.body:
Journal of a Somerset Rector 1803-1834
John Skinner
Oxford University Press (1984)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This volume of diaries is as fresh and moving as the day it was written. John Skinner is the difficult, irascible and priggish rector of a coal-mining town. Life for his parishioners is short, brutish and full of drama; his congregation flocks to the Methodists. His wife dies, his sons turn into mini-Kevins. Oh, the rows, so painful and so funny. The reader grieves for him.

webTitle: Observer review: Grammars of Creation by George Steiner

fields.headline: In the beginning...
fields.standfirst: George Steiner's new book, Grammars of Creation, is a riveting guide to language and existence
fields.trailText: George Steiner's new book, Grammars of Creation, is a riveting guide to language and existence
fields.body:
Grammars of Creation
George Steiner
Faber £16.99, pp288

Grammars were once books used to teach grammar. They seem peculiarly old-fashioned now, as literacy itself is soon going to seem, in George Steiner's view, though they were among the first 'how to' books. They had to be grammatical themselves, good examples of what they taught and they had to be unembarrassedly instructive. It was through grammars that the great classical and biblical civilisations of the past were opened up, and through grammars more and more people in the West were initiated into what was once deemed to be the best future, literacy.

Even though grammar was itself technical, a discipline in its own right, speaking and writing seem the most natural things in the world. The study of language shows us that we are, paradoxically, utterly law abiding and innovative in our language use. We can only improvise when we have something to improvise with. We are in the process of losing our faith in language, Steiner believes, and that this is just like losing our faith in God, and may be even worse.

Steiner has been writing grammars of an unusually baroque and dramatic kind all his (writing) life. And in Grammars of Creation, he has come out as the remarkable grammarian that he is, to write a kind of summa of his work, to tell us about the rules and regulations - and the complementary inspirations and anomalies - of creation in its fullest and most fulsome sense. He is, as ever, grandly erudite and thrilled by crisis. But like all the most intent cultural critics there is something he is daunted by, and the occasional melodrama of his style, no less than the many pointed and provocative formulations in this book are reflective of this abiding preoccupation.

That people are excessively cruel and excessively imaginative - and also sometimes concerned to temper their excesses - has always been for Steiner the theme, as it were, of the twentieth century. What Grammars of Creation homes in on, continuing the argument in Real Presences, and that began most vividly in Bluebeard's Castle, is just what it is that sustains our modern confidence in being alive.

Our faith that life is a virtue in itself, or even an outright gift is, in Steiner's view, constantly under threat, and never more so than now. What he calls 'the gusto of optimism', our more ambitious hopes for ourselves, are fading. There is, he believes, 'in the climate of spirit at the end of the twentieth century, a core-tiredness'. Though Grammars of Creation is characteristically exhilarated and exhilarating about our cultural achievements in the arts and the sciences - and Steiner is as riveting in this book talking about modern cosmology as he is about Philip Larkin as 'an annotator of common ground' - it reads rather more as a Decline and Fall of the Human Empire.

So Grammars of Creation is about everything grammars and creations hold at bay. 'Our thoughts and feelings,' Steiner writes, 'find nothingness and the pressure of non-being difficult to sustain.' He has always written against the grain of British no-nonsense philistinism. His style and abiding preoccupations always court the reader's prejudices (it is as though there has always been a satirist in Steiner who knows too well about the exasperation and mockery he incites).

In Grammars of Creation, he puts pressure on us to consider the various nothingnesses we live with. Not only are our individual lives haunted by our forthcoming absence, but every work of art - and art, for Steiner, is at once our grand inquisitor and the best way life has come up with of justifying itself - is 'attended by a two-fold shadow: that of its own possible or preferable inexistence, and that of its disappearance'.

The phrase 'two-fold shadow' is worth attending to here because it keeps in focus the very difficulty that Steiner is exploring: the way our ideas of creativity and creation (in the theological sense) are ways of countering and acknowledging the absences, the disappearances we have to live with. Our futures (what might happen) are, in Steiner's sense, as 'inexistent' as our pasts (what might have been). Our erotic lives are made out of what isn't there. 'Love knows of absences more vehement, more expressive of the promise of hope,' Steiner writes, 'than is any presence.'

Music transforms silence by including it in its structure. Any work of art, like any individual life, need not have happened, and could always have been different. And it is only in language, through grammar, as Steiner is so keen to impress upon us, that our lives have such tenses available to them. Without language, we can't tell the time.

Steiner suggests in this book that our sense of ourselves as creators - and we can only bear ourselves in his view as creators and inventors, a distinction that is at the heart of the book - has quite literally depended upon our assumption of divine or supernatural creation. As though the existence of God (or gods) is the only thing that can make us at all god-like; and if we are not god-like, we are merely 'barbarous', to use one of Steiner's key words. 'Can there, will there be major philosophy, literature, music and art of an atheist provenance?' Steiner asks plaintively at the end of this book.

And 'major' culture of any sort, with its absurdist military connotations, may not be the be all and end all. Grammars of Creation, even when it seems to be simply a 'salutary exaggeration' (to use one of so many good phrases in this book) is a fabulous education.

An academic life

Professor George Steiner

Born: Paris, 1929

Education France, US and Britain, including a Rhodes Scholarship to Balliol College, Oxford.

webTitle: Bombing a Publisher

fields.headline: Bombing a Publisher
fields.trailText:
Imagine, for days after the sirens,
book-ash falling like fingerprint dust, soft
tonnes of poems making a slow Pompeii
of Manchester, the air guilty with it...
fields.body:
Imagine, for days after the sirens,
book-ash falling like fingerprint dust, soft
tonnes of poems making a slow Pompeii
of Manchester, the air guilty with it:

a grey broadcast among aerials,
interfering with satellite dishes,
sly in the creases of morning papers,

printing its unwelcome news on shirt-fronts
and carry-out cappuccino, trodden
down hall-carpets, making itself at home;

filling sewers with shampooey fervour,
filtering into the water-supply,
half-inching its way into lungs, leaking
into blood, heart, brain. Breathe out, now, and speak.

webTitle: The rise of the reading group

fields.headline: The rise of the reading group
fields.standfirst: Join the Guardian Unlimited reading group
fields.trailText: This column likes to provoke a response, but it has only once received a death threat (from an enraged sci-fi enthusiast). Second only to the science-fiction buffs in prickliness are the devotees of the book club, or reading group.
fields.body:
This column likes to provoke a response, but it has only once received a death threat (from an enraged sci-fi enthusiast). Second only to the science-fiction buffs in prickliness are the devotees of the book club, or reading group.

A few years ago, I wrote a lighthearted piece about book clubs, flippantly suggesting that they were a fundamentally American import and that the focus of their interests was - shall we say? - not entirely to do with books. All hell broke loose. Round robins were drafted; letters were signed; retractions demanded. My long-suffering wife was obliged to pretend that divorce papers were in the post. I made a pact with myself to leave the subject well alone for the foreseeable future.

Today, I am breaking that vow, and I am doing so chiefly because I was 100 per cent wrong. Reading groups are not a passing fad or fancy. They are not just a girls' night out. They have become an essential part of civilised life up and down the country. So much so, indeed, that savvy publishers like Random House and HarperCollins now issue reading guides (available free at most bookshops) as a way of promoting an interest in their backlists.

What's more, this holds good internationally; today, book clubs are flourishing from Spain to Singapore. In America, where the idea originated in the aftermath of the women's liberation movement, you will find book clubs up and down east and west coasts. The online magazine Slate also has a weekly online book club initiated by journalists, to which the reading public contributes. Oprah Winfrey's celebrated TV show features a reading group segment, whose capacity to create overnight bestsellers has been widely reported.

These literary lightning strikes are all very well. In fact, the appeal of the book club is precisely its indifference to hype, and the warmth of its embrace of the solitary, the bored and the independent-minded. In a jangling, culturally overloaded time, the book club is a riposte to big- city anomie and the relentless, atomising pressure of modern life, as well as the yuppy answer to that old complaint: 'I just don't get time to read any more.'

Proof, if proof were needed, that this phenomenon has finally arrived comes this week with the publication of Jenny Hartley's survey, Reading Groups (OUP £5.99, pp198). This fascinating study inevitably reinforces some of the conventional wisdom about reading groups, a movement that numbers some 50,000 in the UK. For instance, 69 per cent of the 350 groups surveyed across the United Kingdom are indeed all-female (only 4 per cent are all-male). The reported reasons for this ranged from: 'We can't find any men who read' and: 'Men don't seem to enjoy the process of discussion as much' to: 'We felt the men would dominate... and the women would slide into the background and make the tea.'

More surprisingly, Dr Hartley's research reveals that about a fifth of all groups has been running for more than 10 years; that they can be found in schools, pubs, libraries, even a zoo; that some groups only meet via their computer screens and that one group dates back to 1799. The Bristol Friendly Reading Society takes us back to the sober, self-improving ethos of the early nineteenth century. It's also a reminder that, as recently as 100 years ago, the Victorian working-men's clubs were offering a proto-reading group experience. Similarly, the women's suffrage movement derived much of its initial strength from the reading groups of the day.

Dr Hartley, who is evangelical about her subject, demonstrates that there's a strong drive among reading group members to fight complacency. Consciousness-raising is an important part of the book group's appeal. Not surprisingly, some respondents to her survey reported 'shouting matches and power struggles' over the choice of the week's book, together with a general fear of 'long and heavy' classics such as The Brothers Karamazov and Tristram Shandy. Unlike those classics, the books enjoyed by the clubs of the nineteenth century are now long forgotten.

It's odd, and slightly chilling, to think that the same fate almost certainly awaits the writers whom Ms Hartley reports to be 'most read' by the groups she surveyed: Louis de Bernières, Anne Tyler, Jane Smiley, Pat Barker, Frank McCourt, Beryl Bainbridge, Arundhati Roy, Sebastian Faulks and Margaret Atwood.

Dr Hartley's list implicitly challenges those who have bewailed the 'dumbing down' of our culture by the pressures of rival media - video, TV and the internet. But it also confirms that, if there's one kind of book the British reading public favours over all others, it's a novel, preferably in the English language, and ideally by a woman.

robert.mccrum@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Observer review: George IV by Steven Parissien

fields.headline: Vain, obese, childish and so majestic
fields.standfirst: Steven Parissien leaves out the case for the defence in this startlingly abusive biograhpy of George IV
fields.trailText: Steven Parissien leaves out the case for the defence in this startlingly abusive biograhpy of George IV
fields.body:
George IV: The Grand Entertainment
Steven Parissien
John Murray £25, pp462
Buy it at a discount at BOL

George IV has often been deplored, and at length; in the long line of terrible English kings, he can easily be turned into a monster by a serious-minded historian. He was vain, extravagant, lecherous, hideous and childish; in short, there is no difficulty in mounting the case for the prosecution.

Nevertheless, there are things to be said in his defence, few of which are granted by the author of this startlingly abusive biography. He was a determined patron of the arts, and some of his most extravagant projects are still with us, adding some beauty to our lives; some of his worst behaviour was occasioned by circumstances which would try the patience of a saint; his beliefs were not just his wilfulness, but shared by his age. I have a soft spot for him; sandwiched between his serious father, George III, and his serious niece, Victoria, he seems like a Brighton Vathek. He gave a line of Germany country squires a much needed air of disgraceful glamour.

To a large degree, it was all George III's fault. By the age of 23, the Prince of Wales had run up debts of £269,878. It was not just that, following Mandeville's economic theories, every rich Englishman knew it was his duty to feed the poor workman by building gigantic gilded palaces; the Prince of Wales just knew he had an obligation to live up to his station. 'Would your Lordship,' he shakily wrote to the Groom of the Stole in 1784, 'with your ideas of propriety, have the Prince of Wales the Heir of Apparent [sic] to the Crown, dismiss his servants, sell his horses, and part, in short, with every magnificence annexed to his situation in life? It wd be improper for me to live with a less degree of magnificence than I hitherto have done.'

This is not something which we have much patience for; indeed, Steven Parissien doesn't even quote this letter. But it is important to understand this when reading the eye-stretching accounts of the Prince of Wales's wardrobe - £1,350 on a single Highland outfit, including 61 yards of satin. Most of all, we must bear this sense of propriety in mind when going round that splendid mirage, the Royal Pavilion at Brighton. Parissien obviously doesn't like it that much, making you wonder what on earth he is doing writing a biography of the king.

The book dwells ceaselessly on the king's incredible obesity, but for me it is less illuminating than E.A. Smith's careful, sympathetic biography of last year. It is unfair to ridicule George for saying: 'I will not allow these maidservants to look at me when I go in and out' - that was the etiquette of his father's court. What would be more interesting is an account of what, in his legacy, proved valuable and even what he most hoped, magnificent.

webTitle: Observer review: Reading Pictures by Alberto Manguel

fields.headline: Read any good pictures lately?
fields.standfirst: Every picture tells a story, but it takes an original mind to interpret plot and characters properly. Alberto Manguel reclaims the right to 'read' images in Reading Pictures
fields.trailText: Every picture tells a story, but it takes an original mind to interpret plot and characters properly. Alberto Manguel reclaims the right to 'read' images in Reading Pictures
fields.body:
Reading Pictures
Alberto Manguel
Bloomsbury £30, pp337

Pictures are deceiving. They appear to disclose themselves to the viewer, utterly and without qualification. What indeed could be more self-evident than the markings on a canvas, exposed on a wall to our closest scrutiny? And yet they contain mysteries. That they do so is not generally assumed, however. While literary works are assumed to be opaque, difficult - a whole school of criticism emerged in the early twentieth century dedicated solely to the investigation of poetry's ambiguities - pictures are taken to be transparent, accessible, readily intelligible.

So while it is conceded that literary critics, successors to interpreters of the Bible, do a necessary job, art critics have a somewhat harder time making a case for their profession. Many do not even try to make that case, but Alberto Manguel, though not a professional art critic, is persuaded that pictures need interpreters and in Reading Pictures he sets out to explain why.

Manguel is the celebrated author of A History of Reading and his point of departure is, inevitably, the written word. His opening move is to treat pictures as stories. They reveal their mysteries, that is to say, by being treated as texts. 'Much as I love reading words,' says Manguel, 'I also love reading pictures, and I enjoy finding the stories woven into them.' These are not just the stories told by the pictures but the stories that can be told about them and also about their creators.

Manguel's book itself is woven out of stories. It is a text about images that treats images as texts. The book is resolutely anti-professional, but not philistine. Manguel explains that he has not attempted to devise a systematic method for reading pictures such as those proposed by great art historians. He is guided not by a theory of art but by curiosity. His book grew out of the need to reclaim for common viewers the right to 'read' images. As he says: 'When we try to read a painting, it may seem lost to us in an abyss of misunderstanding or, if we prefer, a vast no-man's abyss of multiple interpretations.'

His task is to retrieve paintings from these depths. And so, for example, in one chapter, 'The Image as Riddle', he unravels the complexities of Christian iconography, illuminating a number of images of mothers nursing their infant children, pictures that withhold their complexities by the surface simplicity of their subject.

Following no conventional classification, Manguel organises pictures into 12 kinds. He writes about them as: story; absence; riddle; witness; understanding; nightmare; reflection; violence; subversion; philosophy; memory; theatre. A chapter is devoted to each. These are not, I think, hard and fast categories for him. Indeed, many are not categories at all. He would concede that many of the works that he considers could also fit in several other chapters. His approach is entirely pragmatic. Long after his thesis has been forgotten, the memory will persist of his smoothly deployed learning.

Manguel writes especially well about photography, noting that it allows, perhaps more than any other art, for manipulation and censorship to become an integral part of its own creative process. A piece of writing or a sculpture, he points out, may well suppress information, but such works define themselves as subjective, and thus accept their own fictions; photography is different. It purports to communicate what was there at the time of record and so it can lie. The artist deals in fictions; the photographer trades in the higher currency of truth. And this has a great many consequences for the development of art in the twentieth century because, as Manguel says, photography was undeniably that century's 'emblematic art form'.

This leads Manguel into a discussion of the career of Edward Weston who, in his attempt to 'see' his subject with the least possible interference, refused to crop his final prints. But, as Manguel goes on to note, this commitment to the 'truth' can become addictive and lead to the abandonment of art - photography, even - altogether. This was the fate of the artist Tina Modotti who gave up photography because seeing and portraying the social reality of Mexico's poor was too mediated a form of witness. She had to get much closer than her camera would allow and so she retreated into artistic silence.

This book is in a line of works of eccentric scholarship: Pliny the Elder's Natural History (the founding work of the genre), Robert Burton's Anatomy of Melancholy, Sir Thomas Browne's Religio Medici, Isaac D'Israeli's Curiosities of Literature. In this kind of work, wide and eclectic reading is put at the service of a large thesis, one which is not so rigorous as to exclude the entertaining anecdote or the curious fact. (Manguel pays homage to his master Pliny in his chapter 'The Image as Witness'.) The book is thus midway between a treatise and a book of quotations. It is too personal, too idiosyncratic, to be either the one or the other.

Part of the pleasure to be taken in Manguel's work (every one of his books, indeed) is in his retrieval of obscure aphorisms; the other part is his ability to give these aphorisms a context. So he quotes Beckett: 'To restore silence is the role of objects', which is a wonderfully taciturn statement in itself, and he uses it as the epigraph to his opening chapter, on the image as 'absence'.

In a concluding chapter of great modesty, he lists his omissions: prehistoric art, the arcane pictorial vocabulary of the renaissance, the political iconography of the nineteenth century, the arts of graffiti, of installations, of fashion, of pornography, of madness and dreams, of billboards and neon lights. The list puzzles - what exactly is the art of dreams? - but this only adds to its charm. Manguel has written an entertaining work that can be either pondered or leafed through, but is certain to give civilised pleasure.

As he says: 'When we try to read a painting, it may seem lost to us in an abyss of misunderstanding or, if we prefer, a vast no-man's abyss of multiple interpretations.' His task is to retrieve paintings from these depths. And so, for example, in one chapter, 'The Image as Riddle', he unravels the complexities of Christian iconography, illuminating a number of images of mothers nursing their infant children, pictures that withhold their complexities by the surface simplicity of their subject. Following no conventional classification, Manguel organises pictures into 12 kinds. He writes about them as: story; absence; riddle; witness; understanding; nightmare; reflection; violence; subversion; philosophy; memory; theatre. A chapter is devoted to each. These are not, I think, hard and fast categories for him. Indeed, many are not categories at all. He would concede that many of the works that he considers could also fit in several other chapters. His approach is entirely pragmatic. Long after his thesis has been forgotten, the memory will persist of his smoothly deployed learning. Manguel writes especially well about photography, noting that it allows, perhaps more than any other art, for manipulation and censorship to become an integral part of its own creative process. A piece of writing or a sculpture, he points out, may well suppress information, but such works define themselves as subjective, and thus accept their own fictions; photography is different. It purports to communicate what was there at the time of record and so it can lie. The artist deals in fictions; the photographer trades in the higher currency of truth. And this has a great many consequences for the development of art in the twentieth century because, as Manguel says, photography was undeniably that century's 'emblematic art form'. This leads Manguel into a discussion of the career of Edward Weston who, in his attempt to 'see' his subject with the least possible interference, refused to crop his final prints. But, as Manguel goes on to note, this commitment to the 'truth' can become addictive and lead to the abandonment of art - photography, even - altogether. This was the fate of the artist Tina Modotti who gave up photography because seeing and portraying the social reality of Mexico's poor was too mediated a form of witness. She had to get much closer than her camera would allow and so she retreated into artistic silence. This book is in a line of works of eccentric scholarship: Pliny the Elder's Natural History (the founding work of the genre), Robert Burton's Anatomy of Melancholy, Sir Thomas Browne's Religio Medici, Isaac D'Israeli's Curiosities of Literature. In this kind of work, wide and eclectic reading is put at the service of a large thesis, one which is not so rigorous as to exclude the entertaining anecdote or the curious fact. (Manguel pays homage to his master Pliny in his chapter 'The Image as Witness'.) The book is thus midway between a treatise and a book of quotations. It is too personal, too idiosyncratic, to be either the one or the other. Part of the pleasure to be taken in Manguel's work (every one of his books, indeed) is in his retrieval of obscure aphorisms; the other part is his ability to give these aphorisms a context. So he quotes Beckett: 'To restore silence is the role of objects', which is a wonderfully taciturn statement in itself, and he uses it as the epigraph to his opening chapter, on the image as 'absence'. In a concluding chapter of great modesty, he lists his omissions: prehistoric art, the arcane pictorial vocabulary of the renaissance, the political iconography of the nineteenth century, the arts of graffiti, of installations, of fashion, of pornography, of madness and dreams, of billboards and neon lights. The list puzzles - what exactly is the art of dreams? - but this only adds to its charm. Manguel has written an entertaining work that can be either pondered or leafed through, but is certain to give civilised pleasure.

webTitle: Observer review: Arthur the Dragon King by Howard Reid

fields.headline: King Arthur was actually a samurai warrior...
fields.standfirst: So Arthur wasn't an Alan after all... Howard Reid builds his argument backwards in Arthur the Dragon King
fields.trailText: So Arthur wasn't an Alan after all... Howard Reid builds his argument backwards in Arthur the Dragon King
fields.body:
Arthur the Dragon King: the Barbarian Roots of Britain's Greatest Legend
Howard Reid
Headline, £18.99, pp255
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In the opening pages of this book, the author makes one of his least controversial assertions: 'A vast amount of material of very variable quality has poured forth over the centuries about King Arthur.' How very true.

The difficulty in writing about Arthur is that nothing is known of him. He is not referred to at all in the Anglo-Saxon Chronicles. The very first mention of his name comes in a passing observation by a late sixth-century Welsh poet, who remarks that a certain warrior, though brave, 'was not Arthur'. Three centuries later, a monk called Nennius provides an outline of Arthur's life, though he admits that his sources are a rag-bag compilation.

The most famous subsequent account is Malory's Morte D'Arthur, which gives us the familiar details of the knights of the Round Table, the doomed love of Lancelot and Guinevere, the quest for the Holy Grail, etc. In considering this as a historical document, however, we should bear in mind that it was written perhaps 1,000 years after the events it purports to describe.

The subject of Arthur is therefore wide open to speculation, and plenty of speculation there has been. Arthur was a Briton, or perhaps a Celt resisting the Romans; no, he was a Roman fighting off barbarians; on the contrary, he was an Anglo-Saxon, perhaps driving back the Norsemen, and so on. Welsh writers have argued that Arthur was a Welshman, Scottish writers that he was a Scot and French writers that he was French. Since nothing is known about him, almost anything can be said and almost everything has been.

Now Howard Reid, a documentary filmmaker, has come along with a new theory: Arthur came from one of the nomadic tribes attacking the declining Roman Empire from the east. These were not Huns, Vandals or Goths, but the less familiar Alans, tall, blond tourists arriving in Europe by horse.

He comes from, well, we're not quite sure where until the very end of the book, though Reid drops various hints that Arthur's home may have been somewhere around the Caucasus.

This startling notion is founded on the author's comparison of the Arthurian legend as it has come down to us, in particular, the idea of warriors on horseback,with the few facts that are known of the peoples around when Arthur was supposed to have lived. 'It is impossible for any of us to imagine an Arthur who has to dismount before doing battle,' the author proclaims. Right, so Arthur can't have been a Celt. The trouble with this method is that it involves projecting back in time elements of the Arthurian legend, such as chivalry and courtly love, that are almost certainly later embellishments. It is like trying to build a house by starting with the roof.

Reid's argument is scattered with phrases such as 'may well have been', 'almost inconceivable', 'seems entirely in keeping with,' and - my favourite - 'it is surely not too great a step to go on to...' Evidence being scarce, he is forced to use any that he can find, referring, for example, to 'eunuchs and castration', both of course, Arthurian themes. Just run that one past me again, will you, Howard?

His text does not seem to have been sullied by the attention of an editor. The same facts are trotted out again and again, as if for the first time, often word-for-word as before. One howler I particularly enjoyed was the use of 'populous' to mean 'populace'.

In the search for Arthur, Howard Reid takes us ever further east, daringly roaming across two continents and three millennia. Barbarian wave follows barbarian wave; armies, kings and warriors flash past at bewildering speed. The author tries to keep the reader's attention with his lively prose, but towards the finish even he tires: 'History, however, was rushing on and in 451 the Romans were once again calling on the Alans to aid them in their hour of need.'

He saves his most astounding conclusion until the very end. Perhaps Arthur was not an Alan after all? Once all the pieces in the jigsaw have been placed in the correct position, we can see that the real King Arthur may have been - remember, reader, you saw it here first - Japanese.

webTitle: Poetry roundup: Gillian Allnutt, John Redmond, Charles Boyle and Hand in Hand

fields.headline: Surf's up in Galway Bay
fields.standfirst: Gillian Allnutt writes with an uncanny clarity, while John Redmond sees life with a slant and Charles Boyle takes an exhilarating look at the Old World
fields.trailText: Gillian Allnutt writes with an uncanny clarity, while John Redmond sees life with a slant and Charles Boyle takes an exhilarating look at the Old World
fields.body:
Lintel
Gillian Allnutt
Bloodaxe, £7.95, pp64
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Thumb's Width
John Redmond
Carcanet £6.95, pp96
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The Age of Cardboard and String
Charles Boyle
Faber and Faber £7.99, pp96

Hand in Hand
Foreword by Carol Ann Duffy
Picador £7.99, pp116
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Gilllian Allnutt's poetry, like the unpolluted atmosphere of Iceland, is uncannily clear. Every outline is distinct, every colour dazzling. In Lintel, she writes about the loneliness of human beings on a crowded earth and, like Yeats, probes the 'pilgrim soul' voyaging through life.

Allnutt's poems themselves become pilgrimages. Some are to places of recognised beauty and spirituality, such as the island of Lindisfarne, others to a deserted factory in County Durham or to a brickyard in Camberwell. They record moments of pressure, longing and illumination. What is most attractive about her work is that she is never solemn about the spiritual life which fascinates her. Instead, she explores it with a humour which is sometimes deadpan, sometimes broad, and always warm with life.

John Redmond's Thumb's Width has a similar tenderness for the physical world. The islands off the west coast of Ireland are his childhood landscape, seen with the slant truth he describes in 'A Bridge on the Corrib':

As soon as it came to water,

you counted the salmon precisely

and told me, don't see straight.

By seeing with a slant, you see more. Redmond writes of the toy soldiers he played with obsessively in boyhood. Now, to the sound of 'Good Vibrations', he imagines them:

beginning to surf out of Galway Bay

with a hint of blonde on their quiffs

and empty hands fighting for balance.

Redmond excels at miniatures, and paints them with a droll, original touch. His love for the succulence of language can make him too wordy, but he's a poet to enjoy now and watch out for in the future.

Charles Boyle's enjoyment in The Age of Cardboard and String is a drier and wryer thing. He's a more worldly poet than either Redmond or Allnutt. In 'Moonlighting', the world is agape not with wonder but in a yawn:

Europe, the Western world

baring its wet pink gums

and livid tongue, as if slowly beginning

to turn itself inside out...

Every landscape has already been looked at, and every experience has been had before. This may sound cynical, but the effect of Boyle's poetry is exhilarating. He is happy to join literary tradition, to be guided by the penetrating curiosity of Stendhal and then leap off on his own thought tangent. A man settles himself in an armchair outside a junk shop; a woman hurls a volume of Stendhal out of a window; a poet leads a double life in England and New Zealand. Some poets rush to the reader with such subjects, like a cat to its owner with a blackbird. Boyle is content to describe the bird's flight.

As Carol Ann Duffy observes in her foreword to Hand in Hand, a new anthology of love poetry: 'When we fall in love it's often to our poets that we turn', in the hope, perhaps, that the spectacular confusion of their love lives will make our own seem better. In this anthology, published to coincide with Valentine's Day, each featured poet has chosen a favourite love poem, alongside one of his or her own. Dorianne Laux's 'Kissing', chosen by Billy Collins, possesses a filmic, frozen beauty:

when the babies are born crying

into the white air, when Mozart bends

to his bowl of soup and Stalin bends

to his garden. They are kissing

to begin the world again.

Love poems en bloc can cloy, like a thousand brides and grooms assembled for a mass wedding. Buy this anthology all the same, if only for a powerful new poem by Alice Oswald, and for Sean O'Brien's memorable 'Indian Summer', where bewitchment and stringency battle themselves into balance:

Look at this frosty red rose leaning over

The milk on the step. Please take it. But leave me

Its fragrance, its ice in the mind, to remember you by.

Poetry magazines were the proving-grounds for almost all these poets. Fertile, argumentative, passionate, sometimes maddening, sometimes breathtakingly good, the main difficulty of these magazines is that their vitality isn't matched by their circulation figures.

Try the latest Poetry Review, which focuses on South Asian and Caribbean poetry, with a characteristically vibrant blend of poems, reviews and background. Ambit offers a group of new poems by George Szirtes, and some fabulous illustrations by Charles Shearer for George Mackay Brown's poetry.

In the latest Acumen, there's a lucid introduction to Hugh MacDiarmid's poetry by Sean Elliott, which ends on the bracing note that: 'MacDiarmid needs to be rescued from Scotland and, more than anyone else, Scottish writers need to accomplish this task.' No doubt the volunteers are already writing in.

webTitle: Observer review: Fairness by Ferdinand Mount

fields.headline: Really, we must stop meeting like this
fields.standfirst: When Gus goes in pursuit of love, he gets more than he bargained for in Ferdinand Mount's Fairness
fields.trailText: When Gus goes in pursuit of love, he gets more than he bargained for in Ferdinand Mount's Fairness
fields.body:
Fairness
Ferdinand Mount
Chatto & Windus £16.99, pp306
Buy it at a discount at BOL

What constitutes fairness? Aldous 'Gus' Cotton, the narrator of the latest novel in Ferdinand Mount's A Chronicle of Modern Twilight series, makes frequent recourse to the teachings of (fictional) philosopher W.R. Scrannel. In one lecture, Scrannel had posited that 'fair' originally contained all the beauty in the world, but now that the world had become disenchanted, all it meant was 'income tax and waiting lists'. More prosaically, fairness also distinguishes Helen Hardress, 'plainness itself' apart from her milky gold hair. Gus aches for her, but seems resigned to their detached intimacy being 'the last amitié amoureuse of the twentieth century'.

Hopscotching continents from the 1960s to the present, Gus pursues Miss Goldilocks as she jumps from bed to bed in search of something more elusive than even herself. They meet as vacation nannies in Normandy. Gus works for the Stilwells, and ends up bedding Jane, the copper-haired wife who resembles an early President on an American stamp. Confusingly, she also looks like the wife of Dodo Wilmot, a gargantuan, bombastic entrepreneur who spills over with New World vulgarity. A misunderstanding sees Jane try to drown herself. Gus, wisely, decides it's time to move on.

Mortality skulks at every corner of a story containing six attempted suicides, two successful, encompassing drowning, hanging, overdose, jumping, shooting and gassing. Gus acquires a morbid predilection for Victorian cemeteries that polarises Helen still further - she views the death ritual as 'sentimental rubbish'. Agnosticism and spiritual inquiry in a Western world drained of faith are central to the book's investigation, matched against Helen's atheist intolerance and Dodo's Mammonist excess. Gus shares more in common with her father, who reads philosophy and rails against a world he cannot live with. True to form, he hangs himself.

Helen joins Dodo mineral mining in Central Africa, sharing his largesse and his bed until uncovering the unpleasant truth of the project that sends her straight back to England. In a pivotal passage, after appearing to succumb to Gus's avowal of love, she blurts that she is not running to him, but fleeing Dodo. Her point is reinforced when she becomes engaged to, then marries, the hapless Bobs, an ex-schoolfriend's brother, because he 'doesn't lie'. Gus then travels on business to America aboard a convalescent cruise ship that turns out to be owned by... Dodo, who happens to be on board with his new wife... Jane.

It doesn't screw much tighter, for reader or hero, until years later, when Gus takes part in a child sex abuse inquiry in Fairness, a coastal town, at which Helen, now a social worker, is a key witness. The novel closes on a sombre note, as although she is made a life peer, Gus laments the unencumbered, unclothed, young woman who dived from the African rocks. And this, rather than the contrivance of her ennobling, provides a wistful conclusion.

With Fairness Mount eschews the picaresque of his previous splendid novel Jem and Sam for something more attuned to the uncertain mood of the final decades of the twentieth century, bound up in the watchful, loyal attentions of its hero. Gus inhabits the dark suits and brooding silences of Nick Carraway, surrounded by Dodo as a malevolent Gatsby, and the unattainable Helen. His role is observatory, passive to a fault, yet he sees Helen through a lachrymal veil while she wears her moral seriousness like a fragrance, and chides him for having no grasp of the pains of lovers. If her hair resembles butter, her tongue incises like a hot knife, making it hard to share Gus's masochistic passion for what ultimately proves fool's gold.

The dust-jacket claims that this is Helen's story, and that she is a 'female Candide for our time'. This seems misjudged. Mount nourishes his tale with a gentle, unfussy elegance that implies rather than urges, and celebrates a humorous melancholia worthy of Evelyn Waugh, and a fading model of the English novel. Less knockabout than its predecessors, Fairness wears its heart dark on a well-turned sleeve, and speaks compassionately of unrequited love, perhaps the most unfair cut of all.
