webTitle: Observer review: The Testament of Yves Gundron by Emily Barton

fields.headline: It's Grimm up north
fields.standfirst: Emily Barton's debut novel, The Testament of Yves Gundron, is a bewitching parable
fields.trailText: Emily Barton's debut novel, The Testament of Yves Gundron, is a bewitching parable
fields.body:
The Testament of Yves Gundron
Emily Barton
Canongate £9.99, pp303
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Emily Barton's remarkable first novel proves difficult to define; it straddles genres while possessing a curious familiarity, reminiscent at times of Swift and Peake, set against the landscape of a Brueghel painting.

Presented as a historical document, edited with footnotes by a young American academic named Ruth Blum, Yves Gundron's lucid account of the life of his seemingly mythical village begins in an arcane, stylised language evocative of some mid-European folk tale. The characters' names - Ydlbert von Iggislau, Ion Gansevöort - are a mongrel blend of pseudo-Flemish, Old Testament and Brothers Grimm, and the life Yves presents is a bleak one, of rudimentary farming, hostile elements, superstition, devout religion and fear of pestilence, all of which contribute to the medieval flavour.

Yet it gradually becomes apparent that the story is set in the present, and that Yves's village of Mandragora is a quite real but forgotten community, nestling on an unnamed island off the coast of Scotland which is marked on no map and has entertained no foreigners since the time of Yves's grandmother (provoking pedantic questions about the origin of their European names, English dialect and where they might have learned the phrase 'Piss off'). Ruth Blum, an anthropology student, arrives in this lost, pre-industrial hamlet and is invited into Yves's home while she studies the villagers, whose suspicions of her 'witchcraft' fester as the modern world begins to intrude in her wake.

The strangeness and originality of the world Barton has created make the novel difficult to accept at first. Yves's cod-Shakespearean voice appears over-egged, but as the reader becomes acclimatised to the language, the gradual accumulation of detail - of farming practices, weaving and cooking, the personalities and feuds of the village's families - builds an absorbing picture of a self-contained and almost fantastical country with its own lore.

The novel is also a fairly obvious parable about the development of technology as a mixed blessing. Though the villagers endure hardships, they also enjoy simple pleasures and an innocent community with one another and with the land, which is threatened as Yves's inventions grow more ambitious and the desire for greater productivity increases. The careful grafting of Ruth Blum's story on to Yves's own, and the eventual uniting of these two complementary threads, is tenderly and affectionately worked out, and the novel champions the idea of an essential shared humanity that can bridge extreme cultural divides.

The Testament of Yves Gundron is an impressive work of imagination, bewitching, pertinent and yet, like the best parables, seemingly timeless.

webTitle: Budget 2001: Packages for parents

fields.headline: The little monsters - not so dear any more  as Chancellor becomes a family man
fields.standfirst: Neasa MacErlean unwraps the packages of help for parents
fields.trailText: Neasa MacErlean unwraps the packages of help for parents.
fields.body:
Families are set to benefit from Chancellor Gordon Brown's Budget. But to get the most out of the new measures, one parent must be in work, the children must be 16 or younger, and the household will need to be taxed at the 10p or 22p rates.

Campaigning groups believe that the measures will make a huge difference to many families.

The new Children's Tax Credit - which starts on 6 April as a delayed replacement for Married Couples Allowance for people with children - will pay £10-a-week to each working family with a child under 16. The £10 is tapered down if one of the parents is a higher rate taxpayer - and it will disappear altogether if the main breadwinner earns more than £42,000. There is only one credit per household.

Starting in April 2002, the Children's Tax Credit will double to £20-a-week for the whole of the tax year if the family has a baby. The 'Baby Bonus' is likely to work in the same way as the basic Children's Tax Credit - although the Treasury says that there will be a higher earnings threshold of £50,000 on this part. Details have yet to be worked out - but it seems likely that the Baby Bonus will be paid in two parts. If your baby is born half-way through the fiscal year in October, for example, you would get a lump sum soon afterwards to represent your money for the first half of the year and, from then on, you would get it weekly.

The Chancellor also announced more generous terms for the Working Families Tax Credit (WFTC). The minimum household income where one parent works full-time is due to rise from £214 to £225 in October. WFTC is made up of four components - a basic allowance, an additional payment for those working over 30 hours a week, an age- related tax credit for each child and a 'childcare tax credit'.

This fourth element is potentially the largest. All elements are due to rise - but the amounts which can be claimed under this fourth part are increasing substantially in October.

A one-child family can now claim up to £70 a week. In October, the maximum will go up to £94.50. Families with more children in registered childcare can then claim up to £140. Only 124,000 families currently claim for childcare costs - but Lucy Lloyd of the Daycare Trust says: 'Nursery costs are typically £120 a week. So this increase could make a real difference.'

The Chancellor has looked at making the rules easier to encourage shiftworkers and parents of disabled children to claim for childcare costs.

The terms of Maternity Pay are due to be enhanced. It will be payable for 26, rather than 18 weeks, for babies born after April next year. Women will continue to get 90 per cent of pay for the first six weeks - but after that the weekly flat rate will rise from £60 now to £75 in April 2002 and £100 in April 2003. Fathers will, for the first time, be entitled to two weeks Paternity Pay at £100-a-week, starting in April 2003. Parents who adopt will also be covered in the provisions.

The rules are complicated and will change yet again in April 2003, when an 'integrated children's credit' is due to come into place.

Daycare Trust 020 7739 2866

Gingerbread 0800 018 4318

Maternity Alliance 020 7588 8582

National Council for One-Parent Families 0800 018 5026

Working Families Tax Credit government line 0800 597 5976

Local Citizens Advice Bureaux also provide help.

webTitle: Budget 2001: The elderly

fields.headline: The elderly gain a bit now and there's more cheer ahead
fields.trailText: Older people did not benefit hugely from Gordon Brown's fifth Budget and rated a mere four paragraphs in the Chancellor's speech. But they are due to benefit in future from measures he has announced previously.
fields.body:
Older people did not benefit hugely from Gordon Brown's fifth Budget and rated a mere four paragraphs in the Chancellor's speech. But they are due to benefit in future from measures he has announced previously.

Single pensioners will on average be 41p a week better off as a result of the 2001 Budget measures, while couples will gain 97p, according to an analysis by the Institute for Fiscal Studies,

They benefit from widening of the 10p band and the changes to alcohol, petrol and cigarette duties.

Most other measures for the elderly mentioned by the Chancellor on Wednesday had already been outlined and it will be two years before some of them come into effect.

But by 2003, the IFS has calculated, the average single pensioner, will gain £9.68 a week while the average couple will receive £11.05 more.

The measures planned for them include:

 Above-inflation increases this year and next in the basic state pension. Single people will have a rise of £5 to £72.50 next month and another £3 to £75.50 next year. Couples get a rise of £8, to £115.90 next month and another £4.80 to £120.70 in 2002. The Government is forecasting basic state pensions from April 2003 of £77 a week for single pensioners and £123 for couples.

 From next month, pensioners who qualify for a means-tested top-up through the Minimum Income Guarantee (MIG) will get £92.15 if they are single. Couples will have £140. 55.

 More elderly people may qualify for the MIG from next month because of increases in the amount of savings pensioners can have before losing entitlement. Savings up to £6,000 - against £3,000 now - will be ignored, and amounts between £6,000 and £12,000, (£3,000 to £8,000 now) will result in reductions in MIG. Savings of £12,000 or more will remove entitlement to the top-up.

 From 2003 the Minimum Income Guarantee will be £100 a week for a single pensioner and £154 for a couple, and the MIG will rise in line with earnings.

 A new pensioners' credit, which begins in April the same year, will reward savings by low-income pensioners, crediting them with 60p for every £1 of income from savings or private pensions. The credit will apply to single pensioners with incomes up to £135 a week and couples up to £200.

 Personal tax allowances for the elderly will rise in line with average earnings from the same year.

The charities Age Concern and Help the Aged were disappointed that the Chancellor confirmed he will increase the use of means-testing among old people, which reduces the number who claim benefits they are entitled to.

A spokesman for Help the Aged said: 'We are still concerned that the strategy seems to be based on means-testing and one-off gifts.'

The charity had been contacted by a widow whose widows' pension disqualified her from the MIG and council tax benefit. 'She said the £5 a week pension rise would be wiped out by an increase in council tax,' the spokesman added.

webTitle: Maria Scott: Another inquiry? Only if it brings action

fields.headline: Another inquiry? Only if it brings action
fields.trailText: Changes aimed at improving company pension schemes will result from last week's report by a team led by Paul Myners, chairman of investment group Gartmore.
fields.body:
Changes aimed at improving and protecting company pension schemes will result from last week's report by a team led by Paul Myners, chairman of investment group Gartmore and of this newspaper's parent company.

The Government is also to start a new review of the life insurance and investment industries following a recommendation by the Myners report. This should investigate charges, the nature and quality of advice, and whether commission distorts the choices offered to consumers.

These issues are worthy of investigation, though the investment industry will argue that competition and government initiatives such as capping of charges on stakeholder pensions, product benchmarking through the Catmark system, and educational initiatives by the Financial Services Authority, are helping to cut charges.

But change has come slowly, and many people are still buying unsuitable products. Further scrutiny of the industry will only pay off, however, if the Government has the stomach to face deep-rooted problems in the business. The main one is commission, the traditional method of payment for financial 'advisers'.

So far, the Government has shown no enthusiasm for outlawing this, preferring blunt instruments such as the capping of charges on stakeholder pensions and attempts at improving information for consumers. Further investigation of these industries is warranted, but it will be worthwhile only if the Government is prepared for a real showdown.

Education is one of the ways in which the Government, through the Financial Services Authority, believes consumers will become better equipped to avoid being fleeced. The FSA is encouraged by a survey showing that 11-to-16-year-olds are more interested in learning about money than about sex - hoping this shows enthusiasm for personal finance as a school subject.

A more likely explanation is that these pupils already know plenty about sex. And while they may be interested in money, the mind-boggling complexity of Britain's financial services system means that many aspects of it will remain beyond the ken of educators and students alike.

If regulators hope education will allow them to exert a lighter touch, they will have a long wait.

webTitle: Budget 2001: The winners and losers

fields.headline: A good Budget by any means
fields.standfirst: Gordon Brown has made the working poor better off.  Maria Scott reports on the winners and losers after four years Labour
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown has made the working poor better off. Maria Scott reports on the winners and losers after four years Labour.
fields.body:
Do you feel richer or poorer after four years under Labour? With another Budget gone and an election expected in May, voters are taking stock of what the first Labour government for nearly two decades has done for their finances.

Labour was desperate to shed its 'tax and spend' image, and pledged not to raise the basic or top rates of income tax. But while these may not have gone up over the four years - indeed the basic rate is down from 23 to 22 per cent - the Government is collecting more tax than in 1997.

Revenues can rise for reasons other than individuals having to pay more. But there is a consensus among analysts that some of us really are handing over a greater proportion of our incomes than we did.

The winners have been poorer families and elderly people. The losers are middle-income earners, particularly the childless, although their pain has probably been masked by a healthy economy and pay rises.

The difference between old Labour and new is the way that we are taxed. Gordon Brown has withdrawn various reliefs such as mortgage interest, the Married Couple's Allowance - only partially restored by the new Children's Tax Credit - and increased the cost of paying for a private pension by taxing pension funds.

Parents may even see the full withdrawal of student grants under Labour and the arrival of tuition fees as back-door taxation.

The independent Institute for Fiscal Studies is analysing the full effects of five Labour Budgets, including last week's, but researcher Michal Myck says: 'The general picture is easy to formulate - lower-income families with children have certainly gained. Pensioners have gained substantially.'

But while the Conservatives are keen to promote the idea that middle England has been hit by a slew of 'stealth' taxes, the institute suggests this is an over-simplification.

The effect of Brown's changes vary greatly according to individual circumstances. For example, a single taxpayer without a mortgage gained from cuts in direct taxes, mainly income tax. Scrapping mortgage interest tax relief has hit all homeowners with loans. Smokers and car owners lost out as a result of big increases in duties.

An analysis carried out before last week's Budget, which took into account changes in direct and indirect taxation, showed that the poorest 10 per cent of households were, on average, 8.8 per cent better off from all the measures introduced after May 1997.

'Further deciles gain proportionately less on average, and the richest 30 per cent of households experience a fall in post-tax income once all the reforms are considered,' said the IFS.

The poorer households gain mainly from increases in benefits for those out of work and the introduction of the Working Families' Tax Credit for those in work.The loss of income for richer households comes from rises in National Insurance and the abolition of mortgage tax relief and the Married Couple's Allowance.

However, within most income groups, even the poorest, there are losers as well as winners. Among the poorest 10 per cent, for example, 2.9 per cent were more than £10 a week worse off. Among the richest, 1.7 per cent were more than £10 a week better off.

Two-earner couples with children gain less than other types of families with children as they are least likely to benefit from the Working Families' Tax Credit and income support allowances, and are most likely to see the Children's Tax Credit withdrawn. Non-earning couples with children gain most: on average, £18.70 per week.

According to the IFS's initial conclusions about the overall effect of last week's measures, the position of people towards the top end of the income scale - but not the wealthiest 10 per cent - will have improved.

The improvement to pensioners' incomes results from increased age-related income tax allowances, increased income support, winter fuel allowances and retention of the Married Couple's Allowance for those born before 6 April 1935. On average, a single pensioner household has gained £6.10 and a pensioner couple £4.20 a week.

Despite the obvious efforts the Chancellor has made to redirect resources, there are concerns about some of his set-piece changes. A strong theme has been a move towards increased means-testing, particularly for pensioners. The institute reckons that by 2003 the average single pensioner will gain £9.68 a week from the package of measures foreshadowed by the Chancellor in his November 2000 Pre-Budget Report, and confirmed last week.

The average couple should pocket £11.05. The extra money comes from above-inflation rises in the basic state pension in 2001 and 2002; above-inflation rises in the means-tested Minimum Income Guarantee - which tops up the basic state pension in low-income pensioner households - in each of the next three years and, from April 2003, the new pension credit, designed to reward saving for poorer pensioners.

By 2003 the average incomes of the poorest 10 per cent of pensioners should be up by more than 20 per cent, according to the IFS.

Its researcher, Tom Clark, says: 'The Government is diverting significant extra resources to pensioners. But its basic strategy is still to extend means-testing.' The IFS fears that this could discourage younger people from saving.

This view is supported by an Institute of Actuaries analysis, which concludes that means-testing leads to people who reach retirement with small savings having to pay high marginal tax rates. It also discriminates against women, because they are less inclined to claim for their entitlements yet are among the poorest pensioners.

The actuaries conclude that means-testing and the poorer returns likely on money put aside for old age are 'likely to make saving for a pension considerably less attractive for increasing numbers of people'.

They suggest that a higher basic state pension may be preferable to means-testing, as it would do more to encourage saving.

The charity Age Concern, long opposed to means-testing, is continuing to campaign for a substantial increase in the basic state pension, and for it to go up in line with average earnings, rather than prices.

There is concern, too, that reforms aimed at low-income families are missing their tar get. The National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux has criticised the Working Families Tax Credit, pointing out that some employers are refusing to employ people entitled to it because of the high cost of the the bureaucracy involved in paying the money. In one case a single parent was dismissed from her part-time job when WFTC had to be paid through her pay packet.

Parents complain that once they receive the benefit it means they lose free school meals and help with rent and council tax.

The Government's emphasis on lower-income groups seemed to be called into question 24 hours after last week's Budget by a report into poverty across Europe, which found that more than 5 million Britons are living at levels thought to exist only in the developing world.

But poverty is concentrated among lone parents, where households may have missed out on the work-ori ented means-tested benefits Labour has introduced.

Despite the shortcomings of some of these changes, their general thrust has been welcomed by the Child Poverty Action Group. Its director, Martin Barnes, says: 'In the last two years we have seen a fairly significant shift in resources towards poorer families with children.'

Even if the Conservatives' claims about stealth taxes are exaggerated, there has been some pain for Middle England. Around 20 per cent more people are paying income tax at the 40 per cent tax rate now than when Labour came to office. This is mainly because earnings have risen more quickly than the higher-rate threshold.

Accountant PricewaterhouseCooper points out that the starting rate is now barely one and a half times' average earnings.

From the new tax year, someone earning just under £34,000 will be a higher-rate taxpayer. Yet an income like this probably wouldn't support a mortgage large enough for a flat in London; financial well-being isn't just about tax.

Ian Brinkley, senior economist at the Trades Union Congress, says that, for the moment, means-testing is extending far enough up the income scale - higher rate taxpayers can get the Children's Tax Credit, for example - for it not to have become offensive.

But Brinkley says: 'If you don't have universality [of benefits] will the middle classes get fed up? Will higher-rate taxpayers say, "Enough is enough. Why should I pay for universal benefits which I can't get?"'

Middle England, as repre sented by teachers, nurses, policemen and other members of the salaried classes, may begin to wonder why people much higher up the income scale are being left relatively unscathed.

Labour has not so far targeted the super-rich. Despite long-running rumours that such moves were coming, there has been no move to cut back on inheritance tax breaks, or higher rate relief on pension contributions. Such moves could, of course, upset the moderately well off as much as the super-rich.

Patrick Stevens, tax partner at accountant Ernst & Young, agrees that a disproportionate amount of pain is probably being felt by people in the £12,000 to £30,000 a year income bracket. Someone earning £100,000 a year has experienced the same changes but will barely notice them.

Middle-income earners have not benefited from the big gains in income seen by people in some industries, such as technology.

'A big chunk of people aren't going to do that [sort of thing] in their lives and have suffered increased tax.'

However, within most income groups, even the poorest, there are losers as well as winners. Among the poorest 10 per cent, for example, 2.9 per cent were more than £10 a week worse off. Among the richest, 1.7 per cent were more than £10 a week better off. Two-earner couples with children gain less than other types of families with children as they are least likely to benefit from the Working Families' Tax Credit and income support allowances, and are most likely to see the Children's Tax Credit withdrawn. Non-earning couples with children gain most: on average, £18.70 per week. According to the IFS's initial conclusions about the overall effect of last week's measures, the position of people towards the top end of the income scale - but not the wealthiest 10 per cent - will have improved. The improvement to pensioners' incomes results from increased age-related income tax allowances, increased income support, winter fuel allowances and retention of the Married Couple's Allowance for those born before 6 April 1935. On average, a single pensioner household has gained £6.10 and a pensioner couple £4.20 a week. Despite the obvious efforts the Chancellor has made to redirect resources, there are concerns about some of his set-piece changes. A strong theme has been a move towards increased means-testing, particularly for pensioners. The institute reckons that by 2003 the average single pensioner will gain £9.68 a week from the package of measures foreshadowed by the Chancellor in his November 2000 Pre-Budget Report, and confirmed last week. The average couple should pocket £11.05. The extra money comes from above-inflation rises in the basic state pension in 2001 and 2002; above-inflation rises in the means-tested Minimum Income Guarantee - which tops up the basic state pension in low-income pensioner households - in each of the next three years and, from April 2003, the new pension credit, designed to reward saving for poorer pensioners. By 2003 the average incomes of the poorest 10 per cent of pensioners should be up by more than 20 per cent, according to the IFS. Its researcher, Tom Clark, says: 'The Government is diverting significant extra resources to pensioners. But its basic strategy is still to extend means-testing.' The IFS fears that this could discourage younger people from saving. This view is supported by an Institute of Actuaries analysis, which concludes that means-testing leads to people who reach retirement with small savings having to pay high marginal tax rates. It also discriminates against women, because they are less inclined to claim for their entitlements yet are among the poorest pensioners. The actuaries conclude that means-testing and the poorer returns likely on money put aside for old age are 'likely to make saving for a pension considerably less attractive for increasing numbers of people'. They suggest that a higher basic state pension may be preferable to means-testing, as it would do more to encourage saving. The charity Age Concern, long opposed to means-testing, is continuing to campaign for a substantial increase in the basic state pension, and for it to go up in line with average earnings, rather than prices. There is concern, too, that reforms aimed at low-income families are missing their tar get. The National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux has criticised the Working Families Tax Credit, pointing out that some employers are refusing to employ people entitled to it because of the high cost of the the bureaucracy involved in paying the money. In one case a single parent was dismissed from her part-time job when WFTC had to be paid through her pay packet. Parents complain that once they receive the benefit it means they lose free school meals and help with rent and council tax. The Government's emphasis on lower-income groups seemed to be called into question 24 hours after last week's Budget by a report into poverty across Europe, which found that more than 5 million Britons are living at levels thought to exist only in the developing world. But poverty is concentrated among lone parents, where households may have missed out on the work-ori ented means-tested benefits Labour has introduced. Despite the shortcomings of some of these changes, their general thrust has been welcomed by the Child Poverty Action Group. Its director, Martin Barnes, says: 'In the last two years we have seen a fairly significant shift in resources towards poorer families with children.' Even if the Conservatives' claims about stealth taxes are exaggerated, there has been some pain for Middle England. Around 20 per cent more people are paying income tax at the 40 per cent tax rate now than when Labour came to office. This is mainly because earnings have risen more quickly than the higher-rate threshold. Accountant PricewaterhouseCooper points out that the starting rate is now barely one and a half times' average earnings. From the new tax year, someone earning just under £34,000 will be a higher-rate taxpayer. Yet an income like this probably wouldn't support a mortgage large enough for a flat in London; financial well-being isn't just about tax. Ian Brinkley, senior economist at the Trades Union Congress, says that, for the moment, means-testing is extending far enough up the income scale - higher rate taxpayers can get the Children's Tax Credit, for example - for it not to have become offensive. But Brinkley says: 'If you don't have universality [of benefits] will the middle classes get fed up? Will higher-rate taxpayers say, "Enough is enough. Why should I pay for universal benefits which I can't get?"' Middle England, as repre sented by teachers, nurses, policemen and other members of the salaried classes, may begin to wonder why people much higher up the income scale are being left relatively unscathed. Labour has not so far targeted the super-rich. Despite long-running rumours that such moves were coming, there has been no move to cut back on inheritance tax breaks, or higher rate relief on pension contributions. Such moves could, of course, upset the moderately well off as much as the super-rich. Patrick Stevens, tax partner at accountant Ernst & Young, agrees that a disproportionate amount of pain is probably being felt by people in the £12,000 to £30,000 a year income bracket. Someone earning £100,000 a year has experienced the same changes but will barely notice them. Middle-income earners have not benefited from the big gains in income seen by people in some industries, such as technology. 'A big chunk of people aren't going to do that [sort of thing] in their lives and have suffered increased tax.'

webTitle: Budget 2001: Savers

fields.headline: Savers find little to cheer
fields.trailText: It was trumpeted as a Budget for savers, with Chancellor Gordon Brown declaring he wanted to cut tax for all savers, especially pensioners. But the financial services experts have dubbed it a 'non-event for the savings industry'.
fields.body:
It was trumpeted as a Budget for savers, with Chancellor Gordon Brown declaring he wanted to cut tax for all savers, especially pensioners. But the financial services experts have dubbed it a 'non-event for the savings industry'.

'Where were all the goodies? It was a non-budget for investors and savers,' said Clive Scott-Hopkins of financial adviser Towry Law.

As expected, Brown confirmed he would be extending the £7,000 annual investment limit for Isas for another five years instead of reducing it to £5,000. Isa and Pep rules will also be harmonised, giving Pep investors greater freedom in investing their money.

Brown also announced he would be extending the 10p starting rate of income tax to the first £1,880 of earnings from next month, a move designed to put more money in people's pockets and act as a tax break on savings.

Savings are automatically taxed at 20 per cent, so hundreds of thousands of people will now be eligible to claim back half of the money that has been deducted at source.

However, the Building Societies Association says the tweak to the 10p tax band is likely to have a 'modest rather than massive' impact on the amount of money being saved.

Pensioners, part-time workers and people just starting work are most likely to benefit from the tax band change but all 25 million of the UK's taxpayers will find themselves slightly better off.

To apply to get back your 10 per cent tax, you need to fill in form R40, obtainable from your local tax office.

Savers due refunds on savings interest because they are 10 per cent taxpayers will not be able to reclaim half of the tax taken at source until the end of April 2002.

Only bank or building society interest which has been taxed can be reclaimed, not share dividends.

The extension of the 10p tax band from £1,520 to £1,880 will shave £36.60 a year off tax bills, equivalent to 70p a week.

So what exactly did the savings industry hope the Chancellor was going to pull out of the bag last Wednesday?

Scott-Hopkins was hoping for radical changes, such as a simplification of the Isa regime to allow the £7,000 allowance to be used in any way the investor wanted. Also on his wish list were reform of the rules that force people to buy an annuity at the age of 75.

Calls to cut or abolish stamp duty on small share purchases were ignored and there was also no mention of plans for a US-style scheme to encourage those on lower incomes to save more, although this was flagged before the Budget.

However, the Treasury has confirmed that it is still looking at this scheme, which would see money invested by the individual matched by a contribution from the state as long as it was earmarked for specific purposes.

webTitle: William Keegan: Overvalued, underplayed

fields.headline: Overvalued, underplayed
fields.trailText: 'This Government has also presided over a prolonged overvaluation of the pound, but so far the traditional consequences have been notable by their absence.'
fields.body:
It always helps to retain a sense of perspective on Budget Day. That evening I was the guest of Sir Donald MacDougall who, as part of a long and distinguished career, worked as an economic adviser to Winston Churchill during the Second World War. One of MacDougall's jobs was to keep down non-essential imports. We remember the effects well. The sight and taste of bananas after the war was an early sign that things were on the mend.

Later in his career, MacDougall invented what economists know as the 'J' curve - the statistical insight which demonstrates that, after a necessary devaluation, the trade balance tends to get worse before it gets better. This is because on the one hand the cost of imports rises immediately, swelling the import bill before higher prices have deterred importers from ordering so much, and on the other hand the immediate value of exports falls - although the idea is that, eventually, cheaper exports will raise the volume of orders and deliveries.

Past Labour governments have been almost routinely associated with financial and currency crises, stemming from balance-of-payments problems. Much of Gordon Brown's caution has sprung from the desire to avoid such crises, and so far he has been noticeably successful.

But the really interesting thing about Labour governments is not that they are associated with embarrassing devaluations but that they usually preside over prolonged periods of overvaluation of the currency, which then lead to embarrassing devaluations. This was the story of 1931, 1949, 1967 and 1976.

This Government has also presided over a prolonged overvaluation of the pound, but so far the traditional consequences have been notable by their absence.

This does not, however, mean they are not lying in waiting; indeed, almost everyone who thinks the pound should join the euro also seems to think that it can only sensibly do so after a serious devaluation.

This is a huge issue for policy in the next government; indeed, the question of the appropriate valuation of the pound is a major issue even if in the end this Government shies away from joining the single currency. But such policy issues barely rated a mention in the Budget speech, which was long on politics and very short on economic policy.

Insofar as the Chancellor took notice of the plight of our manufacturing sector, and especially the export sector, in his speech at all, he did so early on, when he said: 'I can also report that manufacturing - despite the euro-sterling exchange rate - grew last year by 1.6 per cent; manufacturing productivity grew by 4.4 per cent and manufacturing exports by 11.8 per cent; and it is to the credit of thousands of successful British companies that overall British exports grew by 7.4 per cent.'

He did not refer to imports in this passage, but they grew by almost 9 per cent. He did not say that a 1.6 per cent rise in manufacturing output is pathetic during a world boom, or that, despite the seemingly good export figure, we continued to lose market share.

Nor did he say that, during the previous decade, indus trial output in the UK grew by barely a tenth, compared with growth of a third in the US and a fifth in the eurozone.

The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development recently noted (about UK experience in the year 2000): 'Exports picked up, reflecting the dynamism of demand overseas, but market share erosion continued owing to strength of the pound, despite the compression of exporters' margins... On most estimates the pound remains overvalued. In this context, and given the vigour of domestic demand, import growth barely abated and the goods deficit widened to over 3 per cent of gross domestic product [at current prices].'

According to the OECD, the volume of merchandise imports rose at twice the rate of exports during the three years 1998-2000, and Britain's 'export performance' (the ratio between the total of export volumes and the size of export markets) deteriorated dramatically over those years.

The International Monetary Fund recently pointed out that between the first quarter of 1996 and the second quarter of 2000, 'sterling appreciated by almost 60 per cent in real effective terms'. Unit labour costs rose by 18 per cent between 1995 and 1998, compared with small declines in France and Germany over the same period. 'This sizeable increase in UK unit labour costs in manufacturing compounded the effect of the appreciation of the nominal exchange rate.'

The IMF refers to recent research from the Confederation of British Industry which indicates 'that many firms have shifted the supply-chain, sourcing overseas as a means of combating the rising cost base brought by the strength of sterling, thus raising imports and further widening the external deficit.'

The IMF comments: 'The side-effect of this phenomenon is the threat that it poses to firms further down the supply chain in those sectors, especially in terms of investment plans and long-term profitability.'

Our trading performance may have deteriorated sharply, but - the obverse of Sir Donald MacDougall's 'J' curve - the terms of trade (the ratio of export to import prices) 'improved' in 1999 and 2000 so that the impact on the trade balance was less than the underlying trend might suggest.

Even so, a table in the Budget Report shows that by last year we were running a deficit on our trade in goods and services of £18.5 billion. And, according to the Treasury's forecast, the deficit will deteriorate further in 2001, 2002 and 2003, reaching a cumulative £97bn over those three years.

How long the financial markets will be prepared to go on financing this country's endless appetite for living on tick at an overvalued exchange rate is an interesting question.

But such has been the Chancellor's good luck that it does not seem to have marred the rapturous reception for a Budget that hardly addressed such an important issue.

It worries MacDougall, who has experienced previous Labour government efforts to escape from potential currency crises via higher productivity (he was director-general of the Department of Economic Affairs in the Sixties) and knows how difficult such aims are to achieve.

At the age of 88 MacDougall has been conducting a correspondence in the Financial Times drawing attention to, among other things, the dangers of entering the euro at an overvalued exchange rate.

His serious concern about the exchange rate problem voiced last Wednesday evening at the Political Economy Club was a necessary antidote to the complacency surrounding the Budget.

webTitle: Budget 2001: Verdict on the story so far

fields.headline: Verdict on the story so far
fields.standfirst: The tax changes seem laudable, but those who need them most may not benefit
fields.trailText: The tax changes seem laudable, but those who need them most may not benefit.
fields.body:
Working families tax credit

 Introduced in October 1999 and aimed mainly at lower to middle-income homes with children.

 Means-tested and payable to lone parents and couples with at least one child and where at least one partner works 16 hours a week or more.

 The average tax credit awarded in February this year was £71 a week, against the £65 paid in family credit before it was withdrawn. Also offers extra credits for childcare.

Verdict: Generally welcomed by poverty campaigners but citizens' advice bureaux say some employers are getting rid of workers who need to claim through payrolls and that some recipients are losing other means-tested benefits because of increase in income from WFTC.

Children's tax credit

 To be introduced next month at a maximum rate of £10 a week.

 Payable to households with a child under 16. From April 2002, worth up to £20 a week in the year after the birth of a child.

 Parents must claim and 1 million have not.

Verdict: Worries that many of those eligible won't claim.

Minimum income guarantee

 A top-up to the basic state pension.

 Pensioners must claim

 MIG from April this year to be £92.15 for a single person (of which £72.50 will be basic state pension) and £140.55 for couples (£115.90 basic state pension).

Verdict: There was initial confusion and disappointment among pensioners that the MIG was not automatic. Around 600,000 are estimated to be eligible but not claiming.

Pensioners tax credit

 Due for introduction in 2003 to benefit people on MIG wit h modest savings, and some whose income is higher than MIG.

 Aim is to give extra state help to single people with incomes up to £135 and couples up to £200 a week. The credit will be worth 60p for every £1 of income from private pensions, savings or the state top-up pension Serps.

Verdict: Details have yet to be fleshed out but the scheme is criticised for its complexity. There are also fears that means testing will still discourage private saving.

Stakeholder pensions

 To be introduced next month for people without access to an employer's pension scheme, although they can also be used to top up saving with occupational schemes.

 Charges capped at 1 per cent a year with no transfer penalties.

 Lump sums of £3,600 (including tax relief) can be made in a year and payments can be made on behalf of a child or non working partner.

Verdict: Has forced insurers to cut charges on existing pensions, but there are doubts about whether the original target group - with incomes of between £10,000 and £20,000 - can afford to save in private pensions.

Individual savings accounts

 Up to £7,000 can be put tax free into a mixture of cash, stocks and shares and insurance-based funds.

 Limits on amounts that can be sheltered from tax lower than under the Tories Peps and Tessas.

Verdict: Scheme has proved popular, assisted by booming stock markets until last year. Sales are down this year. Increasingly recommended as an alternative to a pension, but jury is still out on whether people are putting money into an Isa in addition to what they would have put aside anyway.

webTitle: Budget 2001: Brown's budgets

fields.headline: Measure by measure
fields.standfirst: Brown's budgets 1997-2001
fields.trailText: Brown's budgets, 1997-2001.
fields.body:
1997

 19p tax rise on a packet of 20 cigarettes

 Beer up 1p a pint, wine 4p a bottle , spirits 19p a bottle, from 1 January

 4p a litre on petrol and diesel

 Stamp duty up to 1.5 per cent on properties over £250,000 and 2 per cent on those over £500,000

 Mortgage tax relief cut from 15 per cent to 10 per cent from April 1998

 Tax relief ends on over-60s' private health cover

 New individual savings account to replace personal equity plans and Tessas

 Pension funds no longer able to reclaim tax on dividends. The same to apply to charities and individuals from April 1999

1998

 21p on 20 cigarettes, from 1 December

 Beer up 1p a pint from 1 January; wine up 4p a bottle

 Petrol up 4.4p a litre for unleaded and 4.9p for leaded. Road tax to be cut for small cars the following year

 Married Couples Allowance to be cut from 15 per cent to 10 per cent in 1999

 Capital gains tax reform to help long-term investors

 Stamp duty on property up to 2 per cent for homes worth more than £250,000 and to 3 per cent for those over £500,000

 Plans for £50,000 cap on tax-free investments in Peps and Isas abandoned

 Working Families Tax Credit announced with a pledge that full-time workers with a family would have an income of at least £180 a week and no income tax on pay below £220 a week

 New Childcare Tax Credit to start in 1999, allowing working parents earning up to £30,000 to reclaim up to 70 per cent of costs, up to a maximum of £100 a week for first child and £150 for two or more

 Child benefit up £2.50 a week for the first child, from April 1999

1999

 New 10p lower rate of income tax to apply to first £1,500 of taxable income

 Children's Tax Credit to replace Married Couple s Allowance, but not until April 2001, a year after scrapping of allowance

 Mortgage interest tax relief to be abolished from April 2000

 17.5p tax on 20 cigarettes

 Petrol up 4.25p a litre for leaded; 3.79p on unleaded

 Car tax disc down by £55 to £100 for cars with smaller engines, but up by £5 to £155 for larger vehicles

 Stamp duty on home sales up 0.5 per cent to 2.5 per cent on purchase of property over £250,000 and by 3.5 per cent over £500,000

 Child benefit up by 60p to £15 a week for first child and by £10 for other children, but not until April 2000

 State pensioners' winter bonus up from £20 to £100

 Elderly people promised guaranteed minimum income through introduction of means-tested top-up to basic state pension. It will be £78 for single pensioners and £121 for couples. Figures to rise in line with earnings, rather than inflation

 Starting point for paying National Insurance raised from £64 a week to £66, but ceiling for levying NI raised from £485 to £500

2000

 Petrol up 2p a litre

 Cars up to 1,200cc to claim the £55 tax discount

 25p extra on 20 cigarettes.

 Stamp duty on property purchase up to 3 per cent on homes worth more than £250,000; 4 per cent on those over £500,000

webTitle: Budget 2001: Small business

fields.headline: Modest plus for small business
fields.trailText: If it wasn't an obviously generous Budget for small businesses, perhaps that should be counted good news.
fields.body:
If it wasn't an obviously generous Budget for small businesses, perhaps that should be counted good news.

'The last thing businesses want is a giveaway Budget, if it means interest rates are likely to go up,' says David Hands of the Federation of Small Businesses (FSB).

What the Budget did offer was simplification of accounting procedures, in particular for VAT and the tax treatment of small limited companies.

In addition to the increase in the threshold for VAT registration from £52,000 to £54,000, more companies are to be allowed to submit annual, rather than quarterly, VAT returns, and more will be allowed to calculate their VAT on a cash accounting basis, so that VAT is payable only when payment is received and not on the basis of sales invoices issued. Firms with a taxable turnover of less than £600,000 will be eligible for both these schemes.

The major VAT change proposed is for very small firms, with VAT turnover below £100,000, which will be permitted to pay VAT as a percentage of their turnover, avoiding the need to tot up each VAT transaction.

A more radical proposal is for tax to be levied on smaller limited companies (typically those with no more than 50 employees and a turnover below £2.8m) on the basis of the figures in the accounts.

There was a small concession for authors, composers and other 'creative artists', whose income fluctuates from year to year: they can now average profits over two consecutive years.

webTitle: Heather Connon: Wim predicts vim and vigour in Europe

fields.headline: Wim predicts vim and vigour in Europe
fields.trailText: Europe, according to its central bank president Wim Duisenberg, should enjoy another year of 'robust growth' and be relatively unaffected by a slowdown in the US economy.
fields.body:
Europe, according to its central bank president Wim Duisenberg, should enjoy another year of 'robust growth' and be relatively unaffected by a slowdown in the US economy. A number of fund managers seem to agree: Schroders and Credit Suisse Asset Management are among those predicting that the Continent could be a safe haven for investors in a difficult year.

The arguments do seem convincing. Economic growth is expected to slow from last year's 3.3 per cent, but economists are still expecting a healthy 2.5 per cent. Inflation is under control, unemployment is falling and consumers are feeling confident.

Of course, Europe will feel the effects of a US slowdown but, as Duisenberg points out, much European trade is with fellow members of the eurozone. Only 18 per cent of output is exported, and less than a sixth of that goes to the US. So, Europe may escape with a minor sniffle if the US catches a cold.

Some are worried that Duisenberg's confidence could start to look like complacency. But, as Threadneedle's William Davis points out, sentiment can be as important as hard numbers. And, among larger blue chips - the kind of companies that most European funds invest in - the US accounts for 20 per cent of sales. If the US slowdown deepens, sentiment across the world, not just Europe, could take a severe knock.

Nor is Europe uniformly buoyant - Germany was slowing faster than the US in the fourth quarter. Some worry that Duisenberg's optimism will mean he delays cutting interest rates.

Raj Shant, director of European equities at Credit Suisse, agrees that a delay in cutting interest rates would be bad news, but he believes Duisenberg is just following Britain's lead. 'A cut is an insurance policy against a US slowdown,' he says.

European economies and corporate profits were buoyant last year too, but that was not reflected in the stock markets: the average European ex-UK fund has fallen 14 per cent over the last year, according to Micropal. Shant believes that European companies are less exposed to the problems of over investment and stock build-up, which is producing a wave of profit warnings in the US.

What should private investors make of Europe? Provided Duisenberg is not too dilatory in cutting interest rates, the economic outlook is undoubtedly better than elsewhere.There is no reason to rush into the market - by waiting three months or so, you could pick up a better bargain.

webTitle: Budget analysis: At least he didn't take a penny off

fields.headline: At least he didn't take a penny off
fields.standfirst:
William Keegan on the case for tax and spend

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: William Keegan on the case for tax and spend.
fields.body:
He can be very stimulating and amusing when he wants to be, but Gordon Brown has resoundingly succeeded in his self-imposed task of boring the country into submission. The Chancellor surpassed himself in last week's Budget speech, setting records for the sheer speed of his delivery of worthy but tedious measures, many of which belonged in written technical annexes.

It all reminded one of Beachcomber's List of Huntingdonshire Cabmen. Only the latter seems in retrospect to have had a certain air of excitement about it. A Roy Jenkins or a Nigel Lawson would have choked with laughter as detail followed detail. Perhaps in retirement the Chancellor should go on the stage and give readings from Yellow Pages.

It may be one's imagination, but the general impression is that much of the sense of occasion has disappeared from the Budget. Indeed, it was difficult to find people last Wednesday who knew there was going to be a Budget at all. Perhaps this was all part of the Chancellor's long-term strategy: it may be that the goal of elimination of the 'boom and bust' requires the elimination of the Budget itself. It is, after all, the Budget ritual which most reminds people of past booms and busts.

The Chancellor has got the art of repeating measures and phrases down to a fine art. By reiterating 'stability', 'a balanced approach' and 'the need to avoid boom and bust' he has perfected the political art of not answering any question that is inconvenient. It is a breathtakingly successful technique, and Brown seldom stops for breath when answering, or not answering, questions.

The 'balanced approach' - of public spending increases but also tax cuts - is confirmation that, even now, the Government is only frolicking in the margins of any plan it may have to alter the ground rules it inherited after 18 years in the wilderness. There is no sign of any major attempt to raise tax and spending plans to continental levels.

Labour's recent conversion to the cause of higher public sector investment in education, health and transport is certainly welcome; but it comes terribly late. The Government has wasted most of its first term summoning up courage to do the things it was elected for in 1997.

This is an awfully long time. The Second World War was two-thirds over after four years. It would have been a tragedy if, after all that, Labour had then lost the election. Fortunately for the Government, however, the Conservatives are doing everything to ensure another resounding Labour victory.

It is certainly an achievement for a Labour Government to have managed to survive four years without a financial crisis. But it is an achievement won at some cost to the nation's quality of life. And judgment has to be suspended on whether the Chancellor will succeed in his longer-term aims of raising the nation's economic growth rate and narrowing inequality.

Welcome though they are, measures to help the poor, when they penetrate the bureaucratic machinery of means tests, do not seem to have narrowed the gap that much.

If there is any sign that all is not yet lost in Labour's battle with its conscience and the Daily Mail, it is in the fact that the Chancellor eschewed the opportunity to lower the basic rate of tax by another penny, choosing more socially oriented measures instead. This is only a straw in the wind, but it was interesting to note how many people thought before the Budget that he would not be able to resist the headline '1p off'.

Which brings us to the widespread misunderstanding about the Budget and all those surpluses. Many people seem to assume that, if the Chancellor has a surplus, he should spend it (or give it back). This view is often held by people whose first reaction to the thought of a recession is: 'That means the Chancellor will not be able to afford spending increases, and will have to raise taxes.'

This is all most unKeynesian. Keynes's great contribution was to point out that hoarding can damage your health, and that if you are in a hole you should not dig deeper. He advocated public spending rises to get out of recessions; this approach was later developed to include tax cuts as well, the point being that once the economy gets going, the revenues flow in anyway.

The revenue point has been well illustrated in recent years. As the Institute for Fiscal Studies has said, most of the Chancellor's extra revenues (leaving aside the mobile phone auction) have flowed from higher indirect taxes as a result of economic growth (helped, until recently, by the fuel tax 'escalator'). 'Stealth' taxes have made a small contribution.

The books have benefited from the Chancellor's acceptance of a public spending freeze that even its original author, Kenneth Clarke, says he would have dumped.

But when the economy is forecast to expand at around its long-term potential of 2.5 per cent a year, to have rained down the surplus on voters would have risked serious action from the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) to prevent domestic demand getting out of hand. The recent fiscal surplus has been the counterpart of low saving by the public, as consumer spending has remained strong. All this may change if the US slowdown causes serious damage in Europe; but last week it was not obvious that the UK needed a huge batch of tax cuts to keep the economy moving.

Apart from anything else, there was already a lot of fiscal expansion in the pipeline from previously announced measures.

Indeed there would be less confusion if the Treasury ceased announcing so many of its plans so far in advance, not to say the other irritating practice of reannouncing them as new.

The real danger the Chancellor risks on the fiscal side is, to coin a phrase, going from bust to boom. He saw his long period of fiscal austerity as the necessary - though very unKeynesian - way of gaining credibility so that he could then spend. Now, ironically, the International Monetary Fund and other European governments are criticising him for fiscal profligacy, although if you take the recent period of austerity and the plans for growth together, the cumulative effect is hardly sensational.

Until the US slowdown brought a new factor into the MPC's calculations, there was a real worry that the continued high consumer demand and planned boost to public sector investment might provoke the MPC into raising interest rates.

That is not what an ambitious Chancellor wants before an election. In a funny way Brown has been saved, for now, by the US setback.

webTitle: Scandal of the Treasury and a missing £10bn

fields.headline: Very flash, Gordon - but  it's not nearly enough
fields.standfirst:
Scandal of the Treasury and a missing £10bn shows up the need for real public investment

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Scandal of the Treasury and a missing £10bn shows up the need for real public investment.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's fifth budget was received rapturously - something for everybody within an economy that is set fair. And by again using the Budget to raise public spending while targeting tax cuts on the most needy, the Chancellor emphasised a control of the political agenda that the Tories find hard to counter.

Labour's emerging political narrative is governing to serve the public interest. It is persuasive, effective and right.

But while the Chancellor is showing his mastery of public finances, it does not yet extend to the warp and woof of the economy in the way he would like. Brown's attachment to economic stability is not an end in itself; he sees it as a means to lift productivity, wages and thus the condition of ordinary people. By that yardstick, his chancellorship has been a failure.

Britain's productivity gap with its competitors has if anything widened under his watch; R&D spending as a proportion of GDP has fallen; and while business investment may have climbed, public investment has slumped. A successful second-term Labour government will need to be seen not only to have made a substantial impact on the delivery of public services and the quality of the public infrastructure - it will need to see the rate of productivity growth and British innovation pick up if it is to satisfy its own targets.

Brown and his team know this but, so far, they have pulled their punches. The classic example is how public investment has fallen away, which Brown masked in his Budget speech.

For the second year running, government departments have succeeded in spending none of the extra cash allocated to them, so that a £5 billion underspend in the last financial year has been followed by a similar underspend this year; cumulatively a £10bn capital investment that should have been made but has not.

If a failure to commit investment on this scale had been made in any private-sector organisation there would have been uproar; the non-executive directors would have asked increasingly tough questions of the chief executive, finance and production directors - and heads would have rolled.

In Government, there seems blithe indifference. The Chancellor should have offered an explanation in his Budget speech. There should have been an account of why the recent dearth of capital investment has not been succeeded by a splurge as departments use both two years of underspend and next year's budgeted increase simultaneously. Instead, silence reigns.

The inside story is that officials are being more careful to bring forward investment projects that are coherent, and this is time-consuming. In any case, there is less urgency because, under new fiscal rules, cash underspent in one year is simply carried forward to the next.

This is only part of the story. It is not difficult for projects to be specified and put out to tender; each department nurses schemes that it has wanted to implement for years - so it should not take two years to get them under way.

No, the reason for the underspend is that the Government wants its investment projects 'market-tested' to see if they could be done either wholly or partly by the private sector via the private finance initiative (PFI) or a public private partnership (PPP). The result is that new investment is being paralysed.

Sometimes, as in the railways, the investment is stymied because Railtrack, the privatised operators and the Strategic Rail Authority have been unable to get to the first base of agreeing priorities. In other areas, like the NHS, chief executives know that to protect their careers they should only try to finance investment conventionally in the public sector as a last resort. New Labour only rewards those who pull off deals with the private sector.

If Brown wants change, he needs to impose deadlines on how long public-sector managers can spend faffing around with PPPs and PFIs before they get on with it. He should introduce an incentive system which rewards those who act rather than those who delay.

There are now three permanent secretaryships vacant in the Department for Education and Employment, the DTI and the Home Office. Blair and Brown should ensure the vacancies are filled by those with a track record of delivery.

This demands a lead being given from the top, and it also implies a less ideological approach to advancing public investment. What matters is what works.

The enormously complex PPP for the London Underground has taken four years even to approach the starting blocks, and still needs major redesign before it is acceptable; four years of appalling travel conditions that could have been avoided.

The Treasury has plenty of economists who can write papers about the efficiency savings in theory from PPPs and PFIs, but I have yet to see one calculation that adds the cost of delay to the overall price of the PPP or PFI contract. Be sure that when the DETR finally does its public-sector comparator tests on the London Underground to see that it represents value for money, the four years of suffering experienced by London travellers will be written out of the script.

This lack of practicality has its roots in the ideological Treasury view that all public enterprise is by definition inefficient while all private enterprise is necessarily efficient. This view is hard to square with the British private sector's endemically poor record on productivity. The Chancellor identified the short-term, disengaged attitude of British institutional investors as a major cause of low business innovation and poor company performance - and set up a review under Paul Myners, head of the investment management company Gartmore and chairman of the Guardian Media Group (which owns The Observer).

In essence, Myners argued that the herd-like behaviour of Britain's investment community was due to the behaviour of pension funds, which own most shares. They lack confidence and professionalism in the way their trusteeship is discharged, he said, and if that was remedied they would take a longer-term view and set fewer absurd benchmarks for investment performance.

There should be a new professionalism with properly paid trustees, and pension funds should incorporate the American-style duty to intervene directly in under-performing companies in their statement of investment principles. Brown accepted the Myners Review completely.

This may be useful at the margins, but it fails to go to the root of the problem: the competitive dynamics of the investment management business rewards those who treat companies as commodities to be traded rather than business organisations that require to be husbanded - and that is as true in the US as it is in Britain.

What the Government should have done was to undertake its ongoing review of Company Law in tandem with Myners and produced a root and branch overhaul of the way the entire system operates. Myners wants to professionalise pension fund trusteeship within an unreformed system of company law, which is fine as far as it goes. But the real task is to professionalise ownership rather than allow it to be degraded into something akin to gambling.

This is not the sole route to raising British productivity, but it is the necessary precondition. Brown has established a robust framework for economic management under which the economy has performed well. He has put public finances on their firmest footing for 40 years. He has set a new economic agenda in which public spending matters more than blanket tax cuts. He has launched an innovative array of social policies that have improved the conditions of the poorest. But he is ambitious to go the last step, and decisively raise investment and productivity.

If he achieves this, he really will deserve the accolade of being a great Chancellor - but unless he applies the same single-mindedness and application in this area as he has in the rest, it may elude him.

webTitle: Trains and brains would put Britain on the right track

fields.headline: Trains and brains would put Britain on the right track
fields.standfirst:
Richard Freeman on ways to close the productivity gap

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Richard Freeman on ways to close the productivity gap.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown justifiably proud of his prudent stewardship of the British economy when he presented his pre-election Budget last week.

The Government's achievements are real. Inflation is negligible, thanks in part to his early delegation of responsibility for interest rates to the Bank of England and its Monetary Policy Committee. The proportion of the adult population in work is well above the EU average. Economic stability has replaced the stop-go cycles of the past 50 years.

The UK ranks among the top handful of economies in terms of how its market-friendly policies have affected economic outcomes. By most measures, it is just behind the US and way ahead of Germany or France. Its product markets are the least regulated of all the economies in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, compared with sixth place for Germany and fourteenth for France.

The Fraser Institute's index of 'economic freedom' ranks the UK in fifth place (Germany 22, France 24) and the Heritage Foundation's equivalent puts it seventh in the world (Germany 20, France 39). It is easier to form a new business in the UK than in almost any other advanced country.

You may have thought that the combination of macro-stability and 'supply side' reforms would have put the UK among the top advanced countries in productivity and standards of living. At a minimum, the reforms of the past two decades should have lifted the country in the league tables of output per head and per person. But it has not.

In 1980, before Margaret Thatcher started her programme of pro-free market reforms, the UK was ranked number 15 among advanced countries in per capita GDP. Twenty years later it was at 17. Productivity per employee and per hour are still 20-30 per cent below the US, Germany, or France. GDP per employee is 26 years behind the US, 12 years behind France, and nine years behind Germany. The UK is no longer falling behind these countries, but it has barely gained on them.

So the big economic question Brown has to face is what can be done to close the productivity gap and create an economy where living standards can rise more rapidly.

A policy that relies on still more liberation of market forces - more privatisation, more market deregulation, yet lower tax rates - is unlikely to do the trick for two reasons. First, so much has already been done in making the UK market-friendly that the return on further moves in the same direction will be increasingly marginal.

Second, more private ownership does not by itself guarantee greater economic efficiency. On average, private markets are better at allocating resources than the state, but not in all cases.

For the UK to move up the economic league tables, the next government will have to develop policies that advance beyond the now orthodox 'free market' mantra. Here are some suggestions:

 The Government must improve the UK's infrastructure and bring the performance of public services up to world standards. Anyone who uses UK public transport knows that it is a barrier to productivity. Workers who spend hours travelling to work under appalling conditions cannot possibly be as productive as they could be with a proper public transport system.

Most UK privatisations have improved economic performance. Rail privatisation has not. Rethink this one fast, Messrs Blair and Brown. If the Tube becomes the next decade's Railtrack, we are all in big trouble.

 Analyses of the productivity gap between British and German workers show that 20-30 per cent of it results from UK workers having lower skills. This is particularly marked in the bottom half of the skill distribution.

Measures such as literacy and numeracy hours in schools have improved primary school performance, but in the long run it will be difficult to improve education without improving the quality of teachers; and difficult to improve teachers without raising pay. Raising productivity involves more than just investing in human and physical capital. The best companies motivate and reward their workers in ways that give them a personal stake in improved performance.

Brown's Treasury has developed tax policies that encourage the granting of options or shares to workers and for them to hold those shares for extended periods. The TUC has developed a partnership strategy to help firms raise productivity, including the creation of a new Partnership Institute to consult with unionised companies and unions on ways to improve productivity. No other trade union movement has taken such a bold step. These efforts should be expanded to target companies with low productivity.

 Historically, one of the UK's great weaknesses has been its failure to adopt and exploit new advances in science and technology, even though it has often pioneered them. While Brown was much mocked for once talking in public about 'endogenous growth theory', in fact encouraging the development and use of science is critical for a premier league economy.

In 2000, the UK Government increased public investment in the nation's science infrastructure, boosted research in key areas and gave top scientists more pay. There needs to be more targeting of public research and development support in terms of sectors or specific technologies. This targeting should be based on the economic potential of the R&D just as much as on its scientific potential.

 The US, Canada and Australia all view immigration policy in terms of increasing the supply of skilled workers and thus increasing economic growth. The US grants visas to people in occupations in short supply. Germany is introducing a programme to bring in software engineers. Canada makes a person's occupation a key element in immigration policy. The UK should look upon its attractiveness to immigrants as a comparative advantage.

There is a triple litmus test that should be applied to policy initiatives of this kind. First, they must not put at risk what has been achieved in terms of economic stability and flexible markets, because those achievements are a necessary, though not a sufficient, condition for higher productivity.Second, they should be conceived on a large enough scale to matter in an economy the size of the UK's, but they should begin modestly and be geared up only after there is evidence that they are working. Government (and private) programmes that make a splash by starting big risk failing big. Third, they must be promoted and judged pragmatically, not ideologically. The Thatcherite legacy of 'public sector bad, private sector good' is damaging.

An economy that is in the top ranks in terms of economic stability and market freedoms has nothing to fear from well designed policy ini tiatives that seek to guide, augment or reinforce. Without such initiatives, the UK will not make it to the top of the league tables in productivity and living standards.

 Richard Freeman is co-director of the Centre for Economic Performance at the LSE and Ascherman Professor of Economics at Harvard.

webTitle: 'Give us the chance to run rail network,' says National Express

fields.headline: 'Give us the chance to run rail network,' says National Express
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Train operators must take over the day-to-day running and maintenance of large parts of the national network from Railtrack, leading industry figures told The Observer this weekend.
fields.body:
Train operators must take over the day-to-day running and maintenance of large parts of the national network from Railtrack, leading industry figures told The Observer this weekend.

Widespread frustration at Railtrack's weakness and the industry's lack of strategic direction are set to boil over tomorrow into calls for a major shake-up.

Richard Brown, chief executive of Britain's largest train operator, National Express, will call for passenger franchisees to take charge of the track and signals from Railtrack. They would form a single organisation to invest in and manage the infrastructure as well as the trains in many areas.

The Rail Passengers Council watchdog will chime in, urging that Railtrack be split into regional chunks, with operators and local government representatives given seats on each of the boards.

Railtrack would still own the assets, avoiding renationalisation or fresh legislation, but, after agreement on spending and quality targets, would be kept at arm's length, giving unprecedented power to operators to control the railway on 20-year contracts.

Brown will advocate the plan for Scotland, Wales, East Anglia and parts of the South-East, where the network is least complex and where National Express runs some of its nine franchises.

'We want fewer, larger, stronger organisations,' he said. He added that it was necessary to 'narrow down' Railtrack's 'huge' task of running, fixing and expanding the network and urged the Strategic Rail Authority to speed up reorganisation.

His proposals will be launched tomorrow as part of a campaign by lobbying group Transport 2000, debating the future of the industry.

webTitle: Tube deal rests on safety issues

fields.headline: Tube deal rests on safety issues
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Intense negotiations between the Government and Bob Kiley aimed at reaching a settlement on the London Underground now hinge on who controls the maintenance of the Tube system.
fields.body:
Intense negotiations between the Government and Bob Kiley aimed at reaching a settlement on the London Underground now hinge on who controls the maintenance of the Tube system.

In what has been described as 'the deal breaker', it is understood that, if maintenance is handed over to Kiley, the transport commissioner appointed by London Mayor Ken Livingstone, a deal will be struck. Otherwise, Livingstone will carry out his threat to take the Government to court.

A resolution to this one remaining issue is expected early this week.

Livingstone this weekend told The Observer: 'Bob Kiley has informed me that he cannot accept any agreement which will leave open the Hatfield scenario. That is, he must be able to control the maintenance of the system. If this issue can be agreed, I believe, on the information I have available, that most of the other matters can be resolved.'

A spokesman for John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister, said: 'Talks are at an advanced stage. They're on-going. We're hoping to reach agreement soon.'

Kiley is concerned that without controlling maintenance, a Hatfield-style disaster could be repeated below London's streets. His stance was vindicated last week by a government safety report which warned that 69 'significant issues' had to be addressed on the Government's proposed Public Private Partnership for the Underground.

The vexed safety issue prompted the Tube's biggest union, the RMT, to vote by a seven-to-one majority to strike on 29 March.

Private consortium bidders, meanwhile, are still concerned that any new remodelling of the controversial PPP may be 'unworkable'. 'If we're borrowing huge amounts of money to do our business, we need to be in charge,' said one.

Insiders believe the Government will stump up more cash to bidders, who could, under new Treasury proposals, see Kiley replace their chief executives, set a timetable for infrastructure improvements and replace other key staff .

For four years, the Government's attempt to force its PPP model through has been opposed by most Londoners.
