webTitle: Slipping through the net

fields.headline: Slipping through the net
fields.trailText: 'I can't believe I let myself be nagged into allowing the children to have their own Hotmail addresses.'
fields.body:
I can't believe I let myself be nagged into allowing the children to have their own Hotmail addresses, but needless to say they are up here every five minutes in the bijou workspace formerly known as mine, expecting me to wait out on the landing while they sit around fine-tuning the unprofitable e-businesses they have somehow set up under my nose offering services arising from their undeniable mastery of lolling about in front of a Nintendo all day and sending hilarious fart soundfiles to friends they have just spent all morning talking to on the phone.

The eldest sticks his head out. 'Dad, what does "Empty entire cache" mean?'

'I don't know, but whatever it is, don't do it,' I snap. 'And hurry up .'

'Oh yeah right,' he's saying, 'and how am I supposed to hurry up when I don't even know what to do? Maybe if I just...'

I rush in and wrestle him out of my swivel chair before he manages to pull the plug out and everything goes gurgling round the U-bend again, to use a metaphor best suited to my understanding of computer science. The fact is, I am hysterically fearful for the health of my mischievously marketed 'just get behind the wheel and drive' iMac, which imploded a few weeks ago while I was in the middle of downloading some important Elvis Costello lyrics, thus obliging me to call out an emergency husband-and-wife team of flying computer doctors who then spent five hours using magic software designed to piece together the virtual smithereens of my hard disk and in the process rake through all my long-deleted (or so I thought) emails, the sensitively handled bedroom scene from my forthcoming (July, actually) novel about a blameless northern journalist who accidentally exchanges bodily fluids with someone he isn't married to, and pages of internet idlings that on the face of things seem not exactly to betoken a man 100 per cent occupied in arduous employment.

'This is how Gary Glitter got caught!' says John, who is the husband part of the unnecessarily cheerful doctoring team scrolling so quickly through the names of every website I have ever visited that I don't quite get the chance to explain how I came to hit upon the 'Hot Baps' er, organic bread home delivery service, or retell the hilarious story of how I keyed in 'Bygones' - the Victorian museum in Torquay - and ended up with 'Big Ones' instead. Ha-ha-ha-ha-ha! Rarely have I laughed so uncontrollably in a situation that could only be brought to an end with the presentation of a large bill, since which moment I have been anxious not to have my expensive new innards clogged up with rubbish that has not even the distinction of being of my own making.

The eldest comes clattering back up the stairs, with the other three in tow. 'Dad, how can we get a video off the internet?'

'Not possible,' I say.

They give me a list of 14 schoolchums who have done the not possible. I explain that the reason it is not possible is that they'll have to get past me first, which I admit is a rash challenge since three of them boast yellow belts in karate while I only have a bad back and a certificate commemorating the day I swam two widths of our local non-Olympic-sized municipal pool in 1964.

My wife chooses this moment to shout up from the kitchen and remind me that the subject of today's cruel irony is that she is about to gambol off delightedly to her IT training course, which is the first strand of a reskilling money-disposal programme designed to free her from the tyranny of teaching and create exciting, flexible opportunities in who knows - online shopping perhaps! I give the children a stern warning and pop down to warm the little one's milk and in the process break two of my wife's favourite rules by standing in full view of the neighbours eating spaghetti from the pan using my fingers. I get back upstairs to find that my computer alert message has been changed from a pleasant pipe-organ effect to a loud 'Oi, what do you think you're doing!' The answer to which is, of course, I've no idea.

webTitle: The Networker: Surfers give advertisers a good click in the teeth

fields.headline: Surfers give advertisers a good click in the teeth
fields.trailText: 'The advertising industry, bless its white cotton socks, remains baffled by the internet. This is partly because - despite its image - advertising is a deeply conservative business.'
fields.body:
The advertising industry, bless its white cotton socks, remains baffled by the internet. This is partly because - despite its image - advertising is a deeply conservative business. It has grown fat mainly by feasting on push media, and is therefore completely thrown by a pull medium such as the net, where the consumer is absolutely in charge - choosing what to look at, download or skip.

The first business model for advertising on the net was the 'eyeballs' one, based on the notion that if you could attract millions of surfers to a site, it ought to be possible to sell advertising space on its pages.

Thus was born the banner ad - that block of 468 by 60 pixels which now infests the commercial web. The theory was that visitors would see the banner, click on it and instantly be transferred to the website of the advertiser's client. In doing so they would leave a digital trail, providing online advertisers with a Unique Selling Proposition: namely that, for the first time in commercial history, they would have comprehensive empirical data on the effectiveness of their product.

The technology delivered everything that was expected of it. Surfers came, saw, and a few clicked through. Web servers logged the clicks and sent invoices, and advertisers pondered the effectiveness of banner ads. What they discovered was not comforting. For it transpired that web users abhor banner ads. Some even download software which automatically blocks ads. And of those who endured the pestilence, very few clicked through to the site advertised.

For a time, these sobering realities were obscured by the Internet bubble, when dotcom companies burned uncon scionable amounts of money on futile advertising, and by arcane practices borrowed from the porn industry such as 'click-through farming' (funnelling clicks to particular sites). But in the end, the story told by the web-logging software could not be denied: less than 0.5 per cent of visitors click on a banner ad.

The conclusion is that banner ads are less effective than other media, such as hoardings and billboards, on which advertisers spends billions of dollars annually. But, as a media expert told the Financial Times last week: 'Nobody says a poster campaign is useless because 99 per cent of people who drove past it didn't stop their car, read it and take the message in.'

The truth is that online banner ads are judged a failure simply because they come with a performance measure that other advertising media cannot offer. Nobody knows how to measure the effectiveness of offline advertising with that kind of precision. And if they did, perhaps they would come to even more pessimistic conclusions about it.

Having decided that banner ads don't work, the advertising industry is tooling up to produce new kinds of online ads which will be even less effective. According to the Internet Advertising Bureau, the new standards for 'interactive media units' include a 600x120 pixel 'Skyscraper' on the left-hand side of the screen and a 600x160 pixel 'wide Skyscraper', not to mention a 250x250 pixel in-your-face 'Square Pop Up'.

You do not have to be a rocket scientist to predict what will happen when these new 'interactive media units' start to consume our bandwidth. Stand by for a stampede to sites offering ad-blocking software, such as AdWiper, AdSubtract, Adfilter, Guidescope, Webwasher and the magnificently titled Internet Junkbuster Proxy.

The advertising industry will then retreat again to its intellectual laager, convinced that this Internet lark will never catch on - leaving the field open for the first agency that has the imagination to work with the grain of the Net and the creativity to devise advertising genres which intrigue rather than irritate their target audiences.

webTitle: How search turned to destroy

fields.headline: How search turned to destroy
fields.standfirst:
Yahoo is now valued at a tenth of the $100bn it was worth at the height of the dotcom boom. As key staff leave in droves, the world's second favourite online site may need to be sold, says Jamie Doward

More net news
fields.trailText: Yahoo is now valued at a tenth of the $100bn it was worth at the height of the dotcom boom. As key staff leave in droves, the world's second favourite online site may need to be sold, says Jamie Doward.
fields.body:
Thomssi was still not convinced. A day trader, he spent most of Thursday lounging around one of Yahoo's financial chat rooms swapping idle gossip. Ironically, most of last week's gossip was about Yahoo, the internet portal now valued at a tenth of the $100 billion it was worth at the peak of the dotcom boom.

Another trader, who went by the handle Coolguy, believed the internet company's share price was due for a rebound. Things couldn't really get much worse, Coolguy figured.

But Thomssi was dubious. 'I still think it's better looking for value in traditionals for the next six months,' was his sober assessment.

Thomssi may be proved right. As the chat rooms hummed with gossip about the world's second favourite online site - the Yahoo portal is visited by nearly 200 million unique users a month - the company's share price ticked ever lower.

It could go further south in the coming weeks. Even Thomssi's professional counterparts over on Wall Street are struggling to find anything positive to say about the business.

After all, this was a company that last week hit the markets with a devastating triple whammy. Revenues, the California-based firm was forced to admit, would be between $170 million and $180m for the latest quarter, compared with an analysts' consensus of $240m.

On the back of the dreadful earnings figures, Tim Koogle, the company's race car-driving, guitar-strumming chief executive, announced he was stepping down, although he would stay on as chairman.

Then, in a lamentable attempt to woo the market, Yahoo unveiled a $500m share buy-back plan. Nonplussed analysts pointed out this would represent only about 5 per cent of the company's outstanding shares based on its current price - hardly enough to have an effect.

'What a difference eight weeks makes,' noted heavyweight Merrill Lynch analyst Henry Blodget, a man whose sparkling predictions for the dotcom sector have spectacularly and repeatedly failed to materialise. Blodget, at the start of this year a buyer of Yahoo, has now gone cold on the stock, noting that 'Yahoo's business has deteriorated significantly... with the market for online advertising falling off a cliff'.

Dotcom companies are Yahoo's biggest headache. As market sentiment has shifted away from them, they have pared back their online ad spend. Merrill Lynch estimates that the dotcom sector was responsible for 33 per cent of Yahoo's revenues in the fourth quarter of last year but will represent only 20 per cent this quarter.

This might not be as worrying as it sounds. Jeffrey Mallett, Yahoo's brash and combative president, has been keen to cut revenues generated by dotcom firms to 15 per cent by the end of the year. But not everyone is convinced Yahoo is well-positioned to grow revenues from the old bricks and mortar world. For a start, fears of a US slowdown have caused companies to cut their ad budgets.

And those companies that are still spending are suspicious of Yahoo. In the past the company, despite its seemingly laid-back West Coast persona, has liked to play hardball, negotiating directly with businesses rather than using the big advertising houses to help forge long-standing relationships.

For a while the approach worked, simply because the ad agencies were slow to embrace the net. But as the markets slide Yahoo may wish it had started to develop closer relationships with its clients much earlier.

It might also have wished that in the past it had been a bit more flexible when negotiating with them. Its heavy-handed manner has left many ill-disposed to Yahoo at a time when it needs friends.

Most alarming of all, the number of unique users has not grown by nearly as much as analysts were hoping. The likes of Blodget were, until recently, suggesting that Yahoo would be capable of drawing in 500 million unique users a month in five to seven years' time.

But in January the company announced that user traffic was up only 3 per cent to 185 million visitors, compared with 180 million in December. Wall Street had been hoping for a 12 per cent rise.

As the company's fortunes slide, there's a growing and damaging suspicion that Yahoo's management team is losing the plot, divided over whether the company should put up a For Sale sign.

Yahoo has been fiercely keen to stay independent since it was founded in 1994 by two Stanford University students, Jerry Yang and David Filo. But it seems that someone high in Yahoo is keen to cut a deal. Disney is certainly interested in the portal. Michael Eisner, its chief executive, has said as much, provided the price was right. Viacom is mentioned as a possible stalking horse. Vivendi Universal wants some sort of relationship.

Some even punt the idea that ever-hungry Vodafone might fancy it. But Yahoo, not to mention its rivals, is split on whether the move would make sense.

'Do they need to do a deal? I'm not convinced. They remain a strong player in the market,' said Alex Kovach, managing director of Lycos UK.

There are also suggestions that Koogle, Yang and Mallett are split over future strategy. Mallett is keen to remove Yahoo's reliance on advertising revenues by diversifying. He has plans to develop its e-commerce arm as well as its web-conferencing businesses, turning it into much more of a business to business player.

Others within Yahoo appear cautious. What is irrefutable, though, is that the jury has yet to make up its mind on whether Yahoo can make such a leap, and the markets are not known for patience. Further acquisitions to help spread the company's portfolio of interests are effectively ruled out by the slide in Yahoo's share price.

Despite its collapse, Yahoo's shares are still valued at 39 times earnings, compared with an average 21 for US equities. Or, to put it another way, it still has a long way to fall if it continues to disappoint. Such concerns seem to have given rise to something of a bunker mentality at Yahoo's Santa Clara HQ. In a bid to preserve cash and weather the bad times, the company, which declined to talk to The Observer , now seems to be focusing on its US operations at the expense of Europe and Asia.

In short, critics say as its fortunes have slumped, Yahoo has taken its eye off becoming a global player. This is perhaps understandable. As one senior executive with a rival portal put it: 'When you're up to your arse in alligators, it's hard to remember your objective was to drain the swamp.'

Disgruntled by the way the parent company was refusing to invest in its operations outside the US, the managing director of Yahoo Europe, Fabiola Arredondo - recently voted the most powerful European businesswoman - quit last month. 'Yahoo seems to have been struggling with investment in international expansion recently and this is no doubt what has been frustrating Fabiola,' said Judy Gibbons, vice president of Microsoft MSN Europe.

Time was MSN could only look on in awe as Yahoo grew. But by November it had 230 million unique users, overtaking Yahoo. Now the company's diminishing place in the world, which so frustrated Arredondo, has sparked an exodus.

Within a couple of days of Arredondo's departure, Yahoo's Asian head Savio Chow threw in the towel. Earlier this month Mark Rubinstein, managing director of Yahoo's Canadian operations, joined the exit club. He is unlikely to be the last: other executives are said to be contemplating the departure lounge. Will the last one to leave Santa Clara please turn out the lights...

From Yahoo! to dotcom hell

1994

Stanford graduates David Filo and Jerry Yang develop the! search engine for their own amusement. By the end of the year the portal has hundreds of thousands of visitors.

1995

Filo and Yang persuade Tim Koogle to become chief executive. Yahoo has enough cash to last a further six weeks.

1996

Investment giant Softbank takes stake. Yahoo goes public, launches in Japan, Europe.

1999

Yahoo radio launched. Buys GeoCities for $3.7 billion and broadcast.com for $5bn.

November 2000

Microsoft MSN overtakes Yahoo! as the biggest portal. French court orders Yahoo to stop French users from buying Nazi memorabilia on its auction site.

2001 January

Yahoo Europe predicts a sharp slowdown in online advertising growth. Koogle tells an audience in Davos that dotcom firms have given away too much content for free in a desperate bid to grab market share.

February

Fabiola Arredondo, Yahoo Europe's managing director, and Savio Chow, head of Yahoo Asia, quit.

March

Yahoo draws up emergency plans to prevent a hostile takeover. Koogle announces he is to step down as chief executive. Company warns earnings for current quarter will disappoint. Share price drops below $30 from a high of $205.

webTitle: MG Rover faces £300m loss

fields.headline: MG Rover faces £300m loss
fields.standfirst:
New fear for carmaker's future | Independence in doubt | Bosses insist recovery is on track

Special report: Britain's car industry
fields.trailText: New fear for carmaker's future | Independence in doubt | Bosses insist recovery is on track
fields.body:
Rescued carmaker MG Rover is preparing to announce losses of £300 million for the first eight months of its independent operation.

This is significantly worse than anticipated by industry experts when the Phoenix consortium paid £10 to BMW last year for the rump of the old Rover Group.

The losses are expected to include £200m on day-to-day car making. The rest is from the cost of restructuring and unravelling the business from BMW.

The figures will fuel concern over the new company's prospects. It is banking on halving its losses next year and breaking into profit by 2002. Leading industry analysts, however, do not expect meaningful profits until 2004 or 2005.

One observer who knows the company well said: 'If losses continue it will become plain that they can't make money from making cars. Making is what matters, and this is not encouraging.'

But the management will present the loss as being in line with its plans, and draw attention to the company's strong cash position, founded on a debt-free balance sheet and a £500m interest-free loan being paid by BMW in three annual tranches.

The firm's finances are extremely complicated because of the way MG Rover had to be extracted from BMW. The figures are being finalised, and will be ready at the end of March for release next month.

Sources close to the company said the £300m comprises losses on operations, restructuring costs such as redundancy payments, and problems from the split with BMW. This included a 12-week halt to production of the flagship Rover 75 as the assembly line was moved from Cowley in Oxford and rebuilt at MG Rover's Longbridge base.

The figure is down from the £880m the Rover Group lost under its German owners. Some £100m of that was from Land Rover, which is now owned by Ford.

MG Rover has a two-year plan to turn this around. It will apply less strict depreciation rules to its accounts, minimising losses on the 'distressed value' of its used car fleet, as well as cutting redundancy and IT costs.

MG Rover's chief executive Kevin Howe has said the full effect will be felt by the end of this year, when the company will move into profit. When the results are presented MG Rover is likely to declare a cash balance of £200m at the end of 2000 made up of money from the first tranche of the BMW loan, with a further sum from the sale of 30,000 of the 70,000 cars left by BMW as part of the deal.

The company will emphasise this strong cash position to help it go forward. This, along with sales, it believes, can underpin the development of new models, expected in 2004.

However, some analysts fear it is living off its cash and free stock, and will find it hard to make profits.

Professor Garel Rhys of Cardiff University said he expected Rover to break even in 2002 and 2003 and perhaps achieve a good profit in 2004.

But he added: 'The real test will be whether they can run a tight enough ship to make profits on their operations. This is the key to finding what is crucial - a buyer or major partner. It'll be tough, but they have a chance.'

webTitle: Poison used in bid to murder Adair

fields.headline: Poison used in bid to murder Adair
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Johnny 'Mad Dog' Adair, the convicted loyalist leader, was poisoned with strychnine in prison, it was learnt last night.
fields.body:
Johnny 'Mad Dog' Adair, the convicted loyalist leader, was poisoned with strychnine in prison, it was learnt last night.

A toxicology report has confirmed that the poison was placed in a bodybuilding drink Adair consumed while working out in the gym at Maghaberry prison, outside Belfast.

Adair, who is serving a 15-year sentence for directing acts of terrorism, claims he was the victim of an attempted murder.

The Northern Ireland Prison Service has confirmed that the Ulster Defence Association leader complained of feeling unwell on 23 December after a drinking a 'contaminated' drink.

The Observer has learnt that the report into the incident has found that drug was strychnine and had been smuggled into a drink Adair bought from the prison tuck shop. Adair only drank a small quantity after complaining of feeling unwell. He spends most of his free time working out in the prison gym.

A Prison Service spokesman said: 'Mr Adair and the RUC were notified immediately. It would be inappropriate to comment on the circumstances surrounding these allegations, pending a police investigation.'

It is not known if either republicans or loyalists were responsible. Adair was the target of repeated murder bids by the IRA and INLA before the ceasefires. However, last summer he became a prime target for the rival loyalist terror group, the Ulster Volunteer Force, which blamed Adair for instigating the bitter feud between them and the UDA.

John White, a spokesman for the UDA's political wing, the Ulster Democratic Party, said the incident prompted fears among loyalist inmates in Maghaberry, where republican and loyalist prisoners are held together on integrated blocks.

webTitle: Rover suppliers fight global trends to ensure future

fields.headline: It's hard wiring, but jilted Leoni woos on
fields.standfirst:
Rover suppliers are fighting global trends to give British engineering back its future, writes Paul Farrelly

Special report: Britain's car industry
fields.trailText: Rover suppliers are fighting global trends to give British engineering back its future, writes Paul Farrelly.
fields.body:
The dark day 12 months ago, when BMW switched off life support for its 'English Patient', is indelibly etched in pain, sweat and fear among Rover's 2,000-plus suppliers in the West Midlands.

One firm, however, had more reason than the rest to be dumbfounded. Leoni Wiring Systems, based in the traditional pit town of Newcastle-under-Lyme in north Staffordshire, was one of the troubled carmaker's bigger suppliers. Almost two-thirds of its sales - and the livelihoods of most of its 1,800 employees - were dependent on Rover and Land Rover.

Ironically, Leoni is not British, but German-owned. The factory, which used to belong to Lucas, had been in German hands for only 10 days before BMW pulled the plug. More poignantly, it was the BMW link which had encouraged Leoni to buy the old Lucas Rists Wires & Cables in the first place.

The story of Lucas Rists also takes in the troubles of British manufacturing and Britain's motor industry in microcosm. Since the Rover crisis, around 900 jobs - half the workforce - have gone in Newcastle. Sister plants in Accrington and Luton have been closed, with the loss of 700 more jobs. But the firm's gritty determination to survival, both management and unions hope, shows that British engineering expertise has a vibrant and valued future.

'Last year we could have ended up with no Rover and no Land Rover,' said Jack Grindrod, general manager of Leoni Wiring Systems UK. 'But we still have engineers, which Germany is crying out for. It has been a hard year, but we've diversified and won new contracts. And Leoni is committed to building us here into their second centre of engineering excellence.'

Lucas Rists was founded in 1927. At its height in the 1970s it was the Potteries town's biggest employer, with 5,000 people manufacturing electrical wiring systems, power leads and battery cables. Before the Rover crisis, it had already been through Lucas' traumatic and short-sighted multi-billion merger with debt-laden US rival Varity. In one fell swoop a great British name in motor components was dismembered and destabilised.

In 1999, when the new LucasVarity was picked off by TWH, another predatory US component maker, Rists found itself surplus to requirements. No wonder, then, that BMW's purchasing people preferred a reliable German firm to snap up a key Rover supplier.

Formed from a merger in 1917, Leoni traces its roots to the sixteenth century, when a French craftsman from Lyon - where the art of drawing wire was developed - set up shop in Nuremberg. In the last five years, while British firms have retreated, sales have tripled to £600 million as it has snapped up rivals and expanded rapidly into eastern Europe, the Americas and Africa. But when it moved on the UK, sadly for Leoni, it was completely unaware of BMW's secret plans to offload Rover.

The reality is, however, that to stem looming losses the Rover crisis simply accelerated what was going to happen to Lucas Rists anyway. Under relentless price pressure from the carmakers, component firms have long been shifting manufacturing from high-cost countries such as the UK and Germany to eastern Europe, Asia and even North Africa. Wiring assemblies for the Rover 75 were already destined for Leoni's brand new plant in Romania (opened, ironically, by the British ambassador to Bucharest) and cable manufacture has transferred to the Czech Republic..

'We have lost far more manufacturing jobs as a result of pressure from carmakers to leave these shores than from the collapse of Rover,' said Tony Woodley, the Transport & General worker's Union's national organiser for the motor industry. 'From where we could have been, Rover and its suppliers have done reasonably well in tough circumstances.'

West Midlands suppliers have certainly suffered hundreds of job losses since Rover was taken over. But the total is a fraction of the 50,000 predicted had Rover shut down and difficult to differentiate from the other pressures facing the industry.

Since the crisis, Leoni has worked more, not less, closely with Rover. It has just won new contracts for the Rover 25 and MGF. While the design work will be done in the UK, however, the contracts have been priced to be made abroad.

But from adversity has also come opportunity. Leoni is forging strong ties with Premier Automotive Group, part of Ford, the US car-maker which bought Land Rover, Lucas Rists' biggest customer. Following the ending of carmaking at Luton, Leoni UK is hoping that the Newcastle factory's proximity to Vauxhall's Merseyside plant at Ellesmere port will also bring new opportunities. As part of a strategy to develop specialised lower-volume business, Leoni has also wooed construction equipment makers and engine manufacturers. The new, medium-sized Bentley, to be made by Volkswagen nearby at Crewe, is another major opportunity for Leoni.

With price pressure unrelenting, however, doubts remain over whether much manufacturing - even specialised small-volume work - will be carried out in the UK in future. For staff and the unions, the question is crucial: of the 850 workers left at Newcastle, about two-thirds are hourly paid assembly workers.

'The future isn't rosy, but the good thing is that the Germans at Leoni have shown a long-term commitment here,' said TGWU regional official Margaret Armstrong. 'When the Rover crisis hit and Leoni had only been in the picture a matter of weeks, I had great reservations. They could have upped sticks and said we bought a pig in a poke, but they haven't. They have had to change the focus, but at the same time they haven't tried to save costs by cutting wages and eroding terms and conditions.'

At Leoni's European works council, British union delegates get little tea and sympathy from their German comrades. Over the past few years, Leoni's engineering centre at Kitzingen in Bavaria has gone through the same mill. Ironically, the one big carmaker Leoni does not yet supply in Germany is BMW.

webTitle: Few laughs in the Rover.comedy

fields.headline: Few laughs in the Rover.comedy
fields.standfirst: Special report: Britain's car industry
fields.trailText: There is a company in the West Midlands that should think of putting 'dotcom' at the end of its name.
fields.body:
There is a company in the West Midlands that should think of putting 'dotcom' at the end of its name.

Like most dotcom firms, it racks up multi-million pound losses. And like most dotcom firms it explains this away by saying that it's on a long-term path to profitability, so analysing its bottom line now makes no sense. Like many dotcom firms, it faces huge competition from a plethora of (bigger and tougher) rivals with deeper pockets. But unlike most dotcom companies, Rover actually makes something.

But for how much longer? A year after Phoenix snatched Rover away from venture capitalists Alchemy Partners, its future is still uncertain. The company says it is confident that it will move into the black next year. And it points with pride to the launch of three new MG-badged cars - the X10, X20 and X30 - as evidence that its development plans are on course. But the profitability claims should be treated gingerly. Rover may slip into the black next year, but experts say it is not certain that it will stay there the following year.

And if it does manage to turn a profit, even the company's chief executive, Kevin Howe, concedes it will be only a 'marginal' one. As such, the management's ultimate aim over the next four years is to cut costs and polish the marques in order to make Rover as attractive as possible to a buyer prepared to invest for the long term.

But can this be done? Rover faces enormous challenges. Its business plan is predicated on selling 200,000 cars a year. It sold just over 205,000 cars last year, half of these outside the UK.

Heightened fears of a global slowdown do not provide much succour for those keen to talk up Rover's mid-term prospects.

Back in the UK, the company is in the midst of a vicious turf war, with rival manufacturers slashing prices to dramatic effect. Prices fell by 9.4 per cent in January compared with the same month the previous year. As a result, most UK carmakers are struggling. The biggest casualty so far has been Vauxhall's Luton plant. Like Vauxhall, Ford, Nissan, Toyota and Honda have all announced increased losses over the past few months. If they find the going tough, whither Rover?

And even if Rover does manage to stay alive until 2005, it may not find a buyer. After all, only Proton of Malaysia has shown any interest in cutting some sort of deal. But that is tomorrow's problem. Rover's challenge for now is to be around in four years' time.

That's a frightening prospect for most dotcoms, never mind ones ratcheting up losses approaching £300 million. And no dotcom employs 5,500 people.

webTitle: English patient off critical list

fields.headline: English patient off critical list
fields.standfirst:
Or so its owners claim. One year after news that BMW wanted out, Rover predicts security with new models and a mystery partner. But is it barking? Oliver Morgan reports

Special report: Britain's car industry
fields.trailText: Or so its owners claim. One year after news that BMW wanted out, Rover predicts security with new models and a mystery partner. But is it barking? Oliver Morgan reports.
fields.body:
A year ago on Wednesday a small report appeared on the news agency wires. The German daily Suddeutsche Zeitung had a story that Munich-based carmaker BMW was to dump its £880 million loss-making Rover subsidiary.

The next day - 15 March - it emerged that the buyer was London venture capitalist Alchemy Partners, whose head Jon Moulton quickly outlined his plan.

At a packed press conference on 16 March, Moulton coolly said he intended to cut the output of Rover's Longbridge plant in Birmingham from 230,000 cars a year to fewer than 100,000 and to concentrate on MG sports cars.

The implications were horrendous. Experts forecast that Longbridge's 8,000 workforce would fall as low as 1,500, with thousands more jobs lost at suppliers.

BMW had kept everyone in the dark, while reportedly calling its UK arm 'the English Patient' in private. Industry Secretary Stephen Byers was furious. Only the previous Friday he had met Rover boss Werner Samann, who made only anoblique remark about BMW's future involvement.

In fact BMW had been negotiating with Alchemy for six months, and had effectively carved Rover up, giving Moulton Longbridge and the Rover and MG names. Land Rover was sold separately to Ford, while the Germans kept the Cowley factory to build the new Mini.

Byers travelled to Longbridge on 17 March to set up an emergency task force. He also met John Towers, a former Rover executive, and suggested he should rescue the group. This idea also came to local businessman and councillor John Hemming, and to Tony Woodley of the Transport & General Workers' Union. All three claim they had it first.

Towers' Phoenix consortium emerged amid much back-biting. Hemming was soon distanced: Byers was worried about his non-Labour political connections.

Byers told BMW of a rival bid at the DTI in London on 6 and 7 April. On 10 April, again at the DTI, Towers presented his plan to BMW. There were problems. Towers had no financial backing. He wanted BMW's new Mini.

The Germans would not agree. Alchemy was to take over Longbridge on 28 April.

Towers struggled to find the £200 million he needed to persuade BMW. DTI officials say the Germans were nervous about being liable for redundancies if his consortium failed.

The clock continued ticking, but BMW's board in Munich - pressed by Woodley and concerned at the ferocious response in the UK - swung in favour of Phoenix, which promised fewer job losses.

Then Moulton unexpectedly pulled out. The field was clear for Towers, who found the £200m from US company Burdale Financial. On 9 May his company, Techtronic 2000, took over at Longbridge, paying only £10.

For his tenner Towers and his fellow directors - Nick Stephenson, local car dealer John Edwards and the finance director of Edwards' firm, Peter Beale - picked up assets and stock at Longbridge worth £740m, an interest-free £500m loan or BMW 'dowry', to come in three tranches - and no debts. BMW, which had invested £3 billion in Rover, took responsibility for those.

Yet sceptics felt the new company was thin on resources - a view that took hold partly because, as a private operation, it gave out little information. And experts did not believe Rover could take on giants such as Ford and General Motors in an oversupplied global market.

Nor did Rover's 200,000-car-a-year target impress. It would not be enough to compete with high-volume, low-cost giants. When Rover announced sales of 205,000 last year, there was concern over margins: Rover had twice cut its prices.

And when Towers said the revamped small and medium R25 and R45 and the executive R75 would be the basis for the medium term, experts snorted, pointing to a flow of gleaming new rival models.

Towers had to forge a partnership with a major manufacturer to share the estimated £400m-plus costs of developing new car platforms. But as the months wore on, no details emerged. Then a name did appear, little Proton of Malaysia, which seemed interested only in a partnership to produce engines.

Meanwhile, the squabbling continued. Towers' strategy was not always clear. In October he was reported as wanting to sell the company. Later that month unhappy non-executive directors were said to be planning to bid for MG. The same week, directors Terry Whitmore and Brian Parker resigned. There were also wrangles with BMW about the valuation of the company and the Longbridge Powertrain engine plant, which Rover wants and BMW still owns.

These last two problems are expected to be resolved soon. but the scepticism persists. Critics point to the US, where Ford, GM and Chrysler announced profits warnings before Christmas, and to UK closures by Vauxhall and Ford.

Experts say the solution is new models at lower cost with higher technology. 'They must be joking, with their model range,' says one observer.

Chief executive Kevin Howe argues that the renamed MG Rover can turn the £880m loss by BMW's old Rover into a financial improvement of £600m - of which £100m would come from Land Rover and £500m from stripping out BMW losses over two years. But losses will go on for two years: £300m for eight months of 2000, and half that expected in 2001.

The cash position is vital. Rover ended last year with £200m in the bank: £200m from BMW's first dowry payment, and working capital from the sale of 30,000 of the 70,000 cars left by BMW. Set against this are losses, among other things, the £100m it cost to develop the new MGZ-badged 25, 45 and 75, along with the 75 estate and two new MGFs.

Howe believes he can finance new models from the balance sheet and cash generated by sales for five years.

Rover is cagey about costs, partly because they depend on whether it stays alone. If it does, Howe says, the R75 platform can be used for new small, medium and large cars. On this basis, the new range would cost more than £300m.

But Rover's Plan A is still to find a credible partner. Howe says there are three options: first, a collaboration with a components and systems supplier such as the UK's Mayflower (a partner in the MGF), or with Magna of Canada to develop the 75 platform; second, a new platform developed with a supplier; or third, a new one with a manufacturer. Observers point to Peugeot, VW and Fiat as partners. Howe will not discuss names.

Professor Garel Rhys of Cardiff Business School says: 'I expect more than half of development costs [to come] from revenues. The less of the dowry is used, the more attractive the company to a partner or buyer.'

Howe is sticking to Towers' 200,000 target. Rhys says it is achievable, with 50,000 MGs, 50,000 R75 saloons and estates, and 100,000 split between the 25 and 45. But 180,000 is more likely for 2001.

Not all are convinced. One critic says: 'We don't know how many cars they produced last year. I suspect it will be much lower than 200,000. They have cleared out people. They are concentrating on sporty MGs. It looks similar to Alchemy.'

Howe claims the number of employees fell last year from 6,800, to 5,500. Rhys says: 'What has been done in steadying the ship has been done well.' Now, 'they have to make up their mind which strategy to go for... Whatever happens an autonomous future is not on the cards.'

At least when that comes about - whether Rover is sold or a partnership is announced - we will not read about it first in the German press.

And when Towers said the revamped small and medium R25 and R45 and the executive R75 would be the basis for the medium term, experts snorted, pointing to a flow of gleaming new rival models. Towers had to forge a partnership with a major manufacturer to share the estimated £400m-plus costs of developing new car platforms. But as the months wore on, no details emerged. Then a name did appear, little Proton of Malaysia, which seemed interested only in a partnership to produce engines. Meanwhile, the squabbling continued. Towers' strategy was not always clear. In October he was reported as wanting to sell the company. Later that month unhappy non-executive directors were said to be planning to bid for MG. The same week, directors Terry Whitmore and Brian Parker resigned. There were also wrangles with BMW about the valuation of the company and the Longbridge Powertrain engine plant, which Rover wants and BMW still owns. These last two problems are expected to be resolved soon. but the scepticism persists. Critics point to the US, where Ford, GM and Chrysler announced profits warnings before Christmas, and to UK closures by Vauxhall and Ford. Experts say the solution is new models at lower cost with higher technology. 'They must be joking, with their model range,' says one observer. Chief executive Kevin Howe argues that the renamed MG Rover can turn the £880m loss by BMW's old Rover into a financial improvement of £600m - of which £100m would come from Land Rover and £500m from stripping out BMW losses over two years. But losses will go on for two years: £300m for eight months of 2000, and half that expected in 2001. The cash position is vital. Rover ended last year with £200m in the bank: £200m from BMW's first dowry payment, and working capital from the sale of 30,000 of the 70,000 cars left by BMW. Set against this are losses, among other things, the £100m it cost to develop the new MGZ-badged 25, 45 and 75, along with the 75 estate and two new MGFs. Howe believes he can finance new models from the balance sheet and cash generated by sales for five years. Rover is cagey about costs, partly because they depend on whether it stays alone. If it does, Howe says, the R75 platform can be used for new small, medium and large cars. On this basis, the new range would cost more than £300m. But Rover's Plan A is still to find a credible partner. Howe says there are three options: first, a collaboration with a components and systems supplier such as the UK's Mayflower (a partner in the MGF), or with Magna of Canada to develop the 75 platform; second, a new platform developed with a supplier; or third, a new one with a manufacturer. Observers point to Peugeot, VW and Fiat as partners. Howe will not discuss names. Professor Garel Rhys of Cardiff Business School says: 'I expect more than half of development costs [to come] from revenues. The less of the dowry is used, the more attractive the company to a partner or buyer.' Howe is sticking to Towers' 200,000 target. Rhys says it is achievable, with 50,000 MGs, 50,000 R75 saloons and estates, and 100,000 split between the 25 and 45. But 180,000 is more likely for 2001. Not all are convinced. One critic says: 'We don't know how many cars they produced last year. I suspect it will be much lower than 200,000. They have cleared out people. They are concentrating on sporty MGs. It looks similar to Alchemy.' Howe claims the number of employees fell last year from 6,800, to 5,500. Rhys says: 'What has been done in steadying the ship has been done well.' Now, 'they have to make up their mind which strategy to go for... Whatever happens an autonomous future is not on the cards.' At least when that comes about - whether Rover is sold or a partnership is announced - we will not read about it first in the German press.

webTitle: Provos scout terror targets in England

fields.headline: Provos scout terror targets in England
fields.standfirst:
Freed prisoner 'at centre of new bomb campaign'
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: One of the Provisional IRA's most feared terrorists is carrying out reconnaissance missions and collecting intelligence on targets in England, heightening security service fears that it is planning a high-profile 'spectacular'.
fields.body:
One of the Provisional IRA's most feared terrorists is carrying out reconnaissance missions and collecting intelligence on targets in England, heightening security service fears that it is planning a high-profile 'spectacular'.

Other members of the IRA's England department, responsible for bombing Canary Wharf in 1996, have also been deployed to gather information on targets including Army regiments and MPs.

One member is a former Provisional IRA prisoner from Derry who was released under the Good Friday Agreement. The leader of the unit was responsible for bombing Army headquarters in Northern Ireland in 1996.

Security sources said sophisticated electronic intelligence-gathering techniques had been used to 'eavesdrop' on an IRA member who recently used an internet cafe in Ipswich to contact an IRA commander in Belfast. They have since lost trace of him.

News that the Provisional IRA has dispatched senior members to Britain has alarmed Dublin and London and comes at a delicate stage in the peace process. It is not, however, believed that an attack is imminent.

With the peace process deadlocked over the decommissioning of arms, the IRA last week offered to speak to General John de Chastelain, chairman of the body set up to oversee the handover.

Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, yesterday called on the Government to accelerate the withdrawal of troops from Northern Ireland. He said the issue was one of the key problems contributing to the difficulties in the peace process.

Speaking ahead of the party's conference in Dublin yesterday, he said: 'Whatever excuse there was for the deployment of troops and for the development of a cutting edge of a killing machine in the RUC, and all of the repressive legislation - three years after the Good Friday Agreement, there's no excuse for it.'

He dismissed suggestions that lack of progress on IRA decommissioning was the principal problem. 'It wasn't an essential part of the Agreement, and there's the nub of it. The difficulty is that it has now become a precondition.'

Dissident republicans have been responsible for a spate of attacks including last week end's bomb at the BBC's news centre in west London. Police believe the Real IRA and Continuity IRA were involved.

Republican and security sources said that, by reactivating its England department, the IRA was 'keeping all options open' in the event of the Good Friday Agree ment collapsing after the general election.

It is understood Ministers have been made aware of the unit's presence in England and that it is being run by a senior Provisional from west Belfast who masterminded a plot to smuggle guns from Florida in 1999. He is said to be a close ally of Adams. The British and Irish governments are understood to be perplexed that the Provisionals have intensified their 'targeting' in Britain. A senior Irish source said: 'They are creating the impression that they might go back to war if the Agreement fails. But in reality it does not fit the strategy of their political leadership at the talks.'

Security sources believe the activities of the Provisional IRA are entirely separate from those of the Real IRA, led by former IRA quartermaster Michael McKevitt. Republicans say the organisation is growing all over Ireland including west Belfast, the Adams stronghold.

The Real IRA is a relatively small organisation compared to the Provisionals, with only a couple of hundred members on either side of the Irish border. What it lacks in numbers it makes up for in experience.

Security in Lisburn was stepped up yesterday to prevent what security sources called an 'imminent' terrorist attack. Sources said there were fears the Real IRA was behind a plan to carry out a major bombing in the town.

The move followed the discovery of a stolen white van, which was abandoned three miles outside the town last Tuesday. The vehicle had been hijacked in Dundalk. Security forces believe it was left there as a decoy.

webTitle: The questions unanswered by Hammond

fields.headline: Unanswered questions
fields.trailText: 1 Why did Tony Blair sack Peter Mandelson?
fields.body:
1 Why did Tony Blair sack Peter Mandelson?

2 Was Blair or Downing Street shown intelligence reports questioning the 'dubious' business activities of the Hindujas?

3 Why did Mandelson write in November 1998 in a memo about Dome sponsorship: 'Incidentally, if Mr S.P. Hinduja wishes to pursue his citizenship application he can do so without further involvement or commendation from me!'

4 What did Home Secretary Jack Straw mean when he asked that one of the Hinduja passport applications be dealt with 'helpfully'.

5 Did Mandelson's personal contact with Home Office Minister Mike O'Brien and his office help fast-track Srichand Hinduja's application?

6 If it was policy from 1991 not to grant citizenship to people who are known to be the subject of criminal investigation, why was this not followed in the case of the Hindujas?

7 Why was advice given to O'Brien from the Nationality Directorate on Srichand Hinduja's application not copied to other ministers as is normal practice?

8 Why is Straw's private secretary Jane Fowler 'adamant' that she was told by Mandelson's office that the call between Mandelson and O'Brien was a private matter?

9 How did the Hindujas know in June 1998 about the change in Government policy on naturalisation when it was only announced on 27 June 1998?

webTitle: Blair feels 'isolated' by loss of Mandelson

fields.headline: Blair feels 'isolated' by loss of Mandelson
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Tony Blair believes the loss of Peter Mandelson has been a severe blow to the Government and left him isolated in a Cabinet dominated by Chancellor Gordon Brown.
fields.body:
Tony Blair believes the loss of Peter Mandelson has been a severe blow to the Government and left him isolated in a Cabinet dominated by Chancellor Gordon Brown.

The Prime Minister has told colleagues that without one of his oldest political friends he feels the Blairite wing in the Government could suffer and he regrets having had to sack the former Northern Ireland Secretary, according to sources close to Mandelson.

In comments that will revive speculation about ten sions between the Blair and Brown camps, friends of the Prime Minister say that he feels exposed and that 'Gordon is rampant'.

Although Downing Street sources insisted that Blair, if presented with the same facts on the Hinduja passport affair, would act in the same way again, they admit that the loss of Mandelson has produced a 'big hole' in the Prime Minister's political life.

Blair and Mandelson are now in regular telephone contact, revealing the importance that Blair still places on the man he once thanked for masterminding his campaign to become Labour leader.

'The relationship is much the same as it was before all this happened,' said one senior party source. In addition, relations between Mandelson and Alastair Campbell, Blair's official spokesman, were described as warm, despite allegations that Campbell had been feuding with the ex-Minister.

The fact that Mandelson has been so readily rehabilitated into Blair's inner circle will alarm many in the Government who thought that the former Minister misjudged the seriousness of the passports issue which led to his resignation six weeks ago. Many in the party, some of them enemies of Mandelson, were predicting that he would be cast into the political wilderness and that Blair would turn his back on him. But the Prime Minister is now expected to use Mandelson as a sounding board on issues such as Northern Ireland, Europe and the general election. He specifically refused to say what he felt about Mandelson's resignation when asked about the crisis on Friday after the publication of the Hammond inquiry report which cleared Mandelson of any impropriety over the Hinduja passport applications. Last week the ex-Minister admitted adding to the 'muddle' over the issue, and said he would not seek a return to government.

The revelations come as the Prime Minister faces increasing pressure to reveal whether he saw intelligence documents suggesting the Hindujas 'had been involved in a number of dubious practices, in some cases potentially amounting to illegal activities'.

The Hammond report confirms that while Trade Secretary and in charge of the Dome, Mandelson was shown security briefings but decided to accept Hinduja funds for the Dome's faith zone. If Blair had seen the reports it would have been before Blair and his wife, Cherie, attended a Diwali party thrown by the brothers. The intelligence material emerged after Jen nie Page, then chief executive of the New Millennium Experience Company, sought a thorough check on the Indian-born businessmen.

One intelligence expert told The Observer that with a project as sensitive as the Dome it would be 'inconceivable' that intelligence briefings on controversial businessman such as the Hindujas had not reached Downing Street.

It has also emerged that in the Nineties the then Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, and her Home Secretary, David Waddington, were advised by officials to stay away from the Hindujas' Diwali party because of fears that it would lead to embarrassment.

Ann Widdecombe, Shadow Home Secretary, said: 'The Prime Minister must tell whether he or any of staff were aware of intelligence material on the Hindujas, and if so why did he continue to do business with them?'

Opposition MPs are calling on Jack Straw, the Home Secretary, to answer a number of questions emerging from the Hammond inquiry, particularly the role he played in helping the third Hinduja brother, Prakash, last May. A minute reveals that Straw wanted the case to be dealt with 'helpfully'.

Liberal Democrat MP Norman Baker, whose parliamentary question originally helped tease out ministerial involvement in the passport applications, said this weekend that the Home Secretary 'must explain why he was willing do such favours'.

webTitle: Now our tourist industry faces ruin.

fields.headline: Now our tourist industry faces ruin. All because of farming
fields.standfirst:
 £100m a week lost as business down by 75 per cent  Americans and French cancel tours  New foot and mouth cases shock chief vet

Special report: countryside in crisis
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:  £100m a week lost as business down by 75 per cent  Americans and French cancel tours  New foot and mouth cases shock chief vet
fields.body:
Harry Berger was in despair yesterday. As he looked out across the rocky fells of the Eskdale valley in the Lake District, speckled with white dots of sheep, he knew foot-and-mouth disease meant his ruin.

Yet Berger is not a farmer. He is a hotelier. He has lost £17,000 since the outbreak. 'We may have to close permanently if this goes on much longer,' he said. It may not sound like a fortune. But Berger's situation is replicated across the country - and means Britain's tourist industry faces devastation.

With tracts of hill and lakes still banned to humans because of an illness that means only that farm animals fetch less at market, the rural tourist industry has already lost £200 million - all sacrificed to save farmers.

While rescue packages are in place to save the people involved in animal farming, there will be no help for Berger and thousands like him. Tourist authorities yesterday warned the industry was being devastated by the closure of much of the countryside. It is being deluged with cancellations.

Hundreds of jobs are being lost, and some hotels have closed permanently. Owners are bitter that the slaughter policy is costing their industry far more than any of the possible benefits to farming. As the crucial Easter weekend approaches, the damage to the industry will escalate.

The English Tourist Council, which estimates countryside tourism is worth £12 billion a year, says business is 75 per cent below normal. Rural tourism should be worth about £150m a week at this time of year, meaning losses of more than £100m a week. The cost to farmers so far been a fraction of that, estimated at less than £30m.

Thousands of people from overseas have cancelled bookings - and the images have even put them off cities such as Edinburgh and London.

'We are very concerned about what the foot-and-mouth outbreak is doing to Britain's reputation overseas,' said Philippa Swaine of the British Tourist Authority.

She added: 'Call centres for foreign travel are very quiet. The worrying thing is that we are having cancellations from France and the US, which are our biggest markets. This is also the time of year that people are planning holidays for the summer, and they are thinking they will give Britain a miss this year.'

This weekend, the number of cases of foot and mouth reached 139, and chief vet Jim Scudamore admitted the scale of the epidemic had come as a shock. It was hoped that the ban on moving livestock would have helped win the battle against the virus, but the disease is being spread by wind. More than 100,000 animals have been earmarked for slaughter.

As the disease continued to spread yesterday because of the tradition of not vaccinating, cases were confirmed at four farms in Cumbria, three in Scotland, two in Devon, two in Co Durham and one in Anglesey.

The total number of animals facing slaughter was now 114,000, of which 82,000 had already been killed. The Government justifies its strategy of slaughter on the grounds that it will work out cheaper for the livestock industry in the long run than vaccination. But tourism - worth £63bn a year - is being crippled by the moves to protect livestock exports, worth £1.2bn a year. Tourism contributes about four times as much to the national economy as farming, and employs four times as many people.

Not that this will last if the crisis in the tourist industry is not tackled, says Berger, who has already had to lay off three staff at his hotel. 'Maff [the Agriculture Ministry] is running all this, but they're not thinking about other businesses,' he said. 'Tourism is much bigger in this county than farming, producing more income, and it's being ignored.'

In the next valley along from Berger's empty hotel, in Wasdale, Howard Christie has been doing the calculations. Since Maff started telling visitors to steer clear, his Wasdale Head Inn has lost £26,000 of business, with cancellations from the Netherlands, Belgium and the US. This weekend, his 54-bed hotel has one couple staying; this week he will have to start laying off staff.

The losses he is sustaining are far higher than any possible benefit to local farmers. In total there are just 600 sheep in the valley, worth an aver age of just £30 each. 'At local market prices, with the money I have lost I could have bought every single beast in the valley and have money to spare for a great night out,' said Christie. 'I could buy all the sheep, slaughter them, let the walkers and climbers back in and remain open for business - it would make more sense. The policy of blanket closure is not doing me, the farmers, any good.'

Cumbria Tourist Board estimates the county is losing up to £8m a week, with 20-30,000 cancelled bookings. It estimates 350 jobs a week are being lost from tourism, which accounts for a fifth of the local economy.

The same story is repeated across the country. Large parts of the Scottish Highlands are now closed to walkers and climbers, with mountain guides and hotel owners around Fort William, Glencoe and Ben Nevis saying they face financial ruin.

At Northcote Manor in High Hampton in Devon, the phone stopped ringing on Wednesday, when the exclusion zone around a cattle market 15 miles away was extended to its front gate.

The South West Tourism Board reckons the industry in its area will lose £500m. One hotel owner in Devon, already burdened with debt, has simply left his keys and fled. 'It was the last straw,' said a friend.

At the bar of the hilltop Malvern Hills Hotel in Worcestershire, Didier Tabeaud is expecting the quietest shift in years. The bar usually takes at least £500 on a Sunday afternoon. But last Sunday, they took only £20. Sue Thomas, spokeswoman for Heart of England Tourist Board, said: 'We're losing £5m a week in this area. Business is down to a quarter of its normal level.'

The National Mountain Centre at Plas y Brenin in Snowdonia should be getting ready for the busiest weekend of the year, but is closed with police tape swirling across its entrance. Iain Peter, the chief executive, has been forced to lay off 40 staff. 'Everything around here, from pubs to the post office and petrol station relies on the trade we bring in. With nobody here, they are starting to feel the pinch. The Government has put in place some stringent powers without thinking of the implications.'

Other industries are suffering and cutting jobs. Northumberland Cheese in Blagden has lost all of its sales to local markets, has had to close its coffee shop, and lack of milk has meant it has stopped producing cheese. Hopefield Animal Sanctuary in Essex, in the exclusion zone from an abattoir, is closed.'We're losing £400 a week from the situation. I am afraid we are going under - in a fortnight we will be in real trouble,' said owner Paula Clark. 'We should get compensation as well as farmers.'

Maff has used economic grounds to justify its extreme policy of slaughter and eradicate for a disease that is not fatal to animals and does not affect humans; in the long run it will cost the industry less than vaccination, or just letting the disease run its course, which would damage productivity. But its cost benefit- analysis has considered only the cost to farmers, and not the wider cost to the rest of the rural economy.

The Federation of Small Businesses has a £500,000 compensation fund to give loans to members, and wants the Government to set up a similar fund. The federation has received a flow of calls from businesses in distress.Ian Fletcher, head of policy at the British Chambers of Commerce backed the call, demanding: 'Others directly affected by the outbreak should also be compensated.'

That looks a long way off. A spokesperson for the Department of Media, Culture and Sport, which is responsible for tourism, admitted it was doing nothing about the calls of distress it was receiving, and had not even discussed the issue of compensation. Nick Brown, the Agriculture Minister, has ruled out compensation to anyone other than farmers.

fields.bodyText: Harry Berger was in despair yesterday. As he looked out across the rocky fells of the Eskdale valley in the Lake District, speckled with white dots of sheep, he knew foot-and-mouth disease meant his ruin. Yet Berger is not a farmer. He is a hotelier. He has lost £17,000 since the outbreak. 'We may have to close permanently if this goes on much longer,' he said. It may not sound like a fortune. But Berger's situation is replicated across the country - and means Britain's tourist industry faces devastation. With tracts of hill and lakes still banned to humans because of an illness that means only that farm animals fetch less at market, the rural tourist industry has already lost £200 million - all sacrificed to save farmers. While rescue packages are in place to save the people involved in animal farming, there will be no help for Berger and thousands like him. Tourist authorities yesterday warned the industry was being devastated by the closure of much of the countryside. It is being deluged with cancellations. Hundreds of jobs are being lost, and some hotels have closed permanently. Owners are bitter that the slaughter policy is costing their industry far more than any of the possible benefits to farming. As the crucial Easter weekend approaches, the damage to the industry will escalate. The English Tourist Council, which estimates countryside tourism is worth £12 billion a year, says business is 75 per cent below normal. Rural tourism should be worth about £150m a week at this time of year, meaning losses of more than £100m a week. The cost to farmers so far been a fraction of that, estimated at less than £30m. Thousands of people from overseas have cancelled bookings - and the images have even put them off cities such as Edinburgh and London. 'We are very concerned about what the foot-and-mouth outbreak is doing to Britain's reputation overseas,' said Philippa Swaine of the British Tourist Authority. She added: 'Call centres for foreign travel are very quiet. The worrying thing is that we are having cancellations from France and the US, which are our biggest markets. This is also the time of year that people are planning holidays for the summer, and they are thinking they will give Britain a miss this year.' This weekend, the number of cases of foot and mouth reached 139, and chief vet Jim Scudamore admitted the scale of the epidemic had come as a shock. It was hoped that the ban on moving livestock would have helped win the battle against the virus, but the disease is being spread by wind. More than 100,000 animals have been earmarked for slaughter. As the disease continued to spread yesterday because of the tradition of not vaccinating, cases were confirmed at four farms in Cumbria, three in Scotland, two in Devon, two in Co Durham and one in Anglesey. The total number of animals facing slaughter was now 114,000, of which 82,000 had already been killed. The Government justifies its strategy of slaughter on the grounds that it will work out cheaper for the livestock industry in the long run than vaccination. But tourism - worth £63bn a year - is being crippled by the moves to protect livestock exports, worth £1.2bn a year. Tourism contributes about four times as much to the national economy as farming, and employs four times as many people. Not that this will last if the crisis in the tourist industry is not tackled, says Berger, who has already had to lay off three staff at his hotel. 'Maff [the Agriculture Ministry] is running all this, but they're not thinking about other businesses,' he said. 'Tourism is much bigger in this county than farming, producing more income, and it's being ignored.' In the next valley along from Berger's empty hotel, in Wasdale, Howard Christie has been doing the calculations. Since Maff started telling visitors to steer clear, his Wasdale Head Inn has lost £26,000 of business, with cancellations from the Netherlands, Belgium and the US. This weekend, his 54-bed hotel has one couple staying; this week he will have to start laying off staff. The losses he is sustaining are far higher than any possible benefit to local farmers. In total there are just 600 sheep in the valley, worth an aver age of just £30 each. 'At local market prices, with the money I have lost I could have bought every single beast in the valley and have money to spare for a great night out,' said Christie. 'I could buy all the sheep, slaughter them, let the walkers and climbers back in and remain open for business - it would make more sense. The policy of blanket closure is not doing me, the farmers, any good.' Cumbria Tourist Board estimates the county is losing up to £8m a week, with 20-30,000 cancelled bookings. It estimates 350 jobs a week are being lost from tourism, which accounts for a fifth of the local economy. The same story is repeated across the country. Large parts of the Scottish Highlands are now closed to walkers and climbers, with mountain guides and hotel owners around Fort William, Glencoe and Ben Nevis saying they face financial ruin. At Northcote Manor in High Hampton in Devon, the phone stopped ringing on Wednesday, when the exclusion zone around a cattle market 15 miles away was extended to its front gate. The South West Tourism Board reckons the industry in its area will lose £500m. One hotel owner in Devon, already burdened with debt, has simply left his keys and fled. 'It was the last straw,' said a friend. At the bar of the hilltop Malvern Hills Hotel in Worcestershire, Didier Tabeaud is expecting the quietest shift in years. The bar usually takes at least £500 on a Sunday afternoon. But last Sunday, they took only £20. Sue Thomas, spokeswoman for Heart of England Tourist Board, said: 'We're losing £5m a week in this area. Business is down to a quarter of its normal level.' The National Mountain Centre at Plas y Brenin in Snowdonia should be getting ready for the busiest weekend of the year, but is closed with police tape swirling across its entrance. Iain Peter, the chief executive, has been forced to lay off 40 staff. 'Everything around here, from pubs to the post office and petrol station relies on the trade we bring in. With nobody here, they are starting to feel the pinch. The Government has put in place some stringent powers without thinking of the implications.' Other industries are suffering and cutting jobs. Northumberland Cheese in Blagden has lost all of its sales to local markets, has had to close its coffee shop, and lack of milk has meant it has stopped producing cheese. Hopefield Animal Sanctuary in Essex, in the exclusion zone from an abattoir, is closed.'We're losing £400 a week from the situation. I am afraid we are going under - in a fortnight we will be in real trouble,' said owner Paula Clark. 'We should get compensation as well as farmers.' Maff has used economic grounds to justify its extreme policy of slaughter and eradicate for a disease that is not fatal to animals and does not affect humans; in the long run it will cost the industry less than vaccination, or just letting the disease run its course, which would damage productivity. But its cost benefit- analysis has considered only the cost to farmers, and not the wider cost to the rest of the rural economy. The Federation of Small Businesses has a £500,000 compensation fund to give loans to members, and wants the Government to set up a similar fund. The federation has received a flow of calls from businesses in distress.Ian Fletcher, head of policy at the British Chambers of Commerce backed the call, demanding: 'Others directly affected by the outbreak should also be compensated.' That looks a long way off. A spokesperson for the Department of Media, Culture and Sport, which is responsible for tourism, admitted it was doing nothing about the calls of distress it was receiving, and had not even discussed the issue of compensation. Nick Brown, the Agriculture Minister, has ruled out compensation to anyone other than farmers. Related story No more Cool Britannia for Europe's leper

webTitle: Men with the hotline to peace

fields.headline: Men with the hotline to peace
fields.standfirst:
A former UDA prisoner and a Catholic can quell trouble in Belfast with a call on their mobiles. Now their funding is drying up, reports Henry McDonald

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A former UDA prisoner and a Catholic can quell trouble in Belfast with a call on their mobiles. Now their funding is drying up, reports  Henry McDonald
fields.body:
Along the peacelines that divide Catholics and Protestants in north Belfast - where a quarter of all the deaths in the Troubles have occurred - a former UDA prisoner, Davy Mahood, and his nationalist counterpart, Mickey Doyle, have been saving lives.

Twenty-fours a day, seven days a week, Mahood and Doyle have been on permanent stand-by waiting for the call to quell trouble on the 15 sectarian interfaces.

Their community mobile phone network has allowed them to get to the scene of trouble within minutes and defuse tensions between loyalist and republican youths.

But now the scheme, which has prevented riots escalating into widespread communal conflict, is closing down.

A delay in funding from the European Union for peace-building projects in Northern Ireland has left the two community workers without the mobile phones they have been using to contact each other across the walls, barriers and fences that keep Catholics and Protestants apart.

The EU's Peace and Reconciliation project for Northern Ireland funded the network. The second phase of Peace and Reconciliation money, known as Peace 2, has yet to be allocated to the Province.

Mahood, who served a long sentence for terrorist offences in the UDA wing of the Maze prison, said the scheme's closure has made it more likely that sectarian clashes in north Belfast will get out of control.

'The scheme worked well - even the police were behind us. It operated like this: I would get a call, say, from Mickey, who told me there were crowds gathering on the Limestone Road [an arterial route divided between Catholic and Protestant zones] and that there was trouble. He would go to his side of the line and I would go to mine. We would keep in contact with each other via the mobiles and inform each other about how we were coping with the trouble on our side. Each of us would try to calm tensions and get the youths off the street and away from the interfaces.

'Sometimes Mickey and I got to our respective sides before the police. On one occasion a senior officer in north Belfast told me that by defusing a potential riot we had saved his sub-division £18,000 as he didn't have to call out the Mobile Support Unit that tackles street disturbances.'

Mahood and Doyle have developed such a bond of trust that the Catholic community worker has been happy to let the former UDA prisoner do the talking for both of them.

The demands were so great during Ulster's marching season, when riots erupted in several different locations over the past few summers, that both men were called to help while on holiday.

'Two years ago, I was celebrating my fiftieth birthday in Salou, near Barcelona,' Mahood recalled. 'I was sitting by the pool on a blazing July day sipping a beer. Then the mobile went and it was an RUC inspector from north Belfast. He said there was trouble on the Limestone and he needed Mickey and myself to do something about it. I said I was on holiday but would see what I could do.

'Mickey called a few seconds later and said he'd been telephoned by the police as well to help out. Mickey was climbing in the Alps at the time. Both of us phoned contacts in the area, I talked to the UDA in Tigers Bay and within an hour we got the clashes called off and I went back to my beer.'

Last July the Community Mobile Telephone Network faced its most serious challenge when republican and loyalist crowds gathered at aninterface close to the Westland Road. Someone fired shots from the loyalist side. With fears mounting that someone on the republican side would fire back, Mahood and Doyle were called.

'I went over to the loyalist side of the line and managed to establish that the shots were in fact blanks from a replica gun,' said Mahood. 'There was evidence to prove it, given that there were no strike marks along the area where the shots were fired. I phoned Mickey from my mobile and told him the shots were blanks and that if republicans dispersed, the loyalist crowd would do the same.

'Mickey then told some prominent republicans monitoring the situation that they were only blanks and after that the crowd on their side melted away. What could have been a major confrontation was defused because we were able to get there in time, establish the facts and persuade each side to back away. On that occasion I am confident the scheme saved lives,' Mahood said.

The RUC fully supports the scheme and tries to liaise with the network when trouble flares. Given police support and the widespread acceptance of the two men by both sides of the divide, Mahood said it was impera tive that the EU - or possibly the Northern Ireland Executive - injects new funds into the scheme.

'At the minute Mickey and I are using our own phones to keep the scheme going, but we can't keep funding it ourselves forever. This scheme is 100 per cent genuine; we don't try to fool each other. If one side is to blame for the trouble, the other accepts that. This was real peacekeeping in action and it would be a disaster if now, at the start of the marching season, it collapses.'

Rioting, incursions by one side into the other's areas and intimidation continue almost on a nightly basis in some parts of north Belfast. The Observer took an early evening drive last week along the Limestone Road, the top half of which is Catholic, the bottom Protestant. As darkness fell, crowds of youths were gathering close to waste ground that separates the Catholic Parkgate/Newington area from Tigers Bay. As we passed across the invisible dividing line, the stones and bottles flew across the road, signalling yet more tension along one of north Belfast's notorious interfaces.
