webTitle: Fragile peace shatters as Balkan hatred overflows

fields.headline: Fragile peace shatters as Balkan hatred overflows
fields.standfirst:
War is looming again as border disputes make enemies of old allies in Macedonia. Nato must deal with a new breed of ethnic Albanian extremists

Special report: Kosovo Balkans hatred overflows
fields.trailText: At first glance the Macedonian village of Tanusevci and the Bosnian city of Mostar do not have much in common. The houses of the former - sitting on the Kosovo-Macedonia border - straggle over a forested ridge sown with mines. It is a dirt-poor place. Its few score inhabitants survive on subsistence farming, cutting timber and smuggling across the border.
fields.body:
At first glance the Macedonian village of Tanusevci and the Bosnian city of Mostar do not have much in common. The houses of the former - sitting on the Kosovo-Macedonia border - straggle over a forested ridge sown with mines. It is a dirt-poor place. Its few score inhabitants survive on subsistence farming, cutting timber and smuggling across the border.

Mostar, by contrast, is a vibrant city that still bears the scars of its siege during the Bosnian war. The streets of its old quarter are lined with Ottoman buildings of honey-coloured stone. It is also divided. Not by an international border but by the ethnic divide that keeps Bosniaks in the city's east and Croats in the west.

Their similarity is this: events in Mostar and Tanusevci in the last two weeks have been ringing alarm bells across the international community as the most visible signs of a new crisis gripping the Balkans from Bosnia to Bulgaria and from Belgrade to Athens.

It is a crisis that is reversing all the assumptions of the international community's experience in the Balkans - one that is turning enemies into friends and old friends into bitter foes. In the new Serbia of Vojislav Kostunica, Nato is suddenly being feted for its tough stance on Albanian extremists in the south of Serbia. In Washington, Paris and London it is the Kosovo Albanians - saved from the hands of Slobodan Milosevic - and the Montenegrans (who supported Nato over Kosovo), who are suddenly the problem.

The heart of the problem is a resurgence in nationalism across the region among minority extremists that some fear could spark a new regional conflagration. In Tanusevci ethnic Albanian guerrillas who fought with the KLA in Kosovo against the Serbs are now fighting the Macedonian security forces. Their aim apparently: to create a 'Greater Kosovo' linking ethnic Albanian communities that live just outside its borders in Serbia, Macedonia and Montenegro, threatening wider ethnic violence between Macedonia's majority Slav population and one third Albanian minority.

For a decade analysts have warned of the risk of war in Macedonia - a conflict, they say, that could suck in countries such as Bulgaria and Greece. Last week - as if on cue - Bulgaria sent military aid to Macedonia's armed forces while Greece sent a mission to report on the crisis on the border.

In Mostar the events have been no less alarming. Last weekend, a congress of the nationalist Bosnian Croat party - the HDZ - voted to set up a Croat ministate. In reply, the international community's administrator in Bosnia - Wolfgang Petritsch - 'fired' the HDZ's leader, Ante Jelavic, disbarring him from politics for threatening the fragile Dayton peace deal that ended the Bosnian war.

And it is not just events in Tanusevci and Mostar that are alarming Western governments. A dangerous coincidence of events is increasing tension across the region. In Serbia, the US government has imposed a deadline of 31 March for the arrest of former Yugoslav dictator Milosevic, if its new rulers want US aid. A few days later the citizens of Montenegro - which, with Serbia, constitutes the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia - go to the polls in an election expected to set the scene for a referendum on independence within three months. In Kosovo itself, where province-wide elections are due later in the year, pressure for independence is growing, amid a slew of murders of ethnic minorities.

And the former leaders of the Kosovo Liberation Army are also accused of backing the fighters of the new National Liberation Army that appeared for the first time last month in Tanusevci, and its sister organisation the UCPMB - which is fighting to establish autonomy for Albanian villages in the Presevo Valley of south Serbia.

'The one thing these crises have in common is borders,' says Chris Bird, a spokesman for the Office of the High Representative which oversees Bosnia's administration. 'People are trying to redraw borders across the region. Our view is that if the international community allows that to happen it will mean dead people.'

In the Balkans, it was ever thus: rival ethnic groups competing with their neighbours for imagined national spaces.

'What defines this rather dangerous phase,' adds a Foreign Office analyst, 'is that we are dealing with losers who are struggling for their survival. We are not looking at a repeat of the circumstances when Yugoslavia began to disintegrate at the beginning of the 1990s. The people we are dealing with now are the fanatics who became wealthy out of nationalist politics, crime and war. They feel that their power is being eroded and they will fight to survive.'

Another dangerous factor, he believes is the complacency that emerged after the removal of Milosevic last October. 'There was a mis placed idea that when Milosevic was ousted things would immediately get better in the Balkans. Instead, his departure has revealed a series of unresolved problems which the international community has yet to get to grips with.'

Biggest among those problems will be what happens in Montenegro. Encouraged by the Americans to believe it would be permitted to split from Serbia, the departure of Milosevic saw the same officials tell Montenegro to forget those aspirations, and renegotiate its ties with Serbia for a looser Yugoslav federation.

It is an idea that angers many in Montenegro who argue that all of the other republics of the old Yugoslavia of General Tito - Croatia, Bosnia, Slovenia and Macedonia - have won their independence. Why, they argue, should Montenegro be the exception?

But while European Union and US policy is that Montenegro should remain in some federal relationship with the new Serbia of Vojislav Kostunica, privately officials believe there is little they can do to stop it seceding.

Their concern, however, is less about the future of Montenegro itself but over the psychological impact that a voting for independence would have elsewhere: not least in neighbouring Kosovo itself, which the international community has decreed should stay within Serbia and not enjoy independence.

'There has been a failure of imagination in the international community over the whole question of the Balkans,' says Mark Thompson, Balkans director for the Brussels-based think-tank, the International Crisis Group. 'There is nothing that physically links the problems in Kosovo and in Bosnia - but what unifies both is this sense of unfinished business.'

While Thompson applauds the actions of Petritsch and the international community in moving against Jelavic, he is worried that, in a wider sense, the glacially slow Dayton peace process may be running into trouble.

'The risk in Bosnia is as much about the spread of defeatism in the international community. There is a mood emerging in some capitals: "We've done our best, but these people do not want a solution".'

Petritsch disagrees with this gloomy prognosis but does not deny that dangerous times lie ahead - in particular amid the growing rhetoric on both sides in Montenegro - which he is worried could contaminate the region with a resurgence of nationalism.

'What we were seeing here with the Bosnian Croats was a return to the old notions of territorial exclusivity. It has never worked in this region and never will. We must not walk into the trap that is being set by the nationalists. It is a blueprint for disaster.'

Petritsch points to the fighting between ethnic Albanian insurgents and Serb forces in the Presevo Valley in southern Serbia as an example of the danger of an ethnically reductive approach of the kind proposed by Jelavic and other nationalists across the region.

Like Thompson, Petritsch is worried that the 'outside world' is experiencing a sense of déjà vu over the current problems that takes them back to the beginning of the 1990s and wars in Croatia and Bosnia. But he believes there is a qualitative difference. 'Those were ethnic conflicts. These are conflicts that are happening as part of progress towards civic society where nationalists are actually on the run.'

Where Petritsch and others find a genuine sense of déjà vu is over the international community's passive stance towards the dangers in Montenegro. 'There is a tendency for the international community to be reactive, to pay attention to where there are men with guns,' he said on Friday. 'That is why so much attention is being paid to the events in Macedonia and the Presevo Valley. But in the case of Montenegro it is up to the EU and the international community to intervene more forcefully.

'WE NEED TO get Serbia and Montenegro to put on the table what the problems are, not start with the immediate question of independence. Then we need to mediate a tough process between the two sides. We need a clear plan. We need them to get engaged otherwise we all have is dangerous rhetoric and escalation.'

The model for the danger of that escalation is already apparent in Macedonia and southern Serbia - a conflict that last week drew in US soldiers into the fighting for the first time when they wounded two Albanian fighters who threatened a patrol near Tanusevci.

Macedonian government officials also warned this weekend in the bleakest terms yet that their country is at risk of splitting in two in the rapidly intensifying fighting on its borders.

The rapidly growing conflict has presented the Nato-led peace keeping force in neighbouring Kosovo with its biggest crisis in over months. Both Macedonia and Serbia blame the alliance for failing to stop Albanian nationalists from using the province as a springboard for their goals. Some officials are more blunt, blaming US intelligence agencies for encouraging the present uprising as part of a misguided attempt to keep up pressure on Milosevic while he was still in power.

WHAT THE guerrillas are trying to achieve is articulated by Shkelzen Maliqi, a journalist for Radio Free Europe based in Pristina, and writer for Institute of War and Peace Reporting . 'I am familiar with the ideology, mentality and motivation behind the forces provoking the armed conflict in Macedonia. I have come to know them, especially the emigrés in Europe.

'They have tried to persuade me that Macedonia is an artificial creation, formed to the detriment of the Albanian nation. They maintain that the enforced division of the Albanian nation was an historical injustice, aimed to prevent it from being equal to its neighbours in the region.'

'That injustice would be rectified, they say, by divid ing Macedonia into Slav and Albanians parts and allowing the latter to unite with Kosovo or, even better, incorporated into a unitary Albanian state.'

Last week those same guerrillas made quite clear what they would do if threatened again by US or other KFor soldiers entering their mountain bases. 'If the Americans enter Tanusevci again,' said one soon after withdrawing from the village, 'we will fire on them.'

Instead, his departure has revealed a series of unresolved problems which the international community has yet to get to grips with.' Biggest among those problems will be what happens in Montenegro. Encouraged by the Americans to believe it would be permitted to split from Serbia, the departure of Milosevic saw the same officials tell Montenegro to forget those aspirations, and renegotiate its ties with Serbia for a looser Yugoslav federation. It is an idea that angers many in Montenegro who argue that all of the other republics of the old Yugoslavia of General Tito - Croatia, Bosnia, Slovenia and Macedonia - have won their independence. Why, they argue, should Montenegro be the exception? But while European Union and US policy is that Montenegro should remain in some federal relationship with the new Serbia of Vojislav Kostunica, privately officials believe there is little they can do to stop it seceding. Their concern, however, is less about the future of Montenegro itself but over the psychological impact that a voting for independence would have elsewhere: not least in neighbouring Kosovo itself, which the international community has decreed should stay within Serbia and not enjoy independence. 'There has been a failure of imagination in the international community over the whole question of the Balkans,' says Mark Thompson, Balkans director for the Brussels-based think-tank, the International Crisis Group. 'There is nothing that physically links the problems in Kosovo and in Bosnia - but what unifies both is this sense of unfinished business.' While Thompson applauds the actions of Petritsch and the international community in moving against Jelavic, he is worried that, in a wider sense, the glacially slow Dayton peace process may be running into trouble. 'The risk in Bosnia is as much about the spread of defeatism in the international community. There is a mood emerging in some capitals: "We've done our best, but these people do not want a solution".' Petritsch disagrees with this gloomy prognosis but does not deny that dangerous times lie ahead - in particular amid the growing rhetoric on both sides in Montenegro - which he is worried could contaminate the region with a resurgence of nationalism. 'What we were seeing here with the Bosnian Croats was a return to the old notions of territorial exclusivity. It has never worked in this region and never will. We must not walk into the trap that is being set by the nationalists. It is a blueprint for disaster.' Petritsch points to the fighting between ethnic Albanian insurgents and Serb forces in the Presevo Valley in southern Serbia as an example of the danger of an ethnically reductive approach of the kind proposed by Jelavic and other nationalists across the region. Like Thompson, Petritsch is worried that the 'outside world' is experiencing a sense of déjà vu over the current problems that takes them back to the beginning of the 1990s and wars in Croatia and Bosnia. But he believes there is a qualitative difference. 'Those were ethnic conflicts. These are conflicts that are happening as part of progress towards civic society where nationalists are actually on the run.' Where Petritsch and others find a genuine sense of déjà vu is over the international community's passive stance towards the dangers in Montenegro. 'There is a tendency for the international community to be reactive, to pay attention to where there are men with guns,' he said on Friday. 'That is why so much attention is being paid to the events in Macedonia and the Presevo Valley. But in the case of Montenegro it is up to the EU and the international community to intervene more forcefully. 'WE NEED TO get Serbia and Montenegro to put on the table what the problems are, not start with the immediate question of independence. Then we need to mediate a tough process between the two sides. We need a clear plan. We need them to get engaged otherwise we all have is dangerous rhetoric and escalation.' The model for the danger of that escalation is already apparent in Macedonia and southern Serbia - a conflict that last week drew in US soldiers into the fighting for the first time when they wounded two Albanian fighters who threatened a patrol near Tanusevci. Macedonian government officials also warned this weekend in the bleakest terms yet that their country is at risk of splitting in two in the rapidly intensifying fighting on its borders. The rapidly growing conflict has presented the Nato-led peace keeping force in neighbouring Kosovo with its biggest crisis in over months. Both Macedonia and Serbia blame the alliance for failing to stop Albanian nationalists from using the province as a springboard for their goals. Some officials are more blunt, blaming US intelligence agencies for encouraging the present uprising as part of a misguided attempt to keep up pressure on Milosevic while he was still in power. WHAT THE guerrillas are trying to achieve is articulated by Shkelzen Maliqi, a journalist for Radio Free Europe based in Pristina, and writer for Institute of War and Peace Reporting . 'I am familiar with the ideology, mentality and motivation behind the forces provoking the armed conflict in Macedonia. I have come to know them, especially the emigrés in Europe. 'They have tried to persuade me that Macedonia is an artificial creation, formed to the detriment of the Albanian nation. They maintain that the enforced division of the Albanian nation was an historical injustice, aimed to prevent it from being equal to its neighbours in the region.' 'That injustice would be rectified, they say, by divid ing Macedonia into Slav and Albanians parts and allowing the latter to unite with Kosovo or, even better, incorporated into a unitary Albanian state.' Last week those same guerrillas made quite clear what they would do if threatened again by US or other KFor soldiers entering their mountain bases. 'If the Americans enter Tanusevci again,' said one soon after withdrawing from the village, 'we will fire on them.' "CIA's bastard army ran riot in Balkans"

webTitle: EU says 'Let it be' to £10m Cavern Club hotel

fields.headline: EU says 'Let it be' to £10m Cavern Club hotel
fields.trailText: It has been a long and winding road, but Liverpool is finally to get a £10 million hotel next to the famous Cavern Club, where the Beatles made their name, writes Nick Mathiason.
fields.body:
It has been a long and winding road, but Liverpool is finally to get a £10 million hotel next to the famous Cavern Club, where the Beatles made their name, writes Nick Mathiason.

A breakthrough in a long-running row over state subsidies between Brussels and the Government means Liverpool can now begin to draw down a £400m European Objective One grant.

The news will kickstart the building of a 120-bed hotel called The Hard Day's Night, which will receive £3m of European money. Hotel visitors will have direct access to the club.

The Cavern, which reopened as a live venue in 1984, is now a tourist mecca for fans of Merseyside's Fab Four. It first opened its doors in 1957 as a jazz club, which was infiltrated by skiffle and blues bands. Between 1961 and 1963, the Beatles made nearly 300 appearances there.

webTitle: Littlewoods staff shocked as ailing group buys 'des res' for the boss

fields.headline: Littlewoods staff shocked as ailing group buys 'des res' for the boss
fields.trailText: Littlewoods, the struggling department store and catalogues group, has splashed out almost £500,000 on a luxury home for the use of its chief executive.
fields.body:
Littlewoods, the struggling department store and catalogues group, has splashed out almost £500,000 on a luxury home for the use of its chief executive.

The loss-making, privately owned company is going through a huge cost-cutting and redundancy programme. Morale among employees is at rock-bottom and the property deal has shocked staff.

Chief executive Barry Gibson joined in 1997 and earned a salary of £700,000 last year. He is also understood to be due a bonus if Littlewoods proceeds with flotation plans, originally scheduled for this year but postponed because of the group's poor results.

Gibson joined in 1997 and last year told staff that he would finally move the family home from exclusive Belgravia in London nearer to Littlewoods' Liverpool base.

Records just filed by the Land Registry, however, show that his Merseyside home was purchased last November for £495,000 by Littlewoods Properties Ltd, a subsidiary.

The large, white, mock-Georgian house is located in the village of Parkgate in one of the most desirable areas of the South Wirral in Cheshire.

This weekend, a Littlewoods' spokesman denied there was anything extraordinary about the purchase.

'Barry Gibson is relocating from London to the Wirral. We have acquired the property and are renting it at a market rent to Mr Gibson,' said Jim Donovan, Littlewoods' communications director.

'We own a range of properties. It is an asset we have... it is let on a one-year rental contract, which can be terminated at that stage.'

In December, the group announced first-half losses of £15.6m and the controlling Moores family are understood to be restless about the poor performance.

webTitle: Barclays pays out £150m in City bonuses

fields.headline: Barclays pays out £150m in City bonuses
fields.trailText: Barclays Bank splashed out more than £150 million in City bonuses to executives at its investment banking and fund management arms last year.
fields.body:
Barclays Bank splashed out more than £150 million in City bonuses to executives at its investment banking and fund management arms last year.

The news will infuriate its 50,000 high street staff, who have borne the brunt of massive cost-cutting and branch closures.

The performance-related bonuses paid to 6,300 staff at Barclays Capital (in Canary Wharf) and Barclays Global Investors made up the lion's share of a £172m increase in the group's salary-related costs last year.

Close analysis of Barclays' annual report also shows that Canadian chief executive Matt Barrett earned a total of £2.8m, including profits on share options. This is much higher than the £1.7m widely reported last week.

The accounts, for the calendar year, were issued on Budget day, last Wednesday, the busiest day of the year in the City.

Since Barrett's arrival in autumn 1999, Barclays has snapped up the Woolwich and forged an insurance alliance with Legal & General. It has also, sources close to the bank confirm, been exploring a possible merger with Dutch bank ABN Amro.

But it ambitions to re-enter investment banking proper will unsettle the City following the disastrous performance and final disposal of BZW in 1998.

This weekend a Barclays spokeswoman declined to discuss the ABN Amro talks or the bonuses. 'We never comment on speculation,' she said. 'Our approach to salaries is to reflect the market and pay for performance.'

Recent City talk has been of 100 bonus millionaires at Barclays Capital. That is an exaggeration, Barclays' sources say, although investment banking chief Bob Diamond - hired on a £5m package - is undoubtedly the bank's biggest earner. The division, which runs Barclays' bond market operations, made £403m last year, up from £311m. Its income, however, rose by £310m - and more than half of that was eaten up by rising costs, principally the huge bonuses.

Barclays put the improved performance down to hectic activity last year in the bond and debt markets. In June, however, it transferred its top 250 corporate loan accounts to Barclays Capital. The effect of this was not disclosed.

Sources close to the bank said the growing power of Barclays Capital had cost shareholders dear. 'Greedy investment bankers still take so much out,' said one. 'For every £1 of income transferred to Canary Wharf, they pocket 50p or more.'

Despite the recovery, Barclays' Capital is still the bank's worst performing division. Its operating return was just 0.25 per cent on its £157bn of assets.

webTitle: Budget 2001: The hard-up pensioners

fields.headline: Real life: The hard-up pensioners
fields.trailText: Pensioners Ernest and Patricia Hallett have found their standard of living falling in line with the real value of their pensions. Ernest, who used to work in the printing trade, gets £17 a week from a non-indexed work scheme plus £129.42 from the basic state pension and Serps, the old state earnings pension scheme.
fields.body:
Pensioners Ernest and Patricia Hallett have found their standard of living falling in line with the real value of their pensions. Ernest, who used to work in the printing trade, gets £17 a week from a non-indexed work scheme plus £129.42 from the basic state pension and Serps, the old state earnings pension scheme.

Patricia belonged to the teachers' pension scheme and receives a slightly higher pension. The couple have some savings and their joint total income totals about £18,000 a year.

This is enough for day-to-day costs, but from this year the Leicester couple will have to give up their annual holiday abroad. Ernest is worried they will not be able to replace more expensive items as they wear out. 'I can see that the car will have to go shortly,' he says.

Ernest has been a lifelong Labour voter, but he is disappointed that the Government has not reintroduced the link between the state pension and earnings, which was abolished by the Conservatives.

'This is costing us £30 a week,' he says. 'We've got a few quid out of Labour, but what we really want is the reinstatement of the earnings link.' He is secretary of the regional branch of Pensioners' Rights Campaign, lobbying candidates at the next election to support a call for a substantial pension increase, an end to means-testing and reinstatement of the earnings link. 'We've told them that if they don't support us, we won't vote for them,' he says.

Ernest has gained from the £200 heating allowance, but at 74 he is not old enough to qualify for a free TV licence, and his council tax is going up by 6.5 per cent.

The couple will benefit from the extension of the 10p tax band.

Guy Smith of accountant Moore Stephens says they will get an £8 a week increase in the basic state pension, and will benefit from the pensioners' tax credit from 2003, which is linked to earnings.

But Smith warns: 'This is nowhere near as attractive as having their whole pension linked to earnings.'

webTitle: Budget 2001: A family with children

fields.headline: Real life: A family with children
fields.trailText: Sharron Murray and her husband Michael have two children, Calum, who is 20 months, and Gregor, three years old.
fields.body:
Sharron Murray and her husband Michael have two children, Calum, who is 20 months, and Gregor, three years old.

Between giving birth to Calum and Gregor, Sharron worked part-time as a buyer for a chemicals company, earning £10,000 a year, but now she is a full-time mother and does no paid work.

She belonged to a company pension scheme before, but has not been able to contribute since leaving work.

She has been investing £100 a month in a Fidelity Isa for her children, and she may invest in a stakeholder pension when they are introduced in April.

Gregor attends a state nursery in the afternoon, so the family has no childcare costs now.

But when he starts primary school in two years' time, Sharron is considering going back to work . If she does, she will need to find a childminder or nanny to look after Calum.

However, the couple's combined salaries will be sufficiently high to ensure that they do not qualify for any financial help with childcare.

The couple live in the west end of Aberdeen and have a mortgage of £90,000. Although interest rates have fallen during the last four years, they lost the benefit of mortgage tax relief, worth £225 a year when it was finally abolished by Labour in April 2000.

The couple will also have to find a hefty amount to pay stamp duty if they want to move home.

Sharron feels generally worse off under Labour. The main reason for this is undoubtedly related to the cost of having children and giving up work, but she also feels she is paying more for groceries, petrol and the utilities.

webTitle: Art review: 19th C paintings from the Nationalgalerie, Berlin

fields.headline: German easels
fields.standfirst: Old Berliners were sticklers for the Teutonic ideal in all its sunlit glory. But amid the Gothic castles and walks in the Black Forest are signs of rebellion.
fields.trailText: ArtOld Berliners were sticklers for the Teutonic ideal in all its sunlit glory. But amid the Gothic castles and walks in the Black Forest are signs of rebellion.
fields.body:
Spirit of an Age: Nineteenth-Century Paintings from the Nationalgalerie, Berlin
London WC2 until 13 May

Anyone who thinks that running a museum is just an easy sleep should consider the fate of Hugo von Tschudi, free-spirited director of that most manacled of institutions, the Nationalgalerie in Berlin.

Tschudi got the job in 1896. Within weeks, he had acquired the first Cézanne ever owned by a museum. Ignoring his predecessor's 20-year struggle to show anything more than patriotic propaganda, he even had the gall to hang this French daub on the wall. At this scandal, the Prussian Parliament erupted in fury and called for Kaiser Wilhelm to intervene. The picture was removed and so, a few years later, was Tschudi himself - following a last brave bid to introduce Delacroix to Berlin.

If it hadn't been for Tschudi, there would be very little foreign painting in the Nationalgalerie at all. There isn't much as it is - a handful of works by Courbet, Manet and Monet, plus the offending Cézanne. To understand what Tschudi was up against you need only read the diktat that confronted him every morning - 'To German Art' emblazoned in gold on the neo-classical facade of the building.

Every director before or since has had to contend with this nationalist imperative. Those who made the effort to resist the Prussian patriots were generally wounded in action. The director who tried to defend the avant garde by constructing a 'Nordic' tradition - from Friedrich to German expressionism - was swiftly sacked by the Nazis. In 1937, almost all of the twentieth century art was seized and the modern wing was shut down.

It is worth remembering that golden diktat as you walk through Spirit of an Age at London's National Gallery. Seventy-seven works have been borrowed from Berlin, all but seven painted in the nineteenth century. A filleted edition of an entire museum, the show is inevitably incomplete. It is also extremely various and wildly uneven, ranging from the outstanding to the strikingly bad. But every one of these pictures has had to conform at some time to an ever-changing ideal of German art.

In the nineteenth century, that meant Gothic castles, swooning damsels and lovelorn heroes in medieval footwear. It meant Frederick the Great performing flute recitals to rapt audiences at Sanssouci and William I receiving a grand send-off to the Prussian Front. It meant Protestant sermons and national legends, divine sunsets over Bohemia and classical ruins transposed to Black Forest glades. Above all, at the beginning and end of the century, it meant the romantic yearnings of Caspar David Friedrich.

There are seven paintings by Friedrich in this show, all of them purest content. Here are his mighty German oaks, shattered or snowbound, but still thrusting upwards like signposts to a future of national resurgence and hope. Here are his moons, seen from mountains and cliff-tops by lone figures silhouetted against the screen of glowing light - the immanence of God as revealed to awestruck mortals.

One of these, Moonrise Over the Sea, is among the transcendent images of German art. A man and two women are seated on a rock, gazing out over a motionless sea. It is not clear exactly what they're looking at - Friedrich's onlookers experience such diffuse visions - the tall ships, the violet light on the water or the moon itself, rising behind a distant veil of clouds. Nor can one easily decipher the Christian allegory Friedrich compressed into this small picture in 1822. What remains is the powerful aura of significance: the spectacle of religious contemplation has become a contemplative object in itself.

Beautiful as they are, these images are also coercive. In the flat plane of Friedrich's paint, so dead and uninflected, there is nowhere for the eye to go except where the master directs - to the top of the German tree, or out across the peaks to God in his Sudeten sunset. Friedrich's vision of the infinite is always circumscribed by the banality of his brushwork. So it's good to know, in the context of this show, that he had subversive aims as well. The figures in these paintings are wearing altdeutsch costumes - banned as the uniform of liberals in 1819.

The seaside figures in Carl Blechen's Gulf of Naples are gazing into a wild blue never found in nature. Overexcited by the Italian skies, Blechen squeezed the cobalt directly from the tube. He was one of a dozen artists in this show who went south to Goethe's 'land where the lemons flower' for the landscape, the classical ruins and the example of the Renaissance. The 'Nazarenes' settled in a ruined monastery, painting each other in their cells and studying Raphael with religious fervour. Their stiff and pious works are remarkably hard to look at today. But at least one of them had a sense of humour. Carl Spitweg sketched English tourists among the ruins: bored, querulous and deeply buried in their guidebooks.

All roads led to Rome for nineteenth century artists. The unexpected connection in Spirit of an Age is between Germany and its once and future enemy - France. You see this relationship flourish in the room where Manet and Courbet hang next to their German peers. Hans Thoma's Bunch of Wild Flowers is a beautiful variation on a Manet still life, elaborated around a spray of Bavarian gentians and buttercups. Wilhelm Liebl's realist portraits of villagers stand comparison with Courbet, who admired the Munich artist. But the most international of all these painters is probably the least well known - Adolph Menzel, the dwarfish Berliner whose career spanned more than half the century.

Menzel was so versatile that it's hard to fix on his peculiar gift - but it has something to do with freedom, a resistance to the orthodox or predictable in any picture. Eyes conditioned by decades of impressionism may think they see it prefigured in his Balcony Room from 1845. But there is more to this bare interior, painted on a small rectangle of cardboard.

Menzel is certainly interested in light, the way it fumbles among the gauze at the window, swims across the polished floor and dwindles to a mute opacity in the darkened mirror. But his brushwork is even more volatile, performing a single squiggle for a lamp, sidling along a chairback, shifting from matt shadow to melting reflection without any apparent transition. The room is empty. But the painting is full, vibrating with quixotic motion.

Look at his ballroom scene, crammed with guests assaulting the buffet, and you see these transitions multiplied on a massive scale. Menzel works the room with amazing dexterity - slipping between the figures as they laugh, flirt or try to eat while standing upright, goblets precariously balanced on plates. Degas copied this painting, fascinated by its dissolves and shifts of focus as Menzel skims the social theatre, from lonely shadows to super-lit mirth, conversation surging and becalmed.

Menzel painted steam trains, iron works, gas-lit theatres - a modern Germany the Nationalgalerie could accept. He even painted that image of Frederick at Sanssouci, 'like a shop assistant', as he put it, 'piping to mothers on a Sunday'. For Menzel, the real subject of the picture was the blazing light of the chandelier, igniting in a flurry of paint. That is what makes him so different from many of the artists in this show - his painting is independent, not hitched to some ideal of German art.

In the nineteenth century, that meant Gothic castles, swooning damsels and lovelorn heroes in medieval footwear. It meant Frederick the Great performing flute recitals to rapt audiences at Sanssouci and William I receiving a grand send-off to the Prussian Front. It meant Protestant sermons and national legends, divine sunsets over Bohemia and classical ruins transposed to Black Forest glades. Above all, at the beginning and end of the century, it meant the romantic yearnings of Caspar David Friedrich. There are seven paintings by Friedrich in this show, all of them purest content. Here are his mighty German oaks, shattered or snowbound, but still thrusting upwards like signposts to a future of national resurgence and hope. Here are his moons, seen from mountains and cliff-tops by lone figures silhouetted against the screen of glowing light - the immanence of God as revealed to awestruck mortals. One of these, Moonrise Over the Sea, is among the transcendent images of German art. A man and two women are seated on a rock, gazing out over a motionless sea. It is not clear exactly what they're looking at - Friedrich's onlookers experience such diffuse visions - the tall ships, the violet light on the water or the moon itself, rising behind a distant veil of clouds. Nor can one easily decipher the Christian allegory Friedrich compressed into this small picture in 1822. What remains is the powerful aura of significance: the spectacle of religious contemplation has become a contemplative object in itself. Beautiful as they are, these images are also coercive. In the flat plane of Friedrich's paint, so dead and uninflected, there is nowhere for the eye to go except where the master directs - to the top of the German tree, or out across the peaks to God in his Sudeten sunset. Friedrich's vision of the infinite is always circumscribed by the banality of his brushwork. So it's good to know, in the context of this show, that he had subversive aims as well. The figures in these paintings are wearing altdeutsch costumes - banned as the uniform of liberals in 1819. The seaside figures in Carl Blechen's Gulf of Naples are gazing into a wild blue never found in nature. Overexcited by the Italian skies, Blechen squeezed the cobalt directly from the tube. He was one of a dozen artists in this show who went south to Goethe's 'land where the lemons flower' for the landscape, the classical ruins and the example of the Renaissance. The 'Nazarenes' settled in a ruined monastery, painting each other in their cells and studying Raphael with religious fervour. Their stiff and pious works are remarkably hard to look at today. But at least one of them had a sense of humour. Carl Spitweg sketched English tourists among the ruins: bored, querulous and deeply buried in their guidebooks. All roads led to Rome for nineteenth century artists. The unexpected connection in Spirit of an Age is between Germany and its once and future enemy - France. You see this relationship flourish in the room where Manet and Courbet hang next to their German peers. Hans Thoma's Bunch of Wild Flowers is a beautiful variation on a Manet still life, elaborated around a spray of Bavarian gentians and buttercups. Wilhelm Liebl's realist portraits of villagers stand comparison with Courbet, who admired the Munich artist. But the most international of all these painters is probably the least well known - Adolph Menzel, the dwarfish Berliner whose career spanned more than half the century. Menzel was so versatile that it's hard to fix on his peculiar gift - but it has something to do with freedom, a resistance to the orthodox or predictable in any picture. Eyes conditioned by decades of impressionism may think they see it prefigured in his Balcony Room from 1845. But there is more to this bare interior, painted on a small rectangle of cardboard. Menzel is certainly interested in light, the way it fumbles among the gauze at the window, swims across the polished floor and dwindles to a mute opacity in the darkened mirror. But his brushwork is even more volatile, performing a single squiggle for a lamp, sidling along a chairback, shifting from matt shadow to melting reflection without any apparent transition. The room is empty. But the painting is full, vibrating with quixotic motion. Look at his ballroom scene, crammed with guests assaulting the buffet, and you see these transitions multiplied on a massive scale. Menzel works the room with amazing dexterity - slipping between the figures as they laugh, flirt or try to eat while standing upright, goblets precariously balanced on plates. Degas copied this painting, fascinated by its dissolves and shifts of focus as Menzel skims the social theatre, from lonely shadows to super-lit mirth, conversation surging and becalmed. Menzel painted steam trains, iron works, gas-lit theatres - a modern Germany the Nationalgalerie could accept. He even painted that image of Frederick at Sanssouci, 'like a shop assistant', as he put it, 'piping to mothers on a Sunday'. For Menzel, the real subject of the picture was the blazing light of the chandelier, igniting in a flurry of paint. That is what makes him so different from many of the artists in this show - his painting is independent, not hitched to some ideal of German art.

fields.headline: Revival of the fittest
fields.standfirst: The elegiac Triad returns after 17 years to expose the pangs of adolescence
fields.trailText: The elegiac Triad returns after 17 years to expose the pangs of adolescence .
fields.body:
Triad, This House Will Burn Royal Ballet, ROH, London WC2

Powder, Concerto Barocco Birmingham Royal Ballet, Alexandra Theatre, Birmingham

Both Royal Ballet companies honoured the passing of their founder, Dame Ninette de Valois, last Thursday, the Covent Garden company by a minute's silence, the Birmingham one with a minute's applause before curtain up. In London, Anthony Dowell paid tribute to her as one of the twentieth century's most influential figures in the arts, before touching on his personal memories of her. Foremost among her qualities, he said, was her practicality - there could be no question of cancelling performances to mourn her death. 'Get on with it, dear,' she would have decreed, and so her two companies did, as always, what she wanted.

The Royal Ballet's latest programme showcases work by two of its own choreographers: a new ballet by Ashley Page and Kenneth MacMillan's 1972 Triad. Dowell chose to revive Triad for his last season as director because the role of the older brother had been created for him and he wanted to see the ballet again after its 17-year absence. Coincidentally, de Valois had sent MacMillan a cable after Triad 's opening night, saying: 'For me your finest work.'

MacMillan's seashore ballet seems an elegy for the end of innocence. Set to Prokofiev's first violin concerto, it recalls the pangs of first love and the pain of being unwanted. Childhood allegiances shift as a girl comes between two brothers. She is drawn to the older one, sending the younger boy wild with a resentment he barely understands. He comes between them with the rage of a child trying to separate parents whose sexual passion excludes him.

As danced by Jamie Tapper, the girl is unconsciously provocative. She seems a wanton water creature who tumbles with the two boys like an otter or a mermaid. The older brother (Johan Persson) knows how to handle her. He shows his younger sibling (Edward Watson in the first cast) what the holds are; the boy copies him until his eyes are shielded by his brother's hand: don't look now, this is not for you - yet.

Watson lays bare the agony of adolescence - the conviction that life will never come right, that he will never know love. Hectically out of control as a dancer, he makes the ballet come alive; the other two are featureless, their intimacy shutting out the audience as well as the desolate youngster.

Ashley Page's This House Will Burn could almost be a projection of the same boy's overheated imagination. It starts with Watson keeling over like a cokehead at a gruesome party. Maybe it's not a party but the overlapping stories of three couples and a child molester. Or a serial murderer and a prostitute. Maybe the two pyromaniac kids fantasised the whole thing. Whatever.

Page has taken his inspiration from tantalising paintings by Stephen Chambers (who co-designed the set and costumes with Jon Morrell). This is today's world seen through disturbed children's eyes: adults do strange things to each other, trading partners and identities. Courtship rituals are games of violence whose rules remain a mystery. The nine dancers appear to know what is going on; we cannot focus on their simultaneous activities, which take place in a junkyard of a house, including the proverbial kitchen sink.

Orlando Gough has supplied a suitably rackety score, whose jazzy sonorities are punctuated by hoarse cries and grunts. Urged on by the music, the dancers couple with fierce intensity. Each duet is in a different style, bringing out the particular qualities of the astonishing performers; to what end, though, is impossible to tell. After 40 minutes, Johan Kobborg is lit up like a bogeyman, Zenaida Yanowsky climbs the wall, Watson wears a frock and the nameless children have presumably gone for counselling.

Birmingham Royal Ballet's dancers and audiences are considerably less challenged by Stanton Welch's Powder, created for the company three years ago. Its revival, like Welch's reputation, is a puzzle even in a low period for choreography. He embroiders Mozart's lucid clarinet concerto with funky footwork, twitching fingers and wagging heads. There is just one coherent solo for Dorcas Walters among meaningless flourishes, impassioned hugs and rushings in and out in fluffy skirts.

Welch's lack of rigour is shown up by Balanchine's Concerto Barocco, to Bach's double violin concerto in D minor. BRB's cast are decorous rather than daring but they grasp the logic of dancing these steps to this music. The ballet will teach them how to dance it better, faster, with more surprises. Balanchine is bracingly ruthless - no emoting, no distracting sets or costumes.

After 20 minutes (half the length of Page's ballet), the dancers are at the end of their tether and we are left wanting more.

Dame Ninette de Valois

1898-2001

Right to the end, Madam (as Dame Ninette de Valois was known to the Royal Ballet) refused to dwell on her glory days. She was far too concerned with the present, with how and what her two companies were dancing. She questioned visitors for their opinions rather than delivering hers. In her hundredth year she said to me, wickedly: 'I'm interviewing you now, aren't I?'

She always had a clear vision of what she wanted to achieve. Her rival as the midwife of British ballet, Marie Rambert, operated on a hand-to-mouth basis; De Valois knew her long-term plan for a national ballet company needed support from the British establishment. She had to communicate her enthusiasm to them as well as build audiences. Above all, she needed to ensure that the institutions she put in place could survive without her.

In this, she was wiser than Diaghilev, whose Ballets Russes she joined as a dancer from 1923-25. 'Diaghilev gave us all something, but you took something from him,' one of his former ballerinas told de Valois years later. She took the understanding that a great company had to be founded on a strong classical training, however experimental its choreographers might be.

De Valois was a versatile choreographer herself, creating 110 works, 40 of them complete ballets. The two she wanted to be remembered by are Checkmate and The Rake's Progress, which have been shown all over the world. Job, her 'masque for dancing', has been frequently staged, and the Birmingham Royal Ballet revived The Prospect Before Us for her centenary celebrations.

She gave way to other choreographers once her duties as director took up most of her time. Thanks to Lilian Baylis, De Valois had been able to establish her company at the Old Vic, then at Sadler's Wells. In 1946, they expanded into the Royal Opera House and De Valois set up a second touring group - now the Birmingham Royal Ballet (BRB). She was eager to bring in new blood, as well as to give every opportunity to Frederick Ashton who became her successor as director of the Royal Ballet in 1963.

Her last protégé was David Bintley, now director of BRB. She gave him a hard time, however, when she prepared him for the role of the Red King in Checkmate. Notoriously tough in rehearsal, she insisted her memory was correct - until she admitted she was mistaken. 'I've got it all wrong. Let's do it again and get it right.'

One of her most disarming traits was her capacity to change her mind, rally the rattled troops and go for a drink with them to forget about her tantrums. She made all her speeches without notes. 'I suppose I remember things that interest me,' she explained at an Observer lunch in her honour. Almost bumping into her in the ladies' loo, I curtsied in apology: an odd thing to do, except that she was accustomed to dancers' revérences. In the ballet world, she was royalty, an imperious figure, small and rather fierce, until she shook with laughter. Her departure leaves us bereft.

webTitle: Television: The Human Face

fields.headline: Facial prejudice
fields.standfirst: You can learn a lot from a face - but not much from watching John Cleese and Liz Hurley talk about them.
fields.trailText: You can learn a lot from a face - but not much from watching John Cleese and Liz Hurley talk about them.
fields.body:
The Human Face BBC1
Horizon BBC2
Fertility Tourists BBC1
ER C4
Crossroads ITV

Elizabeth Hurley was hired to inject some va-va-voom into BBC1's new science show, The Human Face, playing 'Janet' - a glamorous-but-dumb assistant in a series of unfunny sketches alongside John Cleese's 'Professor Cleese'. Oddly, there were all sorts of mildly cheeky, yet laboriously scripted digs, from Cleese about 'Janet's' acting ability ('I told 'em to get Judi Dench'), so one can only assume she was there to wear yet another catsuit and prove herself to be a jolly good sport in the process.

Hurley-burlesque costume changes aside, it was possible to watch 50 minutes of The Human Face without learning a single thing one couldn't have picked up from a 10-year-old copy of Cosmo: laughing and smiling is good for you; too much time spent in front of computer screens is alienating and married couples who display sneering expressions of contempt while in each other's company are likely to be heading for divorce... er, run that by me again, John!

Cleese is such a national treasure that he could propose a history of toasted sandwiches and the BBC wouldn't hesitate to commission a 10-part series!

It's been, oh, easily weeks since the last highly emotive, breast-beating, whither-our-children documentary, but along came Horizon's Taming The Problem Child to scare the hell out of parents, while putting everyone else off procreation. Given the choice between procuring the services of Michael 'Heal the Kids' Jackson as a childminder or hiring American psychologist Dr Ron Federici to tame your troubled offspring, don't hesitate: at least with Jackson the kids would get to pet a llama.

In Sussex, five-year-old Hayley's parents were at the end of their tether - mildly autistic and prone to spectacular tantrums, Hayley had been excluded from school for fighting. While in Texas, 12-year-old Sergei had been adopted by an American couple from a Russian orphanage at the age of eight (he had been found wandering the streets of St Petersburg like a stray puppy four years earlier). Sergei's rages were now threatening the very stability of his family.

These were two very different cases but Federici chose to treat them exactly the same way: deprived of their 'personality', with books, toys and computer games consigned to packing cases, the two kids were expected to spend several weeks no further than three feet away from their parents, obeying orders at all times. Violations and tantrums were punishable by being held face down on the floor until the children complied, and then in order to recreate what Federici perceives to be a broken parent-child bond responsible for the bad behaviour, there was also enforced hugging.

In the event, the hold-downs made for grim viewing and while it was one thing to watch a little girl being forced to sit on her mother's knee, it was quite another to witness burly Sergei being made to do the same: his fury was palpable. In children's homes this kind of behaviour might prompt an investigation, but elsewhere it seems documentary camera crews can stop by to watch. I hasten to qualify this, however, by stressing that Hayley's and Sergei's parents were patently decent well-meaning souls with all the right motivations. In other hands, though, one shivered to think how such a radical course of 'treatment' might be employed.

And the outcome was predictable: at five, Hayley was, presumably, sufficiently emotionally and physically malleable to learn the 'correct' responses. She 'improved' at home but once back at school, carried on fighting: 'two steps forward, one step back' reported her mother. Unsurprisingly, Sergei lapsed immediately. Nobody knows about the first four years of Sergei's life (not even Sergei, who has 'forgotten'), but surely any doctor who prescribes treatment for a patient without knowledge of their medical and psychological history is potentially in violation of the code of medical ethics?

This was enormously distressing television and I remain entirely ambivalent about whether Horizon should have given Federici the airtime without also carrying a warning.

In comparison, Fertility Tourists came as light relief. Here we met the Mastertons, the grieving parents of four sons whose only daughter had died in an accident, and who were now wanting selective fertility treatment to ensure another female child - a procedure outlawed in Britain. To Italy then, where sixtysomething would-be mother Jenny has also been seeking a child. Back in 1992, she was the subject of a documentary in which her Italian doctor was confronted by a pre-peerage Robert Winston, questioning the ethics of assisting post-menopausal women with conception.

Jenny, a mildly eccentric retired zoologist, had no doubt it was the right choice, despite the fact that she seemed only to have noticed the lack of a child in her life when it was far too late to have one by normal methods - perhaps it was when she'd stopped working with animals? I couldn't help feeling that if maternal yearnings kick in when you're about to pick up your bus pass, one should probably just shrug and visit Battersea dogs home. Either way, Jenny's treatment has been unsuccessful, even though she says she'll probably still be at it when she's 70 - 'well, why not?' No, Jenny, not 'why not?' but why?

Unlike Jenny, the Mastertons could only afford one shot - and it failed. Or rather, though successfully fertilised, the result wasn't female, which was as good as a failure in this case.

Though one sympathised with the couple, the lesson seemed to be that four healthy sons could be more than enough children for anybody. Fertility Tourists followed another couple, too - from the Middle East to Harley Street - but their story was entirely dull for the simple reason that, being Muslims who were in defiance of religious law, their faces were necessarily hidden. As Cleese had reminded us, it's very hard to engage with people whose faces you can't see, never mind those who speak only through an interpreter. For all we knew the couple were cracking jokes, but without the close-ups of joy and grief, even the most potentially heart-string-tugging documentary comes across as dry as a medical text.

More mad medics, manipulatively-tugged heart-strings and desperate 'our-baby-heartbreak' plots than you could poke a thermometer at in ER, including a premature birth and the resultant breathing doll fighting hopelessly for its spooky little plastic life.

Oh and I had intended to review Crossroads (the creaky old 'brand' has been revived as a robust and bustling four-star hotel for no reason other than that soapland's holy grail is the cloistered co-dependent community and we've got enough squares, streets and hospitals already) but, frankly, how many emergency resuscitations can one survive in a week?

More mad medics, manipulatively-tugged heart-strings and desperate 'our-baby-heartbreak' plots than you could poke a thermometer at in ER, including a premature birth and the resultant breathing doll fighting hopelessly for its spooky little plastic life. Oh and I had intended to review Crossroads (the creaky old 'brand' has been revived as a robust and bustling four-star hotel for no reason other than that soapland's holy grail is the cloistered co-dependent community and we've got enough squares, streets and hospitals already) but, frankly, how many emergency resuscitations can one survive in a week?

webTitle: Music review: Gorillaz in our midst

fields.headline: Gorillaz in our midst
fields.standfirst: Damon Albarn thinks his new animated outfit could change the world.
fields.trailText: Damon Albarn thinks his new animated outfit could change the world.
fields.body:
Damon Albarn, sitting astride a broken office chair in his west London studio, attempts to restrain a grin from consuming his entire face, and fails. 'Unfortunately, Gorillaz couldn't be with us here today,' he smirks. 'But don't worry, me and him will act as their spokespeople, if you like.'

Him, it transpires, is Tank Girl creator and former Albarn flatmate Jamie Hewlett. Hewlett nods, and says hello. 'The band is real,' he insists, 'but they are currently indisposed. They've briefed us on what to say, though, so fire away.' He glances over at his co-conspirator, his own grin now every bit as wide.

What larks. Gorillaz, then, is the country's first virtual act, an entirely animated four-piece masterminded by the Blur frontman and brought to vivid, if ultimately two-dimensional life, by Hewlett. 'Gorillaz may not be real,' says the latter, 'but they are no less so than the caricatures that are Marilyn Manson and Eminem.'

The band consists of four very different individuals, each, their human counterparts claim, with their own distinct personality. Singer 2D looks not unlike Albarn in need of immediate dentistry; bassist Murdoc, with a nuclear mushroom head of black hair, bears certain resemblance to Blur's Alex James; Russel is the bulky New York-born drummer/ rapper; and elfin Japanese guitarist Noodle doesn't speak a word of English, but smiles freely.

'We - I mean they - are a complete reaction to what is going on in the charts at the moment,' says Albarn, catching himself. 'Everything is so manufactured these days, and pop stars seem to be lacking in character and personality. Gorillaz are different. They may only appear in cartoon form but, believe me, they are larger than life. Anyone who is bored with music today will love Gorillaz.'

The entire concept came to Albarn and Hewlett late one night two years ago, the pair keen to break boundaries and the Blur frontman reluctant to simply record a regular solo album. They then spent several protracted months compiling a wish list of collaborators and eventually came up with an impressive roll call of world music talent: former Talking Heads members Chris Frantz and Tina Weymouth, old school US rapper Del Tha Funkee Homosapien, Cibo Matto's Miho Hatori and Cuban singer Ibrahim Ferrer.

The resulting, eponymously titled debut album - recorded in Jamaica largely, it seems, because of the pleasant climate - is wildly esoteric, a jumbled rag bag of lo-fi scratchings, hip hop and reggae, all glued together by Albarn's often disarming falsetto and his ability to craft melody from unusual sources. If it's patchy in places, then that can only be expected from an experiment as mad as this. Mostly, though, it's inspirational.

'This is not novelty,' says Albarn. 'In fact, it's quite the opposite. We see Gorillaz not as just another new pop act, but a complete subversion of current trends. Everybody who contributed to the album felt that little bit more confident in being expressive in ways they've not tried before, and the results speak for themselves. It's been incredibly liberating, and I'm very interested to see how influential the band becomes. Within a year, I bet the charts will be full of animated bands.'

Despite the obvious limitations of a cartoon pop creation invented by millionaire rock stars - they'll never sign a single autograph, and guesting on Saturday morning kid shows in the 'flesh' remains highly improbable - Gorillaz, nevertheless, aim to be as accessible as possible, in cyberspace. Their website, www.gorillaz.com, will give browsers the opportunity to interact with each band member, hack into their personal computers, chat with fellow fans on the message board and even spray graffiti on the bathroom walls. Both Albarn and Hewlett, who oversee it on a daily basis, are convinced that it has the potential to be one of the biggest sites of its kind, a sort of dotcom shopping mall on many levels, renting out space to artists and high street retailers. 'The possibilities are endless,' they say.

If all this seems like rather a lot of work for two men both in their thirties and both with small children, they insist it's worth it.

'We're breaking new ground here,' says Hewlett, who spent three and a half sleepless months creating the video that accompanies new single 'Clint Eastwood'. 'As far as we know, no one else is doing this in the world right now, not on the level we are operating on, anyway. Effectively, we're revolutionaries, changing the face of pop.'

Before complete cyberspace domination ensues, they are more planning their very first live performance (at London's Scala on 22 March, with more dates to be announced). It will, they predict, be very different.

'The band are a little nervous about it right now, but I can promise you it'll be like nothing you've ever seen before,' Albarn says, leaning back and allowing the sly grin to become increasingly self-satisfied.

 The single 'Clint Eastwood' is out now; the album Gorillaz is released on 26 March

webTitle: Radio: Richter Night, R3

fields.headline: I've already found my programme of the year - all five hours of it
fields.trailText: Remind me, someone, this time next year, when radio critics are traditionally requested to submit their nominations for best programme and radio personality of the year. You need only say one word - Richter.
fields.body:
Richter Night R3

Remind me, someone, this time next year, when radio critics are traditionally requested to submit their nominations for best programme and radio personality of the year. You need only say one word - Richter.

On Wednesday night, Radio 3 cleared its schedules and devoted the entire evening to the life and work of Sviatoslav Richter, often described as the greatest pianist of the century. There was no particular peg, no anniversary or centenary (Richter was born in the Ukraine in 1915 and died in Moscow four years ago), but pegs are too often an excuse and an event like this needed no excuses. The only requirements for a broadcasting marathon on this scale are a fascinating subject and a presenter who can maintain the listener's interest in said subject for five whole hours without repetition, hesitation or deviation. Fortunately, in Sviatoslav Richter and Sir John Drummond, we had both.

Much of Richter's fascination is due to the fact that we in the West knew so little about the legendary Russian musician until he was well into middle age. For political reasons the man who played at Stalin's funeral was not permitted to travel abroad until 1960, when he gave his first international concert in Helsinki.

Of the many revealing anecdotes from the programme's contributors - there was a wealth of both - I liked the one about that concert in Finland. At the time, every recording manager in the West was desperate to get Richter to sign a record deal. One enterprising aspirant, having failed to get a ticket to the Helsinki concert, climbed into the hall by a back window and found himself fortuitously in the artist's dressing room. He persuaded Richter to come to Paris to record, the proviso being that there must be at least three pianos for him to choose from - two Steinways from Hamburg and a Bösendorfer. He loved Bösendorfers.

The great musician arrived in Paris, tinkled, chose one of the Steinways and decided on Schubert's Wanderer Fantasy for his first record. The following morning he was taken ill and remained indisposed for a week. On his return he said he was ready to start, but in the meantime he had changed his mind about the piano; he wanted the Bösendorfer. This meant major upheavals but eventually they started to record.

Richter was a perfectionist insisting on playing on into the night until he considered the piece perfect. At last he was presented with the final edited version. He listened critically and then said: 'Well, I think we'll remake it on the Steinway after all.'

It's hard to imagine any other medium but radio, or any other station but Radio 3, giving as comprehensive a portrait of musical genius as this. Drummond paced it perfectly, giving us just the right amount of personal opinion, studio chat, technical analysis, recorded reminiscences from people like Vladimir Ashkenazy, readings from Richter's diary and, of course, punctuating all these, the music.

I've contributed to the odd radio programme with musical interludes, during which the guests drink plonk and chat. On Wednesday night you knew that Drummond and his guests were listening as intently to Richter playing Prokofiev, Schumann and Liszt as we were; you could feel their involvement. Drummond's style is uncompromising in that he demands and gets the same commitment from his listeners. His knowledge of his subject is awesome (look at his CV - former director of the Edinburgh Festival, controller of Radio 3, governor of the Royal Ballet) but his manner is so conversational, so intimate, it never intimidates.

Programmes like this one remind you - as if you needed it - that Radio 3 is quite simply the most intelligent radio station on earth.

webTitle: Theatre review: Unheimlich Spine | King John | Loveplay

fields.headline: Chamber of love and horrors
fields.standfirst:
Unheimlich Spine
Riverside Studios, London W6 King John
Dean Clough, Halifax Loveplay
Barbican Pit, London EC2
fields.trailText: You couldn't call it wholesome. You could think it overreaches itself. You can see that it's not finished. And yet this new production from the David Glass Ensemble - a work in progress which will tour later in the year - keeps snagging at the mind.
fields.body:
You couldn't call it wholesome. You could think it overreaches itself. You can see that it's not finished. And yet this new production from the David Glass Ensemble - a work in progress which will tour later in the year - keeps snagging at the mind.

Unheimlich Spine (presumably the foreign title is meant to impart a sub-Transylvanian chill to the idea of 'The Unhomely Spine') was inspired by the 1959 Vincent Price horror movie, The Tingler. It deals with the antics of a loony coroner who discovers that fear can breed in people a killer parasite. Amit Lahav - wall-eyed, wild-haired - swerves deliciously between the frenzied and the sepulchral. It features the endlessly transforming Kathryn Hunter, whose character is in turn a fluidly gesturing deaf-mute, a corpse with awkwardly sticking-out limbs, and an appealing wife who pops back, lust-filled, from the dead. It twists between lurid spoof and love story. It trades in puns: while anatomical pictures of a crimson human heart are flashed on to a video screen, a white-frocked siren croons 'Love Letters' ('straight from yo' heart'). Its mood is, you might say, campassionate.

And sometimes it's even more extraordinary than that, risking a shift from the scary to the disturbing. At the centre of the action is the wheelchair-bound actor Sophie Partridge, whose legs and arms are not fully grown. She waves a wand above the scrambled action, smiling seraphically, speaking with a snap of steel as she inquires of those around her, on and off the stage: 'Am I really so frightening?'

More than once in Northern Broadsides' staging of Shakespeare's King John, war chariots mounted on castors - like giant television trolleys - fluttering with national flags and bearing huge drums, rumble towards each other, while on them English and French beat out great martial rolls. The loud simplicity of this is the essence of a production directed by Barrie Rutter, the company's founder who appears, actor-manager-style, like a latter-day Welles or Hitchcock, in unexpected incarnations in his own productions: here, he is a cardinal, patrolling political exchanges with his head cocked like a bird of prey.

Anyone enrolling for the degree in Yorkshire Studies announced this week by Hull University should go at once to Dean Clough: B. Rutter will surely be a module on their course. The Yorkshireness of his company lies only partly in the uniform dialect of the actors, which has proved an enlightening factor in the speaking of Shakespearean verse: why, after all, should Ophelia sound like Princess Anne?

It's a thoroughgoing notion of Northernness that's being projected: from the moment when the director signs his introductory notes, in a single bark, 'Rutter', through to the no-nonsense design, with its black body-warmers, bright sashes and a red carpet dropped on to the vaulted cellars of the old mill at Dean Clough. It's as if each actor had been handed notes printed with 'gritty' and 'flinty' in capital letters. And, in the case of King John, 'angry'. Everybody roars.

Nevertheless, not for the first time, Northern Broadsides have got on to a good wheeze ahead of the game. It's over a decade since the last major production of King John , a play steeped in political argument but skimpy in the human busyness which makes Shakespeare's other histories so appealing: there are hardly any underlings here, and no bawdy.

The richness of the drama is intermittent: it comes from the sound of unusual, eloquent voices. The regal John himself may (as ably shown here by Fine Time Fontayne) be an intellectual and moral weed, but he's surrounded by characters who, though disqualified from power by sex or parentage, command attention. It's not hard to detect a precursor of Shakespeare's Edmund and Richard III in Philip the Bastard, the calculating spin-doctor who ends up by sounding like the voice of principle: Conrad Nelson's rendition is too muted. There's a trio of magnificent women characters, the strongest of which is violently over-played - all heaving bosom and rolling eye - by Marie Louise O'Donnell.

By a strange coincidence, at the end of the month King John will also be staged at Stratford. Meanwhile, the RSC have commissioned a series of modern dramas to form a counterpart to the terrific Shakespearean history cycle which has been making the company look once again like a contender.

Loveplay is the first of these. Moira Buffini's speculations on English history are snippets strung together on a dogged sex-in-the-absence-of-love theme and an it-was-ever-thus attitude. A sloppy, sniggery opening scene - whose jokes could be refugees from a heavy-handed student skit - features a Roman soldier, an early-English whore and banter about latrines. A far more acute episode - set in a dating agency and starring a pair of wrangling lesbians - closes the sequence of short scenes, proving once again that the taxi driver's - and publisher's reader's - test of a book doesn't work for a play. There may be no good novel which has a terrible first page, but there are plays which begin feebly and get stronger.

webTitle: Pop review: Manics strum up revolutionary zeal on home turf

fields.headline: Preaching to the diverted
fields.standfirst: Say it loud: 'I'm Welsh and I'm proud.' The Manics strum up revolutionary zeal on home turf, but not before they trash Anne Robinson
fields.trailText: Say it loud: 'I'm Welsh and I'm proud.' The Manics strum up revolutionary zeal on home turf, but not before they trash Anne Robinson.
fields.body:
The Manic Street Preachers Cardiff Coal Exchange

Earlier this month, as the Manic Street Preachers celebrated their visit to Cuba, Hot Press, the long-running and politically vibrant Irish music magazine, featured James Dean Bradfield on their front cover. The Manic Street Preachers' call to arms, following favourable previews of their forthcoming album, Know Your Enemy, has been met with enthusiasm. On the Hot Press cover, Bradfield's shadowy outline is tinted in sepia and offset by a Guevara beret and rainforest stubble.

The Manics' continuing success as revolutionary firebrands seems to know few limitations - in fact, they've become more vigilant of Western wrongs since their punky debut, Generation Terrorists in 1992. Few white rock acts have successfully used political imagery: Primal Scream's Xtrmntr album of last year - while trying to highlight the plight of British race crime victims, such as Satpal Ram - was, simply, the sound of white noise, frustrated and unfocused. Similarly, Billy Bragg's tribute to the dustbowl politics of Woody Guthrie, 1998's Mermaid Avenue, while accomplished, was little more than a reverential reworking of old standards.

Tonight's concert is being broadcast by Radio 1, and incensed by Anne Robinson's attack on the Welsh on BBC's Room 101 last week Nicky Wire uses the opportunity to shout: 'Who does Anne Robinson think she is? She's a fucking dog!' The crowd scream their approval; and a chorus of 'Fuck Anne Robinson' rings through the Coal Exchange.

The set premieres new material from Know Your Enemy, a record that best illustrates the group's ability to shape-shift their sound around punk rock and ballads. New songs like 'I Found That Soul' and 'Freedom Of Speech Won't Feed My Children' indicate a new found passion with mid-Eighties era Californian pop punk. But nearly 10 years after its initial release, 'Motorcycle Emptiness' - with its soaring guitar melody still intact - has evolved into a glorious paean to twenty-something disaffection. It stands as their most affecting moment. And the group, on the whole, are on a more even keel with mid-tempo numbers. Bradfield's voice, having matured to a sonorous plea on elegantly paced songs like 'A Design For Life', is a harassed yelp on early material like 'You Love Us'. The group uncomfortably alternate between The Ramones and West Coast rock.

But it's another, otherwise unnoticed new song, 'Let Robeson Sing', that marks the group as culturally aware. The eulogy to Paul Robeson, the celebrated American singer and political outcast is wonderfully eloquent - with the group chiming, 'Sing it loud / Sing it proud / I will be heard / I will be found' over a recording of Robeson's wounded, soulful baritone.

'I have to admit, I didn't know who they were singing about,' admits one fan, later. 'But then, that's why people like the Manics - they make you learn things.'

Yet for all the revolutionary rhetoric, the group seem to have completely abandoned the military garb that once made them famous. Bradfield lurches around onstage, clad in nondescript trousers and a short-sleeved shirt. Wire, on the other hand, and in slight tribute to the erratic fashions of their early days, wears a helmet, schoolgirl skirt and apes punk postures for the audience.

The two-hour show is weighed heavily in favour of Know Your Enemy - it's almost as if the group has finally gotten over the loss of its founder-member, Richey Manic. But despite their obvious interest in American imperialism, the Manic Street Preachers' appropriation of late-Sixties counter culture strikes me as an oddity. Can a white rock group from mainland Britain - in an era of manufactured pop - prove truly radical? After all, the racial legacy of black music provides countless examples of desperate politicism. US rapper Ice-T posing as a reviled LAPD officer for the cover of Rolling Stone magazine in 1992 springs to mind.

The Bradfield/Guevara conceit used by Hot Press, and detailed throughout their current album, by comparison, is a voiceless icon: unlike, say the Black Panther imagery purloined by Public Enemy, or the Nation of Islam rhetoric employed by rappers such as KRS-One. On the Hot Press cover, Bradfield's shadowy outline is tinted in sepia and offset by a Guevara beret and rainforest stubble. The Manics' continuing success as revolutionary firebrands seems to know few limitations - in fact, they've become more vigilant of Western wrongs since their punky debut, Generation Terrorists in 1992. Few white rock acts have successfully used political imagery: Primal Scream's Xtrmntr album of last year - while trying to highlight the plight of British race crime victims, such as Satpal Ram - was, simply, the sound of white noise, frustrated and unfocused. Similarly, Billy Bragg's tribute to the dustbowl politics of Woody Guthrie, 1998's Mermaid Avenue, while accomplished, was little more than a reverential reworking of old standards. Tonight's concert is being broadcast by Radio 1, and incensed by Anne Robinson's attack on the Welsh on BBC's Room 101 last week Nicky Wire uses the opportunity to shout: 'Who does Anne Robinson think she is? Bradfield lurches around onstage, clad in nondescript trousers and a short-sleeved shirt. Wire, on the other hand, and in slight tribute to the erratic fashions of their early days, wears a helmet, schoolgirl skirt and apes punk postures for the audience. The two-hour show is weighed heavily in favour of Know Your Enemy - it's almost as if the group has finally gotten over the loss of its founder-member, Richey Manic.
