webTitle: Sounding Off: triumph for theatre is tragedy for Warehouse

fields.headline: It was a triumph for theatre - but a tragedy for the Warehouse
fields.trailText: This has been a week of strong and mixed emotions for me and for the Croydon Warehouse Theatre. Chris Smith and Gerry Robinson have to be applauded for winning a £25 million uplift for English theatre from the Government. However, the decision on how to distribute the money has clouded the celebration for us.
fields.body:
This has been a week of strong and mixed emotions for me and for the Croydon Warehouse Theatre. Chris Smith and Gerry Robinson have to be applauded for winning a £25 million uplift for English theatre from the Government. However, the decision on how to distribute the money has clouded the celebration for us.

We received our bad funding news in the most abrupt way. No warning, just: 'You're not getting any money.' We have been underfunded for so long that we were really looking forward to money that would release the enormous potential of our theatre. We are still in a state of shock. We're going to appeal, of course.

Why was it decided that some theatres should miss out? Perhaps to show that the Arts Council was tough? A progressive decision would surely have been to let everyone share in the money and then judge the theatres on what they did with that investment. Robinson said yesterday: 'I hate the bureaucracy that surrounds arts funding. The other side of the coin is that when it doesn't work, we are going to say, "Hey, we thought we were going to get this for our money".' Well, quite. I have no argument with that.

But the Warehouse Theatre was appraised by London Arts five years ago and judged to be doing an excellent job; in fact, more funding was recommended. We excel in discovering, promoting and producing new writing, we are continually applauded for the excellence of our productions and we are very proud of our promotion of new, young theatre companies like Frantic Assembly and Theatre Alibi. We are also great at education work and theatre for children. Social inclusion in staffing, in casting and in our audience has always been a key objective.

We are foremost in international work through our International Playwriting Festival. All this meets the priorities which the Arts Council and London Arts have published. So why pick a strong bud off the branch? Possibly because we are in a delicate stage of relocating to a new theatre and there's no done deal yet?

It seems to me, looking at the grants announced last week, that the penalised theatres were all in different kinds of trouble. So the easy option was, presumably, to take them out. Was there any consultation about that decision? Not with us, nor the London borough of Croydon, there wasn't.

Some of these theatres, such as the Theatre Royal in York and Worcester's Swan, will live on to fight another day, but the Arts Council decision has been a big disappointment.

In London, 75-80 per cent of the money is going to organisations that are north of the river. Take out the Warehouse Theatre in south London and there's no producing theatre from Stratford East and Hornchurch in the east to the Orange Tree and the Polka in the west. Do the taxpayers of outer south and south-east London get the value of that extra money from the Government? I don't think so.

London Arts insists that there will be money for the Warehouse, but through a kind of project funding.

Robinson is quoted as saying he wanted an end to 'tick-box culture' under which companies were forced to jump through bureaucratic funding hoops, simply trying to meet various criteria and forgetting about their artistic aims, and yet that is precisely what is now envisaged for us - to become a second-class theatre with second-class funding.

 Ted Craig is artistic director of the Croydon Warehouse Theatre. He was talking to Vanessa Thorpe

webTitle: Film reviews: Born Romantic | The Watcher | Dark Days

fields.headline: You'd better watch your step...
fields.standfirst: Thirtysomethings look listlessly for love at a dance class while Keanu hunts for victims in a lacklustre serial killer outing
fields.trailText: Thirtysomethings look listlessly for love at a dance class while Keanu hunts for victims in a lacklustre serial killer outing.
fields.body:
Born Romantic (100 mins, 15)
Directed by David Kane; starring Ian Hart, Craig Ferguson, Adrian Lester, Jane Horrocks, Olivia Williams

The Watcher (97 mins, 16)
Directed by Joe Charbanic; starring Keanu Reeves, James Spader, Marisa Tomei

Dark Days (86 mins, 15)
Directed by Marc Singer

Second movies can be difficult. Either you're recovering from a failure or trying to live up to a promising start. David Kane's Born Romantic is a disappointment after his lively 1999 debut This Year's Love, though it too is performed by a gifted cast of familiar faces. It's another tale of the aimless lives of thirtysomethings - the women assertive, the men surlily submissive - drinking, having casual sex and moaning about their relationships. The form is reminiscent of those old portmanteau movies of couples meeting in dance halls like Ealing Studios' Dance Hall and Merchant-Ivory's Roseland.

Here three couples in search of romantic love meet in a small east London nightclub called El Corozon exclusively devoted to salsa dancing. Liverpool musician David Morrissey finds his long lost girlfriend (Jane Horrocks) there. A handsome, unemployed Scot (Craig Ferguson), recently divorced, and living in a subsiding house he can't sell, encounters a no-nonsense picture restorer (Olivia Williams). Ineffectual thief Jimi Mistry meets neurotic professional grave-minder Catherine McCormack when he steals her purse while she's sitting it out. The problem is that none of these guys can dance, a metaphor you can take with a pinch of salsa, which is indeed what they all do as they get a handsome Cuban couple to give them lessons.

As commentators on this world of the lovelorn we have mini-cab drivers Ian Hart and Adrian Lester. Hart dispenses advice of a Men Are From Mars, Women Are From Venus sort to fellow customers in the Kismet Café. Lester, a recent widower of great wisdom, hears the confessions of his fares and stops just short of saying 'I had that Claire Rayner in the back of the cab once'.

Joe Charbanic comes to feature films from years spent making music videos (some for Dogstar, Keanu Reeves's band) and it shows in his self-consciously arty thriller The Watcher, with every pretentious few seconds in slow motion, speeded up, shown in negative, optically distorted, or shot with a tilted camera. The film is this week's serial killer picture, the mass murderer (Keanu Reeves) being a mad genius who, having driven brilliant FBI agent James Spader crazy in Los Angeles, pursues him to Chicago to commit another series of bizarre killings. Symbiosis is the name of this specious game.

Spader is consulting the world's most unlikely shrink (Marisa Tomei) whom we instantly spot as the next victim, though it takes some days for this to dawn on the cops. To stir up his malevolent protagonist, Spader tells him: 'There are five serial killers here in Chicago I could be chasing, and a dozen within a hundred miles - you're just paperwork.' Whether Spader is referring to real murderers or to films currently in production in the Midwest is not clear.

Five years ago in Michael Apted's thriller Extreme Measures, a doctor (played by Hugh Grant) discovered that in the bowels of New York, living in abandoned tunnels, shafts and vaults, was a community of homeless derelicts, who were being kidnapped by sinister research scientists for illicit medical experiments. Dark Days, a black-and-white documentary by expatriate British filmmaker Marc Singer, shows us that such a band of troglodytes actually exists, or did until very recently.

Singer's labour of love is the result of two years he spent living underground with these people in disused Amtrak railway tunnels. Not only are they the subjects of the film but they actually helped to make it, learning to operate the technical equipment, building camera dollies to use on railway tracks, tapping into municipal power cables for lighting. They talk with a curious equanimity about their lives and backgrounds and why they've opted out of the world to live in this rat-infested Stygian ante-room to hell.

One describes himself as 'homeless but not hopeless'. Another speaks of spending 'five years of my motherfucking life down this motherfucker'. Picking through the garbage outside a café, a third remarks that 'I only eat what I'm familiar with', adding that kosher restaurants are the best because they don't mix the food up when they throw it out. One of the few women in the group speaks ruefully of a daughter raped at the age of seven who subsequently had an arm cut off, lost a leg and then suffered terrible burns in a ghetto fire.

A couple of years ago Amtrak decided to clear the tunnel-dwellers out, presumably as part of Mayor Giuliani's zero tolerance clean-up campaign. Fortunately an organisation called Coalition for the Homeless managed to secure federal housing for them all and we last see them relaxing happily in their new clean well-lighted places.

webTitle: Film of the week: Best in Show

fields.headline: This is spaniel tap
fields.standfirst: Having satirised the world of rock music, Christopher Guest goes to the dogs
fields.trailText: Having satirised the world of rock music, Christopher Guest goes to the dogs.
fields.body:
Best in Show (90 mins, 12)
Directed by Christopher Guest; starring Guest, Eugene Levy, Michael McKean, Parker Posey, Bob Balaban

Dogs have, as it were, left their mark on numerous milestones in the history of cinema. The first significant British movie is Cecil Hepworth's technically accomplished six-minute Rescued by Rover (Rover was a collie), made in 1905. Until the coming of sound, Warner Brothers were kept solvent by films featuring the German shepherd Rin Tin Tin, most of them scripted by Darryl Zanuck, founder of 20th Century-Fox. A little later, the Yorkshire collie Lassie (dubbed 'Greer Garson in Furs') became a major star at MGM, and from Pluto to 101 Dalmatians, dogs have always played a leading role at the Disney studio.

Movie dogs have usually been man's best (sometimes only) friend, as in De Sica's Umberto D. Occasionally, though, they're his worst enemy - in Stephen King's Cujo, for instance, and Sam Fuller's White Dog, which distributors rejected because it featured a canine racist. Dogs have brought disparate people together (the homophobic Jack Nicholson and his gay neighbour in As Good as It Gets), and have helped solve crimes (Nick and Nora Charles's schnauzer Asta in the Thin Man films; Tom Hanks's giant watchdog in Turner and Hooch) and been the victims of murderers (Hitchcock's Rear Window).

Before this column attracts the comment: 'Enough four-footed-friend flicks - Ed', let me proceed to the film that caused my mind to scamper down memory lane, the consistently funny Best in Show . It's directed and co-scripted by the American comedian Christopher Guest, who co-wrote and passed himself off as the English rock musician Nigel Tufnel in This is Spinal Tap. Like Spinal Tap, his new film is a spoof documentary, in this case about competitive dog owners, though in Best in Show we don't get to meet the film's supposed makers, and only when talking direct to camera do the participants show an awareness of being filmed.

As documentaries do, the film follows five couples from different social strata and different parts of America, all of them credible grotesques, and all treating their pets like the children they never had, and probably never will have. Christopher Guest himself plays a North Carolina backwoods store owner, who has a bloodhound and counts as his hobbies hunting, reeling off lists of nuts, and ventriloquism.

Next up the social scale is a lower-middle-class couple from Florida, with a tiny Norwich terrier; the husband (Eugene Levy, the film's co-author) quite literally has two left feet and is constantly being made aware of the raunchy past of his wife (Catherine O'Hara). From Illinois comes a yuppie couple (Parker Posey and Michael Hitchcock), both lawyers and in therapy along with their weimaraner bitch dog that's been traumatised by seeing them have sex.

New York contributes a pair of outrageous Cage aux Folles-style gays, the leading hairdresser Stefan Vanderhoof (Michael McKean, another Spinal Tap alumnus) and his lover Scott Donlan (John Michael Higgins), who dote on two fluffy little shih-tzus. Top of the social scale, but tackiest of all, is the gold-digging Sherri (Jennifer Coolidge), who's married a senile Pennsylvanian multimillionaire, but is on the brink of a lesbian affair with the expert dog handler (Jane Lynch), who cares for Rhapsody in White, Sherri's champion poodle. Guest never runs a scene too long or lets the actors (who improvised a lot of the material) step out of character.

The hearts of all five couples are set on their dogs winning the best in their class, then going on to get the blue riband for 'best in show' at the annual Mayflower Dog Show, which has, we're persuaded, been held in Philadelphia since 1875. Here we meet another splendid collection of characters - the prissy descendant of the show's patrician founder, the manager of the coliseum where the event is staged and, most amusingly, the toffee-nosed manager (Ed Begley Jr) of the hotel where the dog owners traditionally stay. He's very tall and on meeting him the gay hairdresser remarks: 'You make me feel like Alan Ladd on Easter Island.'

The film sends up the conventions and clichés of Hollywood competition movies - the sudden crises, the inexperienced dog handler forced to take over at the last minute, the rejection of the overweaning and the little guy turning up trumps. But what makes the show so splendid is the arrival of two new figures, a pair of TV commentators, one a reserved Englishman, Trevor Beckworth (Jim Piddock), who knows everything about canine competitions, and the other an extravagantly vulgar American, Buck Laughlin (Fred Willard), there to flaunt his ignorance as a representative of the people. The movie provokes steady smiles and chuckles from its opening moments, but the exchanges between Trevor and Buck produce loud laughter.

Best in Show is gentle satire, more at the expense of the absurdity of human life than this particular doggie subculture, which it views with affection. Only occasionally does it sting or draw blood. The astonishing thing is that apart from the hotel manager's little lecture on hygiene, there are no jokes about dogs peeing or defecating.

This is unlike every dumbed-down Hollywood picture you see nowadays, not to mention Robert Altman's Prét-à-Porter , which in satirising the fashion business chooses to have as its chief running gag people stepping in dog shit.

Best in Show is gentle satire, more at the expense of the absurdity of human life than this particular doggie subculture, which it views with affection. Only occasionally does it sting or draw blood. The astonishing thing is that apart from the hotel manager's little lecture on hygiene, there are no jokes about dogs peeing or defecating. This is unlike every dumbed-down Hollywood picture you see nowadays, not to mention Robert Altman's Prét-à-Porter , which in satirising the fashion business chooses to have as its chief running gag people stepping in dog shit.

webTitle: Arts review: the Millennium Bridge is undergoing major surgery

fields.headline: At last - a bridge you can cross
fields.standfirst: After a shaky start, the Millennium Bridge is undergoing major surgery. Here, its creators reveal what went wrong and why the blade of light won't wobble when it reopens
fields.trailText: After a shaky start, the Millennium Bridge is undergoing major surgery. Here, its creators reveal what went wrong and why the blade of light won't wobble when it reopens.
fields.body:
It was just after 9 am on a sunny Saturday last June that the Millennium Bridge first began to wobble. Roger Ridsdill-Smith, the young engineer who had been involved with every aspect of the project since his famous paper napkin sketch of a blade of light had so impressed Norman Foster and Anthony Caro, was waiting for the start of a sponsored walk. As the bridge began to fill with people, he spotted the first sign of movement. 'It happened quite fleetingly, but you could tell it wasn't just a judder; it was a resonant movement. 'I thought, 'That's interesting', but as the numbers thinned out, the bridge calmed down again.'

Then, at lunch time when the bridge finally opened to the public; the crowds swarmed on from both ends. And that's when the bridge really started to move. All 690 tons of its steel-and-aluminium deck began to sway left and right like a giant, executive desktop toy, so much so that pedestrians, suspended above the Thames on slender steel cables, began to clutch at handrails to steady themselves, and throw themselves against the sway, to stay upright. As they did, so the swings began to get increasingly violent.

Ridsdill-Smith and the police working on crowd-control looked at each other. In his mind, Ridsdill-Smith went back over all the calculations, all the safety assessments, all the wind-tunnel tests, even the giant hydraulic tank in Canada used to measure resistance to water. None of them had predicted anything like this. This was simply not supposed to be happening.

All his experience as an engineer told him that the bridge ought to be stable and that it was certainly safe. But even he must have seen an image of the great Tacoma Narrows suspension bridge near Tacoma, Washington in 1940, shaking itself to pieces, flashing through his mind.

'We asked ourselves, "Is it dangerous?" You could see that the movement was self-limiting. Beyond a certain point, it simply becomes impossible to get any more people on the bridge. As it gets fuller and fuller, people stop moving and the effect subsides, long before structural safety limits are reached. We knew it wouldn't fall down, but suppose granny takes a tumble and breaks a hip?'

The next day, Nicholas Serota lent the bridge his security staff from the Tate to limit the numbers crossing at any one time. But the wobble didn't go away. The Millennium Bridge Trust hesitated for 24 hours before making the decision to close it altogether.

As engineering disasters go, the great wobbly bridge fiasco might seem pretty tame. But to see such a high-profile design closed down so soon after opening was a humiliation for Arup, the fiercely proud engineers who have made everything from the Sydney Opera House to the Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank possible. They could build skyscrapers and nuclear-power stations all over the world, but here, in their own backyard, they were conspicuously failing to make a simple footbridge stand still long enough for people to stroll across it.

What made their embarrassment so irresistible to the more pedantic of their fellow engineers, who rushed in to make judgments about what had happened, was that they seemed to have brought it on themselves. The word was that they had allowed Foster, an architect determined to make his mark on the bridge, push them into flouting the sensible limits of design. 'Of course this bridge was going to wobble, just look at it,' was the consensus. With its low-slung outriggers and its very flat profile, the 'blade of light' looked like no other bridge. It was presented as a piece of typical, too-clever-by-half arrogance. Stray too far from tried-and-tested traditional designs and you'll get in trouble was the subtext of much of the debate.

To the enormous relief of both Arup and Foster, it turns out that the striking looks of the bridge have nothing to do with the causes of the wobble. Arup's analysis has been checked by two independent engineers and three university departments.

'It's not what is different about the bridge that caused the problem,' says Tony Fitzpatrick, who has lead the Arup team struggling to find a solution. 'Every issue about the bridge that was innovative was properly researched and it worked perfectly. What hit us in the back of the head was that bit of the bridge that was the same as every other long-span bridge. We assumed it would work like other bridges have until now; that was the mistake, but there has to be a first time for everything.'

What Arup eventually discovered was a previously misunderstood phenomenon. Once the number of pedestrians on a bridge passes a critical mass, their footsteps start to make it move and the more that they react to that movement to stay upright the more the bridge shakes. It could potentially effect any pedestrian bridge over a given length. Fitzpatrick believes that there are least 70 such bridges in Britain alone, with hundreds more around the world.

'We are not ashamed,' says Fitzpatrick, who is presenting Arup's findings in a guidance note to John Prescott's DETR. 'We want the full story to be out there. We are very clear about what we have done; we are happy for others to judge us. Any conspiracy to keep quiet about the bridge only makes us look worse. We have had only one thing on our agenda - to get the bridge open. I just want to be allowed on the bridge to fix it.'

As soon as the bridge closed, Arup began talking to the world's footbridge experts in Japan and Germany. At the same time, they did urgent checks to see if the bridge had been built exactly as they had specified - it had - and then they looked yet again at their own calculations to see if there was any elementary mistakes in the numbers. There weren't.

All bridges are liable to move. Their weight and structure keep them still to a certain extent, but get enough people walking across a bridge and all the natural damping is cancelled out; then the next few footsteps will set it wobbling violently. It's not a gradual effect. Arup found it's all or nothing. 'Put 1,000 people on a bridge and it will seem to be OK. Put 1,100 and it starts to wobble,' says Fitzpatrick.

Arup discovered a number of bridges which had suffered from the problem, and every one of them looked utterly different. There is a high-level suspension bridge in Tokyo, completed in the 1980s, that had a makeshift damping system retrofitted after its opening; a 100-year-old steel truss bridge in Canada that never moved a millimetre in its entire life, until the day of the firework display on its birthday that attracted so many pedestrians that it began to wobble. Then there was was the Pont Solferino, a graceful arched footbridge across the Seine which stayed closed after its opening, ostensibly because its surface was slippery. This, too, turned out to be the victim of wobbly-bridge syndrome. Fitzpatrick hints at a cover-up. 'If the engineers involved with some of these cases had been as open about their bridges as we are being now, the problem would have been resolved long ago.'

The best news from Arup's point of view was the footbridge linking the National Exhibition Centre in Birmingham to its neighbouring railway station with all the grace and subtlety of a sledgehammer. This was a design clearly untroubled by the least vestige of aesthetic ambition. Yet it, too, suffered from wobbly-bridge syndrome. The avant-garde was off the hook.

Why had none of these cases forewarned Arup? Fitzpatrick's answer is that they were never reported to the people who write the codes that bridge designers must follow.

Who is to blame? After the few ill-judged words uttered by Foster to the mob of reporters besieging his office on the day of the bridge closure, the various members of the design team are going out of their way to be nice about each other. Foster now says: 'You can only use the word blame in a situation in which somebody says, "My God, we missed that code, or didn't make that test which anybody else would have done". That's not what happened here. If you look at the record, much more was done for this bridge than you would reasonably expect. Nobody could ever have anticipated that it would happen to the bridge. In a sense, it is a consequence of its popularity.'

Fitzpatrick is clear that responsibility for the bridge is Arup's. 'Norman made it look more people friendly; he made it more sensual than we would have done on our own, but the concept was an engineering one. It certainly wasn't a case of Norman forcing us to make something work.'

Once the final signatures are added to a £5 million financial settlement for the bridge (this will avoid any legal action against the design team), work can start on ensuring that the wobble is eliminated. It will involve fitting a pair of X-shaped braces under each of the structural bays under the bridge, along with 37 viscous dampers (the kind of large shock-absorbers you might find on a truck), and another 50 tuned mass dampers. These are heavy blocks that sit in baths of oil and are connected by springs to the structure. When the bridge starts to move, the blocks absorb the energy triggered by pedestrians and stop the wobble. It's all been done deftly enough for the additions to look like part of the original design.

How much long-term damage has been done by the bridge's closure? Arup are hoping that their reputation will emerge intact. They were just unlucky to be the first people to face a previously unsuspected problem, just like the engineers who designed the Comets that kept falling out of the sky because of stress fractures that nobody had predicted, or the engineers who built the wartime Liberty ships that kept sinking because nobody could predict the behaviour of the welds used to put them together.

And as far as Tate Modern, prime mover in the original bid to build the bridge, is concerned, director Nicholas Serota says: 'It doesn't appear to have deterred visitors from coming, but we were disapppointed that it had to close. The bridge is a symbolic link to the City and it's great that they have found a solution.'

Fitzpatrick says he is looking forward to reopening day in six months' time. 'We shall go to watch and enjoy the opening,' he says. One of his more cautious colleagues, the engineer who helped the Atomic Energy Authority test what happened when a train travelling at 100 miles a hour crashed into a flask of nuclear waste, is a little more circumspect. Asked how confident he is about the bridge, he tells you about the day of the nuclear test. 'At the last minute, once the train had started to gather speed on the test track, one of the AEA managers turned to me, and said, "Are you sure it's going to work?" I had to think for a minute before I answered.'

webTitle: Living: Charm is back in style

fields.headline: Charmed I'm sure
fields.standfirst: Monkeys use it, politicians use it, even socialites in Manhattan use it. None of us can now do without it. Charm, the skill the Nineties sneered at, is simply thrilled to be back
fields.trailText: Monkeys use it, politicians use it, even socialites in Manhattan use it. None of us can now do without it. Charm, the skill the Nineties sneered at, is simply thrilled to be back.
fields.body:
Whether the election is in April, May or some time that no one has even thought of yet, one thing is certain. The amount of charm which candidates can muster on the doorstep, in dole offices and - harder, this one - when face to face with Paxman or Humphrys will determine who wins hearts and votes. Policies, manifestos and track records fade into insignificance alongside the visceral power of just the right amount of eye contact (enough to appear sincere, not too much to seem creepy).

After a couple of decades in the wilderness, charm is making a comeback. Carole Stone, whose parties are legendary for introducing people in the media, politics and business to one other, has just written a book called Networking, with the revealing subtitle 'How to Make Friends'. There's no doubting her expertise (her Christmas parties became famous for the way that 1,000 guests as grand as Rory Bremner or William Waldegrave queued patiently to get in), but what is interesting is the way that her modus operandi depends on nothing more technical than good old-fashioned charm.

While Manhattan professional women have reduced the art of working a room to the icy precision of a gavotte - five minutes interaction and a crisp exchange of business cards - Stone's technique, if it can be called that, is simply to be charming. Not charming as in smarmy, but charming as in genuinely interested in the people she has invited along to her home (or the Reform Club or the Queen Elizabeth Hall, or wherever she happens to be celebrating Christmas that year). Stone, who made many of her charm conquests producing Any Questions in the Eighties, maintains: 'I always assume people are going to like me, not because I am wonderful but because I like them.' And, actually, she's right, they do.

Stone has recently started giving masterclasses in Manhattan to show Americans how to play nicely with one another. This call to charm has been taken up by New Yorker Richard Stengel, formerly a senior editor at Time magazine, in his new book You're Too Kind: a Brief History of Flattery (Simon & Schuster £14.99). Stengel argues that while flattery has for a long time had a bad press (no one likes a brown-noser), it actually consists of nothing more sinister than 'strategic praise'. Wherever you find hierarchies, which is pretty much anywhere from a troupe of vervet monkeys to an FT 100 boardroom, you'll find dollops of flattery being used to oil the social machinery.

It is only in the last few decades, with their emphasis on democracy, equality, plain speaking and fair dealing, that charm has fallen out of favour, along with flirting and flattery and all those other social strategies which the stern Nineties deemed manipulative, inappropriate or indirect. The discourses which have predominated since then, especially counselling and management speak, have become a kind of linguistic and social straitjacket for anyone who ever prided themselves on being able to establish instant rapport.

Caroline Smart, a 38-year-old PR, remembers the torture of her early psychotherapy sessions: 'I spent the first three months doing what comes naturally, trying to bond with this frosty woman on the other side of the room. After one particularly painful session, when I'd given her my best riffs, she fixed me with those cold blue eyes and said, "I get the feeling that you're working very hard to be charming", as if there were something pathological about it.'

In some extreme cases, charm even became an indictable offence. Catherine Hamilton, a 40-year-old university lecturer, found herself the subject of a complaint by one of her undergraduates. 'She listed all her grievances and then finished off with "Dr Hamilton relies on her considerable personal charm to conduct her seminars", as if I had been employing the dark arts. I found myself in the ridiculous position of having to defend myself against the charge of being too charming.'

Far from being pathological, charm is an essential social glue which keeps communities intact while allowing individuals to do the best that they can for themselves (which is, surely, what New Labour has been promising all along). Chimps, who share 98 per cent of our DNA, use charm with utter ruthlessness to get what they want without offending anyone else. According to Richard Stengel, male chimps vying for group support in power struggles go out of their way to groom females and play with their infants - something which they can never normally be bothered to do. This behaviour, suggests Stengel, has its exact corollary in the campaigning tactics of politicians, who scour provincial branches of Iceland hoping to capture the female vote by kissing sticky babies.

Stengel calls charm 'the ultimate victimless crime'. He argues that it is quite distinct from good looks, good manners or the capacity to flatter other people, although it contains healthy dollops of all three. Good looks, certainly, are not essential. What matters is the capacity to manage your body in particular ways during social interaction. For chimps, this means fondling each others' scrotums with just the right amount of élan. For humans, though, it has more to do with keeping the correct distance (one metre, unless you've slept with each other), empathetic listening (no butting in, no matter how predictable the other speaker) and smiling with your eyes as well as your mouth.

Good manners, too, are an integral part of the mix. This has nothing to do with etiquette, with which it is often confused. Knowing how to address the younger son of a marquis or how to finish a letter to your solicitor is unconnected with the point of good manners, which is to make people feel as if they matter to you. Nicholas Coleridge of Condé Nast, which launched Glamour this week, is known not only as one of the shrewdest magazine publishers in the country but as a man of impeccable courtesy (recipients report feeling cherished and charmed). Likewise, one of the nicest things that can be said about the late Princess of Wales is that she never let the sun go down on an unwritten thank you note.

Of course, in order for charm to work, it has to follow a few key rules. Charm must be personalised, honed and aimed squarely at the person to whom it is directed. The best charmers make you feel that it is specifically your wit, intelligence and warmth - your charm, in fact - which is keeping them at your side waiting for your next incomparable observation. The moment you feel that there is something prefabricated, one-size-suits-all about the attention coming your way, then you feel diminished, unseen (Robert Kilroy-Silk, at least in his television persona, is the obvious example here). The biggest giveaway is the self-consciously attentive listener who still can't stop herself from glancing around the room to check whether a worthier recipient of her charm has just walked in the door.

But if charm needs to feel tailor-made to work, it also has to be heedless of any endgame. There is nothing worse that someone who turns it on to obtain a particular goal (love, promotion, a lift home). Indeed, obviously self-interested charmers resemble nothing so much as Leslie Phillips, circa 1963, investing every 'Well, hello' with a desperate invitation to sex. True charmers, like good flirts, are indiscriminate in their favours and casual about the outcome (they know they can afford to be). They bestow their attentions on cleaning ladies, small boys and dogs without looking for any particular return. They treat their bosses like their secretaries and vice versa because they don't, in actual fact, see any difference between them. And the delightful result is that not only do they get a rise, they also get their letters typed on time.

This behaviour, suggests Stengel, has its exact corollary in the campaigning tactics of politicians, who scour provincial branches of Iceland hoping to capture the female vote by kissing sticky babies. Stengel calls charm 'the ultimate victimless crime'. He argues that it is quite distinct from good looks, good manners or the capacity to flatter other people, although it contains healthy dollops of all three. Good looks, certainly, are not essential. What matters is the capacity to manage your body in particular ways during social interaction. For chimps, this means fondling each others' scrotums with just the right amount of élan. For humans, though, it has more to do with keeping the correct distance (one metre, unless you've slept with each other), empathetic listening (no butting in, no matter how predictable the other speaker) and smiling with your eyes as well as your mouth. Good manners, too, are an integral part of the mix. This has nothing to do with etiquette, with which it is often confused. Knowing how to address the younger son of a marquis or how to finish a letter to your solicitor is unconnected with the point of good manners, which is to make people feel as if they matter to you. Nicholas Coleridge of Condé Nast, which launched Glamour this week, is known not only as one of the shrewdest magazine publishers in the country but as a man of impeccable courtesy (recipients report feeling cherished and charmed). Likewise, one of the nicest things that can be said about the late Princess of Wales is that she never let the sun go down on an unwritten thank you note. Of course, in order for charm to work, it has to follow a few key rules. Charm must be personalised, honed and aimed squarely at the person to whom it is directed. The best charmers make you feel that it is specifically your wit, intelligence and warmth - your charm, in fact - which is keeping them at your side waiting for your next incomparable observation. The moment you feel that there is something prefabricated, one-size-suits-all about the attention coming your way, then you feel diminished, unseen (Robert Kilroy-Silk, at least in his television persona, is the obvious example here). The biggest giveaway is the self-consciously attentive listener who still can't stop herself from glancing around the room to check whether a worthier recipient of her charm has just walked in the door. But if charm needs to feel tailor-made to work, it also has to be heedless of any endgame. There is nothing worse that someone who turns it on to obtain a particular goal (love, promotion, a lift home). Indeed, obviously self-interested charmers resemble nothing so much as Leslie Phillips, circa 1963, investing every 'Well, hello' with a desperate invitation to sex. True charmers, like good flirts, are indiscriminate in their favours and casual about the outcome (they know they can afford to be). They bestow their attentions on cleaning ladies, small boys and dogs without looking for any particular return. They treat their bosses like their secretaries and vice versa because they don't, in actual fact, see any difference between them. And the delightful result is that not only do they get a rise, they also get their letters typed on time.

webTitle: Moral Muse: Is it right for me to open my friend's letters?

fields.headline: Is it right for me to open my friend's letters?
fields.trailText: Until recently, I had a good friend living with me who has all his mail sent to my address. He is now staying at a temporary address until he can find a place to live.
fields.body:
Until recently, I had a good friend living with me who has all his mail sent to my address. He is now staying at a temporary address until he can find a place to live.

I know he is about to be made bankrupt and I am concerned because it will be at my address. To protect myself, I have been opening his mail to see how far things have gone. However, he is furious. Am I morally justified in my actions?
A.F. Hayes of Kent

Given how few (if any) of us are completely honest, it's surprising how reprehensible we believe reading someone else's mail to be, never mind actually opening it. The degree of moral turpitude is on a level with petty theft. We all have secrets, usually shaming ones, and there is a network of freemasonry within family groups which says: 'you leave mine alone and I'll leave yours'.

Knowledge is power and perhaps people are afraid that the facades they are at such pains to present to the world will be demolished if they appear in their true light. Also, situations in which someone else controls your letters imply a steep power gradient, such as occur in schools or in authoritarian states.

So yes, he's rightly furious. You have used your position of strength, receiving his mail in the sanctum of your own home and prying into it on the basis of this very shaky justification. Is there more to the story than you have let on? If there is a clear distinction between your property and his, it is hard to see why you need protection. 'A good friend' can be a coded name for a lover. Even if he wasn't, as he lived with you people might presume so. You are perhaps concerned that if he is seen as a common-law husband it may not be easy to disentangle your belongings in the eyes of the law.

On the whole, this interpretation seems unlikely, but we cannot judge. How long has he lived with you? Is the house your own? How much has he contributed to buying domestic items for mutual use? Why did he move out, and was this directly linked with his imminent bankruptcy?

You have resorted to underhand methods to find out (I presume) about whether you are likely to get sucked into the debts and payments which are linked to his insolvency; the act of a person who feels vulnerable. Your interests are opposed to his. If you believe you have cause for concern, grasp the nettle. Get some dispassionate advice from a lawyer. Then make your peace with your ex-lodger, explain your natural concern for your own welfare, and try to clarify things if there is a question of joint property.

Remember that his debtors, too, will suffer from his insolvency, probably more than you, and they have a just claim to anything which is currently his.

Reader's replies

Give your friend back his responsibility. It is his mail, so stop opening it on his behalf. Redirect the mail to where he is staying.

You do not have to take responsibility for his mail and it might help if the Post Office knew he had moved on.
N.G. of Wilts

Opening private mail addressed to others is morally justifiable in highly exceptional circumstances when a reply may be urgently needed. Opening a friend's personal mail is not an act of friendship.

If your writer is really concerned to protect herself, she/he should ask the friend to make immediate arrangements for post to be re-directed to a new address or to a post office. If nothing happens immediately, she/he should return the post to sender with 'Gone Away' on the envelope.

The friend may be 'furious' at these courses of action as well. But it will prevent the temptation to pry into another's life, and will maintain the confidentiality of the friend's private mail. It may also prevent the writer from being unwittingly manipulated by a friend who seems to want to remain hidden.
P.G.A. of Oxfordshire

Next week's dilemma

Before I married and had children, I travelled extensively. My husband did not do as much as he would have liked. Now we have a family we have to do 'family-type' holidays.

However, my husband finds these hard work and is vocal about the fact he would rather be walking in Iceland or visiting a place he has never been before.

I've suggested just the two of us going somewhere together but to be honest, I cannot contemplate leaving the country without my children and walking in Iceland is not really conducive to a four-year-old and a six-month-old baby. He knows this. How can we compromise?

N.S. of Reading

 Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk Views on problems must reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal.

webTitle: No shortcuts to cab driver's 'knowledge'

fields.headline: Where to, guv'nor?
fields.standfirst: How long does it take to get from King's Cross to Abbey Road? About five years. That's how long the average London cab driver spends learning the 'Knowledge'. But with plans afoot to make it easier, cabbies have only one thing to say - there are no short cuts to excellence
fields.trailText: How long does it take to get from King's Cross to Abbey Road? About five years. That's how long the average London cab driver spends learning the 'Knowledge'. But with plans afoot to make it easier, cabbies have only one thing to say - there are no short cuts to excellence.
fields.body:
At the Public Carriage Office in London, which controls the city's taxi licences, they like to emphasise the importance of communication skills. Roy Ellis, head of the PCO, uses his bi-weekly passing-out speech to press home the point. 'Never swear at customers,' he warns the eight, neatly suited men who are about to join the ranks of London's 20,000 black cab drivers. 'You never know who you might be swearing at. Chat to them. Remember, the public like sometimes to be told who they should vote for at the next election.'

Often referred to as the last outpost of the British Empire, the PCO holds on to a number of curious and antiquated ideas, not the least of which is the notion that fare-paying passengers are keen to hear the driver's political advice (in much the same way, no doubt, that the drivers are offended by large tips). Nevertheless, the PCO has maintained a standard of excellence that nowadays is so unusual as to be almost unique. If you conducted a global poll to see in which aspects of life Britain leads the world, the answer would not be public transport, town planning, manufacturing, national cuisine, plumbing, dentistry, nightlife, education or sport. But, by general consent, we do have the best taxi-drivers.

London's licensed cabbies are safer, more polite, better trained, better prepared and more knowledgeable than any other taxi drivers on the planet. Whereas elsewhere in the world, driving a cab is something you do while you study to get a proper job as a teacher or actor or novelist, in London, it is the other way round. In fact, there is really only one problem with the capital's black-cab drivers - there's never one when you want one.

In 2001, the year in which we had dreamed of visiting the stars, you are more likely to be killed by a meteorite than find a cab in London after 9pm, unless it is in the dead months of January and February, when the city hibernates. Throughout the remainder of the year, the apparent shortage of taxis has become so chronic that even the authorities have noticed. 'There are simply not enough cabs about when you want one,' said Mayor Ken Livingstone recently. 'If it's raining, or if it's late, then the common problem is that you just can't find one.'

Thus Livingstone and his American transport supremo, Robert Kiley, have plans to overhaul a licensing system that dates back to the mid-nineteenth century. The aim is to get more taxis on to the streets, which means licensing more taxi drivers. And that could spell the end of the Ulyssean journey of discovery forbiddingly known as the Knowledge. 'The cab trade needs to consider whether the current administration of "the knowledge" system is holding up the numbers of cab drivers who qualify,' said Livingstone, ominously.

Ask anyone at the PCO what the Knowledge is and they start talking in gnomic similes. During the course of an induction lecture to prospective taxi drivers, Alan Price, an examiner at the PCO, posed the rhetorical question: what do you have to know to gain the Knowledge? 'The short answer,' he responded to himself, 'is everything. The Knowledge is like a toothache, it doesn't go away. The longer it goes on, the worse it gets the Knowledge is like a big jug of water and your brain is like a cup. You pour it in slowly so you don't lose it the Knowledge never stops.'

In the literal sense, the Knowledge is the information that a student taxi driver - a 'Knowledge Boy' - is required to learn to be awarded a London taxi licence. The basis of that information are the 400 runs, each one a mental blow, that are contained in the so-called Blue Book. A run is the shortest route between two points that are located within a six-mile radius of Charing Cross.

Without doubt, London is the most unplanned big city in the world. There are no grids, blocks or grand avenues, just a complex of seemingly random roads and streets. And even for the casual driver, the desire to understand the chaos can become dangerously absorbing. It's not uncommon for people to spend whole dinner parties in one part of London relaying how they got there from another part. So the appeal of the Knowledge goes beyond the lure of self-employment and a good wage to that of a heroic endeavour - to boldly go where no man would think of going, if it wasn't in the Blue Book.

The first and most renowned run in the book is Manor House Station to Gibson Square. Followed by 399 others even more unmemorable. But it's not just the 400 runs, and as many as 25,000 streets, that a Knowledge Boy must commit to memory. All the points of interest along the way and within a quarter of a mile of the start and finish of each run must also memorised. As a point of interest can be anything from a place of worship to a shop, an official building to a nightclub, that amounts to perhaps hundreds of thousands of bits of data and an infinite number of relationships between them all. It is mind-expanding stuff.

A study at the department of neurology at University College, London showed that the posterior hippocampi (the elongated ridges on the lateral ventricle of the brain) of a group of London taxi drivers was significantly larger than that of the general population. Dr Eleanor Macguire, the senior research fellow who conducted the experiment, says that there could be a number of explanations but all of them add up to the fact that this part of a taxi driver's brain grows while doing the Knowledge. As he make the links between different roads, so, it seems, the neurons and synapses in the posterior hippocampi make new links. In this sense, the map of a taxi driver's brain is the map of London.

It could also mean that Fred Housego, the cabbie who famously won Mastermind, was not a fluke. Taxi drivers have bigger brains than the rest of us. Or do they? It turns out that the growth in the posterior hippocampi was accompanied by a corresponding decrease in the anterior hippocampi of the taxi drivers. If the posterior hippocampus is where our spatial information is stored, could it be that the anterior hippocampus houses whatever it is that prevents us from expressing extreme political opinions and pulling U-turns in inconvenient locations? 'I couldn't possibly comment,' said Dr Macguire.

You can see why the Knowledge lends itself to metaphor. After a while, the search is not so much geographical as existential. You start out looking for the Samaritan Free Hospital and end up finding yourself. For as well as being a toothache and a jug of water, the Knowledge is a life-changing task that takes upwards of two years to complete.

To memorise the routes and points, you have first to acquaint yourself with them in person (most often on a moped), rather than via a map. 'If you can't see it,' they say at the PCO, 'you can't call it.' Many drivers spend five, six or even 10 years mastering the Knowledge (although a very few exceptions have taken as little as a year). And many more fall by the wayside - the drop-out rate is more than two-thirds.

The reason some people take more time to finish the Knowledge than doctors take to qualify is that it's not a one-way street. You can go backwards as well as forwards. Each candidate is assessed in a series of 'appearances' before a PCO examiner and depending on how well the appearance goes, the length of time until the next appearance is shortened, extended or unchanged. You start out with 56-day, or sometimes 80-day, gaps between appearances and aim to get down to 21-day gaps to pass out. The effect might be compared to walking blindfold up a down escalator.

Although the questions change all the time, a not untypical example of an appearance might be as follows: Noel Road to Liam OGG's; Gallagher & Sons P.H. to Popstars Bar; Beatles Crossing to Oasis Sports Centre; Oscar Wilde's Rooms to Oscar Wilde's Blue Plaque. The method of the Knowledge - reciting the route from one place to another - was once brilliantly spoofed in Viz magazine. Instead of street routes, the cartoon cab drivers were asked to move from one annoying conversational gambit to another. For example: the Spice Girls to And I'd Pull the Lever Myself.

It seemed childishly amusing at the time, but now I wonder if it doesn't contain the mystery of that expanding and shrinking hippocampus. Perhaps the necessary corollary of making spatial connections is losing conversational coherence. To put it another way, the taxi driver's compass floats on a white-water stream of consciousness.

Roy Ellis told me that he expected the means of assessment to change in the new system. One of life's natural technocrats, who welcomes the challenge of strategic initiatives and report implementations, Ellis has not always been in accord with some of his examiners. For a start, he is a civilian. Not only has he never done the Knowledge, unlike all the examiners, but he has also never been a policeman, unlike all the examiners bar one (who also happens to be the only woman). For many years, the PCO operated as a adjunct to the Metropolitan Police Force, a relationship that is reflected by the Carriage Office itself, a meticulously impersonal building that resembles nothing so much as a police station.

A kind of masonic austerity was enforced by the Met veterans in an effort to maintain a rigid code of discipline, much of which still remains. Candidates must wear suits and ties to appearances. 'The difficulty of the questions asked is directly linked to the size of the earring or length of pony tail,' Bishop told me. Examiners are addressed as 'Sir'. Failure to arrive on time results in forfeiting the appearance.

'When a guy leaves this office,' said Bishop, a jovial man who wears his pride in the job with a large smile, 'he won't even remember his own name.' One cabbie described it as a terrifying experience. 'A bit like a very nasty version of The Weakest Link.'

A Modern Times documentary made four years ago focused on the climate of fear created by the examiners. And the most feared of all examiners was Mr Ormes. A lugubrious character with a bone-dry delivery, Ormes was seen asking one nervous candidate with a criminal record how to get to the Penal Reform Society. He looked and sounded like a copper who had seen it all and didn't believe your story.

Ormes disliked Ellis's ideas about changing the appearance of an appearance by making it look more informal. Ellis wanted to rearrange the furniture of the interview-rooms and place a vase of flowers in each of them, so that they would seem less like interrogation-rooms. It was the beginning of the end for Ormes, and it wasn't long before he resigned to become a taxi driver. I met him in the forecourt of St Pancras station, where we sat in the back of his cab. He wore a shirt and tie and his upright posture belied the months and years spent sitting in a vehicle. There was a detectable note of humour in his speech, though, which was emphasised by his resemblance to comic actor Roy Hudd. Ormes was very much against the recent innovation of a written introduction test to the Knowledge, and the proposed use of computers. He argued that they discriminated against the illiterate.

'You can smell if people have what is needed,' he explained. Despite describing himself as 'more right wing than Attila the Hun', Ormes felt the answer to speeding up the flow of taxi drivers through the Knowledge was to spend more public money by employing more examiners and extending the appearance time from 15 to 20 minutes. Yet the truth is that most taxi drivers don't want the Knowledge changed, and certainly not made easier, nor do they want more examiners. First, and perhaps understandably, they are unenthusiastic about the idea of new recruits suffering less than themselves. But more than that, the difficulty of the Knowledge naturally restricts the number of licensed drivers and, therefore, most taxi drivers think, ups the number of potential fares.

Although no taxi driver will ever admit (at least not to the tax man) to earning more than £30,000 a year, rumours persist that some make double or even treble that amount. 'We don't believe the Knowledge should be tampered with in any way shape or form,' Bob Oddy, head of the Licensed Taxi Driver Association, told me. Oddy represents around 6,000 drivers. He is firmly of the opinion that the impetus to get more taxis on the road comes not from frustrated members of the public, left to roam darkened streets with large denomination notes in their fists, but from a conspiracy of taxi-cab manufacturers, rental firms and radio-cab circuits, for whom more cabs equals more money.

He also thinks that the reform is somehow linked to the intention, contained in the Private Hire Vehicle London Act of 1998, to license minicabs. Oddy did not fully explain the relationship, but he seemed to suggest that as the PCO will also be responsible for licensing minicabs, its resources will be too stretched to run the Knowledge in its present form, hence the reappraisal. Ellis denies any linkage, although he accepts that the PCO has not yet worked out how it's going to undertake the enormous job of licensing London's growing flotilla of pirate cab firms. The whole problem of lack of cabs, Oddy argues, could be solved by creating a special night tariff.

The man who will ultimately decide what to do is Robert Kiley, the new head of Transport for London, brought in from New York by Ken Livingstone in an effort to rethink a transport system that is on the verge of collapse.

The fact that responsibility for the PCO has moved from the Metropolitan Police to Livingstone's office is an ideological shift that draws diplomatic grimaces from the old-timers at the PCO. Dave Wetzel, Livingstone's right-hand man and former head of transport at the old GLC, is careful not to exacerbate the situation. 'London taxi drivers can be proud of themselves,' he told me. He also batted away my efforts to draw him on the question of their willingness to share their political viewpoints. But he agreed that the male-dominated, Met-dominated PCO did not fit with his and Livingstone's vision of modern London. 'We don't want a mono-culture. We're looking for change at the Public Carriage Office,' he said. 'But not of any individuals.'

Kiley might be a little preoccupied with the Tube system to take much notice of the PCO, but as a onetime inhabitant of New York, where cabs run on a shift system, he might find the idea of taxi drivers knocking off at rush hour rather quaint. At the same time, he will doubtless be impressed by the way that when they're not watching the telly, London cab drivers know where to go, in contrast to their New York colleagues, who seem to know their home town the way I know my way around Pyongyang.

I still recall with amazement a New York cab driver upbraiding me because I only knew the address of where I was going and not the route of how to get there. It would be nice if more of us got to benefit from the extraordinary knowledge of the London taxi driver, but it would be a shame if it was at the cost of that knowledge being downgraded. Outside the PCO on an icy morning, I met a middle-aged man named Steve. He was made redundant some years ago and for the past five years he has devoted himself to the Knowledge. He was collecting information from candidates leaving from their appearances, collating a list of questions asked.

If he didn't recognise any of the points, he would go and find them on his moped. But he seemed to know them all. He even helped a passing taxi driver, who didn't know the whereabouts of some obscure nightclub. Steve, incredibly, was still on 56-day gaps. My God, I said to him, aren't you fed up?

He looked at me with an expression of genuine bemusement. 'No, I love it.'

A little knowledge

1633 First recorded plying of coaches for hire in the street.

1694 Parliamentary Act passed to regulate Hackney carriage trade.

1834 Hansom cabs introduced.

1850 Public Carriage Office opened.

1851 Knowledge is introduced.

1903 The first petrol-driven cab took to the road.

1907 Taximeter introduced.

1952 First diesel cab.

To become a London taxi driver, you must be: over 21; of good character; fit, physically and mentally; and have a thorough knowledge of London. The 'All London' licence requires a detailed knowledge of the 25,000 streets within a six-mile radius of Charing Cross with a more general knowledge of the major arterial routes throughout the rest of London.

Cabs around the world

New York There are 40,000 licensed taxi drivers and 11,787 licensed cabs in New York City. Drivers work shifts and let their cabs to other drivers.

Paris There are 8,474 plate holders in Paris who are the owners of their vehicles.

New Delhi The only requirement for a Delhi taxi driver is to have a driving licence. There is no body governing cabs and no legislation covering quality of cars.

Rome There is a long waiting list for the strictly limited number of licences in Rome. Hopefuls must wait for a driver to retire or die before taking their place. They must then take a strict geography test.

Kim Bunce

So the appeal of the Knowledge goes beyond the lure of self-employment and a good wage to that of a heroic endeavour - to boldly go where no man would think of going, if it wasn't in the Blue Book. The first and most renowned run in the book is Manor House Station to Gibson Square. Followed by 399 others even more unmemorable. But it's not just the 400 runs, and as many as 25,000 streets, that a Knowledge Boy must commit to memory. All the points of interest along the way and within a quarter of a mile of the start and finish of each run must also memorised. As a point of interest can be anything from a place of worship to a shop, an official building to a nightclub, that amounts to perhaps hundreds of thousands of bits of data and an infinite number of relationships between them all. It is mind-expanding stuff. A study at the department of neurology at University College, London showed that the posterior hippocampi (the elongated ridges on the lateral ventricle of the brain) of a group of London taxi drivers was significantly larger than that of the general population. Dr Eleanor Macguire, the senior research fellow who conducted the experiment, says that there could be a number of explanations but all of them add up to the fact that this part of a taxi driver's brain grows while doing the Knowledge. As he make the links between different roads, so, it seems, the neurons and synapses in the posterior hippocampi make new links. In this sense, the map of a taxi driver's brain is the map of London. It could also mean that Fred Housego, the cabbie who famously won Mastermind, was not a fluke. Taxi drivers have bigger brains than the rest of us. Or do they? It turns out that the growth in the posterior hippocampi was accompanied by a corresponding decrease in the anterior hippocampi of the taxi drivers. If the posterior hippocampus is where our spatial information is stored, could it be that the anterior hippocampus houses whatever it is that prevents us from expressing extreme political opinions and pulling U-turns in inconvenient locations? 'I couldn't possibly comment,' said Dr Macguire. You can see why the Knowledge lends itself to metaphor. After a while, the search is not so much geographical as existential. You start out looking for the Samaritan Free Hospital and end up finding yourself. For as well as being a toothache and a jug of water, the Knowledge is a life-changing task that takes upwards of two years to complete. To memorise the routes and points, you have first to acquaint yourself with them in person (most often on a moped), rather than via a map. 'If you can't see it,' they say at the PCO, 'you can't call it.' Many drivers spend five, six or even 10 years mastering the Knowledge (although a very few exceptions have taken as little as a year). And many more fall by the wayside - the drop-out rate is more than two-thirds. The reason some people take more time to finish the Knowledge than doctors take to qualify is that it's not a one-way street. You can go backwards as well as forwards. Each candidate is assessed in a series of 'appearances' before a PCO examiner and depending on how well the appearance goes, the length of time until the next appearance is shortened, extended or unchanged. You start out with 56-day, or sometimes 80-day, gaps between appearances and aim to get down to 21-day gaps to pass out. The effect might be compared to walking blindfold up a down escalator. Although the questions change all the time, a not untypical example of an appearance might be as follows: Noel Road to Liam OGG's; Gallagher & Sons P.H. to Popstars Bar; Beatles Crossing to Oasis Sports Centre; Oscar Wilde's Rooms to Oscar Wilde's Blue Plaque. The method of the Knowledge - reciting the route from one place to another - was once brilliantly spoofed in Viz magazine. Instead of street routes, the cartoon cab drivers were asked to move from one annoying conversational gambit to another. For example: the Spice Girls to And I'd Pull the Lever Myself. It seemed childishly amusing at the time, but now I wonder if it doesn't contain the mystery of that expanding and shrinking hippocampus. Perhaps the necessary corollary of making spatial connections is losing conversational coherence. To put it another way, the taxi driver's compass floats on a white-water stream of consciousness. Roy Ellis told me that he expected the means of assessment to change in the new system. One of life's natural technocrats, who welcomes the challenge of strategic initiatives and report implementations, Ellis has not always been in accord with some of his examiners. For a start, he is a civilian. Not only has he never done the Knowledge, unlike all the examiners, but he has also never been a policeman, unlike all the examiners bar one (who also happens to be the only woman). For many years, the PCO operated as a adjunct to the Metropolitan Police Force, a relationship that is reflected by the Carriage Office itself, a meticulously impersonal building that resembles nothing so much as a police station. A kind of masonic austerity was enforced by the Met veterans in an effort to maintain a rigid code of discipline, much of which still remains. Candidates must wear suits and ties to appearances. 'The difficulty of the questions asked is directly linked to the size of the earring or length of pony tail,' Bishop told me. Examiners are addressed as 'Sir'. Failure to arrive on time results in forfeiting the appearance. 'When a guy leaves this office,' said Bishop, a jovial man who wears his pride in the job with a large smile, 'he won't even remember his own name.' One cabbie described it as a terrifying experience. 'A bit like a very nasty version of The Weakest Link.' A Modern Times documentary made four years ago focused on the climate of fear created by the examiners. And the most feared of all examiners was Mr Ormes. A lugubrious character with a bone-dry delivery, Ormes was seen asking one nervous candidate with a criminal record how to get to the Penal Reform Society. He looked and sounded like a copper who had seen it all and didn't believe your story. Ormes disliked Ellis's ideas about changing the appearance of an appearance by making it look more informal. Ellis wanted to rearrange the furniture of the interview-rooms and place a vase of flowers in each of them, so that they would seem less like interrogation-rooms. It was the beginning of the end for Ormes, and it wasn't long before he resigned to become a taxi driver. I met him in the forecourt of St Pancras station, where we sat in the back of his cab. He wore a shirt and tie and his upright posture belied the months and years spent sitting in a vehicle. There was a detectable note of humour in his speech, though, which was emphasised by his resemblance to comic actor Roy Hudd. Ormes was very much against the recent innovation of a written introduction test to the Knowledge, and the proposed use of computers. He argued that they discriminated against the illiterate. 'You can smell if people have what is needed,' he explained. Despite describing himself as 'more right wing than Attila the Hun', Ormes felt the answer to speeding up the flow of taxi drivers through the Knowledge was to spend more public money by employing more examiners and extending the appearance time from 15 to 20 minutes. Yet the truth is that most taxi drivers don't want the Knowledge changed, and certainly not made easier, nor do they want more examiners. First, and perhaps understandably, they are unenthusiastic about the idea of new recruits suffering less than themselves. But more than that, the difficulty of the Knowledge naturally restricts the number of licensed drivers and, therefore, most taxi drivers think, ups the number of potential fares. Although no taxi driver will ever admit (at least not to the tax man) to earning more than £30,000 a year, rumours persist that some make double or even treble that amount. 'We don't believe the Knowledge should be tampered with in any way shape or form,' Bob Oddy, head of the Licensed Taxi Driver Association, told me. Oddy represents around 6,000 drivers. He is firmly of the opinion that the impetus to get more taxis on the road comes not from frustrated members of the public, left to roam darkened streets with large denomination notes in their fists, but from a conspiracy of taxi-cab manufacturers, rental firms and radio-cab circuits, for whom more cabs equals more money. He also thinks that the reform is somehow linked to the intention, contained in the Private Hire Vehicle London Act of 1998, to license minicabs. Oddy did not fully explain the relationship, but he seemed to suggest that as the PCO will also be responsible for licensing minicabs, its resources will be too stretched to run the Knowledge in its present form, hence the reappraisal. Ellis denies any linkage, although he accepts that the PCO has not yet worked out how it's going to undertake the enormous job of licensing London's growing flotilla of pirate cab firms. The whole problem of lack of cabs, Oddy argues, could be solved by creating a special night tariff. The man who will ultimately decide what to do is Robert Kiley, the new head of Transport for London, brought in from New York by Ken Livingstone in an effort to rethink a transport system that is on the verge of collapse. The fact that responsibility for the PCO has moved from the Metropolitan Police to Livingstone's office is an ideological shift that draws diplomatic grimaces from the old-timers at the PCO. Dave Wetzel, Livingstone's right-hand man and former head of transport at the old GLC, is careful not to exacerbate the situation. 'London taxi drivers can be proud of themselves,' he told me. He also batted away my efforts to draw him on the question of their willingness to share their political viewpoints. But he agreed that the male-dominated, Met-dominated PCO did not fit with his and Livingstone's vision of modern London. 'We don't want a mono-culture. We're looking for change at the Public Carriage Office,' he said. 'But not of any individuals.' Kiley might be a little preoccupied with the Tube system to take much notice of the PCO, but as a onetime inhabitant of New York, where cabs run on a shift system, he might find the idea of taxi drivers knocking off at rush hour rather quaint. At the same time, he will doubtless be impressed by the way that when they're not watching the telly, London cab drivers know where to go, in contrast to their New York colleagues, who seem to know their home town the way I know my way around Pyongyang. I still recall with amazement a New York cab driver upbraiding me because I only knew the address of where I was going and not the route of how to get there. It would be nice if more of us got to benefit from the extraordinary knowledge of the London taxi driver, but it would be a shame if it was at the cost of that knowledge being downgraded. Outside the PCO on an icy morning, I met a middle-aged man named Steve. He was made redundant some years ago and for the past five years he has devoted himself to the Knowledge. He was collecting information from candidates leaving from their appearances, collating a list of questions asked. If he didn't recognise any of the points, he would go and find them on his moped. But he seemed to know them all. He even helped a passing taxi driver, who didn't know the whereabouts of some obscure nightclub. Steve, incredibly, was still on 56-day gaps. My God, I said to him, aren't you fed up? He looked at me with an expression of genuine bemusement. 'No, I love it.' A little knowledge 1633 First recorded plying of coaches for hire in the street. 1694 Parliamentary Act passed to regulate Hackney carriage trade. 1834 Hansom cabs introduced. 1850 Public Carriage Office opened. 1851 Knowledge is introduced. 1903 The first petrol-driven cab took to the road. 1907 Taximeter introduced. 1952 First diesel cab. To become a London taxi driver, you must be: over 21; of good character; fit, physically and mentally; and have a thorough knowledge of London. The 'All London' licence requires a detailed knowledge of the 25,000 streets within a six-mile radius of Charing Cross with a more general knowledge of the major arterial routes throughout the rest of London. Cabs around the world New York There are 40,000 licensed taxi drivers and 11,787 licensed cabs in New York City. Drivers work shifts and let their cabs to other drivers. Paris There are 8,474 plate holders in Paris who are the owners of their vehicles. New Delhi The only requirement for a Delhi taxi driver is to have a driving licence. There is no body governing cabs and no legislation covering quality of cars. Rome There is a long waiting list for the strictly limited number of licences in Rome. Hopefuls must wait for a driver to retire or die before taking their place. They must then take a strict geography test. Kim Bunce

webTitle: Spitting images

fields.headline: Spitting images
fields.standfirst: Four other chicken-licking good restaurants  by Sue Webster
fields.trailText: Four other chicken-licking good restaurants  by Sue Webster.
fields.body:
Nando's
Branches in outer London, Surrey and the north of England
(call 0800 975 8181 for details, or go to www.nandos.co.uk)

Peri-peri may sound like a fatal illness, but it's actually a bird's-eye chilli and the main ingredient in a range of 'secret' sauces developed to accompany the marinaded, flame-grilled chickens of this fast-expanding Afro-Portuguese chain. Cosier than your average fast-food outlet and with better service, Nando's can lay claim to fans such as former President Nelson Mandela in Johannesburg and snooty food critic Nick Foulkes in London, despite offering main dishes such as half a chicken, coleslaw, spicy rice or chips for no more than £6.95. If you haven't tried it yet, you will soon: outlets are opening up all over the plave this spring.

Firehouse Rtisserie
2 John Street, Bath (01225 482 070)

Californian/South-western cuisine is the theme at this lovely, light Georgian building off Milsom Street in the centre of Bath, where the rtisserie turns relentlessly, producing 18 golden, free-range birds at a time. Some are flavoured with fresh lemon and thyme (Dijon tarragon aioli is on the side, never to be touched by dieters), some with a Texas spice mix (garnish: jalapeño coleslaw). Both cost £10.95. Even regulars who call in for the LA-style gourmet pizzas appreciate the rtisserie, which is on full view in the peekaboo kitchen. They say watching it has a 'mesmeric, calming' effect.

Coq d'Argent
Poultry, London EC2 (020 7395 5000)

Naturally, classic coq-au-vin, served with the coxcomb (ooh-er) is the winter staple at this Conran restaurant in the City. But come summertime, when the spectacular rooftop gardens sprout classy parasols and huge rtisseries are set up on the terrace, Coq d'Argent must be the place in London to enjoy barbecued chicken. Cooked by chefs in impeccable whites and served al fresco by impeccable waiters, it has been a longtime secret of the local suits - but shall be no more.

Parisienne Chophouse
3 Yeoman's Row, London, SW3 (phone number to be confirmed)

Let's face it, if it is good enough for Marco Pierre White, it is good enough for us: chicken-on-the-spit is back. This latest MPW venture will open at the end of this month at the site formerly occupied by Brasserie St Quentin and then Chez Gérard and is billed as a place for grills and dishes to be shared by two people, including chickens, ducks and even legs of lamb roasted on a spit. Like the promised 'simple, unfussy' décor, these are presumably further examples of the simple, unfussy cooking which the master has espoused of late. Sauces have not been mentioned.
