webTitle: Mr Smith goes to Milan

fields.headline: Mr Smith goes to Milan
fields.standfirst: Paul Smith is big in Japan, with 200 franchised stores bringing in £150m a year. But can he cut it in Italy? As he opens his first shop in fashion's golden triangle, he talks to Tamsin Blanchard about money, marriage and making frocks
fields.trailText: Paul Smith is big in Japan, with 200 franchised stores bringing in £150m a year. But can he cut it in Italy? As he opens his first shop in fashion's golden triangle, he talks to Tamsin Blanchard about money, marriage and making frocks.
fields.body:
A pigeon has just dive-bombed Paul Smith's shoulder. We were merrily enjoying a quick lunch of panini and pasta, and there it was. Splat! A big white stain on the British designer's immaculate, navy, silk-lined with purple, Paul Smith suit jacket. For most fashion people, this would be the trigger that snaps a very taut spring. Imagine Giorgio Armani's face if such a thing happened to him. He would be swarmed by PRs and assistants. The offending pigeon would be shot down on sight. The jacket would be ceremoniously removed for some serious cleaning and a new jacket would be found. Pronto.

And then everybody would act as though nothing had happened. But this is no ordinary fashion designer. It's Sir Paul Smith, the Nottingham lad made good. As soon as he notices, his face lights up. He's delighted. 'It's good luck for the new shop!' he declares, attempting to mop it off with a handkerchief. And then to our photographer for the day: 'Look! Take a picture of this!'

While his story is a familiar one, it is also unique in the British fashion industry. Milan has Donatella Versace, Giorgio Armani, Tom Ford, Alberta Ferretti, Dolce & Gabbana and Miuccia Prada, and numerous other highly successful designers who have built up their own companies, but Britain has Smith. Sure there's Betty Jackson, Katharine Hamnett, and John Rocha, who all turn over healthy businesses. And there's Alexander McQueen who has sold a 51 per cent stake in his company to Gucci. But in terms of a solid, established, independent brand that is known from Taipei to Toronto, Smith is the only one. He's our equivalent, albeit on a much smaller scale, of Ralph Lauren, or Mr Armani, who has also remained independent. 'It's so difficult to talk about yourself without sounding big headed, but I just think we've got it right,' he says.

And now he's moved into the very heart of fashion's golden triangle, where flagships for Armani, Versace, Gucci and Dolce & Gabbana all jostle for space. Milan is a serious business. And Smith's first Italian shop (there are 10 in the UK, one in Paris, one in New York and 200 in Japan) is on Via Manzoni, right opposite the super-slick, ultra-minimal Giorgio Armani department store which opened last year, and positively vibrates with fluorescent light.

It is the day before the opening and there is still white paper covering the door. But the window display is finished. It couldn't be more low-tech if it tried. There are no clothes in the window - no product whatsoever. Instead, there is a mound of screwed up pages from the Financial Times . That's it. Crinkly balls of pink newspaper. While passers-by seem oblivious to the bright white glow of Armani's windows, they stop in their tracks at the sight of Smith's. They do a double take. Children stand and point. People look a little confused. Some look amused. And others, when they catch sight of Paul Smith, grinning widely and waving at them from inside the shop, really don't know what to think. Some wave back. Others look vaguely embarrassed and walk away.

'It's not necessary to have clothes in the window,' says Smith. 'It's obvious it's a clothes shop. We're just trying not to take the obvious route all the time. We can do anything we want to do. Sometimes we don't have anything in the window. Sometimes it might be just a frog. Look! Everybody's stopping!' And it's true. The lunchtime shoppers of Milan are thoroughly enjoying Smith's first little window joke. And he is loving every minute of it.

So why the FT ? Is this Paul Smith's little joke about big business, money and fashion? Before Christmas, there were rumours that the designer was the next to join the massive LVMH luxury goods conglomerate - along with an ever increasing list of design houses and brand names, including Givenchy, Dior, Louis Vuitton, Celine, and Pucci. In November, the New York Post reported that LVMH was chasing a 25 per cent stake in the privately owned company, which is estimated to be worth £220m. Business in Japan alone, is worth £150m. In September, LVMH's arch-rival, Gucci Group was reported to be hot on the trail. So, too, were Richemont, the Swiss group which owns Chloé, and the Italian jewellery house, Bulgari. According to Smith, there were so many parties interested in investing in his company, negotiations had become a full time job.

He employed the services of merchant bankers, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. It was time to do some hard thinking. 'I think I'm my own worst enemy commercially, because everything I stand for is the opposite to what it's supposed to be in business,' he says. His life is comfortable and happy, shared with his wife, Pauline (they married last year, after being together over 30 years) and her son, Jason, who is involved in the business in charge of export sales.

'Pauline and I are not motivated by getting more and more money. We have made some money over the years but it was never a plan.' They have a house in Notting Hill Gate, complete with a studio where Pauline can paint, and holiday homes in Tuscany and Sardinia. Paul's car collection stretches to a Mini in Sardinia, a Toyota Land Cruiser in Tuscany, and an old BMW and a Bristol in London. He lusts after quirky Morris Minor vans rather than Ferraris.

By accepting a £30m investment in the company, however, Paul could put his feet up, and Pauline, who is no longer involved in the business, could paint to her heart's content. But Paul is hyperactive. He has more energy in his little finger than many people have in their whole bodies. And he actually enjoys what he does so much that, in a funny kind of way, his life is one long holiday - even though he never seems to stop working. 'I am just absolutely, totally, genuinely enthusiastic about what I do for a living,' he says. And you have to believe him. 'I don't need the money anyway. If I suddenly got x number of millions tomorrow, it wouldn't change my lifestyle. You know, I'm still in love with Pauline after 33 years; we've paid for our houses; we're not into yachts or whatever; anybody can have a car these days - you don't have to be rich. So I don't see what it can bring you more than what you've got.'

So it seems, Paul Smith is not for sale. 'We had all the proposed deals - we were talking about millions and millions of quid - but we rejected them, in preference for staying independent for the time being.' And he's really enjoying his state of independence, on a bit of a one-man crusade about the globalisation of fashion.

'I'm not saying the large brands are not creative. But sadly they are over-distributed and over-produced. Where it used to be about individuality, it's actually more about well designed, well-made clothes that are available in every corner of the earth, which to me is terribly sad, because you used to spend your hard-earned money on a bit of designer clothing, because you wanted to have the individuality that came from the designers head and heart. Now it's all about brands.'

A shop in central Milan does not come cheap. 'Key money' paid to the landlord can be in the region of £1m. And then there's the rent on top. But the Italian customer has been a good, loyal one for Smith, and he is confident that, despite the fact that it's like 'bringing coals to Newcastle', the move will pay off. The shop, designed by Sophie Hicks, who created Smith's flagship shop-within-a-house Westbourne House store, is plastered in a sugary shade of peachy pink throughout - a twist on the traditional siena red of Tuscany. 'We wanted a vulgar pink,' says Hicks. 'It's as shocking a pink as the plaster will take.' She has just completed two more shops for Smith in Tokyo. One, specialising in his Red Ear denim range, will be decorated with hundreds of hunting trophies. The idea is that the jeans will hang from antlers rather than hangers.

The new shop is unlike anything Milan has to offer. But then that's not hard. The city has honed down shop fitting to its most basic show and sell. At Paul Smith, there are clothes and handbags (lots of vintage ones mixed with the new). There are sunglasses and shoes. But there is also a really eclectic mix of books (from a 70s publication called Disco by Albert Goldman to Flower Decoration by Constance Spry and the entire collection of books by Cecil Beaton), bits of china, toys, and photographic prints by society photographer Slim Aarons, whose 1950s pictures of the jet set hanging out in Palm Springs and St Tropez inspired this season's collection for both men and women. It is the extra 'stuff' that makes the customer return. 'It goes back to my original little shop in Nottingham,' explains Smith, 'when Pauline and I used to go on holiday to Greece, and I'd buy six pen knives or four pencils from an old utilitarian shop, or some old school exercise books and actually offer them for sale.'

Smith has a bit of a problem with 'stuff'. He just can't resist buying it. And usually in bulk. He's been known to buy entire shops. 'I bought 350 robots in one go,' he confesses. 'There was a stall in Paris selling badges, and I bought the entire stall.' On holiday recently, a shop full of crockery caught his eye, but he realised it would have taken a few days to sort out and he was on holiday after all, so he resisted. 'You should see my room at home,' he says, before reeling off a list: 'five massive piles of magazines; two doll's houses; a fantastic old trunk; model churches; 16 train sets; 400 books; 18 paintings_ masses of stuff.'

A photographer recently used Smith's office, in the attic above his Covent Garden shop, as part of an ongoing project. The idea was to photograph the office as if it were a beach. Every time the post arrived, the shore line would build up a little bit more, with gifts, souvenirs, postcards, letters, and toy rabbits (he says rabbits bring him luck, so his Japanese fans send him about 20 a week).

'I'll collect, say, doll's houses for four years and then they'll just build up, and then I'll sell the whole lot.' Like the Cecil Beaton books in the Milan shop. He has his own collection as well. These are just duplicates. But he says he's not a collector, and knows little about the stuff he buys. He just likes to accumulate things en mass. And then he likes to sell them again. The office and his room at home are just the tip of the iceberg. In his hometown of Nottingham, where the company still has its headquarters, he has 'Paul's Room', which is actually one of a series of warehouses. It has recently been archived, all 80 to 100 cartons.

Before Christmas, Robert Violette published a tiny book of photographs taken by the designer and his father, who was a Nottingham draper. I find it disappointing, that's all. You would show a simple navy blue suit and it would still be in the papers.' Needless to say, he is contemplating moving his catwalk shows to the Italian fashion capital.

The knighthood, last November, came as a surprise to Smith, who had already received a CBE in 1994. It also happened on the day that he and Pauline had arranged to finally get married, a simple registry office job, and then off to a party with friends at the Tate Modern. Typically, Smith, who above all else, is an incorrigible salesman, managed to sell something to one of the ushers during the ceremony at Buckingham Palace. He had forgotten his wife's birthday, and Smith wrote him a note to give to the shop manager: 'I've met this guy at Buck House (honest!). He's a nice bloke and he's forgotten his wife's birthday - give him 20 per cent off.' Another happy customer.

'I'm not sure about having the knighthood,' he says 'It's just in a drawer at home.' He is not really an awards person. He has consistently snubbed the British Fashion Awards. 'It's not right to have an awards ceremony when you haven't got an industry. It's not on - it's just for the wrong reasons. Often, the designer of the year has been on the verge of bankruptcy. I just don't think it's right.' This year, he won the prize for Classic Design, but he didn't attend. His friend, GQ editor Dylan Jones picked up the award on his behalf. While his menswear is still a hit with fashion editors, as well as his customers, his womenswear doesn't set the pulse racing; he has never been a contender for the designer of the year prize. He just isn't 'fashion' enough.

'He's very unspoilt,' says Sophie Hicks. 'Most people who've reached that point would be quite tricky and full of themselves. He's just very natural. Always straightforward. There's no hidden agenda.'

Meanwhile, the Italians and the Swiss and the French are still knocking on Smith's door. The Milan shop, with its bold style and unique stock, will only add to their determination. In the long term, Smith might have no option but to sell a percentage. 'The massive dilemma is what happens after Paul Smith,' he says.

It's a problem he shares with Giorgio Armani opposite. 'I am 54 years of age. You don't go on forever.' Everything about the brand is so closely tied up with the personality of the man, an investor would worry about what would happen to Paul Smith the brand without Paul Smith the man. As he says, commercially he's his own worst enemy. But then, he really wouldn't have it any other way.

webTitle: Pole positions

fields.headline: Pole positions
fields.standfirst: Dirty dancing
fields.trailText: Dirty dancing.
fields.body:
In a recent episode of Frasier, the doctor's 13-year-old son Fredrick comes for a rare visit, and shocks his father and grandfather by turning the TV to an R&B station. 'Those women are half-naked!' exclaims his grandfather. 'That can't be right!' As Fredrick leaves the room to make a phone call, the two older men continue to stare at the screen, dreamily agreeing that they'd never seen such dancing before.

Clearly, they don't hang out in strip clubs, for this is where the moves come from. If you've missed the trend for so-called 'booty videos', tune into MTV or The Box late at night and you'll see endless variations on a theme of male rappers and female flesh: barely dressed dancers bumping and grinding on luxury yachts, on the beach, in Playboy -style mansions, at parties and in clubs. One of the hottest new names in hip hop, N*E*R*D (No one Ever Really Dies), doesn't even bother with the fantasy setting in the promo for its debut single 'Lap Dancing' (out in May), which is simply set in a strip club with the girls peeling off clothes and wriggling over the rappers. The pole dancers in the video for Snoop Dogg's recent single with Dr Dre, 'The Next Episode', look tame in comparison, but Snoop is also producing a series of 'Doggystyle' porn videos with Larry Flint's Hustler empire.

Hip hop has always been about male fantasies, and scantily clad ladies have featured in the videos for years. But Florida's 2 Live Crew was probably the first to employ real strippers, in the video to their 1989 hit 'Me So Horny'. Slowly, the notion caught on. Lap dancers move better than models, they have fewer inhibitions - and they're far more available. As hip hop has spread across middle America, video directors often find themselves working in unfamiliar cities. If they need some good-looking extras at short notice, a trip to the local table-dancing club will usually do it.

Booty videos have become so mainstream that the moves in them have filtered down to the dancefloor. The women at New York hip- hop clubs tend to keep their tight designer clothes on, but their on-the-spot grinding is straight out of the strip club. 'Now when I go to trendy clubs downtown, the girls look like they're in my line of work,' 20-year-old Christina Veclet recently told the New York Times . A dancer at a Bronx strip club, she has appeared in several rap videos, including Notorious B.I.G's classic 'Notorious'.

The same feature quotes a 21-year-old stripper, Babygirl, who has been in dozens of rap videos, including Sisqo's 'Thong Song Remix'. When director Hype Williams came into the Gentlemen's Club in Atlanta two years ago and hired her to do her first video, she was the only stripper on set. 'Now, when I turn on MTV... I see all my co-workers.'

Nor is the trend confined to the rap world. When Peter Stringfellow brought lap-dancing to London, it was seen as naff. But for whatever reasons - irony, a more open interest in eroticism, an appreciation of the art the dancers bring to their work - it's now considered cool to pay to see girls take off their clothes. The Astral in Soho's Brewer Street, a former gay-porn cinema, is London's most stylish pole-dance venue. Among the celebrities spotted there: Damon Albarn, Kate Moss, Jade Jagger and Goldie.

'It's more acceptable partly because the girls are glamorous,' says make-up artist turned designer J Maskrey, who chose the club to show her collection of adhesive skin jewellery as part of Fashion Week last year. 'I wanted a Blue Velvet atmosphere - people looking on to the stage like voyeurs, the darkness of it. The dancers were more flexible in their bodies than models, and very comfortable with not wearing much. They also had more personality.'

And did it work commercially? Maskrey laughs. 'People are still talking about it.'

As the language of lap-dancing moves into the mainstream, it also loses its power to cause controversy. For his London catwalk show last month, Alexander McQueen had candy-striped poles surrounding the set. Being McQueen, he couldn't resist getting some of the models to use the poles for some dirty dancing, but the only thing that was shocking was how little coverage these moves garnered.

For its launch issue, the cool fashion/art magazine Pop featured influential women from the fashion world pole-dancing on its cover. But it was about as far from a men's magazine image as could be imagined. Indeed, Pop 's editor, the talented stylist Katie Grand, was one of the shoot's seven participants. 'Seriously, what do you do with a pole?' wondered accessories designer Katie Hillier in the accompanying interview, underlining how far the imagery has moved from its origins. But it's the ever-sensible Stella McCartney who asked the most pertinent questions. 'Do we give a shit? Aren't we supposed to be talking about our achievements as women?'

The pole dancers in the video for Snoop Dogg's recent single with Dr Dre, 'The Next Episode', look tame in comparison, but Snoop is also producing a series of 'Doggystyle' porn videos with Larry Flint's Hustler empire. Hip hop has always been about male fantasies, and scantily clad ladies have featured in the videos for years. But Florida's 2 Live Crew was probably the first to employ real strippers, in the video to their 1989 hit 'Me So Horny'. Slowly, the notion caught on. Lap dancers move better than models, they have fewer inhibitions - and they're far more available. As hip hop has spread across middle America, video directors often find themselves working in unfamiliar cities. If they need some good-looking extras at short notice, a trip to the local table-dancing club will usually do it. Booty videos have become so mainstream that the moves in them have filtered down to the dancefloor. The women at New York hip- hop clubs tend to keep their tight designer clothes on, but their on-the-spot grinding is straight out of the strip club. 'Now when I go to trendy clubs downtown, the girls look like they're in my line of work,' 20-year-old Christina Veclet recently told the New York Times . A dancer at a Bronx strip club, she has appeared in several rap videos, including Notorious B.I.G's classic 'Notorious'. The same feature quotes a 21-year-old stripper, Babygirl, who has been in dozens of rap videos, including Sisqo's 'Thong Song Remix'. When director Hype Williams came into the Gentlemen's Club in Atlanta two years ago and hired her to do her first video, she was the only stripper on set. 'Now, when I turn on MTV... I see all my co-workers.' Nor is the trend confined to the rap world. When Peter Stringfellow brought lap-dancing to London, it was seen as naff. But for whatever reasons - irony, a more open interest in eroticism, an appreciation of the art the dancers bring to their work - it's now considered cool to pay to see girls take off their clothes. The Astral in Soho's Brewer Street, a former gay-porn cinema, is London's most stylish pole-dance venue. Among the celebrities spotted there: Damon Albarn, Kate Moss, Jade Jagger and Goldie. 'It's more acceptable partly because the girls are glamorous,' says make-up artist turned designer J Maskrey, who chose the club to show her collection of adhesive skin jewellery as part of Fashion Week last year. 'I wanted a Blue Velvet atmosphere - people looking on to the stage like voyeurs, the darkness of it. The dancers were more flexible in their bodies than models, and very comfortable with not wearing much. They also had more personality.' And did it work commercially? Maskrey laughs. 'People are still talking about it.' As the language of lap-dancing moves into the mainstream, it also loses its power to cause controversy. For his London catwalk show last month, Alexander McQueen had candy-striped poles surrounding the set. Being McQueen, he couldn't resist getting some of the models to use the poles for some dirty dancing, but the only thing that was shocking was how little coverage these moves garnered. For its launch issue, the cool fashion/art magazine Pop featured influential women from the fashion world pole-dancing on its cover. But it was about as far from a men's magazine image as could be imagined. Indeed, Pop 's editor, the talented stylist Katie Grand, was one of the shoot's seven participants. 'Seriously, what do you do with a pole?' wondered accessories designer Katie Hillier in the accompanying interview, underlining how far the imagery has moved from its origins. But it's the ever-sensible Stella McCartney who asked the most pertinent questions. 'Do we give a shit? Aren't we supposed to be talking about our achievements as women?'

webTitle: Go see...

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: The League of Gentlemen
fields.trailText: The League of Gentlemen.
fields.body:
Are you local ? If so, you'll be delighted to hear that the missing link between Emmerdale and Eraserhead is rolling into town. The League of Gentlemen's travelling carnival of curiosities begins a four-week London residency tomorrow, transporting cowed theatregoers into the raving, drooling heart of Royston Vasey.

As a warm-up, the League members - mild-mannered Mark Gatiss, Steve Pemberton and Reece Shearsmith - will, in the first half, unveil 'a new range of characters with minimal props' - a set-up that sounds like RV's right-on Legz Akimbo Theatre Company. However, post-interval, the full 40-plus menagerie of misfits that make up the inhabitants of the (semi-) fictional Village of the Damned-cum-BAFTA-scooping, Golden Rose-stealing TV series will, lightning costume changes and prosthetic fittings permitting, strut their stuff in the all-too-clammy flesh.

Cower as porcine Local Shop proprietors Edward and Tubbs - the most effective advert yet against inter-sibling intimacy - unveil their Precious Things! Recoil as pen-obsessed Pauline, the fascistic restart officer, reduces another hapless bunch of JobSeekers to blubber! Cringe as the paedophiliac tour guide Herr Lipp dispenses spittle-inflected malapropisms in all directions! Tremble as you ponder on the likelihood of pre-op transsexual cabbie Barbara revealing his/her legendary bullet-like nipples! And flee the auditorium, probably as minstrel'd-up MC Papa Lazarou stalks the aisles searching for suitable abductees on which to lavish his uniquely chilling but thoroughly inexplicable admonition: 'You're my wife now, Dave!' (which grounds Hannibal Lecter's pathetic 'ta ta' into the dust).

Yes, the show's a bona fide BBC2-ish culty acquired taste; it'll probably attract truckloads of students grateful for any opportunity to bay a succession of catchphrases following the demise of The Fast Show; maybe pilgrims will dress as their favourite characters and turn the whole thing into a Rocky Horror Show. But, for now, the League's creations anatomise the insularity, the quirkery, and the downright oddity of deepest, darkest Britain better than anyone since Monty Python in their heyday, and this is a chance to get as close to them as you dare. To paraphrase Pauline: okey cokey, pig in a pokey - good evening, thrillseekers!

 The League of Gentlemen: A Local Show For Local People , at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, Mondays to Saturdays from 12 March to 7 April. Box office: 020 7439 1202

webTitle: How to cope with a help desk

fields.headline: How to
fields.standfirst: cope with a help desk
fields.trailText: 1 Think about how helpful your employer's helpdesk is likely to be before you contact them. If the computer department is low in the hierarchical pecking order, its staff are badly paid and it is overloaded with other projects, your call could be a low priority. But if your company is well-managed and a high value is placed on you and the functioning of your terminal, service is likely to be better.
fields.body:
1 Think about how helpful your employer's helpdesk is likely to be before you contact them. If the computer department is low in the hierarchical pecking order, its staff are badly paid and it is overloaded with other projects, your call could be a low priority. But if your company is well-managed and a high value is placed on you and the functioning of your terminal, service is likely to be better.

2 Understand just how bad the service can be from under-resourced helpdesks. 'The staff turnover can be similar to that in the restaurant trade,' says Steve, a former helpdesk frontman. 'You can get a new person in every month - and they'll be underskilled, underpaid and under-experienced. They could also be stressed out because when people ring the helpdesk they are generally quite irate and frustrated.' Depressed helpdesk staff will suggest solutions which they know are unlikely to work just to take the pressure off.

3 Keep details of all phone calls, suggests Lewis Gowers of internet services company and consultancy Tankbay. 'Just like when you're diagnosing an illness, the history of a problem is important.' Note the name of the person you dealt with - and, if they are good, keep on dealing with them.

4 Try to understand what has gone wrong with your machine - and politely ask the helpdesk why they think the problem has occurred and why they are making those particular recommendations. If you do not get intelligible answers, you are probably being fobbed off. On some commercial telephone-based helpdesks, operators will frequently throw out a range of suggestions to a variety of problems: many are the equivalent of checking the plug. Your best protection is to understand the system you are working on. If you don't, you are dependent on the goodwill of strangers -- a particularly bad situation if you are dealing with a stream of different people over the telephone.

5 Listen to the tone of voice of the helper. Many will sound depressed -and are therefore more likely to renege on any promises. Check that they are doing what they agreed. If that software engineer has not turned up, then call again and be polite but firm.

6 Look carefully at the terms of the helpdesk arrangements if you are buying your own PC at home. You can get stung by helpdesks which charge £1 per minute and hold you in a queue for five minutes before connecting you to a human being.

webTitle: The cost of...

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ... starting a business
fields.trailText: ... starting a business.
fields.body:
Work, said Oscar Wilde, is the curse of the drinking classes. It has long been acknowledged that we work the longest hours in Europe while our Continental counterparts enjoy long boozy lunches, sunshine, siestas and relaxed camaraderie. Do you despair of the petty bureaucracy, venomous office politics, venal bosses and the general ineptitude that suffuses most modern workplaces? Do you suffer from insomnia, failed relationships, chronic stress or depression? If so, then the solution is to simply give up. Quit.

Starting your own business is easy. The first thing to do is to incorporate a company, which you do through Companies House. The constitution of a limited company is set out in the Memorandum and Articles (known as Mem and Art to solicitors who supply the documents). You appoint your directors, your company secretary and your registered office in Form 10. The 'limited' is short for limited liability, which means that you can set the value and number of shares in the company (for example 1,000 shares at £1 each), and if anybody sues you they can only sue for the extent of your liability, not your house, savings or assets. Companies House charges £20 for filing these documents and you will have to pay a further £15 each year when you file your accounts.

Solicitors can do all the paperwork. You can either choose an off-the-shelf company - which means transferring everything to your name, which costs about £100, including drafts of the minutes of the board meeting confirming the transfer and company appointments - or you can create your own company from scratch: the solicitor will charge about £120.

Tax laws have changed recently, so it is best to appoint an accountant to deal with anything involving interminable columns of numbers. If you are working for yourself, be prepared to pay about £700 for the accountant to do your end- of-year accounts and £45 per quarter for your payroll details. As company director, you can pay yourself a small monthly salary.

The remainder of your income you can take in the form of quarterly dividends - these attract corporation tax of just 10 per cent (if your turnover is less than £350,000) but no National Insurance bills. Your own company website is obligatory. Even if it is www.whatthehelldoIdonow.com.

Off-the-shelf company £100
New company name £120
Company registration £20
Account filing fees £15 per year
Accountant fees £880 per year
Corporation tax 10 per cent
Domain name registration £50

webTitle: The perfect lounge music

fields.headline: The perfect lounge music
fields.standfirst: Sacha Distel
fields.trailText: Sacha Distel.
fields.body:
The time is right now for a revival of lounge music because the young generation has finally started to like it - they probably never expected to be interested in something their mothers had told them about. The back catalogue is full of so many songs, though, that trying to choose one is like trying to say why you prefer one woman to another. The particular quality is almost impossible to define, but the composition and performance should combine to give tremendous pleasure. If love is the theme, then that's even better.

'My Funny Valentine', 'The September of my Years' or anything by Gershwin all capture the perfect easy-listening mood.

Tony Bennett is one of the great interpreters and Dionne Warwick is not only a great singer, she's a really close friend. Like Sinatra, she has an original voice and excellent phrasing. She's got that vibrato - I asked her one day how she does it and she just said, 'I don't know'.

Easy listening doesn't mean an easy performance. We used to tease Burt Bacharach that his songs were unsingable because they were so difficult. But then, suddenly, songs like 'Raindrops Keep Falling on my Head' and 'Alfie' became hits, and Dionne was very useful in that regard. It's all a question of finding something that works with the current mood.

It's best to listen to it at home, in your own time, when you can relax. My perfect easy-listening moment was in a studio in New York at a recording of one of my songs by Sinatra and Count Basie's band, conducted by Quincy Jones. It's better than hearing it in a restaurant because I never listen to what the other person is saying because I'm so distracted by the music. It's so often treated as background music when it's so much more than that.

webTitle: Loafer's guide...

fields.headline: Loafer's guide...
fields.standfirst: Nelly Furtado
fields.trailText: Nelly Furtado.
fields.body:
Is she the best thing to come out of Canada since Celine Dion?
Oh, please. Twenty-one-year-old singer-songwriter Furtado doesn't indulge in multi-octave power ballads. The Courteney Cox lookalike has been tipped as the (musical) face of 2001.

OK, she looks good - but what does she sound like?
You've probably heard her deliciously funky single, 'I'm Like a Bird', which was instantly playlisted by Radio 1 and MTV. Her debut album, Whoa, Nelly! , has already gone platinum in the US and Canada. It's a retro-flavoured brew of folk, soul, bossa nova and lounge pop - Beth Orton meets Beck with Macy Gray-like vocals.

And how did she get this far?
The daughter of Portuguese parents, Furtado grew up in Toronto. At 19 she made a demo that sparked a bidding war among major record labels. She later turned down a £3m publishing deal and signed a deal with DreamWorks.

Time to bring out the spurious Britney Spears comparisons?
Hardly. For a start, she writes her own songs - and they're rather good. Britney probably doesn't pore over the Beats or Hindi theology in her spare time. Furtado plays the keyboards, trombone and ukulele and sings in English, Portuguese and Hindi. She's also quite witty. She named her debut Whoa, Nelly! because 'I figured writers would use that headline anyway, so I wanted to make them come up with something more original'.

Who's going to buy Whoa, Nelly! ?
Style magazine aficionados, Hoxton dwellers and the CD-buying cognoscenti. Or so the record company hopes. More likely she will appeal to the odd consumer looking for something cool to put next to that Macy Gray CD. There's also a smattering of low-level angst that might appeal to the Coldplay crowd: ' I'm drinking spirits in the hopes that I will find myself one ,' she sings in 'Party'.

Shall we put a large bet on her for next year's Brits?
Yes. Unless she records a duet with Craig David.

webTitle: Agony Aunt: Am I too late to claim for dismissal?

fields.headline: Am I too late to claim for dismissal?
fields.trailText: Three years ago I left my job after 40 years. Five years before I left, I took on extra duties, but shortly afterwards had a minor stroke and was off for a few months. When I returned, I found my shifts had been lengthened from 10 to 11 hours. My employer then downgraded my post. Is it too late to claim constructive dismissal?
fields.body:
Three years ago I left my job after 40 years. Five years before I left, I took on extra duties, but shortly afterwards had a minor stroke and was off for a few months. When I returned, I found my shifts had been lengthened from 10 to 11 hours. My employer then downgraded my post. Is it too late to claim constructive dismissal?

There is little you can do now. Timetables are tight: a claim for constructive dismissal has to be lodged within three months of departure to go through an industrial tribunal. Claims are also notoriously difficult. As well as proving you were treated unfairly, you must prove it was tantamount to breach of contract. Successful claims often hinge on a unilateral changing of terms - increased hours, for instance.

Another successful route is claiming breach of a term which is implied, by law, in every contract - 'mutual trust and confidence'. An employer would be demonstrating withdrawal of trust if it suddenly barred you from meetings you had always attended, your telephone was taken away, or your ability to carry out basic duties.

Some workers go for breach of contract in county courts; claims must be lodged within six years. But courts expect most disputes to go through tribunals.

Legal advice this week from Hammond Suddards Edge

webTitle: Chronicle of a death foretold

fields.headline: Chronicle of a death foretold
fields.trailText: 'John Diamond, and Ruth Picardie before him, expressed all the turmoil of dying, and, especially, of those dying before their time.'
fields.body:
Death is relative. In your younger years, for instance, death is just an enormous V sign. You worship musicians who popped off early - live fast! die young! - ignoring the fact that they did so by prettily swallowing their own puke. You devour books like The Bell Jar , and in times of extreme trouble (when your parents won't let you stay out after midnight), you seriously contemplate ending it all yourself. 'You'll miss me when I'm gone! I'll show you all!' you trumpet, and you stomp to your bedroom to plan your own funeral.

Of course, once you've realised that basking in postmortem compliments isn't that easy when you're not alive to hear them, you change your mind and come down for some toast. Still, there's always other people's deaths to contemplate. Boys draw army scenes in art and watch films about serial killers. Girls weep over Wuthering Heights and watch Titanic. Both dream up horrible fatal tortures specifically for their maths teacher.

Death, at such an age, seems so distant as to appear toothless. You can mould it to your imagination's desire - does sir want his ending gory or artistic? - because you are so full of life that the grave cannot harm you. But as you grow older and death's breath comes nearer, then you stop being so blasé. You feel surrounded by catastrophe: trains crashing, rivers bursting, animals burning, bombs blowing, children shooting each other. And you become frightened - for yourself, and for others. I find it appalling to even think of any of my family or friends dying. I won't talk about it in case I make it happen.

But our adult fear of our own ending means that death is rarely discussed. Or rarely discussed in a way that means anything. Politicians call it collateral damage. Reporters resort to numbers: THIRTEEN DEAD. We all reach for stock phrases: passed on, deepest sympathies, our thoughts are with you. We have hardened ourselves to our own clichés.

Which is why we are touched by writers like John Diamond, who chronicled his own creeping demise with humanity, wit and honesty. He got thousands of letters about his cancer column, because he wrote truly about dying. Knowing you are about to die is not natural. It's ridiculous and frightening, it makes you angry, it makes you laugh, and often it is not the most important thing in life. John Diamond, and Ruth Picardie before him, expressed all the turmoil of dying, and, especially, of those dying before their time. They wrote about dying. But what they didn't write about was death.

Death is about those left behind. Unlike most who die young, John Diamond knew his time was coming. He could prepare his family as well as he was able. And the story of him doing so was, and is, moving beyond belief. But the driver of the train in the Selby crash had no chance to warn his family, tell them he loved them, write a letter to his children, make sure his wife would be cared for financially. He had no chance to tie his life up into an appropriate bow. He just went to work one morning and never came back.

When someone you love dies, it is more terrible than you can ever imagine. More painful, more appalling. That's why we don't talk about it beforehand, because the truth is too unbearable. The time for talking is after death. So we see page upon page, programme after programme discussing the death of Princess Diana. We see enormous obituaries for Paula Yates, Kirsty MacColl, John Diamond. And rightly so: these people touched more than most. They were known, and to be known, these days, means to be a kind of friend of the public. Celebrities are no longer on pedestals. We know so much about them that they become part of the family. And their deaths ripple out to affect more than their own families.

But for every famous person who dies before their time, there are thousands of ordinary people who do the same. And, for their families, that death is more important than any other. They can't understand why that death is not on the news. Or why, if it is, it's just because of its circumstances (accident, murder, lots of people at the same time). Or just because a famous person died at the same time. Remember when Lord Mountbatten was killed? Remember 15-year-old Paul Maxwell, the boat boy who died with him?

If your death is unexpected enough, or shocking enough, or ridiculous enough, then it will always make the papers. But such a death will overshadow what came before. The reporting will be about the manner of the death. Nothing to do with the manner of the life before it. Only famous people are allowed that privilege.

webTitle: Appraisals fail staff and bosses alike

fields.headline: Appraisals fail staff and bosses alike
fields.trailText: A new report by the Institute of Employment Studies (Performance Review: Balancing Objectives and Content) finds that although performance appraisal is nearly ubiquitous, it often fails both employees and organisations.
fields.body:
A new report by the Institute of Employment Studies (Performance Review: Balancing Objectives and Content) finds that although performance appraisal is nearly ubiquitous, it often fails both employees and organisations.

According to the IES, many appraisal systems lack strategic focus, give conflicting messages between encouragement and control, have limited impact on business performance and challenge managers who may lack the skills and motivation to carry them out effectively.

In addition, the report shows that appraisal is heavily overburdened with sometimes conflicting aims, so that as well as reviewing performance, a two-hour interview is expected to identify training needs, provide career counselling, spot high- flyers and manage poor performers.

The report argues that in seeking to do so many things, appraisal systems fail to deliver any of them effectively.

webTitle: My money: Fruits keep falling from lady's diary

fields.headline: Fruits keep falling from lady's diary
fields.standfirst: The Edwardian writer's great niece is now running a healthy business, writes Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: The Edwardian writer's great niece is now running a healthy business, writes Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
If you do not recognise the name Edith Holden, you may have heard of her book The Country Diary of an Edwardian Lady. Written in 1906 to encourage her pupils at Solihull School to take an interest in nature, the book was never intended for a wider audience.

But when her 22-year-old great-niece Rowena Stott took the diary to a publisher she had met at a party in 1976, he recognised its potential immediately and paid her £100 not to show it to anyone else.

It was published the following year and sold 5 million copies in 13 languages. Huge merchandising spin-offs followed including kitchens, china, cards and duvet covers. Visit the Past Times chain to see some of the latest versions. After a few years out of print, the Diary is republished on Thursday.

Holden died at 48 when she drowned in an accident at Kew Gardens, but her legacy changed Rowena Stott's life. 'We have quite a lot to thank Edith for,' says Stott. 'She paid for my education.' Holden had inherited shares in her father's paint and varnish business in Birmingham. These were passed down the family, ending up with Stott's mother. Stott, whose father was not prepared to pay for a daughter's education himself, was sent to boarding school on the proceeds.

Stott had been brought up looking at the pictures of the birds, trees and flowers in her great-aunt's diary. While she was studying at Exeter Art College in the mid-Seventies, she met publisher Richard Webb of Webb & Bower and decided to show the diary to him. The day he gave her the £100 was 'probably the best day of my student life. I remember waking up in the morning and thinking this was fantastic. I could pay off my overdraft and I bought a pair of shoes'.

Soon after the book was published, Stott moved to Manchester to do an MA in Fine Art. But 'in some ways, the book took over'. She formed a company to run the operations. 'I had not realised that interest would go on so long. Even in recessions it did quite well.'

Although she was learning business skills as she went along, Stott never made a huge mistake. 'I am a single parent, so I had to be aware I couldn't do anything outrageous. There's someone else to think about.'

The book produced a comfortable living for Stott and her daughter, who is just starting a Fine Art course. Their one extravagance has been travelling. 'I was born in the fifties into a family that kept everything - string, jam jars. Nothing was wasted. I just carry on like that. I formed the company and took a wage from it, but I never overdid it. I drive a six-year-old Renault Clio.'

'Money has not been a big motivation of mine,' she says. 'But the experience has been wonderful. I could not have survived as an artist otherwise.' She is a painter of figurative work and hopes to exhibit some pictures soon. 'I don't paint like Edith,' she says with a smile.

Edith was also her own woman. A teacher and illustrator from a well-off family, she stayed single until 40 when she married a sculptor, Stott's great-uncle, seven years her junior. Would Edith have been pleased at her diary's success? 'I think she would have been rather bemused at the impact of something that had been written for children.'

 'The Country Diary of an Edwardian Lady' by Edith Holden is published by Michael O'Mara Books, price 15.99.

webTitle: Time to consummate timid Abbey's stormy love affair

fields.headline: Time to consummate timid Abbey's stormy love affair
fields.trailText: Three cheers to John Vickers, the new Director General of Fair Trading.
fields.body:
Three cheers to John Vickers, the new Director General of Fair Trading.

Not just for showing, in the case of the banks over the past fortnight, that he has backbone. In certain important instances - notably supermarkets - the new broom at the Office of Fair Trading still needs to stiffen his act.

No, congratulations are really due for providing the clearest, most succinct reasons why the on-now-off merger of Abbey National and Bank of Scotland would be a wholly good thing.

Naturally, most of the press comment last week, when the OFT finally published its reasoning on the Abbey battle, focused on Vickers' savage indictment of Lloyds TSB's bid, which led to its referral to the Competition Commission. Ignored, really, were indications as to why Vickers waved BoS's deal through: essentially, the potential merger would have to carve out a serious new competitor to the 'big four' not only in current accounts, but in lending to small businesses.

One might have expected Abbey, in particular, to have talked this up, given its aspirations to take on the 'big four'. Abbey's timidity in fighting its corner, however, was no more powerfully demonstrated than a fortnight ago, when it called off talks with BoS until the Competition Commission pronounced on Lloyds TSB.

Following Vickers' reasoning - and the Competition Commission's interim findings last week on the big banks' grip on the small business market - Abbey chief executive Ian Harley should think again, re-open talks and take the arguments back to his shareholders.

What is now much clearer is the struggle Lloyds TSB has to get its rape of Abbey through. Of course, the Competition Commission may canvass options which Lloyds TSB could offer - such as branch disposals or hiving off the Cheltenham & Gloucester brand. But satisfactory remedies look far tougher here than in the case of Interbrew's acquisition of Bass Brewers, which was blocked entirely.

When the Commission's concerns about small business banking are also taken on board, it is clear that Lloyds TSB's Peter Ellwood has little chance. Waving Lloyds TSB's bid through, with bits nibbled off, would make a mockery of the Government's banking concerns. It is Abbey's potential force in competing for small business lending and current accounts that should count as much as its market share in either segment.

As for the Trade & Industry Secretary, decisions on Manchester United/BSkyB, car pricing, supermarkets and Interbrew show that, wisely, Stephen Byers follows his experts' advice. Ellwood would, therefore, be wasting his time lobbying the Minister to do differently.

The story throughout this latest banking tussle has been lack of willpower from Abbey. Is Abbey big and ugly enough to have a viable, independent future? Of course.

Like the Halifax, Harley should have stuck to this tack. Instead, he undermined his credibility through secret talks with BoS while protesting independence and complaining of a City whispering campaign. Pulling a fast one on BoS chief Peter Burt - by turning a merger into a takeover - was also naive. Abbey's investors simply wouldn't wear it.

In all this, however, Harley is the victim, not the villain. That accolade is reserved for the short termism of City institutions. Last week's long-awaited Myners report has a lot to say on that score.

Why was Abbey under pressure in the first place? Because fund managers needed its share price up to bolster their performance before their quarterly meetings with their clients, the pension fund trustees. Why has Abbey balked at revealing the terms of its merger with BoS? Because, for the same reasons, City shareholders made it clear they prefer the higher price Lloyds might still offer, to the longer-term gains of an Abbey/BoS merger.

After last week's trio of announcements - from Vickers, the Commission and Myners - Harley should now reopen talks with Burt and take the deal to institutions with a vengeance. The clear, pathbreaking alternative is for Burt to lay out the terms and do so himself. That would not be so much a 'hostile merger' as fearless taking of the lead. And it would not be very different from BoS's ground-breaking move on NatWest which, though unsuccessful, enhanced Burt's standing no end.

Cream for a few, dry cake for many

Barclays' accounts, issued last week, make interesting reading. And not just for the huge package enjoyed by Canadian chief executive Matt Barrett.

Totting up the whole panoply of salary, bonus, private pension contributions, awards of shares and profits on share options, that came to a mighty £2.8 million last year - not the £1.7m widely reported last week.

The accounts are particularly illuminating about Barclays Capital, which runs the bank's remaining investment banking operations following the sale of BZW in 1998.

As we reveal today, last year bonuses at Barclays Capital (and Barclays Global Investors, the fund management arm) accounted for pretty much all of the bank's £172m increase in salary-related costs. Put another way, just 6,400 of Barclays' 80,000 staff (including agency workers) got the cream, while the rest ate crumbling cake.

Barclays still has a whiff of the BZWs about it, and there is a moral for investors, too.

Barclays Capital lifted profits by £92m last year to £403m, a healthy rise of 30 per cent. Income, however, rose much more, by £310m - as did costs, by £193m. That means for every £1 of extra revenue, the investment bankers took 62p out, leaving shareholders with just 38p. (At BGI, the fund managers took 82p of every new pound earned.)

Just compare that with the retail network, where costs were flat, but income rose by £400m. Here, as in corporate banking, every extra penny dropped to the bottom line.

Last June, corporate banking's biggest accounts, around 250 blue chip clients in all, moved over to Barclays Capital at Canary Wharf. From the figures, it is impossible to say how much of the division's profits increase came from that restructuring. There may be sound business reasons for the move, but it is a dear one for investors, who lose a large chunk of every pound transferred over.

And do the investment bankers justify their whack? On the figures, clearly not. At 0.25 per cent, the riskier Barclays Capital's operating return on total assets is just one-sixteenth of the branch network's. Plus ça change.

webTitle: Profile: Lord Waheed Alli

fields.headline: Mogul at the Crossroads
fields.standfirst: The co-founder of Planet 24 was so soft on the motel soap that he longed to revive it. A move to Carlton made that dream possible, and drew 2 million viewers last week
fields.trailText: The co-founder of Planet 24 was so soft on the motel soap that he longed to revive it. A move to Carlton made that dream possible, and drew 2 million viewers last week.
fields.body:
Name: Lord Waheed Alli

Title: Founder of Planet 24

Born: 16 November 1964

Other directorships: Tornado Group; chairman of the Digital Radio Group

Hobbies: Travelling, helping Labour win the next election

Some things can be revived: Duran Duran, tank tops, even Paul Daniels' career. But a Sixties soap set in a Midlands motel which flatlined in the Eighties does not exactly scream 'resuscitate'.

Yet last week more than 2 million people tuned in for the first episode of the new look Crossroads . Very new look in fact. The setting has shifted from the West to the East Midlands and, shock horror, the motel has gone.

'We couldn't find a motel; they no longer exist,' says Lord Waheed Alli, who brought the soap back from TV purgatory. 'It would have been silly to pretend other wise, so we went for a four star hotel - very comfortable rooms.'

Sitting in the House of Parliament canteen, Alli, small and intense, is clearly excited about the launch of his 'baby': 'I grew up with Crossroads , and I'm anxious to see whether people think we've done justice to it. Hearing that music come up is brilliant.'

Alli breaks off to hum the soap's annoying signature tune. He and his partner, Charlie Parsons, who co-founded TV production house Planet 24 with Bob Geldof, wanted to remake the soap a few years ago, but the company which owned the rights wouldn't sell.

Then, two years ago, Alli, Parsons and Geldof sold Planet, maker of The Big Breakfast and The Word , to Carlton for £15 million, a deal which reportedly earned Alli £5m. The sale cleared the way for him to make a renewed attempt to bring the soap back. He had joined Carlton as managing director of its programming arm, with a brief from chief executive Michael Green to shake up the division. In came Lily Savage and a deal was signed with Ragdoll Productions, maker of Teletubbies , to provide more children's programming. The company also invested in a raft of new prime-time dramas. And then came Crossroads .

'I don't know why I loved the old Crossroads , but you have very few times in your life when you have the creative freedom to do what you want, and we wanted to bring it back.'

The chance came when Channel 5 launched its audacious and successful bid to poach Aussie soap Home and Away from ITV. Alli pounced, seizing the weekday slot for his baby. While soaps tend not to be the greatest revenue drivers for networks, making Crossroads was not about economics, Alli says. It was part of a rebranding exercise, something that is yielding dramatic results - albeit after Alli quit Carlton to concentrate on politics.

'I know I changed the face of Carlton,' Alli says proudly, a sentence which nearly causes Keith Vaz MP, sitting nearby, to choke on his lunch.

'What's this: Lord Alli, my life story?' Vaz asks.

'Keith I'm talking to the Observer ,' Alli says playfully. Vaz doesn't say much after that.

Alli argues that consolidation among media companies means content is now at a premium. 'It's inevitable that Carlton and Granada will merge. Channel 5 is going to RTL. The challenge now is to build brands across the platforms, and this is why content is so important. Content may not be king just yet, but it's close. It's more like queen at the moment.'These days, Alli doesn't get too heavily involved in the production side of things. He's concentrating on his next offspring: winning the next election for Labour.

Alli was probably New Labour before New Labour. Media savvy and, like all Labour apparatchiks, a mix of the urban and the urbane, Alli left school at 16 to find a job so he could support his immigrant parents. It's a stark contrast to the wealth he now enjoys, and his generosity is legendary. He once bought Big Breakfast star Denise Van Outen a £25,000 diamond necklace as a Christmas present.

Other details about Alli's rise to media moguldom are sketchy. A close friend of both Peter Mandelson and Tony Blair, he doesn't do many interviews. He has been targeted by racist and homophobic groups, most notably over his opposition to Clause 28.

After the election, Alli will probably spend more time building his portfolio of part-time careers. He's looking for a directorship with a blue chip FTSE company to add to the non-executive directorship he holds at Tornado Group, a company that specialises in distributing content over the internet. He is also chairman of the The Digital Radio Group.

The two positions seem incongruous at first. 'If you look at Tornado, it seems an odd choice,' says Alli. 'But it's a business I understand. It's about delivering creatively. I love working with creative talent. I love making things.'

He's keen to stress that although Tornado is involved with the internet, it's not a dotcom company, complete with short shelf-life and terrifying cash burn rate.

Alli is scornful of the institutions that created the internet bubble: 'The people to blame are the venture capitalists. You can't give that sort of money to inexperienced managers. But now we've gone from one extreme to another, and the market has completely dried up.'

webTitle: Why time is not on your side

fields.headline: Why time is not on your side
fields.standfirst: BG's direct debit policy is no gas, says  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: BG's direct debit policy is no gas, says Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
You can cut your British Gas bill by 11 per cent if you pay by direct debit, cutting £34 off a fairly typical annual bill of £309, according to the company. But, depending on the date that it last read your meter, you could find the direct debit payments are above what they should be.

This is what happened to one of our readers, known here as Mr A Pensioner. His latest statement from BG in late February told him that his gas consumption had risen by 14 per cent. BG therefore wanted to increase his monthly direct debit from £28.50 to £32.50.

But when he looked closer at the statement, he realised that most of the reason for the 14 per cent increase came from the fact the statement covered 55 and a half weeks.

In fact his consumption had barely risen at all if he calculated the cost over 52 weeks to make it comparable with the previous year. In doing this, he seems to have done a calculation that is beyond the BG computer. Staff describe it as sophisticated in that it can produce direct debit projections that alter according to the number of people living in the house and weather conditions in that part of the country.

But many other people will find themselves in a similar position to Mr Pensioner. BG, which introduced quarterly rather than six-monthly meter readings last April, sends its meter readers to knock on your door in a window of time between 90 and 111 days after your last reading. Since a quarter of a year actually falls on the 91st day, this means that readings will tend to be for longer periods than a quarter. If you have not had your meter read in two years, BG is obliged to do all it can to get one, and will extend the window to 121 days.

When Mr Pensioner rang BG, the company was more than happy to accept his argument and left his monthly direct debit unchanged at £28.50. But this only happened because he took the initiative. He says: 'It would have had £48 more from me during the year than was needed. If just another 20,000 people are in the same position, then that gives British Gas £1 million to earn interest on for a while.'

As BG says, people do pay the right amount in the end. You can get overpayments refunded if you ask BG during the year or it will cut down next year's direct debits if you have paid too much. But it has still had use of your money for a year, and you have lost the use of it.

Many people could find that they are paying too much during the course of a year. Mr Pensioner is particularly worried about other pensioners who may be living on tight budgets.

BG says that its computer system can also throw out underpayments in its direct debit calculations as well. But it will not give statistics on the numbers of over- and underpayments to back up its assertions.

And there is plenty of room for overpayments in the accounts of Centrica, which owns British Gas and its other energy businesses. The latest Centrica accounts up to 31 December 2000 showed £2.7 billion due to be repaid to customers.

webTitle: Garage pumped up my  fuel bill by £70

fields.headline: Garage pumped up my  fuel bill by £70
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
I bought diesel fuel at an Esso petrol station using my Alliance & Leicester Visa card and signed the sales voucher without checking the amount on it.

My credit card statement showed a debit of £93.74 instead of the correct £19.64, so I had signed for nearly 100 litres more than I had put in the tank.

The Alliance & Leicester has credited my account with £40, half the disputed sum. I accept that Esso's bankers are not obliged to act, given my admittedly careless signature, but I question the way the petrol pump worked.
MG, Ruardean

When Esso investigated your problem more thoroughly, it discovered an understandable human error.

While you were taking 24.58 litres of diesel from pump nine on the forecourt, another driver was filling up with 117.32 litres at pump 10.

When you paid, the cashier should have checked the pump number and the amount of fuel with you, asked you to check the amount and sign, and then checked your signature against your card. One of you was not paying attention, and you paid for pump 10's diesel.

As a gesture of goodwill, the oil company is sending you an ex gratia payment of £80 to cover the £74 you overpaid and your costs in sorting it out. Alliance & Leicester confirms that it will not be asking you for the £40 back, so your carelessness has turned out to be lucky.

Double glazing: Loan is a pane

I was encouraged, even pressed, by Everest to take out a loan for the cost of double glazing. I was guaranteed 10 per cent back 90 days after the first payment.

When the £306 had not arrived, I contacted Everest, which said I would not get the cash back because of my age: I would be 75 before the final payment. No mention of this had been made previously, even though my age had been clearly stated and noted.

The only reason I took out the loan was to get the 10 per cent back. I feel that this is a dubious practice.
GR, Penrith

Everest confirms that your age is not a factor in its cashback scheme. You should not have been told that it was.

Although the loan was through First National Bank, the retailer decides on promotions and the Everest salesman appears to have made a mistake.

You were entitled to 10 per cent cashback only if you took a 10-year loan. Your five-year loan was not eligible. Everest admits to some 'confusion' and is sending you the £306 anyway.

Slothful Tessa: Pays to complain

My Northern Rock Tessa 2 will mature with about £12,100. I made a bit of a song and dance in my branch about this low value, and was told that some people had already complained and staff had been instructed to refer them to head office. There would probably be some adjustment made, I was told.

I was surprised by this, as they seemed to realise there was a problem and had worked out a solution. But would they have told anyone unless they took the trouble to complain?
CS, Manchester

Northern Rock says it is standard practice to refer complaints to head office. It insists its Tessa rate is fair, but says it will listen to grievances, review each case and make ex gratia payments if appropriate.

It is worth complaining to head office, particularly if you feel your account has not been handled properly.

Cash protection: On the double

I know that the maximum amount of savings covered by the building societies' Deposit Protection Scheme is £20,000. But if I have a joint account worth £20,000, would £10,000 in another account with the same building society be covered or not?
AB, Newcastle

The £20,000 limit applies to all the money you have in one building society or bank. If the society went bust, the Deposit Protection Scheme would pay 90 per cent of the first £20,000 so the most you could get is £18,000.

However, joint accounts have twice this limit, according to the rules. The result is that if you had £10,000 in a single account and owned half the £20,000, both the accounts would be covered.

Tax return check: Unready reckoner

What do chartered accountants generally charge for filling in a couples' pension tax forms?

We have asked ours for a quotation three times, and we have been given no answer yet. What do you think we should do now?
ED, Paisley

This is appaling behaviour. Your accountant should tell you the fees immediately you ask. In fact, you should ask how much it will cost before you let anyone work on your tax forms. You are entitled to do this and many people do. There are no set prices, so the best way to compare is to telephone several local accountants. You should complain about your existing accountant's behaviour to the Accountants' Professional Standards Office on 01908 546215.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Include a telephone number, but not SAEs nor original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The paper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

webTitle: Cashpoints

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Expert edge | Smoked out | Low returns
fields.body:
Expert edge

Travel insurance offered by specialist firms consistently has the edge on cover from high street travel agents, says Holiday Which?

TravelPlan Direct, a best buy, charges £10 to cover two weeks in Europe, while Going Places charges £40.99. Which? warns that much of the free travel cover offered with credit cards covers only accidents.

Smoked out

Now may be the time to give up smoking. Cigarettes cost 6p more a packet after the Budget, and smokers will have to pay much more for term assurance now Equitable Life has pulled out of this market.

Equitable treated smokers and non-smokers equally, says broker Assureline. But smokers will now have to pay up to 43 per cent more for life assurance than non-smokers, says Direct Life & Pensions which claims it can undercut the competition.

Obtain a quote on www.payingtoomuch.co.uk, or by phoning Assureline on 020 8643 9663.

Low returns

Interest rates were pegged again last week at 5.75 per cent by the Bank of England. (check Thursday) But don't assume there won't be further cuts for savers. These days banks and building societies cheesepare constantly as they set out their stalls for new customers.

Figures from rate-tracking service Moneyfacts show how miserly are returns on the average instant access account: £5,000 earns just 1.4 per cent. And bank profit margins on savings seem to be widening: when the base rate was last at its current level, in February 2000, the average instant access rate was 1.54 per cent.

Card checks

You can help stem the rising tide of credit card fraud by following a few simple guidelines, says the Association for Payment Clearing Services. Tips include: regularly check you still have your cards; keep your receipts and match them against your statement; and report suspicious transactions. Fraud on debit and credit cards cost the UK banking and retail industries £292.6m in 2000, up 55 per cent on 1999.

webTitle: Bonuses not as equitable as they seem

fields.headline: Bonuses not as equitable as they seem
fields.trailText: At first glance Equitable Life's bonus payment for last year, at 8 per cent for with-profits pensions, seems surprisingly good news for a life office in such dire straits.
fields.body:
At first glance Equitable Life's bonus payment for last year, at 8 per cent for with-profits pensions, seems surprisingly good news for a life office in such dire straits. But, as has happened all too often in the sorry saga of Equitable Life, things are not quite so simple.

Returns will be docked by last year's decision to suspend bonus payouts for seven months in the wake of the House of Lords ruling against Equitable. The ruling meant it had to honour guarantees to guaranteed annuity rate (GAR) policyholders and bonus payouts were stopped in order to balance the books.

The new bonuses, 4 per cent less than last year, are also not guaranteed.

'By comparison with other companies this is not a bad return for 2000,' says independent Edinburgh-based actuary Ronnie Sloan. Returns were actually less than 8 per cent but topped up - normal practice for life companies - to discourage policyholders from leaving.

However, after the seven- month loss of bonuses, Equitable says with-profits pensions funds in force for the whole of last year would have their returns slashed to just 3.3 per cent. The return for life policies, including endowment mortgages and with-profit bonds, is reduced from 6.75 to 2.8 per cent.

Not even these returns are secure. They are being paid as a 'terminal' bonus, giving the insurer discretion to remove the bonus later. Normally a chunk of annual bonuses would be paid in guaranteed form. However, the life office may declare a guaranteed bonus, provided policyholders agree to cap amounts potentially owed to policyholders with GAR pensions. Part of Halifax's bid for Equitable is conditional on the cap being set.

Is a bonus that might never be paid reason enough to stay with the life office, especially given that it does not have much in the way of spare capital to offer bonuses in future?

'The cupboard is bare,' says Sloan, but adds that it's worth waiting to see if a deal is struck with GAR policyholders enabling the 10 per cent exit penalty to be reduced before jumping ship.

Is a bonus that might never be paid reason enough to stay with the life office, especially given that it does not have much in the way of spare capital to offer bonuses in future? 'The cupboard is bare,' says Sloan, but adds that it's worth waiting to see if a deal is struck with GAR policyholders enabling the 10 per cent exit penalty to be reduced before jumping ship.

webTitle: Abbey joins loans war

fields.headline: Abbey joins loans war
fields.trailText: Abbey National and Cheltenham & Gloucester have become the latest lenders to take up arms in the mortgage war by offering existing customers big cuts to their interest rates.
fields.body:
Abbey National and Cheltenham & Gloucester have become the latest lenders to take up arms in the mortgage war by offering existing customers big cuts to their interest rates.

Attention will now focus on the NatWest/Royal Bank of Scotland group to see if it follows suit. It has not finalised plans to make an announcement yet.

Abbey is ditching its standard variable rate (SVR) of 7.49 per cent in favour of two new deals. The first is a tracker mortgage at 6.65 per cent and the second a flexible mortgage that charges 6.75 per cent.

The 700,000 Abbey's mortgage holders on the 7.49 rate will have to apply for the new deals from the end of April.

C&G will track the Bank of England base rate until June 2003, currently giving a payable rate of between 6.6 and 6.75 depending on how the interest is calculated. The SVR was previously 7.5 per cent. Existing borrowers not on a special deal will qualify. Those on the deals will see rates capped at 2 per cent above base rate.

Mark Harris of independent financial adviser Savills Private Finance says: 'This is similar to what the Halifax and Nationwide have done. It looks like the others didn't want to be left behind.'

Halifax and Nationwide slashed mortgage rates late last month in a bid to hang on to existing customers and grab more market share. The former cut its standard variable rate to 6.75 per cent while Nationwide pitched its rates at between 6.49 and 6.99 per cent, depending on the size of the deposit.

As far as borrowers are concerned, the cuts are good news for those stuck on a high variable rate, Harris says, but they can still find better deals by looking around - provided there is no exit penalty on their current homeloan.

webTitle: Property: How to be Mr Two Per Cent

fields.headline: How to be Mr Two Per Cent
fields.standfirst: Selling your own home can mean big savings, says  Graham Norwood
fields.trailText: Selling your own home can mean big savings, says Graham Norwood.
fields.body:
The profit made when selling a house does not stop people feeling irritated at the slice given to estate agents - especially in a hot market when houses sell without much apparent work.

If you are well-organised, have modest IT and presentational skills and can spare the time, you could avoid fees of up to 2 per cent on the sale price of your house by doing it yourself.

The Consumers' Association has a four-point guide to selling your own home.

1 Get an estate agent or sur veyor to value your home to ensure the price is fair

2 Advertise in the local or national papers read by your target audience, and include at least one photograph of the house.

3 Prepare a hard-copy brochure (or an online website) with at least the level of detail you would expect from an estate agent. Ensure the contents abide by the Property Misdescriptions Act, passed five years ago to curb the purple prose that surrounded - some say distorted - the facts.

4 Keep accurate records of those who visit and any offers made, so these can be passed on to a conveyancing solicitor as the sale progresses.

Rita Fleet from Morecambe in Lancashire is retiring from the bed and breakfast business this spring and is selling her guest house privately. She is advertising in newspapers and has an internet entry (www.internetonline.co.uk/office).

'We've advertised in the Dalton's Weekly and we've had numerous calls about it. We've prepared a sheet listing the details of the rooms, their measurements and condition. There are also photographs. People get what they would normally expect from an estate agent,' she says.

Her house is relatively low cost, £75,000, but she would face a possible £1,500 bill for estate agent's fees. 'It's really not a lot of work,' insists Fleet. 'But we're leaving all the legal matters in the hands of a solicitor. It's just the estate agent we're cutting out.'

If you are buying from a DIY seller, there is no major difference - except you may get a more detailed description of the house and a more personal service if you view.

Lenders say buying from a DIY seller makes no real difference, so long as basic checks are carried out. 'We've had a small number of customers who have successfully undertaken their own conveyancing,' says Stephen Penlington of the Norwich and Peterborough building society.

'However we'd advise people who may be considering doing their own conveyancing to think about it very carefully and to get as much information and advice as possible before taking the plunge,' he says.

So far DIY sales, perhaps surprisingly, have worked better through newspapers than on the internet. The well-publicised Easier website was set up a year ago for sellers wishing to avoid estate agency fees - but business was poorer than expected and revenue from the sale of associated financial services was low. The service has been put up for sale but a buyer has not been found.

David Bates has had his bungalow at Aberystwyth on sale for £265,000 since September last year, publicised solely through his own website (www.yourpad.org.uk).

'I've had several inquiries by telephone and some emails but no one so far has visited the house. I'm not in a rush to move so it's not a problem, but I think people are still a little shy of the internet. They haven't got the confidence in it yet to think of buying a house after seeing it on the site,' says Bates.

However, DIY sales overall are increasing. More than 5,000 homes were sold this way in 2000, with many more expected this year. The ultimate DIY enthusiast could move on to do his or her own legal conveyancing but that is considered much harder and has many more pitfalls. Some believe it consists only of undertaking local planning department 'searches' to investigate the prospect of new roads or houses being built nearby - but that is only a minor part of conveyancing work.

The Consumers' Association lists seven legal documents that have to be completed after searches are done, and any dispute over boundaries, parking or rights of way will make the legal process much longer and more fraught. Unsurprisingly, estate agents are unimpressed with individual attempts to sell houses privately.

'A good estate agent brings negotiating skills into the equation,' says Hugh Dunsmore-Hardy of the National Association of Estate Agents.

'With the greatest of respect, private sellers are not negotiators and even the saving on an estate agent's commission may not outweigh what a trained negotiator might be able to achieve in terms of a sale price,' he insists. 'And there is security. Free house sales on the internet or through advertising in newspapers sound a good idea, but an estate agent can validate the calibre of prospective buyers and can ensure that those who visit are serious customers. Private sellers cannot always tell over a telephone or via the internet.'

 'Which? Way to Buy, Sell and Move House', by the Consumers' Association, Penguin, £10.99
