webTitle: Property: Conversions

fields.headline: High ceilings, no draughts
fields.standfirst: It used to be barns. Now churches and schools are being turned into homes, says  Graham Norwood
fields.trailText: It used to be barns. Now churches and schools are being turned into homes, says Graham Norwood.
fields.body:
Old house or new? The debate is centuries-old but now the best of both are in one property - a conversion.

This trend is not exactly cutting edge. Some farm buildings were converted in the 19th century, and lofts in warehouses were on sale in the 1960s. But developers are now worried that the rural conversion gravy train may be heading for the buffers, leaving only the cities open to the inevitable development of duplexes and penthouses in what were once industrial buildings.

In some estate agents' offices near the Thames more than 50 per cent of properties for sale are warehouse and riverside conversions.

'It's obvious to me why they are popular. People get plenty of character, plus high ceilings and a feeling that their home is a better, stronger structure,' says David Galman, of Galliard Homes, which has converted warehouses along much of the Thames riverside in central London.

'The sorts of buildings used tend to have central locations and in the big conversions there may be dozens of types of properties - different sized flats, different views, but all in the same place, so offering buyers a great deal of choice,' he says.

Galliard is to unveil shortly the last wharf in the central London riverside area to be turned into luxury apartments, marking the end of a conversion era. Many see such conversions as desirable ways of preserving old buildings that the community no longer needs. Stuart Sapcote's company has converted 350,000 sq ft of school buildings into apartments in London and the South-East, preserving their exteriors but transforming them inside.

Likewise, the Church of England has said it may sell up to 50 per cent of its churches because of changing demographic and church-going trends, offering more opportunities to developers, who have already converted 10,000 redundant clerical buildings throughout Britain. More than 200 former hospitals have been similarly refurbished as flats and houses and have become part of the private housing market.

But conversions are not always good news. One of the earliest conversion fads was to turn barns into homes, but in the past 25 years farmland has declined in value, though farm buildings transformed to residential use have increased in price.

In some places, farmers have sold their farmhouses but kept the land. Living elsewhere, they farm the fields surrounding what has become someone else's home. A former cowshed on a farm at Englefield Green, near Windsor, which has been turned into a house, now fetches a cool £2,000 a month rent (Hamptons International, 01753 867800).

'There aren't a great many rural conversions now,' admits Jan Mazierski, managing director of the County Heritage development com pany, which converts oast houses, barns and mills in the South East.

'The scarcity of properties which would make single homes means they are fought for by do-it-yourself builders as well as developers, and often the asking price means they are no longer economic to turn into a house for sale.

'That's less often the case with larger properties to be turned into multiple homes, but even so there are far fewer of them around these days,' he says.

So where does the conversion bandwagon head next, now the rural market has gone? To the cities. 'We'll see increasing numbers of schools, and almost any other building being made available to the residential market,' predicts Stuart Sapcote.

'In London, turning offices into homes has been the big conversion fashion of the past five years but, apart from Manchester, it hasn't happened much elsewhere,' says Galman. 'What about town halls? As local councils find themselves short of money and turning into smaller organisations, so these will come up for sale.'

Conversions already on the market include:

 Water tower in Boston, Lincolnshire: Already converted to offices but now for sale and ripe for residential use, £450,000, Brown and Co, 01205 311622

 Rope factory in Burford, Oxfordshire: Already converted to a three-bedroom house with a spiral staircase, £575,000, FPDSavills, 01865 269000

 Rectory at Boyton, Wiltshire: A classic Victorian five-bedroom rectory built in 1872 with two acres of grounds, £875,000, Strutt and Parker, 01722 328741

 Former flats in Clerkenwell, east London: The conversion bandwagon has changed these flats to live/work units, £270,000 and above, Galliard, 020 7620 1500

 The Old Lord Nelson pub in west London: Built around 1850, it is now a four-bedroom terraced house, £625,000, Leslie Marsh and Co, 020 7603 5181

 Oast House near Edenbridge, Kent: Now a four-bedroom house with three separate flights of stairs, £485,000, Cluttons, 01892 616666

 Snooker hall in Wimbledon: Is now a set of apartments, priced from £280,000 to £475,000, Knight Frank 020 7938 4311 and Chesterton 020 7235 8090

 Uruguayan Embassy in Kensington: A house originally but it has been in diplomatic use for nearly 50 years, £17 million, Knight Frank and Chesterton.

 County Heritage 01622 817999. Sapcote 020 7937 3878.

webTitle: On the market

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: ABN Amro UK Select Opportunities Fund
fields.trailText: ABN Amro UK Select Opportunities Fund.
fields.body:
Contact 0800 0922 090 or www.abnamrofunds.co.uk

Aim To produce capital growth through UK equities, concentrating on small and medium-sized companies.

Bells & whistles The fund will be managed by Nigel Thomas, who until recently ran the top-performing Solus UK Special Situations Fund, ranked first out of all funds domiciled in the UK over five years, third over three years and ninth over one year. ABN Amro describes him as 'one of the UK's most experienced and widely acclaimed stock-pickers _ Nigel Thomas's proven track record has shown that he is capable of achieving higher-than-average returns, consistently, over a long period'.

How it works While reserving the right to invest in any size of company to achieve diversification, Thomas will focus on small and mid-cap companies. He intends to exploit the 'inefficiencies in the market', by hunting out companies that have been undervalued or underestimated by other investors or that present an opportunity of strong growth - possibly because of a change in management, new products, technological change or an anomaly particular to the company or industry. The portfolio will hold about 50 stocks, including technology companies and those offering takeover opportunities and new issues. These will all increase the portfolio's volatility, making the fund suitable for 'the more adventurous investor', according to ABN Amro.

Minimum Lump sum £1,000, monthly £50.

Charges Initial 5 per cent (for investments via IFAs, 1 per cent discount until end of April for direct and Isa investments, 1.5 per cent for Pep transfers),1.5 per cent annual.

Tax Available tax-free as maxi and mini Isa, and Pep transfer.

Risk High.

Should you invest? John Hutton-Attenborough of adviser Berry Birch & Noble is enthusiastic. He says Thomas's track record will be a great plus point, and the fact that he is setting up a new fund will mean his portfolio will be free of the underperforming equities that most funds collect over time. 'With the market as low as it is, it seems an ideal time to set up this type of fund. It certainly interests me,' he says.

Amanda Davidson of London firm Holden Meehan says: 'It's going to be aggressive and concentrated, an opportunistic fund so not a core holding, but it should add spice to the UK part of an investor's portfolio.'

Points out of 10 Hutton-Attenborough - 8, Davidson - 7.

webTitle: Which is the best current account?

fields.headline: Which is the best current account?
fields.trailText: Which is the best current account?
fields.body:
Three of the 'Big Four' banks represent a poor choice for current accounts, according to a survey in the latest edition of Which? magazine. Satisfaction with Barclays, Lloyds TSB and NatWest is lower than with any other bank in the survey, and all three offer measly rates of interest when your account is in credit (only 0.1 per cent on a balance of £1,000).

To add insult to injury, Barclays and Lloyds TSB are among the most costly for overdrafts, charging£100 a year for an authorised£500.

But where can you find a better current account? Which? has just published a list of current account best buys. Those who are always in credit should look for a reasonable rate of interest. Which? recommends the First Direct bank account, with 2 per cent interest, or the Nationwide FlexAccount with 1.2 per cent.

If you occasionally go into the red by up to £100, there are 11 accounts to choose from in the Which? table, including the Alliance & Leicester premier and current accounts and the HSBC bank and premier accounts. They all charge a maximum of£1 a year for an authorised overdraft of £100 one week a quarter. However, if you regularly go overdrawn, you may be better off with the Abbey National or Nationwide, which charge £22 a year for an authorised overdraft of £500 for two weeks a month.

Other accounts can charge up to £300 for a similar service. But if you go into the red without permission you really get stung, typically 30 per cent of the amount overdrawn, more in the case of NatWest and Royal Bank of Scotland.

If you are prepared to choose a bank without a satisfaction rating, Cahoot pays a generous 6.5 per cent on all credit balances if you do not want a chequebook (5 per cent if you do), Intelligent Finance offers 5 per cent and Smile 4.85 per cent. All three also get a pat on the back for the 'excellent value' of their overdraft facilities.

 Which? magazine is available only by subscription. Ring 0800 252 100. Details of current accounts can also be found in Moneyfacts and in the Observer's best buy tables.

webTitle: Budget 2001: Downshifters

fields.headline: Real life: Dedicated savers shift down to qualify
fields.trailText: Leslie and Susan Arscott's lifestyle has changed radically in the last two years, but more thanks to their own planning than any action by the Government.
fields.body:
Leslie and Susan Arscott's lifestyle has changed radically in the last two years, but more thanks to their own planning than any action by the Government.

The Arscotts are both teachers who have 'downshifted'. Two years ago they moved from Reading, where they lived in a four-bedroom detached house and earned a total of about £57,000 a year. They now live in Exmouth, Devon, in a mortgage-free bungalow, earning a total of about £15,000 between them for working part-time.

In Reading the couple were dedicated savers and paid off their mortgage early. They contributed to additional voluntary contribution pension schemes, Peps and Tessas. Now they have no spare cash to set aside, and in any case Leslie thinks pension investment has become less attractive following the removal of tax credits on the dividends earned by pension funds - a measure introduced by Labour in 1997.

The decision to downshift was spurred by the illness of Susan's late mother, who died of Parkinson's disease last year. 'She had to be cared for in a nursing home for seven or eight years. We saw all Susan's parents' savings go in fees, and when her father died in 1995 the house was sold. That money went in fees too,' says Leslie.

'We thought, "Hang on - if something happens to us, what's the point of having all our money invested?" It made us think seriously about the quality of our life.'

The Government has not yet proposed anything on long-term care that changes the Arscotts' minds. Leslie understands that the enormous costs of nursing home care make it impossible for the Government to sign a blank cheque when it comes to pay the fees of the elderly and disabled. But he is disappointed that nothing has been done to control the fees levied by the nursing home chains, many of which are owned and run by foreign companies. He would like to see measures introduced that entitle people in long-term care to retain a bigger proportion of their savings.

Although their council tax bills increased from about £850 in 1997 to £1,100 in 1999, the Arscotts cut back on all other areas of spending in anticipation of their downshift. They have no children, neither smokes, and they don't drink very much. But as a supply teacher, Leslie drives about 10,000 miles a year to get to different schools in the area. He says: 'It costs more each time I go to the garage. It was £15 to £20 to fill up the car in 1997. Now it's more like £30.'

He thinks his petrol bill will fall by about £1 a week as a result of the 2p per litre cut in petrol tax, and the couple will be about 60p a week better off because of the extension to the 10 per cent income tax band. Otherwise, last week's measures will have little affect on the Arscotts.

Leslie's main reaction to the Budget is relief that money for schools is being given directly to them: 'That means it will be spent where the schools really need it.'

webTitle: Teachers' pension fear

fields.headline: Teachers' pension fear
fields.standfirst: Big public sector retirement scheme is behind the times, writes  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Big public sector retirement scheme is behind the times, writes Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
Teachers are asking for substantial improvements to their pension scheme, which is seen as having fallen behind the times. The scheme is particularly hard hit because many of its members have retired and are now drawing their pensions.

Representatives are this month asking for it to be improved from a 1/80th scheme (giving 1/80th of a teacher's final salary as pension for each year paying into the scheme) to a 1/60th scheme. In a submission to the Department for Education and Employment(DfEE), the teachers' side of the teachers' superannuation working party is also calling for pensions to be paid to all surviving partners - including gay partners and cohabitees as well as spouses - and for partners' pensions to be paid for life, rather than being stopped if the survivor remarries or lives with someone else. Negotiations about the terms are likely to start in April.

'The teachers' pension scheme isn't a particularly wonderful scheme, although it does provide inflation-proofing,' says actuary Bryn Davies of Union Pension Services. The scheme came 143rd out of 275 schemes when ranked in terms of value of benefits by Bryn Davies in his latest comparison of major schemes, Pension Scheme Profiles 2000.

The National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers (NASUWT) is expected to ask for a range of changes, including a move away from the current unfunded basis to a funded arrangement. At the moment, the scheme collects contributions from both teachers and their employers (usually local authorities), but rather than going into a pension fund, the money goes into Treasury coffers. When teachers retire, their pension is paid by the Treasury again. This means that there is no actual fund.

NASUWT pensions officer Brian Clegg is worried that future politicians could try to water down benefits or get teachers to pay in more. 'The campaign has got to be for a real fund,' he says. 'The long-term liabilities of the scheme are just unaffordable, and the problem just comes back to being reliant on the Treasury.'

Data on the scheme is always out of date. The latest valuation from the Government Actuary's Department relates to 1996, but has yet to be published by Her Majesty's Stationery Office. But the valuation report, which has been seen by The Observer , reveals that there were nearly 560,000 teachers paying in at that time. There were nearly 365,000 teachers and their widows and widowers drawing pensions. As the actuary states in the report that in the five years that the report covers, 'expenditure on benefits exceeded the contribution income'.

A scheme in this situation is described as 'mature' when the number of pensioners is very high compared with the number of 'active' contributing members. This means that the scheme is costly. Clegg is therefore worried that politicians could be tempted to tinker.

As Davies says: 'For years and years, the government has had pensions on the cheap.' Even 20 years ago, the Government would have been receiving far more in contributions than the Treasury had to pay out. But now the past is catching up very fast. The proportion of pensioners compared with active members was 65 per cent in 1996, up from 53 per cent in 1991.

The government actuary has also predicted a deficit on the scheme of £4 billion when future liabilities are taken into account. As a result, the employers' contri bution is due to increase from 7.2 per cent of each teacher's salary now to 8.15 per cent from April 2002. In theory, the £4bn shortfall would be made up by these extra contributions over the next 40 years.

Part of the reason for the shortfall is an accounting practice which has notionally invested the contributions received into fixed- interest stocks. But returns would have been far higher if the notional investment had been the stock market. Most funded pension schemes invest well over 60 per cent of their assets in equities, in the expectation of rates of return far higher than on fixed-interest stocks. The Government has now conceded the point and is starting to operate the scheme's notional accounts as if the investments were largely in equities.

Barry Fawcett will be one of the main negotiators with the DfEE in April. As head of pay and pensions at the NUT, he takes some heart from improvements that are being made to the civil service pension scheme. This scheme is soon to pay pension benefits to gay and cohabiting partners, for instance. Fawcett says: 'Many key improvements are being introduced to the civil service scheme and there is no reason why teachers should not be granted the same terms as other public service employees.'

The teachers' scheme was established in 1925 and had its last major overhaul in 1972. From a financial viewpoint, the 1/80th basis is something of a legacy of the past. Most schemes which are seen as attractive these days offer a 1/60th arrangement.

webTitle: Wealthcheck: A brighter future - on equal terms

fields.headline: A brighter future - on equal terms
fields.standfirst: Julie  wants to sort her finances and save for her children's education, she tells  Margaret Dibben
fields.trailText: Julie wants to sort her finances and save for her children's education, she tells Margaret Dibben.
fields.body:
Julie Weir

Age 38

Lives in Harlington, Bedfordshire

Occupation Adoption social worker

Earns £25,500

Mortgage £75,000

Debts Car loan and loan from sister

Investments Endowment

Pensions Local authority scheme

Aims To save for children and retirement

Julie Weir's daughter has just started school. This saves her £250 a month in childcare costs and has made a big difference to her monthly cashflow: 'Now I have a little extra each month for the first time in my adult life.'

As her budget has become easier, Julie wants to sort out the rest of her finances as well: 'I am not financially minded but I want to make the most of the little money I do have. I'd like to invest wisely for my future and for that of my children.'

Julie is single and has two children; Hope, five, and Ben, 19, who is still living at home although he is financially independent.

She says: 'I have not been able to save for my son in the past but I would like to treat Ben and Hope equally. I would also like to save for my daughter's further education. Her dad is keen to consider this also.'

She receives maintenance payments from Hope's father and wonders whether they should save jointly for her university costs.

Julie realises that she should have more saved up for emergency use and is confused about whether she should try to reduce her mortgage to save interest payments or buy an Isa. Perhaps optimistically, she says: 'The thought of making some money quickly appeals and I feel happy to take a higher-risk investment with some money each month.'

Her only savings are £500 in her current account. She has paid off her overdraft and credit card debt but owes her sister money, for which she puts aside £350 a month. She has a car loan through work, with repayments deducted from her salary, which will be paid off in July.

She bought her house nearly eight years ago for £55,000 and extended it three years ago. Last year she remortgaged for £75,000 and discovered that it was worth £150,000.

Originally, Julie had an endowment mortgage for £52,000 with Standard Life. This matures in 17 years' time but Julie does not know if it will reach its target, which is why she switched to a repayment loan.

She says: 'I thought I would keep any extra I had left over when the endowment matures but I don't know if I would be taxed on this if it wasn't used for the house.'

Although she is in a good local authority pension scheme, she started contributing only eight years ago. She would like to retire comfortably at 55 but is not sure how to achieve this: 'I have heard of Additional Voluntary Contributions but also heard that, if I died, the money would not be useful to those I have left behind.'

She would also like to make a will: 'But I am not sure what I would leave to whom, and feel I ought to sort out my finances first.'

Adviser 1: Anna Bowes

Julie's pension is secure but, to retire at 55, she needs to save as much as possible, preferably through the in-house AVC. The Standard Life endowment will provide a lump sum when she retires, which can be used to boost her income.

She needs a higher emergency reserve. In the short term, she can save in an easy access savings account. Currently the best rate is 6.9 per cent from Bristol & West's internet account. She could consider a mini cash Isa, such as 7.05 per cent with Northern Rock.

She can reduce her mortgage rate by switching to a lender such as the Halifax, which is offering 5.35 per cent

If she is prepared to take some risk, she should buy a stocks and shares Isa, but hold it for at least five years. These range from the lower risk corporate bond Isas, such as M&G High Yield Corporate Bond fund, to higher-risk funds such as Framlington Health. She could consider a UK fund, possibly ABN Amro UK Growth fund, or a global investment such as the Fidelity International fund.

These investments should provide healthy returns in the medium to long term. She should keep her investments for her daughter separate from those of Hope's father.

She should have life insurance to provide for Hope. She may find that her employer provides an early retirement package through ill health and a death benefit.

Anna Bowes works for Bath-based Chase de Vere.

Adviser 2: Joanne Cox

First, Julie should ask Hope's father if he has arranged for money to be available if he dies. If not, she can insure his life to replace the maintenance payments. She should also ensure that Hope's father could manage if she died.

She should ask her employer for a pension forecast at 60 and 55. If it is not enough, she can buy added years or make Additional Voluntary Contributions. Most pensions return the fund or contributions to your estate if you die before retiring.

Julie should also check that her mortgage is still competitive. The returns on her endowment are still free of tax provided she pays premiums for at least three-quarters of the term.

She needs an instant access deposit for emergencies, the equivalent of three months' income or £5,000.

If Julie wants to give Ben some money within five years, she should use a cash Isa. She could add the money saved once the loan to her sister is repaid. For Hope she needs long-term saving such as a mini equities Isa, provided she is happy for the fund to fluctuate in value.

She should save as much as she can afford for the children. Julie is wrong to think you can make money quickly by taking risk. High risk means there is a high risk of losing your money.

Joanne Cox works for Co-operative Bank Financial Advisers.

You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

webTitle: Watch out for: Celltech

fields.headline: Watch out for:
fields.standfirst: Celltech
fields.trailText: Despite being one of Europe's few profitable biotechnology companies, Celltech Group may have trouble exciting the market when it issues full-year results on Wednesday.
fields.body:
Despite being one of Europe's few profitable biotechnology companies, Celltech Group may have trouble exciting the market when it issues full-year results on Wednesday. After its blockbuster arthritis drug deal with Pharmacia Corp last week, further fireworks are unlikely, say analysts. Profit before goodwill is expected to be around £24.5 million, bolstered by strong cashflow from the Medeva pharmaceuticals business, acquired in 1999.

Results will be helped by income from leukaemia drug Mylotarg, Celltech's first antibody product. Launched in the US by American Home Products last May, it has been generating sales of more than $3 million a month.

But a solid set of results may not generate much more demand for a stock that has already satisfied the bulls with Europe's biggest biotechnology product deal. 'We expect little more in terms of newsflow or launches,' Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein said in a note.

Celltech surged from a mid-January low of 1010p in anticipation of the co-development/ promotion deal on arthritis drug CDP870, worth $280 million plus a share of sales.

webTitle: Soros: tax my speculation profits

fields.headline: Soros: tax my speculation profits
fields.trailText: In a surprise move George Soros, the international financier and philanthropist, has lent his voice to calls for a a levy on international currency speculation.
fields.body:
Turkeys voting for Christmas hardly compare. In a surprise move George Soros, the international financier and philanthropist, has lent his voice to calls for a 'Tobin tax' - a levy on international currency speculation which would be used to fund education, environmental protection and medicines.

'I'm in favour of the Tobin tax. It doesn't happen to coincide with my personal inter est, but it could be a very good source of funds for providing global [public] goods,' he said.

The endorsement could not have come from a more unlikely source. Soros's Quantum Fund is believed to have made around £1 billion during the ERM crisis in 1995.

Feelings are still running high in East Asia, where he is seen as the cause of the region's 1997-98 financial crisis. He recently abandoned a trip to Thailand after threats from local activists. The Malaysian Prime minister recently denounced a dotcom entrepreneur who accepted investment from one of his funds as a 'traitor'.

But Soros, whose funds suffered from the technology stocks collapse, has found common cause with anti-globalisation campaigners.

The campaign for the tax is gaining ground among groups such as War on Want. Campaigners see it as the next international rallying call after the moderate success of lobbying for debt relief. The United Nations is currently conducting a feasibility study for the levy. War on Want is lobbying for a tax of between a tenth and a quarter of a per cent on $2 trillion of daily financial flows.

'There's a valid argument for it, despite some problems with options,' Soros said.

In the UK to promote his new book Open Society , he said that the intellectual property rights system for medicines was 'anti-competitive'. He also saw merit in a tax on international airline tickets to fund development.

However, Soros will not be manning the barricades outside meetings of the International Monetary Fund just yet: 'I'm not an unequivocal advocate of the Tobin tax. If the government eliminated speculative activities, it would reduce the depth of the market. The [benefit] depends on what it's used for.'

The tax was first proposed by Nobel prize-winning US economist James Tobin in 1978 as a way of 'throwing sand in the wheels' of the financial system.

webTitle: Rival bid means Groucho not likely to Fry tonight

fields.headline: Rival bid means Groucho not likely to Fry tonight
fields.trailText: Benjamin Fry's hopes of bagging the Groucho Club now look as washed out as some of its members after a particularly good night at its premises in London's Soho.
fields.body:
Upstart entrepreneur Benjamin Fry's hopes of bagging the Groucho Club now look as washed out as some of its members after a particularly good night at its premises in London's Soho.

The bo-ho watering hole's management team, which owns 40 per cent of the company's shares, is united in its desire to sell the club to a rival bidder in a move which would net the nine-strong board a £5 million windfall.

Restaurant entrepreneur Joel Cadbury is looking to offer Groucho's 350 share holders an all-cash deal.

The move would value the Groucho Club, and its half share of Groucho St Judes in Glasgow, at 266.75p per ordinary share, giving the company a market capitalisation of nearly £12m.

The offer, subject to due diligence, values the Groucho, whose members include Lord Bragg and film actor Steve Martin, at an 85 per cent premium to its current market capitalisation.

The club's management, which has been in negotiations with Cadbury's company, Newco, for several months, has written to shareholders urging them not to accept Fry's tentative offer of two shares in his company, Zoo hotels, for each Groucho share. Fry's deal would value the club at £9m.

'We've had a number of discussions over the past six to eight months and the Newco bid is the preferred proposal,' said Anthony Mackintosh, the club's chairman.

Mackintosh said he would have preferred to keep the Newco offer under wraps for several more weeks, but had felt compelled to tell shareholders of the plans as soon as Fry had pounced.

Fry, 31, founder of the K-Bar, the Ofex-listed nightclub chain from which he resigned two years ago, tried to bag the Groucho last year.

This time around Fry boasts 'It' girl Tara Palmer-Tomkinson as a consultant. The socialite's role would be to promote Zoo's hotels, which so far include The Westbourne and The Sydney in West London.

But not to be outdone, Newco, which will unveil detailed proposals to develop the club next month, boasts spin guru and Groucho Club member Matthew Freud as a non-executive director. The company also intends to install banker Rupert Hambro as chairman of the Groucho if the deal gains shareholder approval.

Groucho insiders suggest that other shareholders will also follow the board in rejecting Fry's offer.

The move has also provoked a fierce reaction from some of the club's 4,000 members. Another Fry, comedian Stephen, is one of several famous names known to be concerned about the bid.

webTitle: Maggie Hyde's company futures

fields.headline: Maggie Hyde's company futures
fields.trailText: Iceland, the frozen food and retail distribution giant, has suffered an avalanche of financial chaos following its over-ambitious move to organics and the merger with Booker last August. Suspicion hangs over founder and former chairman Malcolm Walker, who offloaded shares worth £13.5 million shortly before their value halved. New CEO Bill Grimsey has a tough task.
fields.body:
Iceland, the frozen food and retail distribution giant, has suffered an avalanche of financial chaos following its over-ambitious move to organics and the merger with Booker last August. Suspicion hangs over founder and former chairman Malcolm Walker, who offloaded shares worth £13.5 million shortly before their value halved. New CEO Bill Grimsey has a tough task.

Iceland is an aggressive Aries and sees itself as the 'consumer's champion in the fight for better food', but its origins are in the fixed water sign (ice) of Scorpio, rising at its incorporation (4 April 1973) and dominant in the horoscope for the first shop (18 November 1970). It has a prominent Uranus which, like its Aquarian founder Malcolm Walker (11 February 1946), suggests ideals of social responsibility coupled with slick, hi-tech marketing. Iceland's current problems are shown by downbeat Saturn. The Booker deal has been a dead weight and more disappointment is likely as Iceland heads towards its 29-year Saturn cycle in May 2002. Its whole strategy involving Booker could start to come undone this August: part of the combined business may have to be ditched, and the Malcolm Walker saga could rumble on.

However, Grimsey, another Aquarian (21 January 1952), has come at the right time. With the sound judgment and management skill of his own well-placed Saturn, he's a good choice - but we won't know whether he has pulled Iceland out of the deep freeze until well into 2002.

webTitle: Isa special: Paying off mortgages

fields.headline: Home and dry on your mortgage
fields.standfirst: Isas can be efficient at paying off home loans, says Christine Stopp
fields.trailText: Isas can be efficient at paying off home loans, says Christine Stopp.
fields.body:
With endowments falling out of favour, some mortgage borrowers are using individual savings accounts to pay off their interest-only mortgages.

About 20 per cent of borrowers opt for interest-only mortgages, where you make interest payments every month leaving the capital untouched. To repay the loan, most people take out a regular savings plan designed top produce a lump sum to repay the capital at the end of the term.

Isa mortgages offer a number of advantages over with-profits endowments:

 Funds with very low - and transparent - charges are available.

 There is a wide choice of investments, and what the fund invests in is clearer than with an endowment.

 Valuations do not depend on bonuses laid down by the insurance company.

 Contributions can be varied if you increase or pay off some of your mortgage.

 There is no fixed investment term, so if the fund does well, you may be able to repay your mortgage early, make withdrawals for other uses, or build up a lump sum.

The obvious drawback with an Isa mortgage, as with an endowment, is the lack of a guarantee that the fund will repay your mortgage. 'The key thing with an interest-only mortgage is the risk you are willing to take on,' says Johannes Kennard, of mortgage broker London & Country. 'It is important that the vehicle you choose meets your level of risk.'

With an Isa plan, monitoring the investment is up to the borrower. One or two providers have sought to overcome this problem by providing an Isa mortgage package. Legal & General's Flexible Mortgage Isa offers a UK Index Tracking Isa fund with regular performance reviews, plus various insurance options.

However, this is not necessarily the cheapest option. Monthly contributions for a £100,000 25-year mortgage for a couple aged 35 would be £157.80 using the Legal & General Isa with term insurance cover, or £176.44 including critical illness cover. This is in addition to the mortgage loan repayments of around £624 a month at Abbey National's standard variable rate - giving a total monthly outlay of £781.80 (or £800.44 with critical illness cover).

Abbey National recommends Isa contributions of £166 a month to cover the mortgage, giving a total of £790 a month without insurance cover. A £100,000 repayment mortgage, where you pay interest plus part of the outstanding loan each month, would cost about £747 a month (without insurance).

Computer contractor Oliver Hall, 29, is based in London but hopes to return to his native Liverpool, where he is buying a flat in a converted block in the old cotton trading area of the city. He chose an Isa mortgage using Fidelity's Managed International fund as he believes he will build up savings while repaying his mortgage. He hopes to pay off the loan early from other resources, leaving the Isa as a bonus savings fund.

As he is not relying on the Isa fund for repayment, Hall chose a relatively high-risk international Isa at the suggestion of broker John Charcol.

Interest-only mortgages were invented when there was tax relief to be had on mortgage interest. With this benefit gone, most people prefer a risk-free repayment- only loan. Investors should consider an Isa mortgage only if they are happy to do their own performance reviews, or if, like Hall, they are not relying on the Isa to repay the loan.

webTitle: Isa special: Corporate bonds

fields.headline: Corporate bonds? As easy as ABC
fields.standfirst: David Hunt points the way on the popular income option
fields.trailText: David Hunt points the way on the popular income option.
fields.body:
Corporate bond Isas are a popular option for income investors. First there is the high level of income. Then there's the tax advantage over equity Isas - income from bonds is taxed as interest at 20 per cent which is reclaimable in full, whereas dividend income comes with only a 10 per cent reclaimable tax credit (nil from April 2004).

But there has always been a nagging doubt that investors are not totally sure what it is they are buying. Sold on the basis of providing a relatively high income while being 'less risky' than equities, the corporate bond market remains, for many, clouded in mystery.

And it is easy to get confused. Take the current situation, for example: Corporate bonds are effectively IOUs issued by companies. Companies are having a hard time of it, with profit warnings coming thick and fast and share values falling in the stock market.

So, presumably, corporate bonds are not such a good deal these days? Not so, say the experts. An economy in trouble means lower interest rates, which is good news for corporate bonds. With declining interest rates, people are keener to lock into a high fixed rate. Yields on bonds appear more attractive so prices go up.

And a stock market in trouble means investors are likely to switch out of equities into the safer haven of bonds, so again prices go up.

'We see a fairly positive outlook for the corporate bond sector,' says Roger Webb, fund manager at Morley Fund Management, the investment arm of Norwich Union. 'The backdrop is much riskier for equities than it is for bonds.'

The problem, as he concedes, is that there are bonds and bonds. At the top end, bonds issued by top notch companies are not much riskier than government securities.

At the other extreme, you can be buying the IOUs of companies which have already filed for bankruptcy.

Most corporate bonds are rated by either Standard & Poor's (S&P) or Moody's, on a scale from triple A, down to a C rating. The lower the rating, the more the company has to pay in interest to get people to accept their IOUs.

Everything above a triple B rating on the S&P scale is called 'investment grade' and anything below this grade, where the risk of default is higher, is called 'high yield'.

Almost 100 bond funds are available, ranging from the ultra safe, offering yields of around 5 per cent, through to the higher-risk end, where you can earn 8 to 9 per cent or more.

'Corporate bond funds are a good home for those looking for income,' says Colin Jackson of Baronworth Investment Services. 'But investors must know what they are buying. Too many people just look at the headline rate. They seem to think the rate is guaranteed and their money is safe; it isn't.'

The experts disagree about where the best bargains are to be found at present. Paul Reed, head of fixed interest at Aberdeen Unit Trust Managers, reckons that there isn't anything very exciting about ?bonds linked closely to government gilts. 'But if you go for slightly higher yields, the returns more than take care of the possible risks.'

Webb is more positive about the top-graded corporate bonds. 'The high-yield market looks expensive,' he says. He likes the telecoms sectors, 'where the market has already priced in most of the bad news'.

So what funds do independent advisers like? Tim Cockerill of IFAs Chartwell likes the Norwich Union, going for the company's Corporate Bond Fund, yielding around 5.9 per cent, and the NU Higher Income Plus Fund yielding around 7.7 per cent as his low- and high-risk options.

Alan Durrant of Hargreaves Lansdown selects the Schroder High Yield Bond Fund, yielding around 5.9 per cent as his more conservative choice, with the Royal Sun Alliance Extra Income Bond Fund, yielding more than 8 per cent as his high-return option.

webTitle: Isa special: Ethical investment

fields.headline: Funds that don't cost the earth
fields.standfirst: Ethical returns are only slightly smaller, says Andrew Bibby
fields.trailText: Ethical returns are only slightly smaller, says Andrew Bibby.
fields.body:
Save tax and save the world.

Well, perhaps not quite, but Isa-hunters can now choose products which claim to bring good returns and to be socially responsible as well.

Ethical investment has come on a long journey in Britain since 1984 when Friends Provident unveiled its pioneering Stewardship fund on a highly sceptical City and proved that there was a market for people who wanted to know where their money would be invested.

Most major investment houses, and some smaller firms, now have their own ethical funds and there are independent financial advisers specialising in ethical investments.

Although opting for an ethical product remains a minority pursuit, and the range of ethical Isas on offer make up only a tiny fraction of the overall Isa choice, this may be changing. Last month came news of the soon-to-be-launched FTSE4 Good UK, an index that will list only companies that meet defined social, environmental and human rights practices.

According to the FTSE, less than half of listed companies are expected to meet the standards when the criteria are announced in May.

The introduction of a socially responsible index will allow for the creation of new, ethical, index-tracking funds.

Until then, would-be ethical Isa investors are likely to be looking at one of the managed general ethical funds. 'Jupiter Ecology is one of our favourites,' says Amanda Davidson of financial adviser Holden Meehan. She also recommends Norwich Union's UK Ethical fund, now absorbed into the CGNU merged group.

The giant of the sector remains Friends Provident's Stewardship fund. 'This has been volatile at times, with periods of underperformance as well as high performance,' Davidson says.

Dedicated ethical investors will be only partly swayed by talk of performance. Each fund has its own criteria, with some more strict - 'dark green' rather than 'light green' funds - than others.

As the Ethical Investment Research Service (Eiris) points out, there are two approaches to investing ethically: the passive approach of simply avoiding companies engaged in particular activities, and the pro-active - seeking out companies with a good track record. The range of ethical issues is wide. Eiris identifies more than 20 areas, including animal testing, environmental issues, employee rights, alcohol and tobacco, arms production or sale, and pornography.

Not every fund focuses on every issue: if drink is your concern, for instance, there is little point choosing a Jupiter Environmental Opportunities or a CIS Environmental Isa. According to research by Eiris, although ethical funds produce lower returns than others, the difference is marginal.

If you want an ethical cash Isa the Ecology Building Society, near Skipton in the Yorkshire Dales, combines enthusiasm for lending on environmentally sound properties with commitment to member democracy and mutuality. The Ecology cash Isa offers an interest rate equivalent to 5.7 per cent a year. The Ecology will check your green credentials before taking your money.

Contacts

Triodos Bank, a pioneer of social investment, offers a mini-Isa, paying 6 per cent pa (6.09 per cent EAR).

Eiris (0845 606 0324) produce a free list of ethical funds, and a list of ethical financial advisers.

Ecology Building Society (0845 674 5566).

Triodos Bank (0500 008720).

Holden Meehan (020 7692 1700) has a free booklet on ethical Isas and investments.

webTitle: Isa special: Fund managers

fields.headline: Changing faces, changing fortunes
fields.standfirst: Keep an eye on changes in funds and managers,  advises Tracey Boles
fields.trailText: Keep an eye on changes in funds and managers, advises Tracey Boles.
fields.body:
Investors in the top-performing Solus UK Special Situations fund are being advised by IFAs to follow its departing fund manager Nigel Thomas.

Thomas is employed by ABN Amro, but has been running the Solus fund on a contract, which has now ended. Thomas is launching a new special situations fund this week called the UK Select Opportunities fund.

At Solus he built up a fund of £47m, producing a return of 231 per cent over three years. Thomas intends to repeat the winning formula, choosing any company he likes from 'high risk, high reward' stocks. But you could be in for a rocky ride.

Ben Yearsley of independent financial adviser Hargreaves Lansdown says investors should follow Thomas. Mike Attree of Torquil Clark agrees: 'You should reconsider your position if you are in the Solus UK special situations fund. The new manager at Solus is not in the same league.'

Thomas was recently named Citywire.co.uk's top fund manager of unit trusts and investment funds investing in the UK stock market over the past three years. He also heads up the ABN Amro UK Growth unit trust.

A new phase

If the thought of a stock market crash puts you off taking out a stocks and shares Isa, you may like to take advantage of 'phasing'.

Phasing is when you put your cash in a stocks and shares Isa now to take advantage of the current tax year's Isa allowances (ending on 5 April). The money is then switched into stocks and shares when you feel more confident about the market.

Torquil Clark's fund supermarket, tqonline, allows customers to transfer up to a maximum of £1,000 a month from cash into stocks and shares. 'Phasing allows you to spread the risk of investing in the stock market over six months,' says Torquil Clark's Mike Attree. 'If the market crashes the day after you take out the Isa, you won't have lost a lot of money.'

Merging paths

If you are thinking of taking out an Isa with Invesco or Perpetual, you should be aware that the investment houses are merging and the manager of the fund you choose could change.

A new guide by the Financial Services Authority is designed to help you pick your way through the many different Isa offerings.

webTitle: Isa special: Toisas

fields.headline: Hunting out Tessa's many sisters
fields.standfirst: Some providers are denying investors their choice of a high-earning Toisa, writes Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Some providers are denying investors their choice of a high-earning Toisa, writes Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
The Halifax, the UK's biggest Tessa provider, is failing to inform its savers about their right to shop around for the best deals on Tessa-only Isas.

Tessas worth about £21 billion are due to mature this year, leaving savers with the happy decision of what to do next with their money.

Those who want to keep it on deposit can continue to earn tax-free interest by rolling the capital from their maturing Tessa into a Tessa-only Isa, or Toisa. The Toisa is much more flexible than the Tessa. You can transfer all the capital, up to £9,000 (but none of the interest earned), into a Toisa, and leave it there as long as you like. There are no penalties for withdrawing money (unless your Toisa has special notice terms or is due to run for a set term), although any amount you withdraw cannot be redeposited.

Most people seem to switch automatically to the Toisa offered by their Tessa provider, and critics say savers are not being informed about their right to go elsewhere. The Halifax, which claims to have the largest share of the Tessa market, says that 80 per cent of its savers are being retained and and are converting their maturing Tessas into a Halifax Toisa.

Head of savings Nigel Payne admits that letters being sent to Tessa savers do not mention the possibility of transferring the money elsewhere. He argues: 'Our research indicates most savers still find Isas confusing. So we wanted to keep the letter as simple as possible. If people want to know more they can phone our call centre.'

Ian Millward of independent financial adviser Chase de Vere says: 'Banks and building societies are desperate to retain as much Tessa money as possible, so it's not in their interests to be too forthcoming about savers' options.'

If your Tessa is coming up to maturity, there is no need to be rushed into a decision. You have six months to move into a Toisa. The disadvantage is that in the meantime tax will be deducted from your interest. You may also lose out if the rate of interest is lower. Alliance & Leicester, for example, transfers savings from matured Tessas into an instant access account, which pays just 1 per cent. Money that goes straight into its Toisa earns 6.15 per cent.

Before transferring to a Toisa, consider your future plans. If you intend to use the money within the next five years an ordinary bank or building society Toisa paying a variable rate of interest will give you most flexibility. The table above shows which organisations are currently offering the best Toisa rates. But check rates by looking in our Databank section on page 16. If you decide to open a Toisa with another organisation, you will need to ask your current Tessa provider for a maturity certificate.

The problem with variable-rate Toisas is that the interest rates on these accounts have just come down and may fall further. To protect yourself against future falls, you could choose a fixed-interest Toisa, but these are scarce. Julian Hodge Bank is currently the only organisation offering a full range of fixed-rate terms.

If you plan to leave your money invested for another five years, you may get a better return from a stock market-linked Toisa.

webTitle: Isa special: Equities Isas

fields.headline: Fortune may favour brave
fields.standfirst: Heather Connon offers advice on how to approach equities Isas
fields.trailText: Heather Connon offers advice on how to approach equities Isas.
fields.body:
The FTSE 100 index has fallen by more than 5 per cent so far this year and is now 15 per cent below its all-time high. The Techmark index of technology shares has fallen a painful 60 per cent from its peak; the US's Nasdaq is down by a similar amount. Experts say things could get worse before they get better. Why, then, should anyone consider investing in an equities Isa right now?

The short answer is that cautious investors probably should not - and the brave should be extremely selective about where they put their money.

'There are lots of lovely stocks which will eventually look very cheap,' says Justin Urquhart Stewart of Barclays Stockbrokers. 'But don't trust the market. We can see clear water ahead, perhaps in a year's time. And we can see where we are now. But in between, there is a big patch of fog.'

The big uncertainty is the US. Companies as diverse as Motorola and Procter & Gamble have been issuing profit warnings, consumer confidence is plummeting and unemployment is rising. Even the chairman of the Federal Reserve, the omniscient Alan Greenspan, believes thing could get worse. Most analysts still believe the US downturn will follow the traditional 'v' shape - a sharp drop in economic activity followed by an equally sharp recovery. But that is not guaranteed, and it will be months before it is clear whether they are right.

Even if they are, company profits are unlikely to follow the same pattern, warns Jeremy Batstone of NatWest Stockbrokers. 'People say the downturn is a demand thing: as soon as demand recovers, companies can put their prices. It is not. The problem is overcapacity around the world, which means companies have no pricing power.'

Certainly, the stock markets are not behaving as they should. Traditionally, shares have risen sharply immediately after a cut in interest rates - and technology shares more than most - as investors anticipate economic recovery. That did happen this time round: markets here and in the US surged in the wake of the Fed's unexpected rate cuts at the start of the year. But the euphoria was short-lived, and the gains have been more than reversed in the past few weeks.

That can largely be traced back to the tech euphoria of last spring. Excitement about the potential of the internet and new generation mobile phones encouraged companies to invest billions in building up stocks - and investors to pour billions of their savings into these companies. It is becoming increasingly clear that demand is not as strong as anticipated so, in many companies, stock levels are far too high. Add that to falling demand as the economy slows, and the outlook for profits remains poor.

But investors need not shy away from the stock markets completely. Batstone believes those whose finances are in order and who have 'the right attitude to investment' should still consider equity investment. But they have to be prepared to be nimble. Last year's favourite sectors - technology, media and telecoms - have been leading the market down and, judging by the pace of profits warnings, there could be worse to come.

Elsewhere, however, Batstone sees some pockets of real value. Housebuilders, automotive companies, property and leisure groups - indeed any cyclical company focused on the UK economy - are his favourites. But he excludes general retailers, which he thinks are dogged by overcapacity and price pressure.

He advises against buying an index tracker, as this would leave investors exposed to tech sectors, as well as to banks - which are vulnerable in an economic downturn - and oil companies - which could be hit by falling prices.

Urquhart Stewart agrees that investors should avoid FTSE 100 or technology trackers. But he says that an i-share - which is similar to a tracker but is sold as an individual share - for the all-share index could be a good bet. With the wider all-share index, exposure to banks and TMT stocks is lower.

But he also points out that Isas are really only worthwhile for those who pay tax and expect to do so in the future. Those who fall into that camp should not let nervousness about the markets deter them from opening one when 'in 10 year's time, it could be a good tax shelter'.

He points out that investors can open a self-select Isa and just leave the cash in it until the direction of the markets is clearer - although they will not get the tax benefit until it is invested. Some investment advisers - including Chase de Vere - offer the chance to drip-feed your investment into the market if you go for one of their fund supermarkets.

Traditionally, investors have been urged to ignore short-term nervousness in the stock market as the long-term performance of shares has been so good. But Batstone warns that these times may be over. Low inflation and stable economies means that returns on equities will be lower than in the recent past.

'The hardest part of investing is knowing when to sell,' he says. 'We will all have to learn that lesson.'

webTitle: Isa special: Self-select Isas

fields.headline: Have some fun with a good little mover
fields.standfirst: Self-select Isas let you respond fast, writes Marianne Curphey
fields.trailText: Self-select Isas let you respond fast, writes Marianne Curphey.
fields.body:
If you're an active investor and enjoy picking individual shares, a self-select Isa could be just the thing for you.

Self-select Isas are tax-free wrappers into which you can put your own selection of investments. They appeal to investors who are confident about choosing companies and trusts, and who enjoy keeping an eye on their holdings.

Much of the fun of a self-select Isa comes from choosing the shares and testing your stockpicking abilities against the market. This type of Isa is not suitable for cautious investors or those with little spare time; these people would be better off buying a cheap managed fund or index tracker.

The cheapest way to operate a self-select Isa is on an execution-only basis - the Isa is administered, but not managed, by a stockbroker. If you want advice, administration costs and annual fees are likely to be higher.

You can buy and sell shares as often as you like. And while it does not make sense to use a self-select Isa to invest small amounts, they are useful for investors who want to maximise capital growth without worrying about future capital gains tax liabilities.

Say you bought a stock which doubled in value. Under normal circumstances, when you sold that share you would have to pay Capital Gains Tax (CGT) on any gain above your annual CGT allowance of £7,200 (for financial year 2000-01).

But on a stock held within a self-select Isa, all those gains would come tax-free. So you could buy and sell stocks with no tax penalty. (For information on personal tax allowances, see www.rate.co.uk).

The self-select Isa enables you to respond quickly to market movements. A number of online stockbrokers operate self-select Isas and allow you to trade in real time. This is very different to some unit trusts or Oeic managers, who only allow you to trade on specific days and where it may take weeks to swap between fund managers.

However, self-select Isas are an expensive option if you plan to hold a couple of unit trusts or open ended investment companies (Oeics. If you want to hold more than one trust or Oeic within an single year's Isa allowance, you are better off buying through a fund supermarket which allows you to mix and match funds.

Those fund supermarkets which allow you to split your Isa allowance between a number of fund managers without incurring an extra charge include Egg and Fundsnetwork.

A key consideration when choosing a self-select Isa is how often you intend to trade. Stockbrokers who administer self-select Isas tend to make their money in two ways - by dealing charges and/or by an annual management fee. If you plan to buy and sell shares regularly, you will need a self- select Isa with low dealing charges.

If you plan to buy one or two trusts a year and hold them for the medium term, dealing charges will be less important, and you need to check whether there is an annual fee taken out of the gross value of the fund.

If the dealing charges are high, you will have to see a significant increase in the value of your shares before you make a net gain.

The bigger your portfolio, the better it is to choose an Isa manager with a flat annual administration fee. That way you aren't hit by heavy charges as your plan grows. Alternatively, in the first few years of the plan's life, when the value of your funds is relatively low, you could be better off linking the fee to the value of the fund.

You will probably be charged a dividend collection fee, levied on dividends when they are collected. This is likely to be twice-yearly, except for a small number of shares which issue quarterly dividends.

Marianne Curphey is the author of E-cash, a step by step guide to managing your money, shares and savings online, and editor of Money, the personal finance website of the Guardian and part of the GuardianUnlimited network.

Self-select selection

E*trade has a fixed flat rate price of £14.95 per trade, regardless of the size of the deal. There is an annual account management fee of £50 (plus VAT) a year.

DLJ charges a dealing fee of 0.75 per cent of the value of each individual order with a minimum charge of £14.95 and a maximum charge of £37.50. There is a half yearly ISA account fee of 0.25 per cent + VAT payable on 30 April and 0.25 per cent + VAT payable 31 October: The minimum charge is £7.50 and the maximum is £50.

Idealing is an independent financial services company which offers an execution-only service to buy and sell UK shares. There is a flat charge of £10 per trade and a management fee of £20 a year.

Stocktrade charges a dealing fee of 0.75 per cent on its execution-only Isa. The minimum dealing charge is £17.50 and the minimum annual management charge is £30 or 0.5 per cent of the value of the fund. Stocktrade is the execution-only division of Brewin Dolphin Securities. It offers real time online dealing.

Sharepeople charges £17.50 for trades over £1,000 plus a quarterly management fee of 0.125 per cent (max £25 per quarter).

Barclays Stockbrokers. This account has an annual administration fee of 0.5 per cent of the value of the fund up to £200 per annum, plus VAT. Charges are staggered, but are 1.5 per cent on trades of £2,500 to £5,000.

Selftrade.The charges are a £12.50 flat online fee per trade plus a 0.25 per cent management fee (plus VAT) every 6 months on your account up to a maximum of £40 (plus VAT).

webTitle: Letter:  Making the point

fields.headline: Making the point
fields.trailText: It is not surprising that your economics correspondent, Faisal Islam, reports poor UK productivity (Business, last week) when so little is done to promote the skills needed to secure it.
fields.body:
It is not surprising that your economics correspondent, Faisal Islam, reports poor UK productivity (Business, last week) when so little is done to promote the skills needed to secure it.

Unlike many countries, the UK has no productivity council to focus on productivity issues. Thus bog-standard topics that deliver productivity such as value management and statistical process control, to name just two examples, get little promotion and are scarcely known. And why is productivity a Treasury matter? Poor productivity is a know-how problem, not a budget issue.
Clive Bone
South Croydon, Surrey

webTitle: Cricket: Time has come for referral

fields.headline: Time has come for referral
fields.trailText: Ugly scenes in a beautiful city, but there has been some exceptional cricket played.
fields.body:
Ugly scenes in a beautiful city. True, there has been some exceptional cricket played. Mahela Jayawardena hit an enchanting century; we could admire Nasser Hussain's grit as he hit himself out of his slump; the irrepressible vim of Darren Gough, Kumar Sangakkara's counterattack and the doggedness of Kumar Dharmesena.

But these stirring efforts were too often overshadowed by so many distasteful incidents on and off the field. The match has aroused some ugly passions. There's something wrong when one of the local papers headlines its match report with 'Cooray bats for England'. Or when well-heeled English tourists sitting in the posh seats with access to TV and all those replays yell 'Out, out,' at Sanath Jayasuriya as he leaves the field, another victim of another umpiring cock-up.

Or when one of the umpires (Cooray) requires the presence of an armed guard as he returns to the pavilion after another tortuous day. Or when Jayasuriya throws his helmet in disgust and Mike Atherton has finger-wagging conversations with Sangakkara and Rudi Koertzen out in the middle. Or when the most sought-after individual at the close of play is not the centurion or the wicket-taker but the match referee Hanumant Singh, who emerges with the latest tally of penalties.

If anything there were more umpiring howlers here than in the first Test. The two coaches, Dav Whatmore and Duncan Fletcher, have chosen their words carefully, anxious to defuse the situation. Whatmore craves two 'neutral' umpires to take the pressure off the home man; Fletcher pleads that technology should be used. Whatmore agrees. At last some unanimity between the two sides.

The players of both sides have overstepped the mark in this match; several have been punished or censured but - my goodness - there has been some provocation. There is some truth in the standard line: the players have put the umpires under intolerable pressure; the converse argument has some merit too; the umpires have put the players under intolerable pressure.

Two of the most mild-mannered have been in the dock, Jayasuriya and Atherton (this is not yet an adjective that we can yet apply to Sangakkara). Jayasuriya has been the most dignified of cricketers. Quite how he was supposed to react as he headed towards a stand of baying English spectators after another miscarriage of justice, I'm not sure. Atherton perpetrated the only act in the match that could be interpreted as 'sporting' when he suggested that his 'catch' at slip from the bat of Russel Arnold should be referred to the third umpire. If these two are taxing the mind of the match referee then the game is spinning out of control, a situation not helped by the constant but inevitable dissection of every error or misdemeanour on the TV screens.

What to do? The referral system, which is the brainchild of Duncan Fletcher, should be examined swiftly and experiments carried out. To some it is too contrived. The romantics crave a return to the 'old days' when players simply trusted one another. Call me a cliché-ridden old cynic, if you like, but this smacks of putting the toothpaste back in the tube.

Tony Greig (not an obvious romantic) among others has utopian leanings. He would like to see the two captains/coaches get together before a match or a series and agree that the players should run the game. But the lines are too blurred. No one has been walking for 40 years or more. There have always been 'optimistic' appeals. One aberration of some idealistic code - and there would be one - and we are back to square one. The players have to be cajoled into behaving properly. It has to be in their interests to do so.

The beauty of the referral system is that good appeals to the third umpire are rewarded, bad ones are penalised with the loss of a referral. The system would not be foolproof; there would still be plenty of controversies to keep us all happy. But it should at least reduce the number of errors, which in turn might lessen so many repetitions of the unseemly incidents that have marred what might have been a magnificent Test match in Kandy.

webTitle: Cricket: Perils of the intrusive lens

fields.headline: Perils of the intrusive lens
fields.trailText: It ultimately doesn't matter who wins this series, the truth is that cricket has been the loser.
fields.body:
It ultimately doesn't matter who wins this series, the truth is that cricket has been the loser.

Two teams have fought well, behaved imperfectly and suffered some of the worst decisions I have seen. They go on to Colombo with umpiring karma levels balanced. It's not the umpires' fault. Making difficult and public decisions with millions looking over your shoulder, fractious players at your side and boorish buffoons in the stands is the umpire's lot nowadays. The game has let umpires down. They should be helped in every way to do their job.

The first umpires I knew were my schoolmasters - their authority was earned and unquestioned. We were immensely competitive, but decisions were accepted in good faith because there was no other possible arbiter. Now there is. And dissenting opinions are easier to voice.

Intense competitiveness is nothing new. The game in Sri Lanka will always have what we call 'chillies'. We are a proud, fiery race! England must understand that they don't have the monopoly on lions on the chest. At the time of my and Sri Lanka's first Test, against England, in 1981 I thought umpires were the master of all that they saw. Visual aids were not even in the reckoning.

Since then the fans and their friends the commentators have come very close to the game - stump-cams/stump-mikes/magnifying lenses and so on. If we are completely honest, we players do occasionally resent this intrusion into our workplace. There is no hiding from Big Brother so he should be stripped of his aura of malevolence and his power used to do good.

There will always be human error in cricket. If the game were as easy as so many of these former players who now pass judgment make it out to be (and, of course we hardly made any mistakes ourselves during our playing days), there would have been 20 Bradmans by now. The best umpires tend, like good bowlers, to be able to anticipate a situation before it happens. They really work out all the angles! Bowlers learn not to take liberties with this kind of authority. The main difference between the umpiring of 1981 and 2001 is that batsmen used to receive 'the benefit of the doubt' a lot more. There were distinct 'not-outers'.

Nowadays, one hardly even hears the phrase. But doubt remains. Playing against England is great for you also take on the world's biggest flotilla of correspondents. Their presence means that the problems of global umpiring, which are nothing new, can finally receive the attention they deserve. I am convinced that umpires have been endeavouring to strike back against the interference of television and reclaim their authority by acting decisively. By firing batsmen out more quickly, more often.

The ICC have a duty now to save the game from itself. They have been working hard to raise its profile, but their marketing job does not end with sponsorship and media exposure. They have let in TV as far as it can go and there has been a price to pay. If the game is to be saved from imploding then the relationship between players, umpires, television and viewers must be formalised.

I propose that the ICC establish a working party - made up of umpires and players who have experience of playing pre-multi-camera and with multi-camera, and with the power to effect change - to examine the problem.

Imran Khan cried himself hoarse in the Eighties advocating neutral umpires - it took too long for that benefit to materialise. We all play more cricket nowadays, and with the upcoming world Test championship every contest matters. There is not much time.

Imran and I had plenty of run-ins during our time as opposing captains, but beyond our on-field concerns as competitors who wanted to win, we were both very aware of our position as guardians of a great game. Each Test captain has a responsibility to carry the game forward to the next generation.

The game is greater than its individuals and it has to be greater than television.

webTitle: Cricket: England in Sri Lanka

fields.headline: Victory beckons - but  cricket is the loser
fields.standfirst: Controversy plagues Test
fields.trailText: For once, cricket was almost the dominant strand of another gripping, gruelling day in the Sri Lankan sun. There was the usual quota of dodgy umpiring decisions and the standard disciplinary hearing at the close of play, but in between an enthralling, nail-biting struggle took place in the middle.
fields.body:
For once, cricket was almost the dominant strand of another gripping, gruelling day in the Sri Lankan sun. There was the usual quota of dodgy umpiring decisions and the standard disciplinary hearing at the close of play, but in between an enthralling, nail-biting struggle took place in the middle.

There is no point having too many preconceived ideas out here and this does not just apply to the decisions of the umpires. Upon arrival we assumed that the fourth day would be the last of the match and that England would be able to head for Colombo with the series safely squared. We left having waited for the deliberations of referee Hanumant Singh and the match in the balance with England needing 70 runs for victory with six wickets remaining. It was Sri Lanka's day, but it still may be England's match. Avid followers, chomping their cornflakes, will know for certain by now.

England will not have been overjoyed that their chief obstacle was Kumar Sangakkara - not their favourite cricketer. Sangakkara is not worried about that. 'If they don't like me that's their problem,' said this articulate law student. 'Any regrets about the way you have played this game?' he was asked. Quick as a flash he responded 'Yes.' We waited eagerly for a confessional. 'I'm very disappointed with the shot I played against Robert Croft.' Sangakkara really does seem to relish the cut, thrust and parry of the modern Test.

He has his limitations behind the stumps, but he is only a makeshift wicketkeeper. However, he is clearly a special talent as a batsman. Yesterday he shrugged off the hostile vibes and hit a defiant 95 before losing his compo sure spectacularly. It looked as if he was trying to reach his maiden century with a six as he galloped down the pitch to heave and miss at Croft to be stumped five minutes before lunch, a dismissal that Stewart seemed to relish even more than usual.

But Sangakkara and his dutiful ally, Kumar Dharmesena, had done some damage. Together they had taken Sri Lanka's fragile overnight total of 98 for six to 187 for seven against an uneven English attack. Darren Gough, his competitive instincts aroused, was superb, but Ashley Giles was inconsistent. Hardly surprising that Giles was visibly frustrated when Dharmesena on 19 was given not out after an appeal for a catch at silly point. Inevitably BC Cooray was the umpire; inevitably the replays suggested that the ball had hit the bat after the pad. Cooray was at least displaying some consistency, I suppose.

Sangakkara played some thrilling strokes: punched drives off the back foot, silky ones off the front. Nor was he afraid to loft the spinners. He gave one chance, a tough caught-and-bowled to Craig White on 89. Only over-exuberance prevented him reaching his century.The England players, whether they like it or not, will be seeing much more of Sangakkara. Odd really: Atherton usually takes to people with brains.

After the break England were convinced that Chaminda Vaas was dismissed by Croft, easily the more impressive of the two English spinners. Again it was an appeal for a bat-pad catch to Thorpe; again Cooray was unconvinced. The players reacted sanguinely to the rejection of that appeal; maybe they are getting used to the new rules.

There were seven consecutive maidens at the start of that afternoon session but the Sri Lankan innings gradually gained momentum. Vaas began to chance his arm with success, top-edging a hook to the boundary off White; Dharmesena swept Croft for four and England were creaking in several areas. The Sri Lankan tail was looking untroubled and Nasser Hussain tweaked a groin muscle and was compelled to leave the field for a while (Stewart took over). So much hinged on the second new ball, which was taken as soon as it was available.

Vaas was soon dropped by Stewart down the leg side off Gough and it took seven overs before the new ball did the trick. Then the indefatigable Gough conjured some steep bounce and Graeme Hick took a fine catch above his head at second slip to end Dharmesena's three-and-three-quarter hours of determined resistance. In Gough's next over, Hick obliged again to dispose of Nuwan Zoysa. Muttiah Muralitharan clubbed one mammoth six over midwicket from Gough's off-cutter but the replacement of Caddick by White finally enabled England to know what their target would be in this match. Vaas hit White's first ball straight to cover.

England replied aggressively in pursuit of 161 but both openers were gone by the end of the seventh over. Trescothick with two cuts and Atherton (two cover drives) found the boundary but then Vaas intervened.

Atherton is becoming ever more like Boycott - seemingly impregnable except when he is facing subcontinental left-armers. He nicked Vaas to Sangakkara again but stood his ground. There was no doubt that he had touched the ball, but given recent history between these two players there was no way that he was going to leave the field without confirmation that the ball had carried. Cooray wisely consulted the third umpire, who could see that it had.

There followed a sterling half-century partnership between a hobbling Hussain and an inspired Thorpe, who threatened to take the game away from the Sri Lankans. Somehow on 17 he survived an lbw appeal against Dharmesena (the umpire was Rudi Koertzen so there did not seem to be so many replays). Otherwise Thorpe's mind was sharp and his touch sure as he resolved to take the initiative. Murali was taken for 20 in his first two overs as Thorpe cut, drove, swept and edged him to the boundary. Hussain occasionally managed a crisp cover drive off Jayasuriya.

Yet both were gone by the close. Thorpe was eventually too ambitious against Murali. This time the ball he chose to cut was a little too close to him and it bounced more than he expected. Sangakkara took the catch. Sangakkara was celebrating again within minutes as Vaas returned and won a caught-behind appeal against Hussain. The England captain looked disgruntled, but it is a foolish man who draws too many conclusions from that in this day and age. So it was left to Stewart and the night watchman Croft to take England to the close of a thrilling, sapping day.

England could not afford to look ahead any further than the taut session that awaited them on Sunday morning. Even though the final Test at Colombo starts on Thursday that was still out of bounds. They do know that they will have Atherton in their ranks in Colombo. Like Sangakkara, Atherton escaped with a 'very severe' reprimand from referee Hanumant Singh for his finger-wagging on Friday night. They do not know whether Hussain will be fit.

My guess is that the England captain, who has always relished a good fight, will be there even if it means aggravating his groin injury and jeopardising his presence in the one-day internationals. With melodrama like this who cares about one-day internationals?
