webTitle: Cricket: A bit rich for Sri Lanka to moan now

fields.headline: A bit rich for Sri Lanka to moan now
fields.trailText: What a nail-biter. Like everyone else, I wasn't expecting this second Test to last into the final day, never mind Sri Lanka still being in with a chance to win it.
fields.body:
What a nail-biter. Like everyone else, I wasn't expecting this second Test to last into the final day, never mind Sri Lanka still being in with a chance to win it.

But England's victory march suffered a few frustrations yesterday and they did well to maintain their discipline first in the heat when the Sri Lankan tail put up such dogged resistance and then when it was their turn to suffer at the finger of umpire BC Cooray.

Poor old BC has had a nightmare, hasn't he? Marcus Trescothick's lbw decision was just the latest of at least half a dozen poor decisions that have not only led to an increase in dissent but also contributed to the bad feeling between the teams.

It's no coincidence that the worst cases of dissent in world cricket always occur when there have been several clear miscarriages of justice in the same Test or consecutive matches. This inevitably leads to the players losing respect for the officials and levels of behaviour soon deteriorate.

No one is condoning the actions of Sanath Jayasuriya on Friday, when he hurled his helmet at an advertising board, but his gesture wasn't over a marginal lbw decision, it was anger at being given out caught when he had clearly struck the ball into the ground. Likewise Graeme Hick's refusal to leave the crease in the first Test followed another umpiring howler. Both Jayasuriya and Hick are struggling for runs at the moment and that makes it even harder to accept a bad decision.

When the finger goes up, and you know as a batsman that it wasn't out, it leaves you with a feeling of helplessness. It is a real test of character to walk back without protesting your innocence and, while getting stuck into Jayasuriya and Hick for making a fuss, maybe we should also be congratulating Trescothick and Alec Stewart, in the first Test, for dignified exits.

Top professionals in any sport rightly demand the same level of competence from the men in charge of their game and when it isn't there niggles over bad umpiring can quickly sour relationships.

It was noticeable in Kandy that the Sri Lankans refused to applaud Nasser Hussain's century, believing they had already caught him twice. And I'd be surprised if Friday's bust-up between Mike Atherton and Sangakkara didn't have its roots in the England opener's final-morning dismissal in Galle. Both sides have far too much gristle to chew on at the moment and relations are on a nasty downward spiral.

Most of the problems stem from the officials not getting a grip from the start of the series. The Sri Lankans clearly set out to put pressure on the umpires in Galle by appealing for everything, in the cynical belief that by shouting loud and often they would pick up a few extra wickets, and the officials didn't clamp down on it. I know if that sort of behaviour was seen in county cricket the captain of the offending team would have been taken to one side and told in no uncertain terms to cut it out.

In my book, if you adopt those tactics you surrender the right to complain when decisions go against you. For the Jayasuriya who obviously felt so aggrieved to be caught off a bump ball was the same Jayasuriya who shouted to get an lbw against Stewart in Galle - when he must have known his delivery had pitched nine inches outside leg stump.

Do the players get the umpires they deserve, or is it the other way around? The ICC's method for cutting down on player dissent seems to be to punish the offending batsmen for sometimes little more than a display of surprise or disbelief, when a more effective way would be to raise the standard of Test umpiring.

There is relatively little trouble on the county circuit because our officials perform consistently. Of course there are occasional mistakes but we are talking about marginal errors not shockers and you can take the rough with the smooth.

Strong umpiring from the outset in Sri Lanka would have kept a lid on the series, brought the bowlers into line over excessive appealing and given the batsmen confidence. Scoring runs is difficult enough without having the very basics laws of the game ignored.

webTitle: Cricket: Stewart faces 'fix' grilling

fields.headline: Stewart's new 'fix' grilling
fields.trailText: Former England captain Alec Stewart faces another meeting with Sir Paul Condon's anti-corruption squad when England return from their tour of Sri Lanka.
fields.body:
Former England captain Alec Stewart faces another meeting with Sir Paul Condon's anti-corruption squad when England return from their tour of Sri Lanka.

And in a separate development, Scotland Yard's Serious Crime Group are hopeful that disgraced former South African skipper Hansie Cronje will come on board their criminal inquiry into claims of match fixing sparked by former England all-rounder Chris Lewis.

There has been a general assumption that Stewart had been exonerated following his first session with Sir Paul's anti-corruption squad in January after the player was alleged to have received £5,000 from an Indian bookmaker for details relating to pitches, weather conditions, team selection and morale. But Stewart is not yet in the clear. After his first interview - or 'interrogation' as it was reported in India - the ICC said a second interview may be necessary to discuss matters in greater depth.

Observer Sport understands that Sir Paul's unit has decided to exercise that prerogative and Stewart 'has been told to attend with his lawyer', according to one source close to the unit.

Neither Condon, the former Metropolitan Police commissioner, nor his team would comment directly but an ICC spokesman said: 'My feeling is that if they [Condon's unit] want to talk to Alec Stewart again they will have no qualms about asking him and, by the way Stewart responded last time, I'm sure he'll have no qualms about coming forward.'

Stewart has faced increasing pressure about his alleged role in accepting cash from a bookmaker and recently hinted that he would quit international cricket after this summer's Ashes series in England. News of a second interview with the ACU is likely to increase pressure on him to quit the Test stage.

Bookmaker Mukesh Gupta said he paid Stewart £5,000 for information. Stewart firmly denies the allegations. He is said to have been introduced to the bookie by Manoj Prabhakar, recently banned for five years by India's cricket board for his role in match fixing.

Lord MacLaurin, chairman of the England Cricket Board, was said to have accepted Stewart's denials at the time - during England's spell in Pakistan - but the ECB also accept that there has been no official 'green light' on the ACU inquiries into Stewart.

The ACU's probe is not a criminal inquiry but Scotland Yard officers are continuing their investigations into allegations of a bid to fix an England Test. This is a criminal inquiry and Yard detectives are now 'hopeful' of persuading Cronje to come forward with vital information. The officers spoke of their optimism at the time Cronje's 'paymaster' Sanjeev Chawla was being re-bailed at a Central London police station last week.

Chawla, 33, from Hendon, was arrested in January. Cronje has admitted receiving £6,000 from Chawla for supplying information during the final Test against England at Pretoria last year.

Chawla is under investigation by the Yard officers who are examining allegations concerning the drawn third Test between England and New Zealand at Old Trafford in August 1999. Former England player Lewis told police that Indian sports promoter Aushim Kheterpal had asked him to help fix the match by targeting England players.

The Yard officers are waiting to hear from the Crown Prosecution Service, who are studying documents seized at Chawla's home. The officers are also considering extraditing Kheterpal, now in India, back to Britain.

webTitle: Cricket:Test ref issues final warning

fields.headline: Test refissues finalwarning
fields.trailText: There were more controversies on the fourth day of the tempestuous second Test match between Sri Lanka and England in Kandy yesterday. As usual, Umpire BC Cooray was at the centre of most of them and so were Mike Atherton and the young Sri Lankan wicketkeeper-batsman, Kumar Sangakkara.
fields.body:
There were more controversies on the fourth day of the tempestuous second Test match between Sri Lanka and England in Kandy yesterday. As usual, Umpire BC Cooray was at the centre of most of them and so were Mike Atherton and the young Sri Lankan wicketkeeper-batsman, Kumar Sangakkara.

The beleaguered Sri Lankan Cooray, who had to endure looking out at banners saying 'Have you got your resident visa for England?' had another poor day. He gave at least two bad decisions against England, adding to earlier howlers against Sri Lanka.

Atherton and Sangakkara were summoned to a hearing with match referee Hanumant Singh at the end of play, which was prompted by their heated exchange during Friday's play. Both escaped significant penalties. Singh's statement said: 'Having given careful consideration to the explanations of both players I have decided to issue a very severe reprimand to both players. I am further issuing a final warning to both teams and should there be any repetition of such behaviour, it will be dealt with severely.'

Earlier the mistrust that exists between the pair was reflected by Atherton's dismissal. After edging the ball to Sangakkara, Atherton stood his ground and waited until Cooray had consulted the third umpire to check whether the ball had carried. It had.

The tension will spill over into this morning. The match, seemingly within England's grasp at the start of play yesterday, was left in the balance after a brilliant innings of 95 by Sangakkara. On a deteriorating pitch England, with six wickets remaining, require another 70 runs for a victory which would square the series.

The continued controversy over bad umpiring decisions and players' dissent has prompted former Sri Lanka skipper Arjuna Ranatunga - an Observer Sport columnist for the series - to call for an ICC working party, with powers to push through changes, to examine ways of curtailing the all-seeing, all-hearing influence of television and the pressure it brings to bear on umpires.

Ranatunga said: 'I propose an ICC working party - made up of umpires and players who have experience of playing pre-multi-camera and with multi-camera, and with the power to effect change - to examine the problem. With the upcoming world Test championship every contest matters. There is not much time. There is no hiding from Big Brother [television] so he should be stripped of his aura of malevolence and his power used to do good.'

Mike Gatting, the former England captain and also an Observer columnist, said: 'It's no coincidence that the worst cases of dissent always occur when there have been several clear miscarriages of justice in the same Test or consecutive matches. This leads to players losing respect for the officials and levels of behaviour soon deteriorate.'

webTitle: Leader: Men overboard

fields.headline: Men overboard
fields.standfirst: Never mind sex, where's the food?
fields.trailText: Leader: Never mind sex, where's the food?
fields.body:
Banishing men from cities is a centuries-old female fantasy, particularly during those insalubrious Friday night moments. Around 400BC, Aristophanes depicts Lysistrata and the women of Athens seizing the Acropolis and refusing conjugal rights to their menfolk in order to stop them fighting. Today's unlikely Lysistrata is the (male) mayor of Bogota, Antanas Mockus Civicas, who declared Colombia's capital a women-only zone for a night and suggested men stay at home to reflect on the nature of violence.

So, the night before last, some half-a-million women took to the women-policed streets (yes, they managed to find the way) and had a good time. But how - without men to make the jokes, pay the bill and charm their way to Saturday morning? What on earth did they do?

If they have anything in common with their British sisters, they probably went for a meal. On the same day, a Mori poll here revealed that 80 per cent of women get more pleasure from food than from sex. But then again, they could be faking it.

webTitle: Life support

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Next month, the trial of the former MI5 officer David Shayler is due to take place at the Old Bailey. Meanwhile, says Shayler, his life with his girlfriend Annie Machon is a bit like being Bonnie and Clyde - without the guns
fields.trailText: Next month, the trial of the former MI5 officer David Shayler is due to take place at the Old Bailey. Meanwhile, says Shayler, his life with his girlfriend Annie Machon is a bit like being Bonnie and Clyde - without the guns.
fields.body:
David Shayler: There was a moment, after Annie and I had been seeing each other for about two months, that I developed this absolute paranoia. She so fitted my perfect specifications for a woman that I thought MI5 had sent her to spy on me.

I fancied her at the start, obviously, but we got on like a house on fire. There wasn't any of the playing around I'd had in previous relationships, where people are scared to say things. It was all very open and forthright. When I decided to go public about MI5, we talked about it over a long period of time. It was quite a surprise to Annie when it did happen, because although I'd indicated what I was doing, suddenly everything came to a head and we had three days to prepare ourselves.

Our lives have been much more like something out of a John le Carré novel since we went on the run. When you work in MI5, essentially you're a bureaucrat. You may be directing a surveillance operation or picking up the contents of a telephone intercept but you're still sitting behind a desk. Now my father says we're like Bonnie and Clyde, only with words instead of guns.

The day I was arrested in Paris I'd gone out to watch a football match on television. It was pouring with rain. I walked into the foyer of the hotel absolutely soaking and this guy steps out in front of me and goes: 'Etes-vous Monsieur Shayler?' I thought he was one of the hotel staff. He said: 'I'm inspecteur de la Police Nationale.' I said: 'Are you arresting me?' I didn't even have a chance to say goodbye to Annie.

When I came out of prison and Annie got ill it was absolutely harrowing. To have the entire British state on your back is bad enough, but when the one person who's supporting you then nearly dies, you really are taken apart by it. It was very distressing because Annie was totally delirious and having vivid hallucinations, and before I knew it was meningitis I thought she was losing her mind.

There was a feeling that the case had pushed her too far. On the third day, she actually recognised me and smiled at me and there was a tremendous sense of relief.

Annie Machon: We met at MI5. I was in the counter-subversives section, looking at counter-subversives, Reds-under-the-bed, which is a section that should have been closed down years ago. Dave was the new boy on the block. He'd been in the service a couple of months and he was having lunch up in the little library. We started chatting and sort of hit it off straightaway. I found him physically very attractive and we got on like a house on fire. He's very sparky, very intelligent, very challenging and he makes me laugh, so we had a whale of a time. We knew each other as friends for about a year and gradually fell in love.

I was frightened about what would happen when Dave went public. It would completely overthrow our lives. But I love the fact that Dave stands up to the bullies, and if he believes something's right he'll fight for it. To have stopped would have been to have stopped him from being himself.

We actually remained hidden for five months. Up to that point, we'd spent eight years living in the centre of London and suddenly we were transported back in time to this sort of isolated, old-fashioned French farmhouse with no proper heating. We spent most of our time sitting in front of the fire. During the day, Dave would write his novel and I'd sort of keep house and cook. In the evenings we'd just talk.

The only reason I knew he had even been arrested was because the police came up to the hotel room in Paris looking for his passport. I asked them if they were arresting David and they said they were just taking him in for questioning, and that was the last time I saw him for nine weeks. He was banned from seeing his family, but even when they were allowed to see him I had problems because I wasn't married to him. I had to get a note off his mum and dad saying I was his girlfriend.

If Dave does go to jail, we'll get through it. We did it before and we'll do it again. We've sort of found roles. There's the relationship and around that there's the case and we sort of work within that. The whole process has taught us a lot about each other and a lot about ourselves.

He'd been in the service a couple of months and he was having lunch up in the little library. We started chatting and sort of hit it off straightaway. I found him physically very attractive and we got on like a house on fire. He's very sparky, very intelligent, very challenging and he makes me laugh, so we had a whale of a time. We knew each other as friends for about a year and gradually fell in love. I was frightened about what would happen when Dave went public. It would completely overthrow our lives. But I love the fact that Dave stands up to the bullies, and if he believes something's right he'll fight for it. To have stopped would have been to have stopped him from being himself. We actually remained hidden for five months. Up to that point, we'd spent eight years living in the centre of London and suddenly we were transported back in time to this sort of isolated, old-fashioned French farmhouse with no proper heating. We spent most of our time sitting in front of the fire. During the day, Dave would write his novel and I'd sort of keep house and cook. In the evenings we'd just talk. The only reason I knew he had even been arrested was because the police came up to the hotel room in Paris looking for his passport. I asked them if they were arresting David and they said they were just taking him in for questioning, and that was the last time I saw him for nine weeks. He was banned from seeing his family, but even when they were allowed to see him I had problems because I wasn't married to him. I had to get a note off his mum and dad saying I was his girlfriend. There's the relationship and around that there's the case and we sort of work within that. The whole process has taught us a lot about each other and a lot about ourselves.

webTitle: Cricket: Revised Kandy scorecard

fields.headline: Arbitrary fairness
fields.trailText: After a long perusal of the video by the panel (Ian Botham and Tony Greig) and plenty of use of the pause button we are now in a position to release the amended scorecard at the end of the fourth day of the second Test between Sri Lanka and England at Kandy.
fields.body:
After a long perusal of the video by the panel (Ian Botham and Tony Greig) and plenty of use of the pause button we are now in a position to release the amended scorecard at the end of the fourth day of the second Test between Sri Lanka and England at Kandy.

Sri Lanka First Innings: Final total should read 328 not 297.

Delete K Sangakkara c Trescothick b White 17 and insert K Sangakkara triggered R Koertzen 48*.

*(Under the Greig-Botham method a player adjudged to have wrongly been given out is awarded a sum of runs equal to his current Test average in compensation. This sum to be added to any runs he has scored at the time of dismissal.)

England First Innings: Final total should read 308 not 387

Delete N Hussain b Muralitharan 109 and insert N Hussain c Jayawardena b Muralitharan 53

Delete G Hick lbw Muralitharan 0 and insert G Hick c&b Muralitharan 0

Delete A Stewart c 54 and insert A Stewart c Jayawardena b Muralitharan 31

Sri Lanka lead by 20 runs

Sri Lanka Second Innings Final total should read 255 not 250

Delete S Jayasuriya c Thorpe b Caddick O and insert S Jayasuriya sawn off BC Cooray 40 (Using the Greig-Botham method Jayasuriya is awarded his Test match average)

Delete Dharmasena c Hick b Gough 54 and insert Dharmasena c Thorpe b Giles 19.

England require 275 runs to win

England second innings Total should read 134 for 4 not 94 for 4

Delete M Trescothick lbw Vaas 13 and insert M Trescothick assassinated BC Cooray 56

The final day's play was set up perfectly for a thriller in Kandy: 141 to win, six wickets in hand, deteriorating pitch, Murali twirling away, Graeme Hick, BC Cooray providing a welcome arbitriness to the proceedings. Cricket just doesn't get any better.

Before getting too carried away it should perhaps be stressed at this moment that the panel's arbitration is in no way intended to replace Wisden's official Test scorecard. It is merely of use in assessing who is entitled to occupy the moral high-ground going into the final Test in Colombo.

England undoubtedly had the worst of it in Galle (utilising the Greig-Botham method Sri Lanka would have required 233 to win in the final innings although pedants might argue they wouldn't have declared had they known it was in operation) and just as indisputably Sri Lanka have been given a raw deal in Kandy.

The strange thing is that the umpiring, which has routinely been described by every pundit as the worst in the world ever has actually produced a fairly level playing field with England suffering 10 bad decisions to Sri Lanka's nine so far. Allowing for a slither of home bias this seems just about right. Arbitrary it may be, but it creates a crazy fairness and, let's be honest, quite a lot of entertainment.

webTitle: Net closes on the thief of sex.com

fields.headline: Net closes on the thief of sex.com
fields.trailText: Everybody wants a piece of the action. Sex.com, the most sought-after address on the world wide web, is at the centre of a remarkable legal dispute involving a fugitive porn baron, betrayed business partners and billions of pounds in potential profits.
fields.body:
Everybody wants a piece of the action. Sex.com, the most sought-after address on the world wide web, is at the centre of a remarkable legal dispute involving a fugitive porn baron, betrayed business partners and billions of pounds in potential profits.

Gary Kremen, then a penniless student, bought the rights to the name in 1994, sensing a chance of a big fortune from the burgeoning internet. But as he studied at Stanford University, California, Stephen Cohen, a convicted fraudster, was plotting a coup.

Jailed in 1991 for impersonating a lawyer, Cohen heard other convicts tell of money to be made from the net. Sex, he decided, would make him rich.

After his release in 1995, he discovered sex.com was registered to Kremen. But he convinced Network Solutions, which controls web addresses, that he was an ex-flatmate of the student, who had agreed to hand it over. Cohen paid £650 to be listed as the owner.

Sex.com was quickly transformed into the hub of a porn empire based in Mexico. Subscriptions to the website grew at the speed of the internet itself. Its nine million users and huge advertising revenues gave Cohen an income of more than $400 million a year, salted away in the British Virgin Islands.

This weekend Cohen is on the run from US police after ignoring court orders to return sex.com to Kremen and hand over a large slice of his fortune in damages. The flight of the playboy businessman ended a six-year saga over the rights to the web name.

Kremen, initially too poor to mount a legal challenge, first filed a lawsuit against Cohen in 1998, using wealth amassed through stock market investments. Expensive teams of lawyers battled it out until a judge ruled last year that the name was not 'property' and could not be 'stolen'. This landmark judgment meant that the most valuable asset a company can have on the internet - its address - was a mere marketing tool.

But Kremen persevered. Cohen told a judge he first had the idea for sex.com in 1979, when he advertised 'nudist camps'. Kremen's side reminded the court that dot.coms did not exist then.

Last November Kremen had a breakthrough. Judge James Ware said Cohen should return sex.com to Kremen. He ordered that $25 million sent abroad should be returned to the US for possible damages.

Cohen ignored the order. When he also ignored a subsequent contempt-of-court ruling, a warrant for his arrest was issued. He is now thought to be on the run.

The businessman may have vanished, but his millions have not. Kremen wants them and he will be helped by a ruling last Friday. It says 'that if you steal a product and sell it, you are competing unfairly,' said Kremen's lawyer, Charles Carreon.

Kremen also plans to sue other companies that have registered variants of sex.com, which he now plans to turn into a 'classy' adult entertainment site.

webTitle: A-list loses its heart to Highlands

fields.headline: A-list loses its heart to Highlands
fields.standfirst: Madonna crossed the border and now a host of other celebs are soaking up the peace and isolation a Scottish hideaway offers. John Arlidge reports
fields.trailText: Madonna crossed the border and now a host of other celebs are soaking up the peace and isolation a Scottish hideaway offers.  John Arlidge reports
fields.body:
It may be colder than Monte Carlo, wetter than Martha's Vineyard, suffer more insects than Barbados, and serve up some of the most unhealthy food in the world, but Scotland is fast becoming the epicentre of cool for the world's show business, fashion and sporting élite.

When England captain David Beckham wore a Pringle V-Neck jumper - more often seen on Fife golf courses than on the shoulders of a trendsetter - to a party celebrating the publication of his autobiography, Beckham: My World , he became the latest A-list celebrity to endorse all things Scottish.

Robbie Williams, Oasis frontman Liam Gallagher, and Naked Chef Jamie Oliver have been spotted recently wearing the diamond-pattern knitwear. Harris Tweed is back on the catwalks of Milan, Paris and New York. And Burberry, the beige check superbrand, is using Scottish supermodel Stella Tennant in its latest advertising campaign. Tennant is pictured in black and white wearing Burberry on her grandfather's estate, The Glen, in Perthshire.

Following Prince William's decision to defy his father and go to St Andrews University, rather than Cambridge, and Madonna's marriage to Guy Ritchie at Skibo Castle, near Inverness, Scotland is shaking off its traditional golf, heather and shortbread image and becoming a glamorous destination. Hollywood actors, fashion designers and sports stars, including Titanic actress Kate Winslet, Donatella Versace, head of the Milan fashion house, trendy London designers Antoni & Alison, and Beckham, are heading for the hills.

Thousands of ordinary holiday-makers and honeymooners are now following in the A-list footsteps. Demand for traditional Highland weddings has never been higher, with some castles and hotels fully booked until the end of the year.

Madonna's marriage last December gave the fragile winter economy a £2 million boost, figures released by the Scottish Tourist Board reveal. The effect has been so dramatic that Highland tourist chiefs now describe the period leading up to the wedding as 'BC' - before Ciccone.

Officials plan to use comments the star - whose surname is Ciccone - made in a recent US magazine inter view to drive home the 'glamorous glens' image in their summer advertising campaign. Madonna called Scotland 'magical, beautiful'.

'The Scots are great,' she said. 'It was like family, instantly. We couldn't have found a better place to do it. I can't tell you how glad I was that we made that choice.' One senior tourism official said: 'If you get the world's most fashionable woman, who is always ahead of the next big trend, praising your backyard, you use it for all it is worth. You only have to look at the effect that celebrity endorsement has on clothes and cars to see what someone like Madonna can do for the image of a small country like Scotland.'

The Madonna effect has already attracted Kate Winslet, 25, who took her husband Jim, and their four-month-old daughter Mia, to the Highlands for their first family holiday last month. Arriving back in London, she said: 'I feel totally relaxed.'

Donatella Versace, who was a maid of honour at Madonna's wedding, has booked to spend her summer holidays in Dornoch with her two children, Allegra, 14, and Daniel, 10. On a recent visit to London to launch her perfume, she said: 'I am going to take my children to Skibo for the summer. It is wonderful. At the wedding we all went outside for long walks and saw eagles. I love the history. You can feel it the second you put your foot in the door.'

Design duo Antoni & Alison recently stayed on the Mull of Kintyre. 'We had no telephone and only had electricity occasionally,' Antoni said. 'A friend came with us and the three of us were in this huge, scary, remote old mill with a big cellar. At night, it was pitch black outside. It was like Scooby Doo .'

David Beckham is to head north of the border next month to visit the Borders town where Pringle knitwear is manufactured.

Even Tony Blair, who addressed Labour Party activists in Inverness on Friday, is basking in the reflected glory of the celebrity boom. Ministers are spending tens of thousands of pounds hosting a weekend conference at Skibo later this year.

The new A-list arrivals join dozens of other well-known figures who are already hooked on the beauty of the mountainous landscapes, the quiet salmon rivers, wind-swept, white-sand beaches, and locals too uninterested to shop a celebrity's whereabouts to the paparazzi.

Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones are regular visitors to Inverness-shire. Billy Connolly recently bought Candacraig House, on the banks of the River Don, near Balmoral, where he has entertained Hollywood stars Steve Martin and Robin Williams.

American-born author Bill Bryson prefers the windswept islands of Orkney, while Newsnight presenter Jeremy Paxman fishes on the Tay.

The celebrity boom has encouraged Dave Stewart, the Eurythmics star, to invest in a £10m film studio being built in Inverness. TVP Film & Multimedia hopes to encourage directors and actors to make films in the area. Mel Gibson's Oscar-winning Braveheart , Michael Caton-Jones's Rob Roy , and Loch Ness , starring Ted Danson, were all filmed in the Highlands.

john.arlidge@observer.co.uk

webTitle: News in brief

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Racist killing at youth prison 'could happen again'
fields.body:
Racist killing at youth prison 'could happen again'

Nick Pascoe, governor of Feltham young offenders' institute where Asian inmate Zahid Mubarek was murdered in a racist attack last year, has warned that a similar incident could occur again.

Pascoe says in an interview with tonight's Panorama that the institute often receives poor information so that potentially violent inmates may be put in the same cell.

Zahid, 19, died after Robert Stewart, a psychopath who revered the killers of Stephen Lawrence, clubbed him around the head with a table leg as he slept. The teenager, who was serving 90 days at the institute in west London for shoplifting, was due to be released on the day of the attack.

Divers search for boy, four

Police divers joined the search for Luke Gargan, four, of Saltcoats, Ayrshire, was reported missing after his mother found his bed empty at about 7.20am yesterday. She had last seen him less than three hours earlier. About 25 officers, with a helicopter and dogs, spent the day searching nearby gardens and woodland.

Trucker bailed after death

A lorry driver arrested after a 10-year-old boy died and his mother was seriously hurt in a crash on the M60 near Cheadle has been released on bail.

Toads need road safety lesson

Thousands of volunteers are being recruited to help toads cross the road in safety during their annual migration this month.

Mel C: 'I'm still a Spice Girl'

Singer Mel C said she was not leaving the Spice Girls and insisted the band still had a future.

She phoned the television show cd:uk during an interview with fellow Spice Girl Emma Bunton to deny remarks attributed to her by an American magazine.

She said: 'I have not left the Spice Girls. We are still together. I'm very sorry to let down the media, but hopefully it won't bother fans.'

Nuns are free

The Alexandra Theatre in Birmingham is offering free admission to the first 10 nuns to turn up to a sing-along version of the Sound of Music on 3 April. Staff have been ordered to keep their eyes out for impostors.

Red alert

The red rubber noses worn on the face in support of Comic Relief could cause problems for latex allergy sufferers, the charity has warned.

Bill Barrett

William 'Bill' Barrett, who has died at 78, was an award-winning photographer and a picture editor, writes Nigel Lloyd .

For the last 11 years of his career he was picture editor of The Observer Colour Magazine. He retired in 1983.

After leaving Leeds College of Art, to which he had won a scholarship, Bill worked on newspapers in Yorkshire before moving to Fleet Street in 1950 on the Daily Graphic , soon to become the Daily Sketch .

His assignments took him all over the world, including the Arctic, Cyprus, Aden and Yugoslavia. He photographed many celebrities, including Frank Sinatra, the Kennedys, Peter Ustinov and most of the royal family.

It was his pictures of King George VI's funeral and wildlife studies of otters that helped him win the 1952 Encyclopaedia Britannica British Press Photographer of the Year award.

Manchester Airport bomb alert

A major security alert took place at Manchester Airport after calls were received saying that a bomb aboard Pakistan International Airways flight F711 from Karachi would explode over the mid-Atlantic during its flight to New York. The aircraft remained in a remote area until the end of its scheduled flight time, while the 462 passengers and 17 crew waited in the terminal buildings.

Baby murder charge

A man appeared in court in Portsmouth charged with the murder of Leiton Rowlands, aged six months, who was found with severe head injuries at his home after a 999 call. He was remanded in custody to appear at Winchester Crown Court on Friday.

Air race propelled forward

Thirty-eight flying enthusiasts from 10 countries gathered at Biggin Hill, Kent, in preparation for today's start of the 2001 London to Sydney Air Race.

They agreed to continue with the event despite the loss on Tuesday of Gwen Bloomingdale and Barbara Gard, from Massachusetts, whose plane crashed off the coast of Iceland.

Some of the propeller-driven aircraft taking part in the race date from the Second World War.

Pensioner sees red

Pensioner Jack Spensley, 70, is to stand at the general election for Arthur Scargill's Socialist Labour Party.

webTitle: Letter: Pathetic fallacy

fields.headline: Pathetic fallacy
fields.trailText: I am accused [by Richard Ingrams] of not understanding why 'the Tories wanted' me 'out' (Comment, last week).
fields.body:
I am accused [by Richard Ingrams] of not understanding why 'the Tories wanted' me 'out' (Comment, last week). What I do know is that in the General Election of February 1974, the Conservative Party polled more votes than the Labour Party, but under our system, Labour got more seats. After this I am accused of living as 'a pathetic and ridiculous figure'.

Was it pathetic and ridiculous that I captained the English Ocean Racing Team for three separate years, on the first occasion winning the championship over 18 other countries?

Was it pathetic and ridiculous that during the 1970s I wrote three best selling books on sailing, music and travel, and repeated this record with my autobiography 18 months ago?

Was it pathetic and ridiculous that the then Secretary General of the Commonwealth and I played the major part in the production of the Brandt report on International Development in 1981, which produced a better relationship between the developed and developing countries together with more aid in the latter than ever before?

Is it pathetic and ridiculous that during this period, I have conducted so many of the world's great orchestras, including the Chicago and Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra, the Berlin Symphony Orchestra, the London Symphony Orchestra, the Beijing and Shanghai Symphony Orchestras, and the English Chamber Orchestra. I have also recorded CDs of classical works, as well as debating the major issues in the House of Commons and completing my fifty-first continuous year in my constituency of Bexley.
Edward Heath
House of Commons, London SW1

webTitle: Letter:  Education's crisis

fields.headline: Education's crisis
fields.trailText: I read the article by Mary Riddell, 'The Defective Inspector' (Comment, last week), with considerable interest as a taxpayer, parent and teacher. I think her assessment is fairly accurate but the crisis in staffing is even worse than she envisages.
fields.body:
I read the article by Mary Riddell, 'The Defective Inspector' (Comment, last week), with considerable interest as a taxpayer, parent and teacher. I think her assessment is fairly accurate but the crisis in staffing is even worse than she envisages.

I am a supply teacher, nearly 53, and I can earn more driving petrol tankers and it's probably less hazardous. No 4.2 per cent increase for me. In the final analysis, Woodhead tilted at the wrong windmills but there again the politicians could hit back - we couldn't. Until teachers take back education from the politicians, the Woodheads of this world will continue.
Harry Harris
Dover

webTitle: Letter: No Middle Way

fields.headline: No Middle Way
fields.trailText: Now that Ken Livingstone and Bob Kiley are being offered £5 billion by the European Investment Bank to build a unified and publicly-owned future for the London Underground (Business, last week) the Mayor should stick to his guns and see off the Government's PPP via the courts.
fields.body:
Now that Ken Livingstone and Bob Kiley are being offered £5 billion by the European Investment Bank to build a unified and publicly-owned future for the London Underground (Business, last week) the Mayor should stick to his guns and see off the Government's PPP via the courts. He should ignore siren voices such as Will Hutton (Comment, last week), who undermines his 'left of centre' credentials by a tacit concession to privatisation.

For far too long politicians of all persuasions have remained shackled to the notion that the shibboleths of Thatcherism can deliver a full range of vital services, including public transport. Both New Labour and the Liberal Democrats have rationalised their conversion to free-market dogma, by calling it the Middle Way. There is no such thing!
Richard Denton-White
Portland, Dorset

webTitle: Stop being paranoid, Britain's parents told

fields.headline: Stop being paranoid, Britain's parents told
fields.standfirst: Controversial book says obsessive fears about children's safety are a bigger threat than bullies or paedophiles
fields.trailText: Controversial book says obsessive fears about children's safety are a bigger threat than bullies or paedophiles
fields.body:
A controversial new book on child-rearing to be published this week will urge parents to let their children take more risks and stop panicking about playground bullies and paedophiles.

The book's author, Frank Furedi, Reader in Sociology at the University of Kent, argues that parents' obsession with the safety of their children is more damaging than the risks themselves.

Paranoid Parenting: Abandon Your Anxieties And Be A Good Parent says parents should be wary of traditional 'child-centred' experts and urges the Government not to meddle in the family and parenting.

Penelope Leach, Britain's leading childcare authority and a target of the book, said: 'Almost everyone who writes about children has something to offer and I don't understand why we end up being so aggressive with each other.' However, she said that she had some fundamental disagreements with Paranoid Parenting : 'He concludes that governments should not get involved, but I cannot think of a more appropriate issue for policy than children's issues.'

Furedi is no stranger to controversy. He was a prominent member of the Revolutionary Communist Party, a Trotskyite group whose members founded the magazine Living Marxism or LM . The magazine was forced to close last year after it lost a libel case against ITN, which it had accused of doctoring footage of Serb concentration camps. LM was one of the few British publications sympathetic to the Serb cause.

In his new book, Furedi argues children are introduced to the culture of fear from the moment they are born. This begins with new measures to guard against hospital babynappers and is followed by guidelines about the minimal risk of cot death. Arriving home, they are surrounded by an army of midwives, health visitors and doctors. They then hem themselves in even more by buying childcare books. As their babies grow, their insecurity makes them easy prey for manufacturers.

Furedi is also concerned about the mixed messages in the news. One day a national charity will be castigating parents for turning their children into couch potatoes; the next, he argues, it will announce that letting children play outdoors on their own is a form of child abuse.

Add to this fears about accidents in the home and paedophiles, and it's small wonder many parents are inclined to be overprotective, says Furedi. Fear of abuse means no one dares to watch over children who are outside without their adult 'owners'. But in watching their backs, they are undermining what Furedi calls 'adult solidarity'. The casual neighbourhood safety net has disappeared, leaving children who do venture beyond their front doors far less protected than they were before. The author also attacks Dr Jane Healy, a childcare specialist who received publicity last year for telling a parenting conference that young children should not be put in front of computers because this changed the way their brains were wired. Supporters of Healy have said her argument was misrepresented in media scare stories that followed. They say that her central argument was that parents need not think they have to buy all the latest educational gizmos, as research showed the children learnt more when parents put their child on their knee and read them a storybook - a position not dissimilar to Furedi's.

According to Paranoid Parenting , it is cruel to keep children inside. They need room to explore the world around them, they need time to make their own friendships in their own way without an army of anxious adults monitoring their every movement.

But at the heart of the Furedi argument is an attack on government interference and in particular Labour's social policy: 'The politicisation of parenthood is a failure of the political imagination. Unable to work out effective social policies that can tackle the real problems facing British society, some politicians have been persuaded that if they can re-educate parents everything would turn out fine. Politicians, who have failed to provide Britain with a decent system of education, somehow assume that nevertheless they are fit to educate parents.'

Furedi told The Observer that he hopes the book will help parents put their anxieties in perspective, and understand that 'most of the really big issues that plague parents have little to do with problems instrinsic to child-rearing'. He believes they should turn their backs on experts and build on their own experiences. Rather than seek support from professionals in all matters, he'd like parents to pay more attention to friends and relatives familiar with their way of life.

Critics of Furedi, such as Guardian columnist Catherine Bennett, argue that he is simply giving parents more to worry about. Writing last week, Bennett quoted Furedi's concern that playground areas are now covered with rubber to limit the damage when a child falls. 'Should they, perhaps be constructed from something more challenging: shards of broken glass, say, or the traditional grit which was once so successful at lacerating young knees?'

webTitle: Revealed: Elvis, the king of karate

fields.headline: Revealed: Elvis, the king of karate
fields.trailText: He was the King of Rock 'n' Roll. But he now turns out to have been the king of karate too.
fields.body:
He was the King of Rock 'n' Roll. But he now turns out to have been the king of karate too.

A long-lost documentary made by Elvis Presley which is to have its world premiere next month will astonish many fans by revealing him to have been a highly-trained grand master of the Japanese martial art. The international interest in the film is likely to come as something of a shock to elderly residents of Worthing, the British seaside town chosen for the premiere.

The New Gladiator was shot three years before Presley's death in 1977, yet it shows the singer in prime physical condition, disproving the commonly-held belief that his health had deteriorated badly by then. He is shown performing perfect Kenpo karate self-defence techniques, involving gouging out eyes, breaking noses and disarming attackers.

His agility proves that 'the king' had attained the high levels of proficiency in the sport that he had claimed. This has always been disputed by biographers who, until now, have almost universally described him as a mere dabbler in the martial arts.

The original footage, which has been brought to this country by Presley's former karate partner, Wayne Carman, makes it clear that the star was an expert who took pleasure in teaching others.

'Elvis was an eighth-degree black belt in karate,' said Andrew Hearn, editor of the fanzine Essential Elvis , who is to stage the first public screening of The New Gladiator . 'It is a privilege for me to bring this unseen film to fans. It shows just how serious about karate he really was.'

The extraordinary documentary-style excerpt lasts 22 minutes and features Presley teaching a karate class. He jokes with students who ask him how to handle an assailant who holds a gun to your head. Presley prepares an elaborate manoeuvre, then simply drops to his knees, as though in prayer.

'Not even grand master can dodge bullet. Old Chinese Proverb,' he quips.

Carman, who was the United States karate champion in 1973 and appears with Presley in The New Gladiator , bought the discarded film from a private museum in Branson, Missouri, four years ago as soon as he realised what it was. So far he has only shown it to friends and, most recently, to Hearn when they met in America.

'There is one other copy of the film which was made out of courtesy for the Presley family,' said Hearn. 'The Graceland Estate has never released it or shown it.'

Presley decided to make the film at a time when martial arts were still viewed with suspicion. Hearn and Carman believe he wanted to spread the word about karate, as well as to star in and narrate the film, to have been shot near his Memphis home.

'Elvis was a great martial artist with 15 years' training,' Carman told The Observer . 'He told me he wanted to make this documentary to show people how important karate was. In 1973 and 1974 his health was up and down - he was crash-dieting - but people can see he was still in great shape.

'It has been a project of mine to bring this film to the public somehow ever since I found it.'

Carman, 51, recalls that after about only half an hour on the first day of filming, the star was called away and the project was never completed.

'It's never been screened before,' said Hearn. 'It was originally 25 minutes long, but Warner Brothers wanted three minutes, so they cut it off the reel and it's still missing.'

The film will be shown on a screen only 8ft tall at the Empress Suite, Worthing, on 28 April.

For more information about 'Essential Elvis Magazine' or the screening contact Andrew Hearn, on 01903 525917, or email him at elvisfanclub@compuserve.com.

webTitle: Letter:  Horror's cost

fields.headline: Horror's cost
fields.trailText: A loud, resounding 'yes' to Ros Coward (Comment, last week). I have no doubt that the constant bombardment with news of tragedies, murders, wars and accidents has reached media plague levels.
fields.body:
A loud, resounding 'yes' to Ros Coward (Comment, last week). I have no doubt that the constant bombardment with news of tragedies, murders, wars and accidents has reached media plague levels. And that we are either brutalised by it or traumatised. Every time we turn on the radio or television we are forced into being specta tors, and thereby participants, in horror. And if it's doing this to adults, what is it doing to children?
Jean Davis
London N6

webTitle: Letter:   Paulin off target

fields.headline: Paulin off target
fields.trailText: I am extremely puzzled by Tom Paulin's assertion that no one responded to the diarist Victor Klemperer's comparison of Zionists with the SS (Letters, last week).
fields.body:
I am extremely puzzled by Tom Paulin's assertion that no one responded to the diarist Victor Klemperer's comparison of Zionists with the SS (Letters, last week). In fact I wrote to him after his poem appeared in The Observer saying:'The Zionists Klemperer was referring to were the followers (among them Arnold Schoenberg and Ben Hecht) of the Revisionist thinker, Ze'ev Jabotinsky, who espoused the Greater Israel idea. The Revisionists were indeed accused of being fascistic, and in my novel, When I Lived in Modern Times , I say so explicitly, but I'm not sure if Klemperer would have described them in the same terms as the Nazis in 1945 once he knew exactly what the Third Reich was capable of. I have never heard that Jabotinsky was proposing a Final Solution to the problem of the Palestinians. At any rate their views have always been held by a small minority in Israel.'

Mr Paulin sent me a short reply. His response was that he thought a radio talk I gave on the Israeli poet, Yehuda Amichai, was 'slack and superficial'. Could be, but what has this got to do with Klemperer?
Linda Grant
London EC1

webTitle: Letters: Learning to live with animals

fields.headline: Learning to live with animals
fields.trailText: Cristina Odone believes that 'there is a hierarchy of beings and we humans stand at the top' (Comment, last week). As a human I would like to make it clear that I do not want to be associated with her trite, sentimental, superficial, narrow-minded opinions.
fields.body:
Cristina Odone believes that 'there is a hierarchy of beings and we humans stand at the top' (Comment, last week). As a human I would like to make it clear that I do not want to be associated with her trite, sentimental, superficial, narrow-minded opinions.

She might find it enlightening to reflect more deeply upon the concept of 'suffering'. Our planet is shrouded in suffering as Ms Odone and others justify human greed, ignorance and exploitation.

Reduction of suffering in one quarter by inflicting it in another does not achieve this end.
M. Jackson
Warrington, Cheshire

Like many other people, I prefer to view animals as co-existing with humans. I found Cristina Odone's comments offensive and narrow-minded. Many people make the rational decision not to include animal products in their diet for a variety of reasons - some also live within farming communities. It is neither 'dangerous' nor 'silly' to want to change out-dated, irrelevant practices such as blood sports.
Rosalind Godfrey
Boughton, Northants

Cristina Odone is right to pillory our muddled attitude to animals but wrong to assume that this absolves us from responsibility. I can think of no ethical justification for the brutal way in which we rear and slaughter animals to provide us with protein, which we could gain much more economically in other ways.
Peter Coltman
Leeds

In making comments like 'animals exist for us' and stating that humans exist atop 'a hierarchy of beings' Cristina Odone has unwittingly and eloquently demonstrated why this planet is facing such a major challenge. It is these attitudes that allow humans to decimate rain forests for logging, and to hunt and kill foxes.

I, for one, do not relish the prospect of living in a world bereft of diversity of life as it inevitably would be.
Simon Morgan
Brighton

Cristina Odone is wrong. To caring farmers a cow is not just a cow like a gear box on a factory production line. Yes, stock is reared for slaughter in the meat trade, but that does not mean the herds have not been cared for as individuals, often in their generations, and a real pride taken in their quality. Yes, the slaughtering of infected stock will be accepted, but there is and will be much heartbreak, as with BSE, to see years of work end like this.
Graham Jones
Axminster, East Devon

How can Cristina Odone be moved by the compassion of her God, yet show indifference to the suffering inflicted on non-human animals who have been created by that same God. Nothing exists in isolation.
Pat Griffin
Linton, Cambs

webTitle: Spain divided by battle for water plan

fields.headline: Spain divided by battle for water plan
fields.trailText: Rain has fallen relentlessly on Spain for the past few months, flooding fields and ruining crops. Yet water - or rather the lack of it - is a burning issue, and a tidal wave of angry Spaniards is due to descend on Madrid today, calling for a change in policy.
fields.body:
Rain has fallen relentlessly on Spain for the past few months, flooding fields and ruining crops. Yet water - or rather the lack of it - is a burning issue, and a tidal wave of angry Spaniards is due to descend on Madrid today, calling for a change in policy.

Some 200,000 people will protest against the government's proposed National Hydrological Plan, which would redistribute the country's water supplies - most controversially by piping water away from the Ebro river towards Barcelona and the popular south-eastern Mediterranean coast.

Lined up against the £14.2 billion plan are nearly all the people of Aragón, a vast region which makes up 10 per cent of Spain's territory but only 3 per cent of its population. The region feels that its only valuable resource, the Ebro, is to be siphoned off to feed the greedy south.

Hence the march. 'This is the rebellion of the Spanish interior,' says José Luis Trasobares, the deputy editor of the Heraldo de Aragón , the local newspaper based in Zaragoza. Trasobares says Aragón and other land-locked areas, such as Extremadura and Castilla-León, have been ignored by successive governments in favour of investing along the coastline.

The voracious appetite of northern Europeans for holiday or retirement homes in Spain, coupled with the growth in greenhouse farming in the arid lands bordering Almeria's beaches and in condos, golf courses and theme parks for tourists, means higher demand for water.

Aragón is not alone in its concern. The Catalan parliament last week voted to reject the plan, 200,000 marched against it in Barcelona, and protesters are expected in Madrid from Navarra, Extre-madura and even Portugal. Environmentalists say it would damage the very coastline that draws in the tourists.

'We are not against using Ebro water in other auton-omous communities,' says Rafael Escanero, president of Araga, a farmers' association that is backing the demonstration. 'If they need it to drink, we are ready to negotiate.' But, he adds, a century of broken promises and the lack of proper irrigation has eroded Aragón's population as well as its lands.

Araga, along with the local Confederation of Businessmen, unions and environmentalists, disputes government figures on the Ebro's flow, saying that the past year has been the wettest for a century in Spain. There are fears that in a dry year Aragón will lose out to the economic interests in the south.

Such fears are dismissed out of hand by Gustavo Alcalde, a leader in Aragón of Prime Minister José María Aznar's Popular Party, which hopes to push the scheme through parliament by the end of the year.

'In Aragón, water is more than a natural resource, it's a feeling,' he says. 'It is not only a motor to drive the economy but to power the survival of the community, so anything to do with water arouses great anxiety.' He says the plan will result in new irrigation systems and economic development for Aragón.

Alcalde says only time will tell who was right about the National Hydrological Plan. But the problem, say its opponents, is that by then the damage will have been done.

webTitle: France must wait for seven samurai of Paris suburbs

fields.headline: France must wait for seven samurai of Paris suburbs
fields.trailText: The new film by the acclaimed French director Luc Besson was set to be the box-office hit of the French spring. Yamakasi: The Modern-Day Samurai was due to open at 400 cinemas across the country next month. It's an adrenaline-pumped drama about seven tough kids from the Paris suburbs and their streetwise acrobatic skills.
fields.body:
The new film by the acclaimed French director Luc Besson was set to be the box-office hit of the French spring. Yamakasi: The Modern-Day Samurai was due to open at 400 cinemas across the country next month. It's an adrenaline-pumped drama about seven tough kids from the Paris suburbs and their streetwise acrobatic skills.

But the film's release has been thrown into doubt by a multi-million-pound legal battle. Besson, director of such French blockbusters as Le Grand Bleu, Subway, Nikita, Léon and Joan of Arc , who also made the Hollywood sci-fi extravaganza The Fifth Element , is being sued by the film's scriptwriters. They want the film banned until they are compensated for Besson's alleged mangling of their work.

A Paris court heard last week that Besson had written a 14-page treatment for the film, which he asked the scriptwriters Julien Sri and Philippe Lyon to develop. Sri was also to direct the film. But last summer Besson fired the pair, hired a new director and rewrote the screenplay himself. Sri and Lyon are suing him for breach of copyright, claiming 31 million francs (£30m) damages.

Besson's lawyer claimed the scriptwriters' attitude was 'professional suicide'. His production company, Leeloo Productions, says it would be too expensive to halt the release at this late stage, particularly as it was backed by a costly promotional campaign organised around an Easter release date.

An attempt to reach a compromise between the two parties has failed, and now judges in Paris are to decide whether to allow the film to open in France on 4 April.

The legal battle is a setback for Besson, who has been trying to establish himself as a film producer as well as director. His production efforts, the thrillers Taxi and Taxi 2 , have been huge successes in France if not elsewhere.

Yamakasi is the story of a group of seven 'spidermen of the suburbs', who train themselves in a new sport that involves leaping from high-rise apartment blocks before stopping their fall on protruding objects - bungee-jumping without the elastic.

The film, which has not yet been shown to the press, is believed to borrow heavily from French bandes dessinées (cartoons) and American comic-book superheroes, as well as Bruce Lee and Jackie Chan martial arts movies.

According to the film's website, each character has special powers. Baseball is good at throwing, L'Araignée can climb buildings like Spiderman, La Belette is as slippery as an eel, and so on. In the film, the Yamakasis' high-rise acrobatic skills are copied by young children. But when one child dies after a perilous leap, the Yamakasi are forced to re-evaluate their lifestyles.

So far, so tacky. But what, potentially, makes the film interesting is that it is based on an urban sport devised by real-life zonards from the outer Paris suburbs of Evry, Sarcelles and Noisy- le-Grand.

The seven Yamakasis claim to have developed an 'art of movement' in response to the alienating conditions of the estates in which they live. Aged between 16 and 26, the young men are from a range of ethnic backgrounds: African, Vietnamese, French, New Caledonian and Italian.

'We call ourselves Yama- kasi because that is the word in the Zairean language of Lingala meaning strong spirit, strong body and strong man,' said one of the Yamakasi. 'That's what we're like. We're urban surfers. Just as the surfer tames the waves, we tame the estates'.

'Originally we were proficient in martial arts, but that didn't satisfy us. So, for the past seven years, we have developed this art of movement. It consists in adapting oneself to the urban environment and involves training for at least six hours a day.'

The Yamakasis - Belle Williams, 17, Belle Chau, 21, N'guba boyeke Guilain, 22, Diouf Malik, 22, Perriere Charles, 23, Piemontesi Laurent, 26, and Hnautra Yann, 26 - argue that their jumping is a philosophy. 'We're trying to invent another way of living on council estates so that we are not alienated from our environment or our bodies.'

'Yes, there is a risk in our jumps,' said one Yamakasi. 'But risk helps us to progress. Risk gives us an education in how to live.'

Their website gives a breakdown of the jumps they practise - the cat jump, the release, the tic-tac among them. Few involve leaping from high buildings, but all require extraordinary agility.

Whether Besson's film is faithful to the real-life Yamakasi remains to be seen, as does the possibility that it will provoke real-life imitators.

Filmed last year in a housing development south of Paris, the picture is believed to have young people from the suburbs as extras, while the leading roles were taken by professional actors. It is the latest in a series of feature films about the dysfunctional lives of young people in the troubled high-rise estates that ring Paris. The trend started in 1995 with Mathieu Kassovitz's film La Haine (Hate), about three kids from the suburbs on a fateful spree in the capital. Last year La Squale (meaning a girl tearaway), directed by a former secondary school teacher who was alarmed at what he had witnessed in Sarcelles, recounted the barbaric abuse of young girls in the suburbs.

Besson's film is expected to have a more positive message from the suburbs, blighted recently by a spate of teenage gang killings.

His current court dispute is the latest in a career pitted with legal wrangles.

webTitle: British firms fan flames of war

fields.headline: British firms fan flames of war
fields.standfirst: Western cash is pouring into oilfields intensifying a bloody 18-year conflict
fields.trailText: Liu Liu saw the army lorries roll into Chotyiel, the village in Western Upper Nile that had been his home for 80 years. As soldiers jumped out of the lorries, firing all around, helicopter gunships appeared overhead. Liu Liu gathered six of his grandchildren and fled into the forest.
fields.body:
Liu Liu saw the army lorries roll into Chotyiel, the village in Western Upper Nile that had been his home for 80 years. As soldiers jumped out of the lorries, firing all around, helicopter gunships appeared overhead. Liu Liu gathered six of his grandchildren and fled into the forest.

Months later, in the temporary safety of Nhialdiu, almost 100 miles away, he described what happened next: 'We saw soldiers burning the houses. It was impossible to get anything from the village because the helicopters shot at you if they saw you. We made a small hole for the children and put a blanket on top. We stayed in that forest for 20 days with nothing to eat but wild fruits.'

A few weeks after we met, the government's local militia allies set fire to Nhialdiu and all the surrounding villages. Almost 20,000 people fled into the bush. Those who were unable to escape - the old, the sick and the very young - were burnt alive in their huts.

This is the biggest scorched-earth campaign in Sudan's 18-year civil war. The government's interest is in what lies underneath these torched villages. Britain - and some of its most illustrious companies, including Rolls-Royce - has an interest in this too.

Last week a European-led oil consortium announced a 'significant discovery' of 'excellent quality' oil in the Western Upper Nile. The discovery came barely a month after the opening of a 50-mile all-weather road linking the consortium's base camp to its wells.

A press release announcing the completion of the road made no mention of a year-long government offensive that depopulated the road and its environs; no mention of villages such as Chotyiel and the tens of thousands of defenceless civilians displaced from them; no men tion of the miles of scorched earth that can be seen by anyone flying over the road.

'All the villages that once existed along the road have been razed by the govern ment,' says a relief worker prohibited from speaking out publicly. 'The only signs of life are the lorries travelling at high speed back and forth to the oilfield. Small military garrisons are clearly visible every five kilometres.'

Today Chotyiel is no more than an army post called Kilo 15 on Oil Road 7. Taban Deng, a member of the Nuer tribe and a native of Chotyiel, was Minister of State for Roads until he defected from the government early this year, accusing it of spending oil revenue on arms rather than development.

'The only primary school and clinic for 80,000 people were in Chotyiel,' he said in an interview in Nairobi. 'You cannot get a trace of Chotyiel now. There are no huts, no school. They have been destroyed and burnt down. The war has become economic. It is for oil.'

Sudan has officially estimated there are reserves of more than two billion barrels of oil, mostly in the African South, a neglected region in revolt since the Sudan People's Liberation Army took up arms against the ruling Arab North in 1983. With the SPLA opposed to oil exploration in the absence of peace, foreign companies buying into Sudanese oil have sought the protection of the government's armed forces.

Oil money has transformed a war that has already killed two million from a bush conflict into a ruthless, mechanised counter-insurgency. Since Sudan began exporting oil 18 months ago, its military budget has doubled and its army has turned the oilfields into a human wasteland. Hundreds of thousands of southerners have been displaced, to be pushed ever further away by Khartoum's refusal to allow the United Nations to fly food and medicine to front-line areas.

UN officials warn that many areas of southern Sudan face a threat of famine as a result of the oil war and fighting between a southern group armed by the government and a section of the SPLA that is responding to burning with burning.

'By provoking divisions among the Nuer and other southerners, Khartoum can develop the rich oil resources that lie beneath Nuer territory,' Human Rights Watch said last week when appealing to the US government to mediate in the conflict. 'In addition to the army, the other organised military players sharing the blame for this looming disaster are the government-backed Nuer militias.'

In a report on the oil war entitled The Scorched Earth , to be published this week, Christian Aid warns that what is happening in the Upper Nile is only a foretaste of what could happen all across the South if the world continues to turn a blind eye to attacks on civilians in the name of profit. Government intentions are signalled by the sale of oil concessions across the South as far as the Ugandan border.

Christian Aid calls on foreign companies to suspend their operations in Sudan as they lend the government spurious credibility. It says oil company facilities such as roads and airstrips are used by the government for military purposes, while oil revenue increases its ability to wage war.

Although British companies are not drilling for oil, British technology plays a crucial role. But the British companies - prime among them being Rolls-Royce and Weir Pumps of Glasgow - like to keep their involvement quiet.

Rolls-Royce has never made any announcement about its work in Sudan. In a series of emails, the company acknowledged its involvement - 34 diesel engines used to generate power and to pump oil along the pipeline, as well as operational and maintenance support to the pipeline infrastructure - but declined to comment on the human rights implications of helping the government to pump oil, for reasons 'of corporate, operational and commercial sensitivity'.

Weir Pumps, which built the pumping stations for the pipeline, issued a press release about a first £20 million contract in 1998, but said nothing about a second. A spokesman said the company 'is not prepared to talk about it for commercially confidential reasons'.

A Foreign Office spokes-man told The Observer : 'Britain is not "promoting" investment' in the Sudan oil industry. But the Government's commitment to 'constructive engagement' with Sudan has failed to dissuade Khartoum from bombing more than 100 civilian targets in the past eight months, among them schools, hospitals, relief compounds and churches.

'The British Government has sent a very mixed message to the Sudanese government,' said Jemera Rone of Human Rights Watch. 'While it claims to support human rights and peace, it is nevertheless doing nothing to prevent British companies becoming deeply involved in the oil industry in Sudan. Khartoum picks and chooses what it wants to hear. And the sound of pennies dropping into the piggy bank is the loudest sound it hears.'

Taban Deng was governor of Unity state, at the heart of the oil industry, when the Red Sea pipeline opened. He fought for southerners to be involved in the industry - through work and direct contact with the oil companies - until Khartoum's closest southern ally, General Paulino Matip, gave him four hours to leave the state or face the consequences.

'It was a real threat to kill me,' Deng said. 'The ideas of southerners are not being taken into the policies of oil exploration. Instead we are being killed in Unity state. In the bush you run away or you are shot, burnt and killed. Inside the towns they make life difficult for you. Two of my Ministers were killed by the army.'

Deng appealed to Britain to interest itself in peace - not oil. 'Without British technology, that oil cannot come out of the ground and it cannot be pumped through the pipe-line,' he said. 'Supporting the oil industry is supporting war.'

Deng said Sudan's future was bleak if greed for profit continued to override concern for human life. 'People will fight back because this is their land,' he said. 'More death, more killing, more suffering to the civilian population.'

Julie Flint's report from Sudan will be broadcast on Channel 4 News tomorrow at 7pm.

webTitle: Elections put women in the spotlight

fields.headline: Elections put women in the spotlight
fields.trailText: When France's voters go to the polls in local elections today, they will be confronted by something very strange on their ballot papers - 50 per cent of the candidates will be women.
fields.body:
When France's voters go to the polls in local elections today, they will be confronted by something very strange on their ballot papers - 50 per cent of the candidates will be women.

Today's first round of voting for mayors and councillors will be the first test of a law passed last year that requires parties to field as many women candidates as men.

The law was introduced because of French embarrassment over the dearth of female politicians. At present 33,380 French mayors are men, 2,939 women. Only 8.7 per cent of the country's national politicians are female.

True, socialist Prime Minister Lionel Jospin has put talented women politicians in senior cabinet posts - Elisabeth Guigou at employment, Marylise Lebranchu at justice, Dominique Voynet at environment. Nonetheless, of countries in the European Union, France has the lowest proportion of female politicians, behind Sweden, which has 45 per cent, and below Italy and Greece, which have more than 10 per cent. There has been only one woman prime minister in France - Edith Cresson in the early Nineties.

webTitle: The Tiger is tamed by a golf ball revolution

fields.headline: The Tiger is tamed by a golf ball revolution
fields.standfirst: Why has the world No 1 lost his aura of invincibility? Because he has been left trailing in a technology war
fields.trailText: He is known as the genius of the greens, the phenomenon of the fairways and the most awesome golfer ever. But the supposedly unbeatable Tiger Woods has apparently been cut down to size by a golf ball he is not allowed to touch.
fields.body:
He is known as the genius of the greens, the phenomenon of the fairways and the most awesome golfer ever. But the supposedly unbeatable Tiger Woods has apparently been cut down to size by a golf ball he is not allowed to touch.

After months of winning everything in sight, Woods has suddenly lost his aura of invincibility. Rivals worried that they would never win a major tournament again are at last experiencing the rare taste of victory.

The golf world has been turned upside down by the introduction of a revolutionary solid-core ball which is helping all Woods's competitors hit their shots far greater distances. The Titleist Pro VI has given players who were previously no-hopers the chance of a swift counter-punch at the champion.

'For years everyone has been looking for the game's Holy Grail, a ball that offers maximum distance and then allows a decent player to caress it softly on to the green', said one of Titleist's technicians. 'Now the Titleist players have, if not the Holy Grail, the closest anyone has come to finding it so far.'

The situation is rich with irony. When last year Woods began using a solid-core ball made by Nike, his sponsors, his performances improved from being simply magnificent to utterly awesome. He won 10 tournaments during 2000, became the first player to win three of golf's four majors in a row, and pocketed millions in prize money.

Davis Love, one of the circuit's leading players, said Woods's use of the Nike ball gave him a distinct advantage and helped explain why he swept all before him.

Now almost all Woods's rivals are playing the solid-core ball made by Titleist which is proving even more effective than the Nike version. Golfers using it have suddenly begun hitting their drives dozens of yards further. After months of frustration at not being able to catch the Tiger, they are enjoying the fact that the tables have been turned.

'Last summer Tiger had the ball we all wanted. We were dying to get our hands on it, but we had to wait our turn,' said Love.

'The first time I put it in play I was jacked up. It was a new toy, a new excitement. Now we've got the perceived advantage, and sometimes that perception can make you play better.'

Phil Mickleson, another leading pro, is also delighted. 'I honestly believe that if you are not playing with this golf ball then you are at a distinct disadvantage to the entire field,' he said.

Woods is unable to switch to Titleist's ball because he has a $20 million-a-year deal with Nike which requires him to use their balls and wear their clothing. Titleist are delighted at their ball's success, as the golf equipment market worldwide is worth billions of pounds.

The Pro V1 was introduced in the United States late last year. Subsequently, Billy Andrade became the first of ten players in seven weeks on six different golf tours to win a 2000 title using it. Previously pedestrian players suddenly became title-winners.

Some golfers rate its emergence as one of the game's great leap forwards, as significant as the switch from wooden to iron clubs.

Woods has not won an event since the Pro V1 arrived. Where previously the 25-year-old dominated the rankings, now a mere golf ball is doing so. With three top ten finishes in five events this year, the undisputed best golfer in the world is not suffering a serious slump. His stroke average is the same as a year ago.

Woods is having to get used to the fact that other golfers are now performing as well as, and often better than, him. With the US Masters next month, it is a bad time to be losing golf's latest outbreak of technology wars.

Asked if Woods was concerned at the decline in his fortunes and the apparently narrowing gap between himself and the pursuing pack, Mark Steinberg, the player's agent, declined to comment.
