webTitle: Focus: Double jeopardy

fields.headline: 'Killers' fear justice at last
fields.standfirst: The law that says no one acquitted of a crime can be tried for it again is under threat. The families of some victims now believe justice is close. Yvonne Roberts reports.
fields.trailText: The law that says no one acquitted of a crime can be tried for it again is under threat.   The families of some victims now believe justice is close.Yvonne Roberts reports.
fields.body:
Nikki Allan, aged seven, vanished on 7 October, 1992. Her body was found the following day near her home in Sunderland. She had been stabbed 37 times. A neighbour, George Heron, 22, was arrested and charged with murder but was cleared after the judge ruled his confession had been obtained under duress. The police maintained Heron knew details of the killing to which only the murderer could be privy.

Sharon Prest, the mother of Nikki, subsequently brought a civil case and was awarded damages. If proposals put forward by the Law Commission last Tuesday become law, then Heron and up to 10 others acquitted of child murders may find themselves facing a second trial for the crime for which they originally walked free.

A review of the rule of double jeopardy, which states that no one who has been convicted or acquitted of an offence can be tried a second time on the same facts, was recommended by Sir William Macpherson after the inquiry into Stephen Lawrence's death. He suggested: 'Perhaps in modern times such absolute protection may sometimes lead to injustice.'

The Law Commission has now recommended that, in murder cases only, double jeopardy should be set aside when there is fresh and 'compelling' evidence; when a judge has ruled crucial evidence inadmissible, making it impossible for the Crown to proceed; and when there has been a 'tainted acquittal' as a result of the intimidation of witnesses or jurors.

The change should be retrospective. In theory, this could allow the retrial of three of the five suspects in the Stephen Lawrence kill-ing. According to the National Crime Faculty, there are at least 35 other murder investigations which have led to an acquittal and in which fresh forensic evidence could justify a second trial.

In addition, fresh forensic evidence may also lead to the retrial of 10 child murderers whose details are on the 'Catchem' national database run by Detective Inspector Chuck Burton of Derbyshire Police. Catchem is an acronym which stands for the Centralised Analytical Team Collating Homicide Expertise and Management.

Catchem records a mass of details from 40 years of child homicide. It was established in 1986 as part of the national police effort to catch Robert Black, eventually given 10 life sentences in 1994 for the deaths of three young girls. Detective Inspector Burton says he is 'optimistic' that, on the strength of new forensic evidence, second trials may prove successful. 'What can be more galling,' he asks, 'than to know that a guilty man remains free?'

New procedures now used by the Forensic Science Services, among them advances in DNA, corneal images and ear prints, provide the most telling arguments for change. Objections have come from, among others, the Criminal Bar Association, the Law Society and Liberty, the civil rights organisation. They argue a second chance may encourage police incompetence; juries could be influenced by an appeal court's ordering a second trial; and 'foolproof' DNA evidence has already figured in a number of miscarriages of justice.

John Wadham, director of Liberty, points out there have been 85 acts of parliament in the past 20 years, each eroding the rights of the individual. 'Everyone assumes this is about convicting guilty people - but what if the individual is innocent?'

Those in favour of the Law Commission's recommendations argue that public confidence is just as surely shaken by a system that repeatedly fails to bring offenders to justice as it is by the spectacle of innocent people being released from jail for wrongful convictions.

The secondary victims of crime, the families of those murdered who, at times, encounter mediocre police investigations, the abysmal standards of the Crown Prosecution Service and the inexplicable rulings of some judges, believe that to set aside the double jeopardy rule would provide the first clear sign that they were no longer battling alone.

In 1989, Ann Ming's daughter, Julie Hogg, aged 23, worked as a pizza delivery girl in Billingham, Stockton on Tees. Mother and daughter were close. On 16 November, 1989, Julie went missing. Her mother said: 'Her disappearance was totally, totally, out of character.'

A forensic team spent five days unsuccessfully examining Julie's house. It remained locked up for three months. In February 1990, Julie's husband, Andrew, returned and detected a strange smell in the bathroom. Ann went to investigate. She accidentally dislodged a panel on the side of the bath and saw the body of her daughter.

'Since then, we've had to battle every step of the way on our own,' she said last week. 'The Law Commission has given us our first glimmer of hope. If we can see my daughter's killer finally convicted then, 11 years after her death, we will finally have closure on a living nightmare.'

BIlly Dunlop, an acquaintance of Julie, was put on trial in 1991 and pleaded not guilty to murder. Julie's house keys with Dunlop's fingerprints were found in his lodging house; the blanket around her body revealed fibres from Dunlop's jumper, semen stains and strands of hair. Cause of death could not be established because the body was so decomposed.

A second trial was ordered because the first jury failed to agree. On the second occa sion, the judge allowed the jury only five hours to reach a unanimous or majority verdict. When they failed, Dunlop was acquitted.

In 1998 Dunlop was given a seven-year sentence for grievous bodily harm after attacking a couple with a knife and a baseball bat. In Moreland Prison, he befriended a woman prison officer and in over 60 hours of taped conversation explained how he had strangled Julie Hogg and mutilated her body. He was subsequently convicted on two counts of perjury and given two six-year sentences to run concurrently. In passing sentence, the judge said he was unable to take into consideration Dunlop's danger to the public or the murder of Julie Hogg.

Dunlop begins serving the perjury sentence in 2003, after completing his existing sentence. In the meantime, the Mings have applied to change the cause of death on their daughter's death certificate from 'not ascertainable' to 'strangulation'.

Lawyers have told them that, under the Human Rights Act, they have to request Dunlop's permission before the change can be made. 'Billy Dunlop symbolises how easy it is to make a mockery of the British justice system,' said Mrs Ming. 'I want him convicted for the murder of my daughter and then I begin again.'

She has given up her job as a nurse and suffers from post- traumatic stress disorder. A survey last year by the charity Victim's Voice of 114 families affected by murder, revealed that 48 per cent of family members had suffered physical or mental ill health; one in three had lost a job and 31 per cent had experienced family breakdown. Trauma is even more acute when individuals are seen as literally getting away with murder.

In 1908, Tony Allis bought Beechwood Cottage, near King's Stanley in Gloucestershire. The cottage had no access for vehicles. Alliss asked his neighbour, Terence Maule, if he could pay for right of way across his land. Maule refused. Eventually Alliss acquired right of way through a wood, Penn Wood, in return for general maintenance.

In 1990, Tony Alliss and a friend bought the wood, guaranteeing Alliss right of way. Several times in the months up to July of that year, Terence Maule tried to claim some of the wood, erecting a fence. Alliss's solicitor requested that the fence should be taken down. Maule did nothing, claiming the boundary had existed for 20 years. Alliss took the fence down, Maule put it back again.

Maule alleged Alliss had attacked him once. Alliss, in turn, made two complaints to police that Maule had fired a shotgun over his head. On the the evening of 26 July, 1990, ambulance men were called to the wood. They found Tony Alliss dying from two gunshot wounds. As they attended to him, another shot was fired. The ambulance men ran for cover. Armed police surrounded Sandpit Farm, home of Terence Maule and his 19-year-old son, Graig. Graig surrendered after a three-and-a-half hour siege.

In interviews read out in Bristol Crown Court, at the Maules' murder trial in June 1991, they said they had come across Alliss dismantling the fence. They had taken guns for their protection. Alliss, unarmed, had allegedly grabbed a gun and struggled with Terence Maule. Graig Maule, in defence of his father, had accidentally hit Alliss. Terence Maule called for an ambulance. The Maules alleged that Alliss's 14-year-old son Leigh, who had gone to discover the cause of the shot, had been accidentally wounded 20 minutes later.

Mr Justice Schiemann stopped the trial at the end of the prosecution evidence, ordering the jury to acquit. He ruled that the prosecution had failed to prove an agreement to kill or to cause grievous bodily harm. He went on to praise how Graig Maule had acted 'in the circumstances', saying his father could be 'proud of him'. Graig Maule pleaded guilty to possessing a shotgun without a certificate, and his father guilty to aiding and abetting his son in the possession. They were given absolute discharges and the guns were confiscated.

Bob Alliss said his brother had taken down the fence on his own land only to be confronted with the Maules, both armed with shotguns. Leigh had been injured by the same gun that had killed his father. Leigh said: 'I heard a voice that sounded like Graig Maule's, saying 'Leigh', then I was shot.'

Seven weeks after the trial, the Maules were fined £50 for trespass and ordered to pay £500 for damage to trees on land they had claimed they had owned for 20 years. An injunction was also imposed upon them to prevent them from going back into the woods.

In 1993, Tony Alliss's widow, Joyce Alliss, was awarded £150,000 from the Criminal Injuries Compensation Board. It decided that Tony Alliss had died unlawfully: 'His conduct in no way contributed to the incident or to his death.'

In November, Leigh Alliss begins a civil case against the Maules that, crucially, will introduce fresh ballistic forensic evidence questioning whether Tony's wounds could have been received in a fight. Hannah Rutterford, Leigh Alliss's solicitor, said: 'The judge refused details of the boundary dispute to be heard on the grounds that it didn't matter. We think it's very relevant indeed.

'Tony Alliss was also portrayed as a big, intimidating person when we have witnesses who give a very different view. Until the double jeopardy rule is set aside, this is the only way the Allisses can obtain a fair trial and an opportunity for the evidence of the other side to be properly scrutinised.' Bob Alliss, a builder, has been unable to work for nine years. 'I shall pursue this case until my dying breath,' he said.

'I know you can't bring back the dead, but my brother was unarmed. He was shot on his own land from both barrels of an unlicensed shotgun. I cannot believe that there's nothing in law that says that's wrong.'

Paul Boateng, Home Office Minister, has pointed out that the Criminal Cases Review Commission considers miscarriages of justice.

'In contrast, if a victim believes there has been a wrongful acquittal, there is no mechanism for correcting that miscarriage... and no right of appeal against judicial decisions that lead to a termination of proceedings.'

Kent's Chief Constable, David Phillips, chairman of the crime committee of the Association of Chief Constables, told the House of Commons home affairs committee reporting on the double jeopardy ruling: 'I am always suspicious of lofty principles that we are encouraged to believe should stand alone.

'In most of these questions there are competing principles. One is the notion that in general there should be finality to prosecutions and the other is that there is real interest in justice.'

In interviews read out in Bristol Crown Court, at the Maules' murder trial in June 1991, they said they had come across Alliss dismantling the fence. They had taken guns for their protection. Alliss, unarmed, had allegedly grabbed a gun and struggled with Terence Maule. Graig Maule, in defence of his father, had accidentally hit Alliss. Terence Maule called for an ambulance. The Maules alleged that Alliss's 14-year-old son Leigh, who had gone to discover the cause of the shot, had been accidentally wounded 20 minutes later. Mr Justice Schiemann stopped the trial at the end of the prosecution evidence, ordering the jury to acquit. He ruled that the prosecution had failed to prove an agreement to kill or to cause grievous bodily harm. He went on to praise how Graig Maule had acted 'in the circumstances', saying his father could be 'proud of him'. Graig Maule pleaded guilty to possessing a shotgun without a certificate, and his father guilty to aiding and abetting his son in the possession. They were given absolute discharges and the guns were confiscated. Bob Alliss said his brother had taken down the fence on his own land only to be confronted with the Maules, both armed with shotguns. Leigh had been injured by the same gun that had killed his father. Leigh said: 'I heard a voice that sounded like Graig Maule's, saying 'Leigh', then I was shot.' Seven weeks after the trial, the Maules were fined £50 for trespass and ordered to pay £500 for damage to trees on land they had claimed they had owned for 20 years. An injunction was also imposed upon them to prevent them from going back into the woods. In 1993, Tony Alliss's widow, Joyce Alliss, was awarded £150,000 from the Criminal Injuries Compensation Board. It decided that Tony Alliss had died unlawfully: 'His conduct in no way contributed to the incident or to his death.' In November, Leigh Alliss begins a civil case against the Maules that, crucially, will introduce fresh ballistic forensic evidence questioning whether Tony's wounds could have been received in a fight. Hannah Rutterford, Leigh Alliss's solicitor, said: 'The judge refused details of the boundary dispute to be heard on the grounds that it didn't matter. We think it's very relevant indeed. 'Tony Alliss was also portrayed as a big, intimidating person when we have witnesses who give a very different view. Until the double jeopardy rule is set aside, this is the only way the Allisses can obtain a fair trial and an opportunity for the evidence of the other side to be properly scrutinised.' Bob Alliss, a builder, has been unable to work for nine years. 'I shall pursue this case until my dying breath,' he said. 'I know you can't bring back the dead, but my brother was unarmed. He was shot on his own land from both barrels of an unlicensed shotgun. I cannot believe that there's nothing in law that says that's wrong.' Paul Boateng, Home Office Minister, has pointed out that the Criminal Cases Review Commission considers miscarriages of justice. 'In contrast, if a victim believes there has been a wrongful acquittal, there is no mechanism for correcting that miscarriage... and no right of appeal against judicial decisions that lead to a termination of proceedings.' Kent's Chief Constable, David Phillips, chairman of the crime committee of the Association of Chief Constables, told the House of Commons home affairs committee reporting on the double jeopardy ruling: 'I am always suspicious of lofty principles that we are encouraged to believe should stand alone. 'In most of these questions there are competing principles. One is the notion that in general there should be finality to prosecutions and the other is that there is real interest in justice.'

webTitle: 'No excuse' for Marchioness mutilations

fields.headline: 'No excuse' for Marchioness mutilations
fields.trailText: Victims of the Marchioness riverboat tragedy were unnecessarily mutilated in the rush to identify them, a harrowing report is expected to show. Cutting off the hands of many of the 51 people who drowned - without relatives' knowledge or agreement - in order to take fingerprints was unacceptable, the report will say.
fields.body:
Victims of the Marchioness riverboat tragedy were unnecessarily mutilated in the rush to identify them, a harrowing report is expected to show. Cutting off the hands of many of the 51 people who drowned - without relatives' knowledge or agreement - in order to take fingerprints was unacceptable, the report will say.

The distress of relatives was compounded by being refused permission to see the bodies for a final farewell. In at least one case the severed hands went astray, only to be found four years later in a black plastic bin liner buried in a mortuary freezer. Several families are now fighting for the right to exhume graves to check if bodies were complete when buried.

The report of the public inquiry by Lord Justice Clarke, which has been delivered to Deputy Prime Minister John Pres-cott, will be published this month. It is set to recommend that removal of hands should only be a last resort where other methods of identification fail, and that families should be consulted.

It is also expected to criticise the role of Dr Paul Knapman, the coroner involved, and back better training for coroners. 'There was really no justification for what happened to these people,' said one Whitehall source who has seen the findings.

The Marchioness, crammed with young partygoers, sank in August 1989 after colliding on the Thames with a dredger, the Bowbelle. Relatives and survivors have fought for more than 11 years to expose the truth about the disaster and its aftermath.

A report into the causes of the accident ordered by Prescott was published last year, but that prompted a second investigation into the process of identification of the bodies.

Relatives found out about the removal of the hands by accident when a funeral director told the family of Simon Senior that his hands were missing. Only when the coroner's office was asked did it emerge that the same was true of 24 others. Margaret Lockwood-Croft, chair of the Marchioness Action Group, found that her son Shaun was among them in a list from the coroner's office faxed to her at a local printing shop.

'I came home and was sick. It has been absolutely devastating for the families but had we been approached from the beginning, told there was going to be a post mortem and why, and what they were going to do, the majority of us would have probably accepted it,' she says.

'But then if we had been informed many of us would have asked why, because there are other ways of identification. We could have avoided this.'

Knapman, who is still the coroner for Westminster, has fiercely defended his actions. Giving evidence to the inquiry, he apologised to the families and conceded some hands were unnecessarily severed but said he was not solely responsible. He also expressed surprise that the practice had caused outrage.

He was on holiday in Devon when the boat sank and returned to London to give initial instructions, granting authority to remove hands where necessary, but went back on holiday leaving his deputy, Dr William Dolman, in day-to-day charge. Dolman has denied knowledge of the removal of hands.

The report will also make clear that relatives have a right to spend time with the bodies of lost loved ones.

webTitle: Admen bid to clean up 'family hour' television

fields.headline: Admen bid to clean up 'family hour' television
fields.standfirst: Big businesses, including Coca-Cola and Kellogg, want no sex or violence on US TV shows before 9pm - and they are using $12bn of cash muscle to bring the networks to heel
fields.trailText: Some of the world's top companies and advertising agencies have joined forces to clean prime-time American television of what they see as gratuitous sex and violence, promoting instead a return to 'family viewing'.
fields.body:
Some of the world's top companies and advertising agencies have joined forces to clean prime-time American television of what they see as gratuitous sex and violence, promoting instead a return to 'family viewing'.

A mighty coalition, the 'Family Friendly Programming Forum', including Coca-Cola, Proctor & Gamble, Johnson & Johnson, General Motors, Ford, Kellogg, Nestlé and McDonald's, plans to use the muscle its $12 billion-worth of advertising buys to nurture programmes during a sacrosanct 'family hour' between 8 and 9pm.

The aim is to use their clout with the networks to develop a 'template' for what one of the biggest names in US advertising, Bill Cella of Universal McCann, calls 'television the whole family can watch together, without people having to explain to their kids what an orgasm is'.

Cella and leading executives from companies that make up the forum are discussing with three of the networks (a fourth is in the wings) the next autumn schedules, and their message is clear: if scripts stray too far from the forum's 'mission statement' on quality and content, their shows may not get the advertising they need.

'This is not right-wing proselytising,' says Cella, who handles $3 billion-worth of corporate television advertising a year, 'this is meeting a need'.

The forum has established a body to commission and develop scripts for 'family-friendly' programmes to present to the networks, set up a scholarship scheme in Hollywood encouraging scriptwriters to deliver quality family programmes, and launched a televised award ceremony for 'family' programmes.

One of the shows propelled by the forum is already established during prime time: The Gilmore Girls , about a one-time teenaged mother who has struggled to raise her daughter. The show holds its own against Survivors and Friends which has become a particular target of the forum's crusade. Its poster-boy star Matthew Perry was plastered across the cover of People magazine after his admission to a detoxification clinic, leaving the programme struggling to complete filming its latest run.

'It simply is not an eight o'clock show,' says Cella. 'It's a successful show and a great show, but it's not for kids. They talk about sex and orgasms - how are you supposed to explain that to your seven-year-old?'

Another series singled out by Cella is the Boston Public show 'in which you see some guy firing off a gun in school; which is happening in real life' - during a week that saw in California and Pennsylvania two more in America's grim series of school shootings.

The forum was co-founded by a captain of American industry - Proctor & Gamble's Bob Wehling - in 1998, since when it has grown to represent 43 of the world's biggest companies.

Wehling recalls how he 'raised six girls during the period when television went steadily from good family programming to shows that you had to think twice about sponsoring'.

By the end of the 1990s, he says, the company found itself with 'fewer and fewer options' of programmes during which to advertise that were not in breach of 'guidelines we had drawn up in the 1950s, which would not surprise you, on gratuitous sex, violence, mockery of the clergy and racial groups' and other offensive content.

Wehling joined Andrea Alstrup, vice-president of Johnson & Johnson, who made a speech launching the forum at a gathering of advertising executives in New York, quoted in Brill's Content magazine: 'Do we really need to continue to support with our advertising,' she said, 'a constant barrage of media that appeals to the lowest common denominators of values? I emphatically say that we do not'.

webTitle: Looted Afghan art smuggled to London

fields.headline: Looted Afghan art smuggled to London
fields.trailText: Scores of artefacts looted from archaeological sites in Afghanistan are being smuggled to Britain and sold to wealthy clients.
fields.body:
Scores of artefacts looted from archaeological sites in Afghanistan are being smuggled to Britain and sold to wealthy clients.

With a single statue worth up to £50,000, the trade is worth hundreds of thousands of pounds each year. London is one of the key centres for the sale of works illicitly excavated in the war-torn state.

Investigators believe there is a 'loose network' of dealers who keep a low profile and, working from home, sell to collectors all over the world.

'You can have deals worth thousands and thousands taking place in someone's front room,' said Charles Hill, an art risk consultant and former head of Scotland Yard's arts and antiquities squad.

'The buyers may be British or American or from the Far East. The works are often small and easily trans portable. That's very difficult for police.' Major auction houses and dealers are careful to avoid smuggled or illegally excavated material, forcing the trade underground, Hill said.

Interest in early Afghan art has been boosted by the attempt by the Taliban, the Islamic militia which rules Afghanistan, to destroy thousands of statues, including two 150ft Buddhas carved into a mountain in Bamiyan.

Governments, museums and private clients have offered to buy them from the Taliban rather than see the works, which are more than 1,400 years old, smashed.

The high sums mentioned have been noticed by those involved in the racket. Law enforcement officers in Pakistan say they are prepared for a fresh wave of trafficking.

'Because of this new issue of the statues we will be looking for any smugglers,' said Major-General Taj-ul Haq, commander of the 30,000-strong Frontier Corps which patrols the mountainous border with Afghanistan. British police sources told The Observer they were 'mindful' of the threat. 'We are watching it carefully,' said one senior policeman. Most major traffickers of Afghan art are based in the Pakistani frontier city of Peshawar. Freelance collectors, often off-duty guerrillas or villagers looking to make quick cash, bring items from Afghanistan to sell for a pittance.

It is easy for the dealers, who often have connections in the drugs trade, to smuggle the art out and sell it at hugely inflated prices.

The size of the trade - and the UK's key role - was revealed two years ago when a consignment of Afghan art destined for London, Frankfurt and Dubai was seized at Peshawar airport. In six metal boxes were 2,500 items including coins, silver daggers, gold jewellery and glazed tiles. There were also dozens of items from the Buddhist Gandaharan civilisation, which fused Indian and Greek styles more than 1,500 years ago.

Two of the crates were addressed to a forwarding agency in London which specialises in moving fine art.

Senior officials in Pakistan had been paid to allow the shipment out of the country. The looted works are under government guard, but there are concerns that, given the corruption endemic in Pakistan, much of it will fall back into the hands of smugglers.

There are also fears that the bulk of the collection once in Kabul Museum, looted during fighting between Afghan groups in the early Nineties, is now in smugglers' or collectors' hands. The most famous exhibits were the Bagram ivories, a series of exquisite Indian panels nearly 2,000 years old, excavated by French archaeologists in the Thirties.

Recently a London-based dealer was offered several of the ivories by a Pakistani politician. He flew to Pakistan, was taken to Peshawar and driven to the home of a tribal chieftain. There he was shown a number of works he identified as from the Bagram hoard. He bought several and donated them to a French museum. But most of the ivories are still missing.

As well as Buddhist works, there is a lively trade in Afghan Islamic art, much of it smuggled via Iran. The Government is under pressure to tackle the trade.

'People in the countries where the works come from are sick of seeing their heritage ripped out of the ground and sold in Western cities,' said one archaeologist. But some say that without the trade much more Afghan art would have been lost.

'If no one had taken anything, far more would have been destroyed,' said one London dealer. 'Look at what is happening there now.'

Additional reporting by Rory McCarthy in Islamabad

webTitle: Minnows' last-gasp Cup hero

fields.headline: Minnows' last-gasp Cup hero
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Football
 Observer Sport
fields.trailText: He did not even know the names of all his team-mates. But the striker nobody wanted inspired a football fairytale yesterday when his last-minute goal produced one of the greatest upsets in FA Cup history.
fields.body:
He did not even know the names of all his team-mates. But the striker nobody wanted inspired a football fairytale yesterday when his last-minute goal produced one of the greatest upsets in FA Cup history.

Roy Essandoh's header in the second minute of added time ensured that lowly Wycombe Wanderers, of the Second Division, beat Premiership high-flyers Leicester City for a place in the semi-finals. Essandoh arrived at Wycombe last week after the Buckinghamshire club issued an urgent appeal via the internet for a striker. An injury crisis had robbed them of all their six forwards.

The Belfast-born, Ghana-raised striker is the ultimate football journeyman. He began with non-league Cumbernauld United in Scotland, appeared five times in three years as a sub for Motherwell and failed to find the net during a trial at East Fife.

webTitle: Family photos aren't porn insists Saatchi row artist

fields.headline: Family photos aren't porn insists Saatchi row artist
fields.standfirst: Police who swooped on a London gallery claim pictures of two naked children, snapped by their mother, are obscene - but only a pervert could imagine that, Tierney Gearon tells Tony Thompson
fields.trailText: They look like happy snapshots from any family album: two naked children playing on a sun-drenched beach, and another image of a boy caught having a pee in the snow.
fields.body:
They look like happy snapshots from any family album: two naked children playing on a sun-drenched beach, and another image of a boy caught having a pee in the snow.

But the police do not think so. After the first raid on an art gallery by Scotland Yard's obscene publications squad for more than 30 years, the photographer who took these images of her own children last night denied she was involved in pornography - and expressed astonishment that anyone could think it.

Speaking for the first time since the furore broke, Tierney Gearon, whose work is part of the 'I Am A Camera' exhibition at the Saatchi gallery in London, said: 'I have had fan mail about these pictures. The only time the question of pornography or exploitation has ever emerged is during interviews with the press and even then it has never been a major issue.'

Gearon has been warned that two of her pictures will be seized unless they are removed from public display. She could also face prosecution under child pornography legislation after it emerged that a report had been forwarded to the Crown Prosecution Service.

The two images which have been deemed obscene both depict Gearon's own children - six-year-old Emily and four-year-old Michael, naked or partly naked while playing. In one, the two children are wearing identical theatrical masks and standing on a beach. In the other, her daughter stands behind her son who is urinating in the snow; both are wearing goggles. The beach photograph has appeared in national newspaper advertisements for the exhibition.

The pictures are part of a series of 15 which document her personal family life. Other pictures in the series also show full or partial nudity but are not the subject of police action because they are not deemed 'indecent'.

Despite the police warnings that the pictures must be removed by Thursday, the gallery said it had no plans to take down the photographs. 'We have received legal advice from barrister Geoffrey Robertson and been told that the police have used the wrong definition of what is indecent,' said Jenny Blyth, the gallery's curator. 'The pictures would have to be lewd or sexually provocative to fall under the auspices of the Protection of Children Act. They are clearly neither.'

Playing with her children in London's Regents Park yesterday, Gearon said: 'My children are my entire life. My children are beautiful and these are beautiful, innocent pictures. I am immensely proud of my exhibition. I do not accept that I have done anything wrong. My children came to the opening of the exhibition. They were showing people their photographs, smiling, running around and having a great time. They were proud and delighted.

'You have to understand the context of these pictures which is that I was documenting my family - not just my children but my dad, my cousins, nephews, everyone - for two years. My son was in his ski suit, shuffling along, telling me he needed to pee badly, then he took off his clothes and did. None of the pictures were posed. None of them have been retouched or cropped or set up in any way. In all cases it was simply a question of waiting for the moment. They are snapshots of family life.'

'When people ask if I am sexually exploiting my children I honestly don't know what to say. It simply isn't true. There are some evil people in the world. It is all in the eye of the beholder. It would take a perverted mind to see these images in any other way. It would only be someone who was already that way inclined who would be able to see anything like that in these photographs anyway.'

The Metropolitan Police confirmed last night that officers had visited the gallery twice this week after three complaints under legislation against child pornography and a report was being forwarded to the CPS. Inspector Brian Ward of Scotland Yard's obscene publications and internet unit first visited the gallery incognito to see the photographs on display before he went to the gallery in St John's Wood, north London, on Thursday for a second time with other officers to confront Blyth. He told them he would return with a warrant to seize the pictures if they were not removed before the gallery reopened to the public on Thursday. The raid was the first on an art gallery since the obscene publications squad seized pictures by John Lennon and others in the late Sixties.

The police have also warned fine art publisher Edward Booth-Clibborn to remove from sale thousands of copies of the £50, 436-page book of the exhibition or face the threat of prosecution.

At least one of the original complaints is believed to have been made by journalists who later visited the photographer at home and confronted her about the raid. 'I was on my way home when my nanny called to say that I was late for my appointment. I wasn't expecting anyone and asked to speak to them. When I arrived home they talked about the exhibition but kept asking if there had been any complaints or difficulties. I said there had not been but then they said they knew the police had visited the gallery that day.'

Hilary Cross of the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children said yesterday: 'We cannot comment on this particular case. However, many family photographs of children without clothes are entirely innocent and we do not want parents to feel uncomfortable about cuddling their children or taking their photographs when they are naked. The problems arise when the children are forced to be photographed against their will or innocently taken photographs are used for sexual gratification.'

Gearon's photographs are part of an exhibition which features the work of a group of artists and photographers selected by Charles Saatchi and taken from his personal collection. fields.bodyText: They look like happy snapshots from any family album: two naked children playing on a sun-drenched beach, and another image of a boy caught having a pee in the snow. But the police do not think so. After the first raid on an art gallery by Scotland Yard's obscene publications squad for more than 30 years, the photographer who took these images of her own children last night denied she was involved in pornography - and expressed astonishment that anyone could think it. Speaking for the first time since the furore broke, Tierney Gearon, whose work is part of the 'I Am A Camera' exhibition at the Saatchi gallery in London, said: 'I have had fan mail about these pictures. The only time the question of pornography or exploitation has ever emerged is during interviews with the press and even then it has never been a major issue.' Gearon has been warned that two of her pictures will be seized unless they are removed from public display. She could also face prosecution under child pornography legislation after it emerged that a report had been forwarded to the Crown Prosecution Service. The two images which have been deemed obscene both depict Gearon's own children - six-year-old Emily and four-year-old Michael, naked or partly naked while playing. In one, the two children are wearing identical theatrical masks and standing on a beach. In the other, her daughter stands behind her son who is urinating in the snow; both are wearing goggles. The beach photograph has appeared in national newspaper advertisements for the exhibition. The pictures are part of a series of 15 which document her personal family life. Other pictures in the series also show full or partial nudity but are not the subject of police action because they are not deemed 'indecent'. Despite the police warnings that the pictures must be removed by Thursday, the gallery said it had no plans to take down the photographs. 'We have received legal advice from barrister Geoffrey Robertson and been told that the police have used the wrong definition of what is indecent,' said Jenny Blyth, the gallery's curator. 'The pictures would have to be lewd or sexually provocative to fall under the auspices of the Protection of Children Act. They are clearly neither.' Playing with her children in London's Regents Park yesterday, Gearon said: 'My children are my entire life. My children are beautiful and these are beautiful, innocent pictures. I am immensely proud of my exhibition. I do not accept that I have done anything wrong. My children came to the opening of the exhibition. They were showing people their photographs, smiling, running around and having a great time. They were proud and delighted. 'You have to understand the context of these pictures which is that I was documenting my family - not just my children but my dad, my cousins, nephews, everyone - for two years. My son was in his ski suit, shuffling along, telling me he needed to pee badly, then he took off his clothes and did. None of the pictures were posed. None of them have been retouched or cropped or set up in any way. In all cases it was simply a question of waiting for the moment. They are snapshots of family life.' 'When people ask if I am sexually exploiting my children I honestly don't know what to say. It simply isn't true. There are some evil people in the world. It is all in the eye of the beholder. It would take a perverted mind to see these images in any other way. It would only be someone who was already that way inclined who would be able to see anything like that in these photographs anyway.' The Metropolitan Police confirmed last night that officers had visited the gallery twice this week after three complaints under legislation against child pornography and a report was being forwarded to the CPS. Inspector Brian Ward of Scotland Yard's obscene publications and internet unit first visited the gallery incognito to see the photographs on display before he went to the gallery in St John's Wood, north London, on Thursday for a second time with other officers to confront Blyth. He told them he would return with a warrant to seize the pictures if they were not removed before the gallery reopened to the public on Thursday. The raid was the first on an art gallery since the obscene publications squad seized pictures by John Lennon and others in the late Sixties. The police have also warned fine art publisher Edward Booth-Clibborn to remove from sale thousands of copies of the £50, 436-page book of the exhibition or face the threat of prosecution. At least one of the original complaints is believed to have been made by journalists who later visited the photographer at home and confronted her about the raid. 'I was on my way home when my nanny called to say that I was late for my appointment. I wasn't expecting anyone and asked to speak to them. When I arrived home they talked about the exhibition but kept asking if there had been any complaints or difficulties. I said there had not been but then they said they knew the police had visited the gallery that day.' webTitle: 'Foreigners killing football'

fields.headline: 'Foreigners killing football'
fields.standfirst: UEFA Chief's call for firm action against big clubs' 'Global Teams'
fields.trailText: Uefa Chief Executive Gerhard Aigner has demanded urgent action to limit the influx of foreign players and stop fans becoming disillusioned by 'international select teams' such as Chelsea.
fields.body:
Uefa Chief Executive Gerhard Aigner has demanded urgent action to limit the influx of foreign players and stop fans becoming disillusioned by 'international select teams' such as Chelsea.

Aigner wants clubs throughout Europe's national leagues to play at least six homegrown players and no more than five imports, and proposes new measures to ensure that a team's line-up always includes several players produced by that club. He wants a special EU exemption for football - overriding freedom of labour movement rules -or a voluntary initiative by clubs to achieve this.

'Teams have to play with a majority of their own players,' Aigner told Observer Sport. 'If we have three English teams in the Uefa Cup, they should be three English teams rather than an international select team. We want to have repre sentatives of this football nation and teams are not representing their football nation. In the long run the fans will not like it.'

Aigner criticised Chelsea and Rangers for having fielded teams with no English and no Scottish players respectively. 'I don't like it. It is bad for football in the long run, and probably not so good for the club either. It is against the spirit in sport.'

Aigner said that while four per cent of the population of European Union countries come from elsewhere, more than 40 per cent of footballers are imports - and that is damaging. 'Four out of ten is not necessary. It doesn't make sense that we have a 40 per cent integration factor in European football. Freedom of movement is more than abundant. Why shouldn't we be allowed to limit it and have 20 per cent?

'We are not against freedom of movement, but we want to have a representative character of teams playing in national and international competitions. It is important that any club playing at the highest level at the same time promotes the national team because the national team is what is closest to the fans' hearts.'

Aigner's attack on the status quo will reignite the simmering debate about the increasingly cosmopolitan nature of European football.

While accepting the EU's decree that freedom of movement is sacrosanct, he wants team sports to be allowed to insist on minimum numbers of homegrown players to ensure 'representativity' (sic). Uefa planned to open discussions with the EU, national governments and sports ministers on the issue, Aigner said. Even without EU action, Aigner would like clubs to agree to play at least some players from that country who have come through their ranks. 'It could be two, three or four to start with; it would be beneficial to clubs. I would like to have six local guys on the field.' But clubs are unlikely to do this voluntarily. At Upton Park last Wednesday, both West Ham and Chelsea fielded what Aigner calls 'international select teams'. The home team featured nine different nationalities, but just four of their 14 players who appeared were English. Chelsea used 14 players from 10 countries, two of them English.

Sports Minister Kate Hoey said: 'I understand Gerhard Aigner's concerns, which are shared by many people who care about the game's long-term future. The present situation is clearly hindering the development of young talent. The football authorities could, if they wished, use their influence to tackle this.'

But FA chairman Geoff Thompson said: 'Our football academies and centres of excellence will, in the medium and long term, ensure that English players come through to play for the first team. But that is a long process.' Thompson said moves to limit overseas players could bring further conflict with the EC.

webTitle: Cricket: The umpire strikes back

fields.headline: The umpire strikes back
fields.standfirst: Call for training programme in face of players' intimidatory tactics
fields.trailText: Call for training programme in face of players' intimidatory tactics.
fields.byline: Barrie Stuart-King, chairman, Association of Cricket Umpires and Scorers
fields.body:
Nowhere, among the reams of outraged copy and uninformed rhetoric blaming the umpires for England's defeat in the first Test in Sri Lanka, have I read any informed comment either on why or how such a predictable situation arose, or what immediate, practical steps need to be taken to prevent a recurrence.

It says much about the depth of cricket journalism that the only 'solutions' proffered by the press pundits and television commentary teams - none of whom is, or include, a trained, qualified umpire - are the quick-fix installation of more sophisticated camera technology to undermine still further the authority of the umpires, and the regressive concept that Test umpires should be selected only from a small, elite panel. This short-term approach is not the solution to a very serious problem.

That both umpires in Galle were inexperienced at Test level cannot be denied; that both umpires, as their trial by repeated video replay and long-range lens showed, made mistakes under pressure cannot be denied. But is it fair that they alone should be pilloried?

Cynically - and, I suspect, with a tacit nod and a wink from their respective managements - England and Sri Lanka players sought to exploit the umpires' inexperience by increasing the pressure on them through persistent, inappropriate, intimidatory appealing and aggressive body language. Such behaviour, an exported Australian art form, is euphemistically described or justified as 'playing the percentages; playing it hard, being competitive'. What pseudo-macho rubbish! Quite apart from being contrary to the principles set down in the 'Spirit of the Game', now enshrined in the new Laws 2000 Code which came into effect on 1 October last year, it is cheating, pure and simple.

What none of the great and the good, who make up the fraternal band of 'expert' cricket journalists and celebrity ex-player commentators, appears to have cottoned on to is that poor standards of umpiring are the direct result of a perpetual failure by cricket's governing bodies to address the underlying, fundamental problem - that cricket is the only professional sport which does not require its officials to be formally trained, qualified, regularly re-assessed, or graded.

Evaluation of the competence of umpires is carried out by getting the respective team captains to complete a confidential ICC/ECB Report Form which invites them to tick one of the optional Excellent, Good, Satisfactory, Unsatisfactory or Poor boxes alongside such questions, for example, as 'Quality of LBW decisions'; 'Quality of Caught Bad-Pad decisions'; 'Knowledge of the Laws'; and 'Players' respect for Umpire'.

A captain, possibly fielding at mid-off, who was given out lbw on the first ball he received in his team's innings - and who has, at best, like many journalists, only a peripheral knowledge of the laws and almost certainly little understanding of their interpretation and application - is in a position effectively to determine an umpire's future. This reinforces the urgent need for the ICC to introduce a more professional, objective, competence-based assessment process.

In conducting their post-mortem of the first Test, the first priority of the ICC must be to examine who assessed, who selected, and who appointed the umpires and the subjective or objective criteria upon which the selections were based.

Their present method of evaluation is subjective, unconstructive and of only limited value in determining the true level of an umpire's competence. Against this background, one can understand why two relatively inexperienced, ungraded umpires whom the ICC appointed to control such a potentially volatile Test made mistakes.

The media have called for umpires in Tests to be restricted to the same panel of familiar faces - and for referees, or third umpires, to have mandatory authority to intervene in, or overturn, decisions without first being requested by the umpire. But simultaneously, the media have demanded the immediate introduction of more sophisticated, expensive technology to obviate the need for umpires to make decisions. This, frankly, is an absurd juxtaposition.

For a start, the referee or third umpire is likely to be as untrained and unqualified as his colleagues in the middle. Take, for example, the 26 umpires on the ECB First Class List; the preserve, with one or two rare exceptions, of former first-class players whose playing careers at that level have, hitherto, been accepted as an appropriate 'qualification' for them to stand as first-class umpires. Of these, only around five or six have attended multi-level, formal training and/or advanced refresher courses, taken formal qualifying (written and oral) examinations and undergone formal assessments by their peers - i.e. have made the commitment to be trained to become qualified. The ICC select from the ECB First Class List for their international panel.

The most regrettable aspect of this Sri Lankan controversy is that to a trained umpire, LBW is not a difficult decision, yet cricket fans watching the Galle Test must have thought: 'If they can't get it right at this level, what must the rest be like?' The answer is that many of the 'rest' are far better qualified and more deserving of appointment to the highest levels.

This arcane system needs reform; it is an anachronism in today's cricket.

Players, at ALL levels, from schools to Leagues to County to national representative sides, deserve and have a right to expect the highest possible standards of umpiring. To achieve this, we need to recruit many more, younger, umpires. In order to encourage them we, the ECB, ICC, ACU&S and the present First Class List Umpires, need to demonstrate our active joint collaboration in providing a genuinely open, merit-based, seamless 'career' development path from the national recreational game through to the highest international professional levels.

The details of how this could be structured and administered are the subject of a separate ACU&S Paper.

It is very much to the credit of the ECB that, recognising the problem, they have recently introduced a requirement that all future prospective candidates for the First Class Reserve List must attend customised ACU&S Training Courses and pass the subsequent examinations.

These are carefully structured modular courses which teach candidates not only the Laws and how to interpret and apply them under pressure, but also, more important, the twin arts of fieldcraft and communication; man-management; awareness; and how to prevent/control gamesmanship and controversy on the field.

Later courses will train umpires how and when they should opt to utilise technology before responding to answering appeals.

The ACU&S have a wealth of very experienced, trained umpires within their ranks who stand regularly in senior Premier Leagues, Minor Counties and County Second XI matches throughout the UK and would make excellent First Class List umpires, but who are denied an invitation by the ECB and ICC to progress to the very highest levels.

By failing to recognise and proactively exploit this pool of younger, active umpiring talent, the ECB and ICC are, I believe, doing themselves, the players and cricket a grave disservice.

With 119 revisions/amendments to the Laws - including some major changes - and additional signals, which came into effect on 1 October last year, professional training, competence-based assessment and grading of umpires are a matter of paramount importance.

So what is the solution? The answer is a phased solution: first, the ICC must immediately give the issue of umpire development a much higher priority.

Second, they must budget to set aside an appropriate annual amount (the ACU&S can advise how much) from their newly acquired kitty of £150 million specifically for: the appointment of a Director of Umpires whose remit and authority would cover all aspects of international umpire training (including mandatory bi-annual refresher courses to retain grade level); selection procedures (including mandatory minimum fitness, eyesight and hearing requirements); progression, monitoring and assessment, and appointments in the professional game.

There must be collaboration with ACU&S and other umpire associations, in the creation of regional, national and international 'pools' of highly mobile, qualified Instructor Umpires and experienced Field Assessors.

There must be the creation and maintenance of an international 'CV' database of all the current and prospective qualified, graded First Class, International/Test Panel Umpires to provide objective assessment records.

We must also have the joint-venture creation, with MCC, national governing bodies, ACU&S and other umpire organisations, of a new international body - e.g. the International Council of Cricket Umpires (ICCU) - as the recognised technical forum for setting, developing and monitoring international consistency in the standards of umpire training, and evaluation programmes, fieldcraft, Grade Levels, fee structures and the type and application of support technology.

Phased in over the next three years, these investment initiatives will provide far greater and more lasting benefits for the ICC (in particular) and cricket (in general) than the media-peddled siren calls to sink everything into sophisticated and equally fallible new, software-based camera/capture technology which does nothing to solve the underlying problem and will only undermine still further the authority of umpires.

webTitle: Forget flying the flag. We're all global now

fields.headline: Forget flying the flag. We're all global now
fields.standfirst: UK icons bite the dust as consumers shop in a world without frontiers, writes John Arlidge
fields.trailText: UK icons bite the dust as consumers shop in a world without frontiers, writes John Arlidge
fields.body:
What could be more British than British Airways, Rover cars and Moss Bros? The answer, a major new study of Britain's consumer culture has revealed, is a wide range of top brands. The rapid explosion of consumer choice has left some of Britain's best-known names looking as outdated as warm beer and village greens.

Superbrands, an independent body that monitors Britain's changing tastes, will this week publish the first league table of the UK's strongest brands. Of the top 100 less than half are British. Once unshakeable icons, notably British Airways, Rolls-Royce, Barclays Bank, Littlewoods and Rover cars, have been forced out by foreign rivals.

The study reveals the dramatic changes in consumer tastes in the days since food meant meat and two veg, MFI was the last word in interior decoration and the only way to arrive was in a car with 'Made in GB' bolted to the bumper. Consumers are more outward-looking than ever and have helped Britain transform itself into the European capital for media, financial services, leisure and pleasure.

Superbrands, an independent group of image makers that has helped to create many of Britain's strongest brands including BT, Vodafone, Tesco and Virgin, collated sales figures, recognition surveys and wide-ranging market research to identify the top 100 brands offering consumers 'physical or emotional advantages which they recognise and for which they are willing to pay a premium'. The results provide a fascinating snapshot of our changing tastes.

Far from being 'little Englanders', consumers have developed a taste for all things European. Ikea, the Swedish furniture manufacturer, outshines Conran and Habitat. More Britons drink Evian than English, Welsh or Scottish bottled water. We may not all look like David Ginola or Jennifer Aniston but we all think we are worth a little L'Oreal pampering and Nivea is our favourite face cream.

Alfa Romeo's recent renaissance has made the marque as desirable as Range Rover. We may be turning our backs on our own railway companies but the Eurostar makes it into the top 100 and Club Med outdoes British tour firms.

Britain is a nation of technophiles, the survey shows. Almost two-thirds of us now own a mobile phone and more than half of those are models made in Finland by Nokia or by the Swedish firm Ericsson. BT makes it into the top 100 along with One2One and the £160 billion global telecoms giant, Vodafone.

Despite the recent collapse in confidence in internet firms, Britons are the most enthusiastic web surfers in Europe. America Online is our favourite service provider, with more than 1 million members, and the burgeoning popularity of email has helped Microsoft's Hotmail win 'superbrand' status.

The travel sector is booming, creating new superbrands, which are outperforming established giants. British Airways failed to make it into the top 100 but Virgin Atlantic is praised as 'distinctive, fun-loving and innovative' and EasyJet, the low-budget Luton-based carrier, has become a new consumer champion, forcing down air fares.

The Superbrands study highlights the astonishing weakness of British manufacturing. The only large-scale British-based manufacturers to gain superbrand status are Land Rover and the electronics firm Psion.

The only compensation is that industrial decline has been partly offset by the rapid growth of the creative industries - media, financial services, fashion and food. Of the 45 British-based companies in the top 100, a remarkable 13 are food and drink firms, 10 provide media services from TV channels to the internet, eight sell financial services and two make clothes and shoes. The leading food firm is Pret A Manger, the upmarket lunch chain, which has transformed the British sandwich from a national joke into something so good that the world's biggest fast-food company, McDonald's, has taken a £25 million bite out of the company.

webTitle: Blades blame blundering referee

fields.headline: Blades blame blundering referee
fields.trailText: Rank officiating is not the exclusive preserve of Sri Lankan cricket umpires after all. While not quite on the scale of the events unfolding in our other national sport, Roy Pearson's unimpressive efforts here could prove to have a major impact on the First Division promotion race.
fields.body:
Rank officiating is not the exclusive preserve of Sri Lankan cricket umpires after all. While not quite on the scale of the events unfolding in our other national sport, Roy Pearson's unimpressive efforts here could prove to have a major impact on the First Division promotion race.

Nottingham Forest's crucial win was set in motion after only three minutes. It was shrouded in controversy as David Johnson's apparently illegal throw-in led to defender Christian Edwards heading in via the despairing grasp of Simon Tracey.

Johnson backed up to the advertising hoardings, where he began his run-up for a throw-in five yards from the right corner flag. Gathering pace, he threw the ball deep into the Blades' area, appearing to have one foot off the ground and to stray a few inches over the line when he released the ball.

Certainly that was how United manager Neil Warnock saw the incident, and how he repeatedly re-enacted it for the linesman, the fourth official, Forest players and main stand spectators. An engaging and, dare one say, borderline eccentric character, Warnock's impression was something of which John Cleese could have been proud.

But this was no laughing matter in a clash between two teams competing for that precious final play-off position.

'David Platt had a moan at the ref afterwards, but I told him not to moan at him because he had done well for him,' said Warnock. 'The first goal was allowed to stand even though David Johnson was two feet on the pitch when he took the throw-in.

'When I told the referee about it, he said his decision was final and then proceeded to blame the linesman. I even asked the fourth official but he said he could only get involved in serious foul play.'

Warnock hinted that Andy Johnson's eighth-minute challenge on George Santos, an incident that left the United midfielder with a double fracture to his cheekbone, qualified as such, but again the officials took no action.

Forest, too, felt they were the victims of a questionable decision when Tony Vaughan was ruled to have handled Paul Devlin's cross five minutes after Andy Johnson had shot Forest into a 64th-minute 2-0 lead, scoring from eight yards after Stern John headed a Chris Bart-Williams corner across the face of goal.

Justice, from Forest's viewpoint, was served when Bobby Ford's spot-kick clipped the bar and flew over, a miss made all the more frustrating three minutes later when Shaun Murphy's stooping header from Rob Kozluk's cross pulled them to within a goal.

The game had, however, hinged more on a long string of wasted half-chances and ill-used possession by the home team.

David Johnson was to conclude the day's events in the same way as he had started them, this time taking, rather than making, a goal three minutes from time. Forest midfielder David Prutton skilfully reached the goalline and pulled the ball back for Johnson to score at the second attempt.

webTitle: Teletext Roy zaps the Foxes

fields.headline: Teletext Roy zaps the Foxes
fields.trailText: The Wycombe Wanderers manager, Lawrie Sanchez, told his team before the game that the FA Cup is a competition for heroes - and he should know, having scored the winning goal for Wimbledon against Liverpool in the 1988 final. The man who took him most at his word was Roy Essandoh.
fields.body:
The Wycombe Wanderers manager, Lawrie Sanchez, told his team before the game that the FA Cup is a competition for heroes - and he should know, having scored the winning goal for Wimbledon against Liverpool in the 1988 final. The man who took him most at his word was Roy Essandoh.

Roy who? You know, the 25-year-old striker born in Belfast and brought up in Ghana, who numbers Cumbernauld United, Motherwell and East Fife among his previous clubs. And to prove that the Cup's capacity to throw up the most outrageous of stories lives on, Essandoh was signed 10 days ago, after Sanchez had advertised on Teletext that he needed strikers to cover an injury crisis. He was the only one to respond.

Seizing the moment and the day, substitute Essandoh, latterly with VPS Vaasa in Finland, popped up in the second minute of added time to head Second Division Wanderers into the semi-finals - just think about it; a non-League club only eight years ago in the last four of the FA Cup - to cap a frantic finale that saw Wycombe denied a clear penalty, Sanchez banished from the touchline for his protestations and the inspirational Steve Brown ridiculously sent off for celebrating the winning goal by removing his shirt.

It was deserved; it was certainly almost impossible to tell which was sixth and which sixtieth in English football's pecking order. Leicester had their moments but they always looked uncomfortable now they were no longer underdogs and forced to take the game to their opponents. Wycombe's game plan worked perfectly, mirroring Leicester's 3-5-2, tackling tenaciously and breaking out swiftly. It seemed they would be forced into a replay when Muzzy Izzet equalised Paul McCarthy's goal, but they are clearly a resilient crew.

For Sanchez it was a remarkable coaching achievement given the resources at his disposal - a playing staff of 26 and 10 of them injured. At the final whistle, half a dozen limped over to join in the celebrations, among them the record signing Sean Devine and leading scorer Andy Rammell.

The white-hot climax scarcely looked likely after a lukewarm first half that Leicester shaded. Robbie Savage did test Martin Taylor with a header from Andy Impey's cross but they were largely restricted to long-range shots, from Izzet and Savage, which the goalkeeper dealt with comfortably.

Wycombe responded with drives by Dannie Bulman and Brown, which Simon Royce turned aside, but it took a confrontation between Savage and Brown, and an exchange of yellow cards, to enliven matters. It was a bit like Anthea Turner and Chris Eubank in the celebrity Big Brother - you wondered which might go first.

It all changed four minutes after the interval. After Impey had fouled Michael Simpson on the right touchline, Brown curled in a menacing free-kick with his left foot and McCarthy arrived ahead of his marker Ade Akinbiyi to bundle the ball past a static Royce.

Now Leicester were riled and, urged on by frustrated fans who must have seen the game as a golden opportunity to progress, they bombarded Wanderers. It produced only one real chance, however, Akinbiyi heading Stefan Oakes's cross too close to Taylor.

When Leicester changed approach, and thought about it for a moment, they duly got a goal. Gerry Taggart, desperately driving his team forward, played the ball wide to the substitute Darren Eadie and from his cross - this time a low one - Izzet, arriving late, had a simple tap-in. Then, Leicester should have been ahead within seconds. Izzet slipped the ball through to Akinbiyi but Taylor blocked his snatched shot.

Reprieved, Wycombe scented their chance, and Sanchez sent on fresh legs, in Essandoh and Stewart Castledine, to replace the labouring makeshift striker Keith Ryan and George Clegg, a 20-year-old on loan from Manchester United. Their deserts should have come 12 minutes from time. Brown sought to get in another of his swinging crosses from the right but this time the left arm of Oakes intervened. It was understandable that the referee might have missed him clearly moving an arm towards the ball but less so a linesman a mere 15 yards away - and in line. For running 40 yards along the touchline to point as much out, Sanchez was sent down the tunnel.

It was there, on a TV monitor, that he witnessed the astonishing endgame. Bulman swung in a cross from the right to the far post and Jamie Bates, hitherto a towering presence in defence, now used his head in attack to guide the ball back across goal for Essandoh to head powerfully home.

For Wycombe, Roy was the boy. For Leicester, it was a Homer Simpson moment: Essan-doh.

webTitle: Fifteen minutes of pain sinks Peterhead

fields.headline: Fifteen minutes of pain sinks Peterhead
fields.trailText: Peterhead's dream of a place in the Scottish Cup semi-finals was destroyed at Livingston in 15 first-half minutes. During that period, the Third Division team, having gone ahead with an early Martin Johnson goal, were effectively sunk by two from Livingston defender John Andersen.
fields.body:
Peterhead's dream of a place in the Scottish Cup semi-finals was destroyed at Livingston in 15 first-half minutes. During that period, the Third Division team, having gone ahead with an early Martin Johnson goal, were effectively sunk by two from Livingston defender John Andersen. The first came with a header from a free-kick, and the other with a shot from a corner. Livingston, who had experienced a major blow before the kick-off with the news that their first-choice goalkeeper, Neil Alexander, had been ruled out because of a hand injury, deservedly made it 3-1 with a delightful volley by David Bingham.

Livingston general manager Jim Leishman said: 'This was a more important and bigger game than the one on Tuesday and that's not taking anything away from Aber-deen, but this game allowed us to get to the semi-finals of a national competition There was no pressure on us on Tuesday. We were underdogs and we had the feeling that we wouldn't get beaten.

'That role was reversed today and all credit to Peterhead. Mentally it took a lot out of us on Tuesday but our fitness was great today.'

Hearts defender Steven Pressley has called on his team to assert themselves physically in today's quarter-final against Celtic.

While acknowledging Celtic's individual skill, he said: 'The one big difference I see in Celtic this season is that they are a very big and physical side.

'I think they scored a lot of goals from set-plays this season and if you look at their squad, they have got Val gaeren, Vega, Mjallby, Larsson and Sutton who are all extremely good in the air.

'I wouldn't say we are a particularly big side, so it is important for us to be aggressive. The fact that they have the height advantage does not mean that we can't compete and hold our own.'

Dundee United, who have a similarly tough task against Rangers, are clearly ignoring the tales of woe emanating from the Ibrox camp because of the number of players unavailable to them.

United's captain, Jason de Vos, referring to the so-called Rangers 'crisis,' said: 'I think it would be nice for us to be second in the league and have to talk about a crisis.'

If only Hearts or Dundee United had a Bebeto at his peak. Indeed, it is tempting to suggest that the former Brazilian World Cup striker could still do a good job for them now at 37, although St Mirren's manager Tom Hendrie clearly does not think do. Hendrie insisted yesterday that he had made the right decision in rejecting the chance of signing Bebeto.

Hendrie explained: 'The player is 37 and he was not prepared to come and allow us to assess his fitness and what condition he is in. The agent said that his reputation should be enough for us to sign him without seeing him but we simply couldn't get ourselves into that position.

'Bebeto is not playing at the moment after playing in Japan following his release from Vasco da Gama in Brazil. He is not signed to a club and it would have been easy to bring him in.

'Though he was a fabulous player, his main contribution to the Brazilian squad was in 1994 and there is a big difference from then to now. Our defender Tommy Turner is proof that some players can play in the first team at 37 but some players can't.

webTitle: Hibs get belated reward

fields.headline: Hibs get belated reward
fields.trailText: A place in the semi-finals of the Tennents Scottish Cup on the back of a beautifully headed goal in the dying seconds from substitute Tom McManus was the minimum due to Hibs from a fifth-round tie at Rugby Park in which they were quicker, smarter and more menacing than a Kilmarnock side whose own fans seemed to have been blessed with prescience.
fields.body:
A place in the semi-finals of the Tennents Scottish Cup on the back of a beautifully headed goal in the dying seconds from substitute Tom McManus was the minimum due to Hibs from a fifth-round tie at Rugby Park in which they were quicker, smarter and more menacing than a Kilmarnock side whose own fans seemed to have been blessed with prescience.

Economic constraints would not be the only reason for a notably low turnout of locals at a stadium whose previous two league matches yielded scoreless draws.

That run of games on their own ground - they were complemented by the replayed cup-tie against Inverness last midweek - and the need to lay out substantial money for next Sunday's CIS League Cup final against Celtic would keep an appreciable number of fans at home.

They would not be shocked to hear from friends who did attend that their team, having departed from their normal 4-4-2 formation to match up to Hibs' favoured 3-5-2, took 33 minutes to have their first and only scoring attempt of the match. Alan Mahood's overhead kick sailed harmlessly over the bar.

His first try was blocked but the ball fell kindly for him, only for his second attempt to be lifted over from 12 yards.

It was O'Neil, too, who squandered another golden opportunity near the break when he went clear on the left of the area and created a good shooting position. The Frenchman stretched a hamstring in the second minute and was replaced in the 26th by Ian Murray, while the Dane departed with a damaged calf muscle after half-an-hour.

webTitle: King reigns as Allardyce's men bottle it

fields.headline: King reigns as Allardyce's men bottle it
fields.trailText: Bolton, having been crushed by Blackburn in the FA Cup, wasted a great opportunity to have the last laugh yesterday. While Graeme Souness's men were given a taste of their own medicine at Arsenal, Bolton were held to a 3-3 draw by Gillingham after being 1-0 and then 3-1 ahead.
fields.byline: Nationwide League Review by Jason Tomas
fields.body:
Bolton, having been crushed by Blackburn in the FA Cup, wasted a great opportunity to have the last laugh yesterday. While Graeme Souness's men were given a taste of their own medicine at Arsenal, Bolton were held to a 3-3 draw by Gillingham after being 1-0 and then 3-1 ahead.

The Gillingham star was Marlon King, who made the score 1-1 and got their second equaliser, too, five minutes from the end.

Bolton's manager, Sam Allardyce, suggested that Gillingham had been helped by his team's 'childish defending', and added: 'We played with fear; that was easy to see.' Equally easy to see is that Bolton's position in the second automatic spot has become more precarious; Birmingham moved level on points with them through a 2-0 win over Crewe - their fifth successive league victory and their eighth in the last nine matches. As if this is not enough to increase the pressure on Bolton, Birmingham have two matches in hand over them.

Against Crewe, Birmingham's manager, Trevor Francis was particularly pleased with his team's patience. Referring to the number of times they were frustrated by Crewe's keeper, Ademola Bankole, in the first half, Francis said: 'We knew how good he was going to be because he was on trial with us two years ago. But we kept pressing and eventually got our reward.'

Birmingham's performance contrasted sharply with that of their neighbours West Bromwich Albion. On Gary Megson's first anniversary as their manager, they took an early lead against Sheffield Wednesday but ended up losing 2-1. What particularly upset Megson was the sight of one of his players having a laugh and joke with an opponent near the end. 'I am not going to name him, but I will not accept that lack of desire.'

One had to look long and hard to find any sign of happiness in the Huddersfield ranks. They, too, took the lead in their clash at Barnsley, but eventually crashed 3-1.

Watford also came from behind for their 4-1 win over Norwich, the biggest First Division victory margin. Norwich's assistant manager, Doug Livermore, admitted: 'But for our keeper, Andy Marshall, they could easily have scored more.'

But any prize for the most dramatic goal of the day would have to go to Portsmouth's substitute Steve Lovell. He came on as an 84th-minute replacement against Stockport, with the score at 1-1, and with his first touch curled an unstoppable shot past Stockport's veteran keeper, Andy Dibble, for the winner.

Things got worse for Oxford United, the team at the bottom of the table and in deep trouble. Apart from a 2-0 home defeat by Swindon, they had two men sent off - Dean Whitehead and Matthew Murphy - and the match was delayed for two minutes because of a missile-throwing incident.
