webTitle: Should all World Cup matches be listed?

fields.headline: Should all World Cup matches be listed?
fields.standfirst: YES
fields.trailText: Peter Salmon, head of BBC Sport, says finals transcend niche interest
fields.body:
Successive governments have wisely foreseen the explosion of broadcasting outlets in recent years to a point where there are literally hundreds of television channels available to the keen viewer, and they have set about protecting specific sports events, which transcend niche interest, for the benefit of the nation as a whole.

So some landmarks in the year, including the Grand National, the FA Cup final, and the Wimbledon finals, are rightly protected for terrestrial television channels such as ITV, the BBC and Channel 4 where the majority of the nation has free-to-air access. Many other events remain unlisted. It is really important that, in a world of vested interests, niche channels and multimedia sports ownership, some events in our lives remain outstanding and shared, like the big news stories - coronations, state funerals and men on the moon.

Of course, there are colossal amounts of money to be made in sport these days, not least in the sale of broadcast rights. But sport and its participants are also beginning to realise that there is more to the broadcasting of their event than sackfuls of money and a restricted audience from one broadcaster. Another broadcaster may not offer so much money but does provide access to an audience of millions - reinforcing the popularity of that sport's heroes and heroines and encouraging thousands of people to take up the sport.

So it is with the World Cup. Fifa, the game's governing body, want to see the popularity of football grow around the world and insist that the important parts of their competitions are available on terrestrial television with its vast audiences.

In the United Kingdom, successive World Cups since 1966 have been shown by both main terrestrial broadcasters - ITV and the BBC - because the government of the day has decreed that the whole of the final stages should be available to the nation. This has enabled the UK to have televised access to all 64 matches in the final stages and still retain plenty of attractive alternative programming.

The way in which a football World Cup grips the nation is astonishing. Twenty-six million people watched England v Argentina in the 1998 World Cup. Nearly 10 million even watched the United States v Iran - an incredible figure for two, shall we say, lower-division football adversaries. Yet for the 2002 competition the agency representing the rights wants to set aside the nation's interest and the Government's listed events legislation and sell to the highest bidder - however small its audience.

Consider how the nation was held spellbound on terrestrial television by the Olympics Games in Sydney last September. Would the same be true if the Olympics had been packaged commercially as Kirch seems to want to do with the World Cup?

Would the Olympics belong to the nation or just a few fortunate subscribers? Commercial interests would snap up some events, like track and field, but who would bother with shooting or sailing, for example?

Swimming might have been on one commercial channel, athletics on another and boxing on a third - all at some extra cost to the viewer. How would the viewer get a sense of occasion from that? Would Jason Queally have pedalled to his gold in prime time? Would seven million viewers have seen the coxless four's epic win after midnight? And would Ben Ainslie have had his moment in the sun with the gripping sailing duel that we watched in awe?

I think not. The stature of our Olympic heroes would simply evaporate. It would be a case of hero to zero. And so it will be in the World Cup if Kirch succeeds.

webTitle: Decadence of the game

fields.headline: Decadence of the game
fields.standfirst: Uefa chief Gerhard Aigner tells Denis Campbell that money is ruining the sport
fields.trailText: The mood inside inside Uefa's sleek, glass-walled headquarters is usually as calm as the waters of nearby Lake Geneva - but last Tuesday it was euphoric. The night before in Brussels, an uneasy peace had finally broken out in football's long-running, bitter dispute with the European Commission over the transfer system. When the Uefa chief executive, Gerhard Aigner, returned to his office, he found a bouquet on his desk, colleagues waiting to offer their congratulations with outstretched hands and celebratory drinks being organised.
fields.body:
The mood inside inside Uefa's sleek, glass-walled headquarters is usually as calm as the waters of nearby Lake Geneva - but last Tuesday it was euphoric. The night before in Brussels, an uneasy peace had finally broken out in football's long-running, bitter dispute with the European Commission over the transfer system. When the Uefa chief executive, Gerhard Aigner, returned to his office, he found a bouquet on his desk, colleagues waiting to offer their congratulations with outstretched hands and celebratory drinks being organised.

Aigner's image may be dour, and his face unfamiliar to most fans, yet he is the most powerful man in European football. Some of those involved in the transfer talks say Aigner's standing has been boosted by the lessons in tactics, diplomacy and media management he and Uefa handed Fifa and their president, Sepp Blatter.

With that saga apparently over, a relieved Aigner spoke to Observer Sport for the next 90 minutes about many of the major issues confronting European football - predictably, most come down to money - including:

 Excessive earnings and the 'decadence' of the Continent's richest players.

 Cash-rich football facing the reality that the stream of money into the game has peaked - and will start to fall.

 Alienation of fans highlighted by pay-TV, high ticket prices and kick-off times tailored to suit media interests.

'A fantastic amount of money has come into the game in the last decade,' he said. 'But too much of it goes to the top clubs and the top players - well, to certain players definitely. If you earn £100,000-a-week, you transgress a border which is difficult to understand by normal people, by those who are actually financing it. Fans have difficulty understanding that. And let's not forget that even the sponsors' money is, somewhere, the consumers' money'.

He does not name names but Ronaldo, Luis Figo and Alessandro del Piero are all in the £100,000-a-week bracket. Aigner believes the greater freedom of movement given to players last Monday will create more of that breed.

Warming to his theme, Aigner warns: It's also the culture that's coming in with these superstars earning so much money. The agents for some of them always bring things into the media. Fans dislike these transactions, especially when players come in and don't perform well and cash in.' He cites Manchester United as a laudable exception.

'Top players there earn a fantastic amount but the fans aren't critical because they win, behave properly and are proper to the fans. There are no signs of the decadence which you can find nowadays.' Decadence is a strong word and will resonate with many fans. In his view 'Southern Europe - Spain and Italy - is much more inclined to have excesses than Britain in this respect.'

Aigner, a trained economist, is outspoken on the 'difficulties' created by the enormous sums that have flowed into the game. Too many people 'see football as a money-making business in itself'. His targets are sponsors, those running TV companies and players who cynically 'cash in', rather than clubs. In his view, football has become 'too much of a commercial activity'. He dislikes the trend, most pronounced in England but now being replicated in Italy, of clubs becoming companies.

He sees this, coupled with high ticket prices, pay-TV subscriptions, saturation television coverage and players' earnings - as likely to alienate fans.

'We can't make the public pay for TV and at the same time increase the prices of the tickets. Somewhere you have to be loyal to your fans and say, "We're making so much money that we will reduce the prices" - that would be fair play. But I don't think we're going that way.'

Aigner agreed to revamp the Champions League to dissuade Europe's leading clubs from breaking away. He is often portrayed as a prisoner of the G14, the influential group of clubs that includes Real Madrid, Barcelona and Manchester United. Mindful of the need to keep the G14 happy, he is also determined to protect the game's roots, as befits someone who played, coached and refereed amateur football in his native Bavaria. Yet he warns that the game is starting to 'disintegrate' as money pours in.

'Football grew because everybody put in. Now everybody is trying to take out,' he says. 'There are too many vested, competing interests. The common interest is not evident - everyone is trying to protect their own interest - the clubs, players, referees, club presidents, the G14, the Euro-League clubs. So we have a disintegration factor, and I regret that.'

Aigner does recognise the benefits that money brings - the £400million-a-year generated by the Champions League helps nurture the game in the poorer countries among Uefa's 51 member states. But he would like to see a broader distribution of the wealth.

He is worried, too, by elitism - another by-product of the flood of money: 'In middle-sized countries like Scotland, the Netherlands and Portugal, two, three or four clubs are always at the top and the quality players gather in these clubs, which then dominate the league. This is not a problem in the big markets, though. In England you have Ipswich doing well, La Coruña in Spain and in Italy the Roman clubs are up.'

Aigner is concerned about the gap between a handful of clubs and the rest in many countries and between the biggest clubs in the major countries - England, Italy, Spain, Germany and France - and the others. 'In some countries, First Division clubs can't get a shirt sponsor because sponsors want teams who play in Europe, not just in their own league.'

Uefa has decreed that the proposed Euro or Atlantic League so that clubs such as Ajax or Rangers can once again take on Milan or Inter with a realistic chance of success, is not the way forward. Aigner is looking at alternatives.

And Aigner insists the momentum for a breakaway European league has gone - for now. 'The G14 know their fans would not understand it. There is no European soul in the fans yet. If you serve fans in England or Italy the menu, they want European football as the pudding, not the main dish.'

Subtle warning to the would-be wreckers, or a genuine assessment of the breakaway threat? With the G14's action now set up as an 'economic interest group', with an office in Brussels, it seems further conflict between them and Uefa is almost inevitable.

England, he believes, is an example of where football still works pretty well. He applauds the Manchester United fans' campaign against the Sky takeover and Brighton fans' backing for their club's search for a new home. 'I could not say that I like the English game, but I like what goes with English football - the atmosphere in the stadia, the passion of the people and the fact that the fan is an expert.' He lets slip that he has supported Ipswich Town since the time of Robson, Muhren and Thijssen. Gerhard Aigner: Uefa's patron of underdogs.

webTitle: Fulham stand alone

fields.headline: Fulham stand alone
fields.trailText: Just in case the beleaguered followers of Queens Park Rangers needed any reminding about how radically the pendulum has swung between these west London neighbours, the scornful message from their soaring counterparts cut deep.
fields.body:
Just in case the beleaguered followers of Queens Park Rangers needed any reminding about how radically the pendulum has swung between these west London neighbours, the scornful message from their soaring counterparts cut deep.

'You're not famous anymore,' suggested the Cottage chanteurs. The gulf between these two clubs at every conceivable level continues to stretch. While Fulham can afford to entertain their wildest dreams, Rangers are living in fear of their worst nightmare. Under Ian Holloway's blindly optimistic stewardship they are certainly improving, but at this stage of the season points count for far more than positive vibes. That said, he could not contain his pride in a performance that made life frustrating for Fulham.

'The key word for us is patience,' remarked their midfielder John Collins. Pleasingly for the league leaders, when the opportunities arose, the irrepressible Louis Saha and impressive Lee Clark dispatched their goals with the confidence of men more than capable of handling top-flight football.

There is something about the Craven Cottage experience that makes it hard to believe they could be hosting Premiership football here in less than six months' time. While the seats at Old Trafford are considered unsafe, the Fulham faithful enjoy a day out on the terraces; while PA systems elsewhere boom out Robbie Williams, here they croon along to Andy Williams. Others may see them as a novelty in the shiny, slick land of the Premier League, but it won't bother Fulham one jot so long as the profile fits on the pitch.

They made heavy weather of overcoming opponents haunted by relegation and financial ruin, but even so, knowing they can grind out results as well as entertain brings its own satisfaction.

It took 27 minutes for them to carve out their first serious chance - Saha heading Bjarne Goldbaek's corner against the woodwork - but 10 minutes before the break Fulham's mounting pressure was rewarded when Steve Finnan's dash into the box was rudely interrupted by Paul Murray. Saha, brimming with confidence, belted the ball past Lee Harper with consummate ease.

Rangers' task suddenly looked a whole lot more thankless. Even more so after Gavin Peacock squandered a glorious chance to equalise just before the break. Mark Perry's driving run and clever pass presented Rangers' most experienced head with a one on one. He lifted his chip over the bar.

Holloway's team selection understandably put the emphasis on defence and it was a lot to ask of Peter Crouch to try to penetrate the Fulham defence on his own up front. The young beanpole naturally won the aerial battle, but needed help on the ground.

QPR gave their all in the second half, and Clark's angled drive in stoppage time flattered Fulham a little. For QPR, who merited something for their ceaseless endeavour, watching their old foes - who were in their shadow not that long ago - cruising onwards and upwards only emphasises their demise. fields.bodyText: Just in case the beleaguered followers of Queens Park Rangers needed any reminding about how radically the pendulum has swung between these west London neighbours, the scornful message from their soaring counterparts cut deep. 'You're not famous anymore,' suggested the Cottage chanteurs. The gulf between these two clubs at every conceivable level continues to stretch. While Fulham can afford to entertain their wildest dreams, Rangers are living in fear of their worst nightmare. Under Ian Holloway's blindly optimistic stewardship they are certainly improving, but at this stage of the season points count for far more than positive vibes. That said, he could not contain his pride in a performance that made life frustrating for Fulham. 'The key word for us is patience,' remarked their midfielder John Collins. Pleasingly for the league leaders, when the opportunities arose, the irrepressible Louis Saha and impressive Lee Clark dispatched their goals with the confidence of men more than capable of handling top-flight football. There is something about the Craven Cottage experience that makes it hard to believe they could be hosting Premiership football here in less than six months' time. While the seats at Old Trafford are considered unsafe, the Fulham faithful enjoy a day out on the terraces; while PA systems elsewhere boom out Robbie Williams, here they croon along to Andy Williams. Saha, brimming with confidence, belted the ball past Lee Harper with consummate ease. Rangers' task suddenly looked a whole lot more thankless. He lifted his chip over the bar. For QPR, who merited something for their ceaseless endeavour, watching their old foes - who were in their shadow not that long ago - cruising onwards and upwards only emphasises their demise. 'There's a lot of jealousy to be honest,' confessed Holloway. 'But we contained them better than a lot of other teams. I can only see improvement in spirit and organisation.' webTitle: Make a new plan, Stan - and set yourself free

fields.headline: Make a new plan, Stan - and set yourself free
fields.standfirst: Ian Ridley hopes Collymore will come back to the game refreshed
fields.trailText: If you wanted an example of the difference between a merely famous player and a celebrity footballer, the car park at Leicester City on the opening day of this season was a good place to be.
fields.body:
If you wanted an example of the difference between a merely famous player and a celebrity footballer, the car park at Leicester City on the opening day of this season was a good place to be.

Local heroes, such as Neil Lennon and Muzzy Izzet, arrived an hour-and-a-half before kick-off, got out of their cars, were surrounded by young lads and duly stood to sign autographs till all were satisfied. Then the tinted-windowed Range Rover of Stanley Victor Collymore (registration no: S7AN V) arrived. Cue a mlée as the door opened.

Stan (funny how when you say the name, everyone knows who you mean, even if Eminem has lately offered some competition) did not stay still to issue his signature, however. He headed for the dressing room and scribbled as he went. First rule of celebrity: keep on the move when you're signing autographs.

I was there observing for a documen-tary we were supposed to be making. A few months earlier, over a meeting at the trendy St Martin's Lane hotel in London, where he puffed on the odd Marlborough Light but drank mineral water, Stan had agreed to the fly-on-the-wall film in an attempt to show everyone that he was not the surly, miserable loner of reputation. He asked for his fee to go to a charity for people with depressive illnesses.

Leicester City put the block on the project, though, and the reasons soon emerged. There were tales of him being overweight and not trying a leg in matches, stories of him wanting a better contract when he had not yet done enough to justify it. The final straw was a dressing-room punch-up with his fellow striker Trevor Benjamin at half-time of a reserve game. Soon after Collymore had been shipped out to Bradford City, that nice Peter Taylor wrote to me to apologise for his veto and hoped that I now understood.

But he didn't understand Stan and how could anyone else? Many have tried, few have succeeded. Now the problem has apparently gone away, as many managers have hoped it would, with the news that he has retired from football, at the wastefully premature - and dangerous -- age of 30. Collymore is almost a morality tale for our times; so many issues of modern football are there embodied in him. Celebrity, arising from notoriety rather than achievement, is one. Huge financial rewards, that give security to players in whom the fires of professional pride do not burn, rather than stoke in them hunger for success, is another.

Then there is the lack of sympathy and support for anyone wealthy but undermined by demons in these jealous days where money should equal contentment. Add to the mix the persistence with Collymore by so many frustrated managers, because there are few players with his talent around, and he became fuel for heated debate.

And Stan had - has - outrageous talent. Physically he had menacing presence and was a powerful header of the ball. He had a keen eye for a sweeping crossfield pass. His pace alarmed defences. His finishing could be explosive. Footage of that remarkable 4-3 game between Liverpool and Newcastle United four years ago, when he scored twice, and his hat-trick for Leicester against Sunderland just a year ago this week, confirms it all.

Everywhere he went, he initially tantalised with some astonishing cameos, before seeming to become quickly bored, possibly at how easy this simple-but- difficult game could be. Perhaps it was his unusual failure to make instant impact at Real Oviedo - and realisation that, at his age, waning natural talent needed the maintenance of hard work - that prompted his decision.

January is always the cruellest month for a depressive. The turning point in Collymore's career certainly came in that month, on Tuesday 10th, in 1995. Collymore was Alex Ferguson's first choice for a new striker for Manchester United. He placed a call to Frank Clark, then Stan's manager at Nottingham Forest, but Clark made himself unavailable for it. 'I just wonder_' Ferguson said to himself and phoned Kevin Keegan at Newcastle. Keegan was indeed willing to sell Andy Cole to him. Ferguson was more the man Collymore needed than, subsequently, Roy Evans at Liverpool.

In January '99, Collymore finally recognised he needed help and was treated at the Priory. A year on, he agreed to explain how depression had affected his career and, more important, his life, and had almost driven him to suicide. It won him some understanding, at least; perhaps helped him in some small way to move from being out-and-out villain to more the Marmite of the game - you either love him or hate him.

A few days ago, I asked his latest representative if Stan would like to talk about his decision, particularly after telling me that previous year that he had years left in his legs. 'I've been instructed to look at a money tabloid deal,' came the reply. Of course it is Collymore's prerogative, but it is exactly the sort of response that provokes ambivalence towards him.

Stan is apparently depressed no longer. 'It's because he's not that he has been able to make this decision,' - an 'irrevocable' one - said the agent. 'He feels he has gone as far as he can go and wants to get out while people remember him as a top footballer.' Hmm. Will they?

You can never inflict on people what you think they should do with their lives - in this case we are tempted because so many of us would so love to have Collymore's ability and are certain we would honour it - but anyone who believes in fulfilling God-given talent will hope he reconsiders and becomes yet what he could become. We've wanted it for Gazza for years.

And perhaps when Stan has had a few months with his family, or dabbled with TV and empty celebrity, he will reassess and risk tampering with some myth that he was a 'great' and actually decide to prove it. Who knows, a break might also show that a love of the game is in his soul. Quitting is easy. Anyone can do that. So much harder to pick yourself up and keep trying.

webTitle: Glitter of the Crown Jewels

fields.headline: Glitter of the Crown Jewels
fields.standfirst: World Cup football - The great debate.
fields.trailText: A wrangle over the televising of the 2002 World Cup finals is threatening to put an end to all matches being shown free, which would affect viewing in millions of British homes. The entire 64 matches that make up the finals are on the list of events, known as the Crown Jewels, that must be offered to broadcasters that don't charge either a subscription or pay-per-view fee. In the case of the World Cup finals, which next take place in Japan and South Korea in 2002, the BBC and ITV have traditionally divided the matches between them.
fields.body:
A wrangle over the televising of the 2002 World Cup finals is threatening to put an end to all matches being shown free, which would affect viewing in millions of British homes. The entire 64 matches that make up the finals are on the list of events, known as the Crown Jewels, that must be offered to broadcasters that don't charge either a subscription or pay-per-view fee. In the case of the World Cup finals, which next take place in Japan and South Korea in 2002, the BBC and ITV have traditionally divided the matches between them.

Now, though, the German media group Kirch, who paid - some would say overpaid - £1.5 billion for the European TV rights to the 2002 and 2006 finals, are set to challenge the protection depending on the outcome of an unprecedented auction due to take place before the end of April. The 2002 finals matches will be sold off in two lots, and Kirch believe one of these lots - the matches that don't involve British teams, the opening match, semi-finals and final - should be allowed to go to a pay-TV company if they outbid the free-to-air broadcasters by offering a fair price. Kirch's view is that protecting all 64 matches is excessive, and that anyway by selling off some of the games to pay TV might offend the spirit, but not the letter, of fairly complex legislation, which Tony Ghee explains below.

Although the European Commission have upheld the shielding of every single finals match, it is a level of protection unique to Britain and Kirch believe it may not stand up to legal scrutiny. Kirch have already taken their case to the European Court of First Instance in Luxembourg, where they are seeking 'clarification of the listings issue'. But don't expect a ruling for 18 months, far too late to be of use to them for next year's finals. If they did get a fair, winning bid from a pay-TV company for the non-British matches, excluding the tournament opener, semi-finals and final, they would take legal action if the Independent Television Commission tried to block the sale. Kirch have been encouraged by a Court of Appeal ruling against the ITC, who tried to stop the British-based subscription television company TVDanmark from beaming live coverage of protected World Cup matches to homes in Denmark.

In their ruling, which is being challenged by the ITC in the Lords, the Court of Appeal spoke of the need to sustain competition and to prevent public service broadcasters becoming over-dominant. There are believed to be plenty of lawyers who reckon they could successfully argue Kirch's case that the blanket protection of World Cup finals is excessive and gain an historic judgement against the Government's listed events. The Government have shown no sign of compromise over the issue of the World Cup finals.

Chris Smith, the secretary of state for culture, media and sport, told Kirch: 'We have some of the most avid and knowledgeable football supporters in the world, which is why we have included the whole tournament in our list.' On the other side, pay-TV companies would love to screen World Cup matches and believe they are being unfairly excluded.

webTitle: Taking every monumental moment as it comes

fields.headline: Taking every monumental moment as it comes
fields.standfirst: Gérard Houllier and John Aldridge agree - the Battle of Birkenhead is not any old game
fields.trailText: We're taking every match as it comes,' goes that tried, tested and horribly tired example of football-speak. For John Aldridge, his team Tranmere Rovers, and his old team Liverpool, that tosh mercifully goes right out the window. Aldridge, admirably honest, says of today's quarter-final at relegation-threatened Prenton Park: 'I couldn't ignore it and concentrate on the League position even if I wanted to. It's a cup quarter-final between the two teams I've got in my blood.' And Liverpool's Gérard Houllier obviously agrees. He claims that he is more fearful of Aldridge's Rovers, bottom of Division One, than of Porto, Liverpool's opponents in the Uefa Cup quarter-final. It is not just the Portuguese club's toothless performance in Thursday's first leg, a 0-0 draw, that has driven him to that conclusion, for Houllier has witnessed Tranmere's remarkable exploits - they've beaten seven Premiership sides in the past 18 months - at first hand twice this season.
fields.body:
We're taking every match as it comes,' goes that tried, tested and horribly tired example of football-speak. For John Aldridge, his team Tranmere Rovers, and his old team Liverpool, that tosh mercifully goes right out the window. Aldridge, admirably honest, says of today's quarter-final at relegation-threatened Prenton Park: 'I couldn't ignore it and concentrate on the League position even if I wanted to. It's a cup quarter-final between the two teams I've got in my blood.' And Liverpool's Gérard Houllier obviously agrees. He claims that he is more fearful of Aldridge's Rovers, bottom of Division One, than of Porto, Liverpool's opponents in the Uefa Cup quarter-final. It is not just the Portuguese club's toothless performance in Thursday's first leg, a 0-0 draw, that has driven him to that conclusion, for Houllier has witnessed Tranmere's remarkable exploits - they've beaten seven Premiership sides in the past 18 months - at first hand twice this season.

The Liverpool manager was amazed to see Aldridge's team overturn a 2-0 half-time deficit to beat Leeds United 3-2 in extra time in the Worthington Cup last October, but that was nothing compared to when he saw them recover from 3-0 down to beat Southampton in an astonishing FA Cup fifth-round replay. Central to Tranmere's Cup achievements is a direct style that makes them the most awkward of opponents, something Houllier knows only too well. 'Having seen those two games, I can't understand why they are where they are in the League,' said Houllier. 'When I've seen them, they've never given up. They're incredible. They make life very difficult for the opposition. The game will be very different to Porto. For a start, our defenders will have to head the ball a lot. 'Tranmere could yet achieve the unthinkable feat of reaching the FA Cup final while being relegated to Division Two. The only thing I can compare it with is Bordeaux four or five seasons ago, when they reached the final of the Uefa Cup but almost got relegated. They're a great cup team, but I'm sure John Aldridge would prefer to stay up than to beat Liverpool and go down.'

Of course he would, but Aldridge - while frustrated and perplexed at the inability to take their Cup form into the League - is not going to admit that he would swap points for Cup glory today. First because football does not work like that, and secondly because this is a Merseyside derby.

Last season's Worthington Cup final might have been a more important occasion, as well as one that proved Tranmere do not automatically prosper against Premiership opponents, but Aldridge agrees today's game is the biggest Birkenhead has ever seen. That's without taking into account the fact that Aldridge and Liverpool go back a bit, and that this will be his first competitive meeting with his old club since leaving Anfield. 'For me it's massive,' he said. 'Of course we'd like to be in the semi-finals. We could buy another player then, couldn't we? If we get a fixture pile-up, the FA will just have to help us out. I don't think anyone here doesn't believe we can do it. It might be a tall order, and it's going to take a huge effort, but we've already beaten a very good Leeds side in the Worthington Cup this season. Liverpool might be a little bit stronger, especially now Robbie's back, but there isn't much in it.'

Houllier has worked hard at making Liverpool mentally stronger, but he will need to go some to produce the effect Aldridge managed in the last round, when he inspired his side to the comeback of the season against Southampton. The potency of the half-time team-talk is a somewhat discredited notion now that managers tend to be softly spoken psychology graduates, but from all accounts Aldridge's performance turned the clock back a decade or two while stripping the paint from the dressing-room walls. 'It frightened me and I was only on the bench,' said Stuart Barlow, the scorer of the winning goal in that astonishing tie. 'For once I was glad not to have started a game. Even though I knew I hadn't done anything wrong, I still kept out of the gaffer's way.'

Aldridge smiles at the recollection. 'I just told a few home truths, nothing was thrown,' he said. 'I wanted a reaction from the lads, and I got one. That sort of thing doesn't work every week, but this was the right time to do it, as I think our second half display showed. I doubt if I'm the only manager to have raised his voice a little at half time.'

Very few have done it to such good effect, although as Aldridge watched the unbelievable come true, the same 45 minutes must have ranked among the worst viewing of Glenn Hoddle's managerial career. What had the former England manager said? 'Well done and goodbye,' Aldridge said. 'It was hard for him to say anything else, wasn't it? I'd have done the same - I'd have just scarpered too.'

And now, Liverpool. No mock diffidence, no clichés here. 'I can't imagine a bigger game for this club,' said Barlow. And he is right.

webTitle: The use of luck and judgment

fields.headline: The use of luck and judgment
fields.standfirst: The Coventry Manager speaks up on the art of putting on substitutes
fields.trailText: Nothing is liable to boost the image of a manager more than a substitution that turns the game for his team. Arsenal's Arsène Wenger, though, has covered himself in glory because of a substitution he didn't make.
fields.body:
Nothing is liable to boost the image of a manager more than a substitution that turns the game for his team. Arsenal's Arsène Wenger, though, has covered himself in glory because of a substitution he didn't make.

In Arsenal's European Champions League tie against Spartak Moscow last Tuesday, Thierry Henry was missing so many chances that even his adoring Gunners supporters were calling for him to be taken off. Wenger had already put on Wiltord for Robert Pires on 71 minutes, and Henry admitted that when Wenger elected to replace Dennis Bergkamp with Nwankwo Kanu , even he was stunned by the decision. 'I was so bad, I did not deserve to be on the pitch,' Henry said. 'I thought I had to be the one to be replaced.'

Maybe so, but Wenger's decision did make a lot of sense - as, indeed, Henry went on to emphasise by scoring the only goal.

All players have their bad matches and, in a lot of cases, keeping them on the field - and thus subjecting them to the displeasure of the crowd - is self-defeating. But as far as strikers are concerned, I think one always has to bear in mind that if they are getting plenty of chances, the bad luck they might be experiencing in applying the finishing touch is bound to change eventually.

One has only to look at the scoring records of Henry and Bergkamp this season to appreciate that Henry, while not as sharp in front of goal as he usually is, would still have been perceived by Wenger as the likelier of the two to break the deadlock. The other reason why I think Wenger did what he did - and this is probably the key - concerns the difference between Henry and Bergkamp in their styles of play.

Bergkamp, like Kanu, likes to drift into deep positions; when an attack is being developed, they have a tendency to come towards the ball, which gives the opposition the scope to push up and squeeze the play. Henry, on the other hand, is always looking to go forward, into the space behind defences, so his presence has the effect of forcing the opposition to defend closer to their goal and creating a bit more space for the likes of Bergkamp and Kanu to express themselves.

The use of substitutes, outside those forced on you because of injuries, is one of the areas which best reflects the essence of being a team manager; and, indeed, the differences between being a manager and a coach.

I think we would all concede that some substitutions work more through luck than judgment. Sometimes, you will just put someone on for no other reason than the feeling that the team need a fresh face - I would love to be able to give the impres sion that some of my substitutions have been tactical master-strokes, but the reality has been different.

However, there is no doubt that using substitutes properly - and certainly being able to keep a clear enough head to be able to do so - is an art. I think all managers start a game with two or three alternative game plans in mind, but inevitably, you cannot plan for everything. For example, there are some instances where managers suddenly have to substitute a player to alleviate the danger of his being sent off.

When it comes to making substitutions under the pressure of your team trailing and struggling to get back into the game, some managers are recognised as being more adept than others.

Sir Alf Ramsey never lived down his mistake in the crucial 1974 World Cup qualifying tie against Poland in not sending on striker Kevin Hector until 90 seconds from the end. Hector's performance suggested that had he been brought into the action earlier England would have got the win they needed to reach the finals.

In recent years, the most vivid example of inspired substitutions must surely be the one presented by Alex Ferguson, in Manchester United's European Cup final victory over Bayern Munich two seasons ago, when he brought on Teddy Sheringham and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer for Jesper Blomqvist and Andy Cole.

Some players are at their best as substitutes. A number also benefit from the fact that, as they are usually brought on when things are not going well, they are generally not under as much pressure as the other players. People will hope that they can change the situation but they do not generally expect it.

Obviously, much depends on a player's ability to quickly get attuned to the pace of a game. At Coventry, two players who have done particularly well for us as substitutes are John Aloisi and Paul Telfer. However, whether they or anyone else are happy with such a distinction is another matter.The one thing common to all substitutes is that the argument about football being a 14-a-side game now is something they find difficult to accept. They all feel they should be in the starting 11.

Come to think of it, those who feel they have a point to prove are liable to make the most successful subs of all.

webTitle: Out of the ether and into history

fields.headline: Out of the ether and into history
fields.standfirst: Wycombe's unlikely goal-hero gets the nod.
fields.trailText: 'I just concentrated on trying to keep the ball down and on target. When it hit the back of the net, I couldn't believe it' - so said unlikely hero Roy Essandoh, the striker who answered Wycombe manager Lawrie Sanchez's Teletext advertisement for a striker. Sanchez was so hard up for a forward as injury had hit his squad that he tried to talk Gianluca Vialli into a comeback.
fields.body:
'I just concentrated on trying to keep the ball down and on target. When it hit the back of the net, I couldn't believe it' - so said unlikely hero Roy Essandoh, the striker who answered Wycombe manager Lawrie Sanchez's Teletext advertisement for a striker. Sanchez was so hard up for a forward as injury had hit his squad that he tried to talk Gianluca Vialli into a comeback.

Sanchez may just be pleased he did not succeed. Essandoh may have no pedigree - a bit of football in Finland last year and some Scottish experience - but his stoppage-time goal propelled Wycombe, a non-League side just eight years ago, into the FA Cup semi-finals at the expense of Premiership hosts Leicester.

Sanchez had been sent off from the dugout after protesting that his team should have had a penalty for hand-ball before Essandoh's timely goal. 'He never got that far forward when we were playing together,' joked Terry Gibson, Sanchez's assistant and former Wimbledon team-mate, of his boss's touchline dash.

There had been mixed feelings for Sanchez, his delight marred by a series of events that so nearly conspired against his team. 'I question why referees and linesmen are out there if they can't make the big decisions,' he said. 'It was an obvious penalty [as the Leicester manager Peter Taylor agreed] and it could have cost us over £1 million, stopped me building a team and damaged my career as a manager.

'It's easy to give out a red card for someone taking off his shirt [schemer Stephen Brown] and celebrating, not so easy to give a penalty against a Premiership team. I've always said that too many referees know the rules but they don't know the game. They need to have their livelihoods on the line like ours.

'But then, everybody wants Premiership teams to get through. Everybody except the public, that is. The public know that there's more to the game than the Premiership.'

Once more composed, Sanchez savoured the achievement. 'The important thing is that we have won the game. I thought we were the better team. Today was our best chance, because the Premiership team usually get themselves together for a replay, even if you're at home. Today luck favoured the brave. We showed real guts and determination. People said we have ignited the competition. We certainly have now.'

Was it as good as his 1988 moment? 'It's a different feeling. As a player, you get selfish pleasure when you score. As a manager you take more pride in the team situation.'

Essandoh, he said, had not particularly impressed him in a reserve game against QPR, a start against Port Vale and a substitute appearance against Reading, but it had been a case of needs must when Essandoh arrived at the club 10 days ago.

Wycombe's players had traded any Cup bonuses for salary up front earlier in the season and were on just £130 to reach the last four. 'You can be the richest player in the world, but if you haven't been involved in a game like that, you are poor,' said Sanchez.

Wycombe will go down in the competition's folklore, joining Plymouth Argyle in 1984 and Chesterfield in '97 as semi-finalists from the third tier of the English game. Follow that, Tranmere, previously the biggest shock-sup pliers after their 4-3 win over Southampton. Like his mentor Glenn Hoddle that night, Peter Taylor was shell-shocked. 'I never, ever thought it would happen,' he said, after his side were made to look ordinary. 'I was staggered.'

webTitle: Women party as city's men are curfewed

fields.headline: Women party as city's men are curfewed
fields.trailText: In a crowded saloon in central Bogotá, Martha Vives sees her husband's number flash up on her mobile phone. She answers, makes sure he's safely at home - and hangs up on him.
fields.body:
In a crowded saloon in central Bogotá, Martha Vives sees her husband's number flash up on her mobile phone. She answers, makes sure he's safely at home - and hangs up on him.

'What a relief! No husband, no daughter, I'm single again!' said Vives, drinking with female friends in the Bar of Dishonour. 'For once, it's our night!'

Famed for donning red tights and parading through the city as 'Super-Citizen', Bogotá's eccentric mayor, Antanas Mockus, had imposed a city-wide voluntary curfew for men last Friday, encouraging women to go out on the town while their husbands and boyfriends stayed at home baby-sitting.

The 'Night Without Men' was designed to combat street crime and domestic violence in the chilly Colombian capital, but the exercise turned into a carnival as thousands of women took to the streets.

'It's great. It's the perfect excuse to do things you don't normally do,' said Vives, a university professor.

Crowds of women took part in council-funded activities, including women-only concerts, film shows, poetry readings and cycle rides.

For unemployed mother of two Ana Lucia Preciada, the curfew was a rare chance to go out. 'Normally it's too dangerous in the evening - I just stay in and watch TV,' she said. But tonight I feel free to walk, free from oppression,' she said, strolling down a blocked-off avenue with a group of female friends.

Women staffed the city's fire engines, and most male police officers were given the night off, while 1,500 female officers patrolled the streets. The police chief Jorge Enrique Lenaris even resigned his command for the night to let Col Gloria Cardilla take control of Bogota's police force.

Many bars and restaurants offered free drinks and discounts to attract women customers, while pizza delivery services gave bonuses to men who stayed at home.

One strip club moved to larger premises to accommodate crowds of women who flocked to its Chippendales-style show. Outside 'Apollo's Men', the queue stretched around the block.

'If it weren't for women's night, we'd never have thought of going to see men dance, especially not naked,' said elderly Fabiola Lozano, as she queued patiently.

Men who ventured out were asked to carry a 'safe-conduct' pass, giving their reason for breaking the curfew. The form could be cut from newspapers, collected from police stations or downloaded from the internet.

In some areas, the thousands of men who ignored the ban provoked nothing more than a few dirty looks. But in others, women pelted the interlopers with water and flour, chanting: 'Go home to bed ! Wash the dishes!'

Soaked to the skin, insurance salesman Gerardo Amortegui sat slumped on a kerbstone after a gang of marauding women cornered him with water bombs.

'I suppose I should be grateful they used bags of water, not bullets,' he said.

Declaring themselves 'conscientious objectors', one group of men marched through the city centre waving signs which read: 'I love women! Don't take them away from me !'

Mayor Mockus himself stayed at home, reading stories to his four-year-old daughter. 'We need to learn how to be better fathers. People should be able to do this kind of thing without a special night,' said the former rector of Bogota's National University, who first found fame bybaring his buttocks to a crowd of unruly students.

Friday's experiment was part of a campaign against Bogotá's rampant violence. Last year, 2,247 people were murdered in the city, while around 700 were killed in England and Wales.

But two men have already begun lawsuits against Mockus, accusing him of violating their human rights.

A recent survey showed that 40 per cent of Colombian men don't let their wives go out alone. Housewife Lucerito Plata, however, said the curfew gave her the strength to resist. 'My husband didn't believe that I would dare come out alone,' she said. 'I just said, "See you later", and walked out the door. They should do this every week.'

webTitle: Should all World Cup finals matches be listed?

fields.headline: Should all World Cup finals matches be listed?
fields.standfirst: NO
fields.trailText: Tony Ghee, a lawyer specialising in media affairs, says it's excessive
fields.body:
When the first match of the World Cup kicks off on 31 May next year, and millions of British football fans turn on their televisions, to which channel will they tune? This is rapidly becoming a hot issue in the UK.

In 1996, Kirch, a large media group, purchased the right to broadcast all the matches of the World Cup in Europe. It was the first time that the television rights to the World Cup were acquired by an organisation who were not in the public sector. Previously, the rights had been acquired by the European Broadcast Union (EBU), who had historically agreed to sell those rights on to either the BBC or ITV.

Now Kirch are about to auction this very valuable property in the UK hoping, no doubt, that a number of British television broadcasters will bid. If this was an auction of anything less exciting, it would hardly raise much interest either in the identity of the seller or the bidders or the auction itself. However, the right to broadcast the World Cup is no ordinary property.

The sale of World Cup television rights is highly regulated, all the finals matches being classified among the 'listed events'. These are the events that the secretary of state for culture, media and sport, Chris Smith, described as 'an issue of shared national experience' and therefore deserving of special attention.

What do the rules surrounding listed events require? First they outlaw any broadcaster (whether free or pay) buying the exclusive live rights to the World Cup. However, the rules do not mandate that any 'listed event' has to be broadcast live on free television, nor do they prevent live broadcasting by a pay television channel. Rather the rules prevent the exclusive live broadcast by only one type of broadcaster, free or pay, of any listed event without the consent of the UK television regulator, the Independent Television Commission.

The ITC Code on Listed Events says exactly this. The rules are concerned with providing an opportunity for live coverage to be made available. But they do not require or guarantee live coverage of listed events, including coverage on ITV, Channel 4 and the BBC. Nor do they prohibit exclusive coverage of listed events on other services.

Even though there is no legal requirement for the World Cup to be broadcast live on free TV, Kirch have always said that a live broadcast on free-to-air TV of the opening match, matches involving UK national teams, semi-finals and the final - the Prime Matches - will happen.

Interestingly, when the list was reviewed by the Government in 1998, the Gordon Committee, of which the sports minister, Kate Hoey, was a member, recommended to Smith that only the Prime Matches should be listed. So everyone who wants to see the Prime Matches will most likely be able to do so on BBC or ITV.

Within these constraints, all that is being proposed is that rather than accept a joint offer from the BBC and ITV, which has always happened in the past, the rights will be auctioned. Given the number of games that will be played during the World Cup, I would expect that broadcasters will be able to bid on separate packages. Perhaps the most likely result is that broadcasters in each category will share the live TV rights to the World Cup, but a broadcaster in either category acquiring the rights to all or some games on a de facto exclusive basis is a possibility.

The Court of Appeal recently ruled that where a broadcaster has won an auction for the broadcasting rights of a listed event, where all the bidders have had a fair and reasonable opportunity to purchase the rights at a fair price, the ITC must consent.

I believe that the listing of all 64 games under UK law is excessive and infringes the Human Rights Act. As Kirch purchased the rights to the World Cup finals before the listed events rules came in to force, the sale of the rights may not be caught by the listed events rules at all.

Finally, the ability to sell packages of rights to certain World Cup games removes the need for any joint bid by the BBC and ITV, which has always been justified in the past on the grounds of scheduling constraints.

Leaving emotion aside, I fail to see how a football game between, say, the USA and Australia, played at eight o'clock in the morning, UK time, is an event of 'shared national experience', which justifies its inclusion as a listed event.

What is certain, however, is that the World Cup Final itself will be on either the BBC or ITV.

webTitle: Morbo than harmony, but Spanish prosper

fields.headline: Morbo than harmony, but Spanish prosper
fields.trailText: It's good to be good, but it's better to be lucky. Phil Ball is both. His excellent book, morbo The Story of Spanish Football , appears just as the country's teams are running amok in Europe. Seven Spanish sides could make the quarter-finals of the Champions League and Uefa Cup, almost as if Ball had arranged the whole thing as a publicity stunt. He has a stab at explaining why the Spanish are so good.
fields.body:
It's good to be good, but it's better to be lucky. Phil Ball is both. His excellent book, morbo The Story of Spanish Football , appears just as the country's teams are running amok in Europe. Seven Spanish sides could make the quarter-finals of the Champions League and Uefa Cup, almost as if Ball had arranged the whole thing as a publicity stunt. He has a stab at explaining why the Spanish are so good.

But more of the great question later, because the bulk of his book consists of something else: stories of morbo, a Spanish word that means something like needle or rivalry. There is morbo between Barcelona and Real, Betis and Sevilla, Serbs and Croats etc.

Using the notion of morbo , Ball has written nothing less than a guide to Spanish life. This is a man who lives in San Sebastian, has played beach football with the legendary winger Lopez Ufarte, and knows someone who taught Luis Arconada English. (Apparently the keeper complained that he would always be remembered for his blunder in the final of the 1984 European Championship.)

The book mixes the historical and the personal, most impressively in his treatment of the 'Guruceta affair'. Emilio Guruceta was a referee who gave Real a soft penalty in a Barcelona-Real Madrid game in 1970, and two months later was driving a BMW. 'To a whole generation,' writes Ball, 'the Guruceta game represents incontrovertible evidence that Madrid could pay off the refs.'

In 1987, while driving another BMW, Guruceta was killed in a car crash. Later he was revealed to have taken a bribe from Anderlecht before they beat Nottingham Forest 3-0 to reach the final of the Uefa Cup in 1984.

So far, so standard. All this is easy to write - just a matter of regurgitating history books. But one night Ball was sitting in a San Sebastian hotel watching a match on TV when there was a power failure, and in the dark silence he discovered that one of the other men in the room, a tailor, had been Guruceta's linesman at the Barcelona-Real game. Quizzed in the dark by Ball, the tailor made a cryptic comment implying that Guruceta was murdered.

Ball gives due honour to Barça and Real Madrid, but also devotes an entire chapter to his conversations with Seville taxi drivers about Betis and Sevilla, and examines the Basque country, which has only three million inhabitants but four teams in the Primera Liga staffed very largely by locals. In fact, if the Basques ever gained independence the Spanish national team would be sunk: the region has produced many of Spain's best players, including almost all the great goalkeepers and the current bright light, Gaizka Mendieta. Even Alavés, one of the smallest Basque teams, have all but qualified for the Uefa Cup semi-final with their 3-0 win against Rayo Vallecano on Thursday.

One year of freakish over-performance in Europe could be dismissed as good fortune, but Spanish teams are doing it for the second time running. Last season they provided three Champions League semi-finalists, and now Sven-Göran Eriksson is simply being his usual bland self when he says that Real Madrid are probably the world's best team. Clearly something is going on.

Ball's explanation is weak. 'It must be something to do with what the Spanish call calidad [quality of technique],' he writes. 'They are obsessed with the concept now, relegating cruder notions of physical fitness to the realms of secondary importance.' That doesn't explain much, given that even some Scottish clubs now relegate cruder notions of physical fitness to the realms of secondary importance.

Rather, there seem to be two reasons why Spanish (and English) clubs have recently overtaken the Italians. First, there is the curse of being first. For most of the Nineties Italian clubs were the best. They didn't have to question themselves, to eradicate their weaknesses, and so the pace of their game seems to have dropped a notch, while they also appear to have lost the knack of switching from defence to attack when required, as Roma showed at home to Liverpool. Meanwhile, Spanish and English clubs have improved, following the old Avis rental car motto: 'We're number two. We try harder.'

The second reason is simply confidence. English clubs such as Aston Villa, Everton and Spurs won European trophies in the Eighties because they thought they could. They assumed that being English they were better than obscure foreign outfits such as Juventus or Bayern Munich, and so were never overawed. Now little Spanish clubs such as Deportivo La Coruña and Rayo Vallecano think they are the best, and therefore become so.

The next round of the Champions League may produce three Anglo-Spanish encounters. That would give us firm evidence as to who is Europe's number two. Number one, for now, is Ball.

webTitle: It's a kind of magic

fields.headline: It's a kind of magic
fields.trailText: Arsenal reached their third FA Cup semi-final in four years with one of the easiest victories anyone could remember.
fields.body:
Arsenal reached their third FA Cup semi-final in four years with one of the easiest victories anyone could remember.

The FA Cup quarter-final used to be an important landmark in the season, but you have to wonder how seriously clubs view the competition these days when both Arsenal and Blackburn left their best players on the bench.

Patrick Vieira and Thierry Henry sat it out for the home side, while Blackburn's contingent of spectators included Matt Jansen, Craig Hignett and Damien Duff. Graeme Souness had indicated in advance that promotion was Blackburn's overwhelming priority, though few believed Arsène Wenger would state his preference for Wednesday's Champions League trip to Munich quite so unequivocally.

Fortunately Arsenal made the sort of start which made arguments superfluous, except to say that Blackburn ought not to get too excited about promotion if they intend to defend like this on Premiership grounds next season. They shipped a goal on Arsenal's first attack and were two down inside five minutes. Big game? What game?

Perhaps Blackburn were surprised at the speed at which Arsenal started, although it is hardly a secret that Wenger puts pace above most other virtues. Robert Pires exploited the inviting space between Martin Taylor and Alan Mahon, who were supposed to be guarding the left flank, as early as the second minute. With Rovers' central defence drawn out of position it was a simple matter to square to Sylvain Wiltord, and with just 85 seconds gone, a first-time finish produced his sixth goal of the FA Cup campaign - he has scored in every round.

If the Blackburn fans in the Clock End could not have imagined a worse start, they were glumly contemplating one four minutes later. Brad Friedel scrambled Dennis Bergkamp's audacious chip over the bar, but Blackburn forgot to pick up Tony Adams from the resulting Ashley Cole corner, with inevitable consequences. 'We were punished for giving the ball away,' Souness said. 'I wanted to go home at half time.'

What with half the star attractions wearing tracksuits and the result a foregone con clusion, so did everyone else. Apart from theatrical penalty appeals by Bergkamp and Eyal Berkovic there was nothing to amuse the crowd except trading insults. 'You're just a small town in Tottenham,' was the best the Rovers fans could come up with, which was original if not strictly true. Some stinging riposte involving Burnley or Chorley was called for, but a third Arsenal goal in the 36th minute provided the cue for a rousing chorus of 'You might as well go home.'

Bergkamp, who will be told today whether he is required to drive to Germany, started the move by finding Wiltord on the left. As the Dutchman moved forward in anticipation of a return Wiltord missed him out in favour of a longer ball to Pires, who took the pace off the pass superbly before lashing a shot past Friedel.

Souness sent on Duff and Stig-Inge Bjornebye at the interval, though his reluctance to use Jansen betrayed the limits of his ambition. When Blackburn put the ball in the net in the 55th minute even the muted celebrations which followed were short lived, referee Jeff Winter having spotted that Jason McAteer had used his arm to control the ball.

Jansen did make it onto the field for the last half hour, yet with the implacably competitive Mark Hughes making way the game became even less of a contest. Nonetheless, Blackburn's best moment came 14 minutes from the end when Jansen eased past Oleg Luzhny on the left and floated a pass across from which Marcus Bent might well have scored had not Cole executed a perfectly timed tackle.

Bent rattled David Seaman's left upright in injury time just to show what might have been, but this was the cup tie that never was. 'Blackburn couldn't get back into it, so it never turned into a real cup tie,' Wenger said. Too true. All the romance was in Leicester, which must be some sort of first.

webTitle: Random drug tests for doctors

fields.headline: Random drug tests for doctors
fields.standfirst: NHS in crackdown on substance abuse at work
fields.trailText: Doctors and nurses face random testing for drink and drugs under radical plans being drawn up by the National Health Service.
fields.body:
Doctors and nurses face random testing for drink and drugs under radical plans being drawn up by the National Health Service.

The proposal, which is backed by the General Medical Council, is designed to prevent doctors and nurses working while under the influence.

NHS Trusts have held talks with companies specialising in testing for substance abuse in the workplace. 'They [the NHS Trusts] are very serious about it,' said one source involved in the talks. The NHS Confederation, which represents the trusts, confirmed that plans for tests were part of a review of work safety procedures.

'We know there is a high incidence of substance problems [among doctors],' said Alistair Henderson, policy manager at the NHS Confed eration. 'It is a question of sifting through and supporting staff. [Tests] should not be show trials.'

Random drug tests in the workplace are increasingly common. Train drivers, military personnel and prison officers already face them. It is illegal for a company to allow intoxicated staff to endanger lives at work. According to some studies, up to 15 per cent of doctors have a drink or drug problem in their lifetime.

The General Medical Council, responsible for upholding ethics in the medical profession, said it was in favour of randomly testing all NHS staff. 'Employers should have robust mechanisms for ensuring that doctors working for them are fit to practise,' a spokesman said.

The plans are likely to provoke fierce opposition. The British Medical Association has vowed to oppose random testing, calling for tests only if an incident arouses suspicion.

The Royal College of Nursing said random compulsory tests were an 'invasion of privacy', but would accept voluntary schemes.

Health trusts have yet to set a date for when the testing will start.

Medical students are overwhelmingly in favour of random alcohol and drug testing and pressured the BMA into considering tests last year.

Last year the GMC recorded a 50 per cent rise in complaints against medical staff, many of which were attributed to younger GPs appalled at the practices of their senior colleagues.

Students told the BMA that random testing would help secure patients' goodwill as the medical profession struggles to stay self-regulated.

webTitle: Gold at end of Turner's rainbow

fields.headline: Gold at end of Turner's rainbow
fields.trailText: A watercolour by JMW Turner is expected to break world records when it goes under the hammer in London.
fields.body:
A watercolour by JMW Turner is expected to break world records when it goes under the hammer in London.

The picture of the German city of Heidelberg is estimated to fetch between £600,000 and £800,000 - easily beating all previous prices for a Turner watercolour.

The existing record for a similar work by Britain's best-known and, arguably, best-loved painter is £473, 000, established in 1990, for a view of Hampton Court. The current work, entitled View of Heidelberg with Rainbow , was painted in the early 1840s.

'It is one of the greatest and loveliest of Turner's landscapes in watercolour,' said Henry Wemyss, British drawings and watercolours specialist at Sotheby's in London, where it will come up for sale on 14 June.

However, the popular painting, which was recently shown in the Royal Academy's London exhibition, 'Turner: The Great Watercolours', is no stranger to breaking records. It first came on to the market in London in 1872 when the Earl of Dudley, an avid collector and one of the richest men in England, paid 2,650 guineas for it. At the time newspapers reported that 'the radiant and rainbowed Heidelberg had been fought for and won' by the earl.

Its next appearance under the gavel was in 1908 at the London auction of the Stephen Holland collection when the opening bid was 100 guineas.

Frenzied bidding ensued between London dealers Agnew and the collector Hugh Blaker of Bath. Finally it sold for a record £4,200 - the equivalent of £235, 000 today - to Agnew, who sold it to their principal client, Belfast-born shipping magnate Sir Donald Currie. It has remained in Sir Donald's family ever since.

'It is breathtakingly atmospheric and highly romantic with its incredible observation and attention to detail, all translated with a lightness of touch, evocative brushstrokes and blending of colours, simultaneously both bright and yet subtle,' said Wemyss.

webTitle: Dentists smile as 'English mouth' goes out of fashion

fields.headline: Dentists smile as 'English mouth' goes out of fashion
fields.trailText: The British - long notorious for crooked, broken and discoloured teeth - are splashing out for a perfect smile in record numbers.
fields.body:
The British - long notorious for crooked, broken and discoloured teeth - are splashing out for a perfect smile in record numbers.

The condition of 'English mouth' has often been lampooned in The Simpsons. But now British dentists estimate the number of people undergoing cosmetic dentistry has tripled in two years, and is no longer confined to the vain, rich and famous.

Howard Stean, a dentist from London who chairs the 'aesthetic dentistry' association Adapt, said: 'It started slowly, but in the last three years there's been a mushrooming of demand. The number of dentists being trained in it is going up by 25 per cent a year, and there's no end to it.' A telephone helpline for queries is taking up to 2,000 calls a month.

Famous Britons who have had the treatment include Anne Robinson, Noel Gallagher, Martine McCutcheon, Martin Amis, David Bowie and Margaret Thatcher. However, dentists report that people going for the treatment now come from all backgrounds.

Julian Perry, managing director of the Ora Dent chain which specialises in cosmetic dentistry, said: 'It now transcends all socio-economic barriers - I have patients who are out of work. I have everyone from shop assistants to company directors, and they come from all ages.' The growth in demand is higher in the more affluent South. It is also becoming popular among older people, who are more likely to have high disposable incomes. Treatments cost from a few hundred pounds to one patient who spent £45,000.

Hayley Wright, who works in the shipping operations department of an oil company, spent about £3,000 on six veneers to disguise her previously crooked front teeth.

'It's a good investment - I'm really pleased with it. I used to smile with my mouth closed. But they look so good that when I smile now, I consciously open my mouth,' she said.

'I now have no inhibition about laughing and smiling with my mouth open.'

The growth in demand is being fuelled by falling prices; new techniques allowing dentists to do more and ensure it is pain-free; and a massive marketing drive by private dentists keen to increase their income. Revenues from traditional dentistry such as fillings are falling as teeth improve.

However, it is also driven by people no longer being content to endure 'English mouth'.

'People want to look better, and they've always been spending their money on clothes, hair and nails, but now it is coming down to the teeth and smiles, which have a big influence on sexual attraction,' said Amarjit Gill, chair of the private practice committee of the British Dental Association.

The biggest growth area is bleaching of the teeth, to make them whiter or all the same colour. New techniques mean it is possible to make a single darker tooth the same colour as the rest, and to choose the precise colour you want your teeth to be.

The usual method for straightening teeth is veneers. But the emerging science of 'cosmetic recontouring' means that, with the aid of a computer, a row of crooked teeth can be straightened with grinding and additions. Cosmetic dentists aim for the 'golden proportion' where teeth are symmetrical and have the most aesthetically pleasing widths and proportions.

webTitle: Britons brave frozen seas for place in history

fields.headline: Britons brave frozen seas for place in history
fields.trailText: They could freeze to death, be eaten by polar bears or perish in water so cold the shock will kill them before they drown. If they are lucky, they will become the first in history to cross the icy wastes between America and Russia. If they are not, they will die.
fields.body:
They could freeze to death, be eaten by polar bears or perish in water so cold the shock will kill them before they drown. If they are lucky, they will become the first in history to cross the icy wastes between America and Russia. If they are not, they will die.

Despite the risks, two British explorers are preparing to tackle one of the planet's last great challenges. Steve Brooks and Graham Stratford will attempt to traverse the 56 miles which separate the former Cold War enemies. Others have tried, but no one has succeeded in negotiating the windswept, treacherous ice floes of the Bering Strait.

For a few weeks each spring, temperatures fall to -70 C and the sea freezes to form an icy bridge between Alaska and Siberia. Down the years that temporary meteorological phenomenon has encouraged a succession of adventurers to try to conquer the Bering Strait. All have been defeated.

'It's very hard on this planet to come up with an adventure that's novel, because so much of the world has been explored and discovered,' said Brooks, leader of the Ice Challenger expedition which leaves Britain on Saturday for Alaska. 'That's the attraction of this for me - it hasn't been done before.'

Those who have failed include renowned adventurer Sir Ranulph Fiennes, who tried to make the crossing in 1998 in a specially adapted amphibious Land Rover. It sank. He has sent the Ice Challenger crew his best wishes. The most recent attempt, by a French team last summer, ended the same ignominious way within a few miles of leaving the Russian mainland.

Based on the snowmobile, it will use tracks to negotiate the ice but it can also float and, crucially, claw its way back up on to the floes if, as seems likely, the ice breaks. An inflatable skirt means Snowbird 5 should remain buoyant, while giant threaded cylinders along each side should let it find solid ice again.

'The trouble with the Bering Strait is that, even when it becomes a 56-mile-wide sheet of ice, the ice is not static. It's actually a shifting morass, so it's like being in an ongoing earthquake,' said Brooks. 'One of our great worries is what happens to us the first time the ice breaks, or we hit thin ice, and drop into the water. Our vehicle will be surrounded by broken ice. If all goes well, their £500,000 mission will take about six days. Just A Drop, a Red Cross charity which provides fresh water in disasters, will make thousands of pounds if they succeed.

'If we hung around on the ice, we would be swept north towards the North Pole because the ice is constantly moving north at 3mph,' said Brooks. He and Stratford will wear survival suits to protect against the cold. Flesh exposed for even a second will freeze. 'We'll try and remember not to take our gloves off, or put our hands in the water, but when you're tired it's easy to forget these things,' said Brooks.

The pair will take with them the flag of the Explorers Club. Barry Ross, chairman of the club's British chapter, said: 'If Steve and Graham succeed, it will be another great first for British exploration, and they will go into the history books alongside some great names. webTitle: Freud museum speaking ban sparks Said fury

fields.headline: Freud museum speaking ban sparks Said fury
fields.trailText: The Freud Society of Vienna has cancelled a lecture by Edward Said, the Palestinian-American professor, after members saw a photograph of him poised to hurl a stone at an Israeli guardhouse last July at the Lebanese border, said Johann August Schülein, the society's president.
fields.body:
The Freud Society of Vienna has cancelled a lecture by Edward Said, the Palestinian-American professor, after members saw a photograph of him poised to hurl a stone at an Israeli guardhouse last July at the Lebanese border, said Johann August Schülein, the society's president.

Said was invited last August to give the speech - on Freud's fascination with the ancient civilisations of Egypt, Palestine and Greece - on 6 May, the anniversary of Freud's birth.

But on 5 February, Schülein wrote to Said, a strong champion of Palestinian causes, and cancelled the invitation because of 'the political development in the Middle East and the consequences expected'.

In a telephone interview from Vienna, Schülein said, 'A lot of members of our society told us they can't accept that we have invited an engaged Palestinian who also throws stones against Israeli soldiers.'

Said's action drew some sharp criticism last summer. Said said he was having a stone-throwing contest with his son and called it a 'symbolic gesture of joy' at the end of Israel's occupation of Lebanon.

'It was a pebble,' Said said this week. 'There was nobody there. The guardhouse was at least half a mile away.'

He called the cancellation of his speech outrageous. 'Freud was hounded out of Vienna because he was a Jew,' he said. 'Now I am hounded out because I'm a Palestinian.'

Said is a professor of English and comparative literature at Columbia University. Its provost and dean of faculties, Jonathan R. Cole, has defended Said's right to free speech.

Several prominent psychoanalysts have written to the society protesting at the cancellation, calling it 'contrary to the spirit of psychoanalytic understanding and dialogue'.

The protesters include Jonathan Lear, an American; André Green and Julia Kristeva in Paris; and Adam Phillips in England.

Learning of the cancellation by the Vienna group, the Freud Museum in London has invited Said to deliver his talk there, and he said he plans to do so.

Schülein said that a majority of the society's 18 board members, who include psychoanalysts and representatives from finance and politics, voted to withdraw the invitation, but he would not give the exact vote.

He said the society acted out of concern for the anxieties of Austria's few remaining Jews in a climate of pro-Nazi and anti-immigration statements by Jörg Haider, the former leader of the extreme-right Freedom Party in Austria's ruling coalition.

'Anti-Semitism hasn't stopped with the Second World War and the Nazis,' Schülein said. 'It has become more dangerous since the Haider party coalition has grown to a mighty force in Austrian politics. Lots of Jews fear a situation when xenophobia and anti-Semitism will grow, and will come to a situation where they fear they have to leave the country again.'

Before the war, there were some 190,000 Jews in Vienna; only 5,000 to 10,000 are there now.

'The majority decided to cancel the Freud lecture to avoid an internal clash,' Schülein said. He said he had argued against the decision, adding, 'I deeply regret that this has been done to Professor Said.'

The Vienna Society occupies the Baroque-style building at Berggasse 19, where Freud lived until 1938, when Nazi commandos raided his home and he fled to England. Freud continued his work in London and died there in Hampstead in 1939.

The Vienna building is now a museum and includes some of Freud's collection of ancient Middle Eastern, Egyptian and Greek artifacts. His interest in such objects is reflected in writings like Moses and Monotheism , Totem and Taboo , Civilisation and Its Discontents and The Future of an Illusion .

Said said that the withdrawal of the invitation particularly angered him in light of his lecture topic. Freud, he said, was a 'Eurocentric who tried nevertheless without being reductive to talk about experience outside of Europe'.

In his writings, Said said, Freud 'was talking about a composite culture that didn't exclude races and civilisations.' New York Times
